*polude/kt|h: so 404, 430 *polude/gmwn. The idea of Hades as the “host of many” is especially Aeschylean: cf. Suppl. 157 to\n polucenw/taton *zh=na tw=n kekmhko/twn: P. V. 152 *(/aidou tou= nekrode/gmonos: Theb.860pando/kon ei)s xe/rson. See Preller-Robert i.^{2} p. 804. On the euphemistic names of Hades and Persephone see Rohde Psyche p. 192.

to/ *ge: this correction depends upon Homeric usage, and gives good sense: the confusion of TE and TE is of course common; cf. Il. 5.853, P. V. 42, 248 etc, and 280 au)th=s for au)gh=s. to/te can hardly be justified.
tou= kai/=Il. 1.249 tou= kai\ a)po\ glw/sshs, where Leaf notes that the kai/ introducing a merely epexegetic sentence is very unusual.

e(kato\n ka/ra: as the flower is miraculo<*>sly created, the exaggeration of its “hundred heads” need not be pressed; but the writer is doubtless thinking of the Narcissus tazetta, the “polyanthus” or “bunch” species (see on 428), Murr p. 248.

Tyrrell's correction of kw=dis t' o)dmh= is recommended by the fact that it only posits the omission of a syllable (zh); for such omissions cf. p. xviii, and h. Apoll. 407 (prw=ta for prw/tista in all MSS. except M). For the construction cf. Od. 5.59 , i 210, and for the crasis of kai/ cf. Il. 2.238 , *z 260 with Leaf's note, Il. 13.734 , g 255, z 282, kou)/ 227, ka)gw/ h. Herm. 173, ka)k pollw=n Theog. 447, kou)/ Parmenides 51, kau)toi/ Xenophanes vi. 5. See Kühner-Blass Griech. Gramm. i. p. 225, Smyth Ionic § 308 for exx. in other poets, H. G. § 377, La Roche H. U. i. p. 283 f., van Leeuwen Ench.p. 50 f.
e)*ge/lasse: see on h. Apoll. 118.
a)/mfw: here indeclinable; a use not found in early epic. Cf. Apoll. Arg. 1.165 (gen.), 1169 (dat.), Theocr. xvii. 26.

xa/ne de\ xqw/n: this explanation was natural when the scene of the ascent or descent of Pluto was localised on a plain; so, according to the actual Eleusinian tradition, the chariot disappeared through the opening ground (fragment of a vase from Eleusis, Ath. Mitth. xxi. pl. 12; J. H. S. xxii. p. 3). In some traditions Pluto disappeared in a cave ( Ausc. Mir. 82). At Enna he ascends through a cave, and descends into the open ground, Diod.v. 3. 4.
eu)rua/guia: in Homer of cities only. The epithet is less suitable to xqw/n. Gemoll compares di/ka eu)rua/guia (Terpand. fr. 6), for a more general use.

*nu/sion a)\m *pedi/on: on the various places called Nysa see i. 8. Whether the Nysian plain is here purely mythical, or whether the poet was thinking of a particular place, it is impossible to say. Förster (p. 268 f.) argues for the Carian Nysa; Preller-Robert (i.^{2} p. 758 n. 3) for the Thracian. The poets generally speak of Nysa as a mountain (e.g. Soph. Ant.1130, i. 8), but the locality is so vague that pedi/on may well stand; cf. Apoll. Arg. 2.1214 ou)/rea kai\ pedi/on *nush/i+on. Hesiod does not localise the myth, but the schol. on Theog. 913 lays the scene by the Ocean. Various other places are mentioned: e.g. Crete (Bacchyl. fr. 64), Eleusis itself (Phanodemus fr. 20, Paus.i. 38. 5, Orph. h. xviii. 15); see Introd. p. 12, and Preller-Robert i.^{2} p. 759, Roscher ii. 1313, Förster l.c. In later times the Sicilian tradition prevailed (first in Carcinus ap. Diodor. v. 5; cf. Mosch.iii. 128, Opp. Hal. iii. 489, and often in Latin poetry; Ov. Fast.iv. 353, Ov. Met.v. 385, Lucan vi. 740, Stat. Ach.ii. 150, Claud. de rapt. Pros. ii. 71). Modern poets have chiefly followed the Romans: That fair field Of Enna where Proserpine, gathering flowers, Herself a fairer flower, by gloomy Dis Was gathered (Milton).

o)/rousen a)/nac: the trochaic caesura in the fourth foot is very rare, except when the caesura is preceded by an enclitic or other monosyllable; see on 248. Tyrrell (Hermath. ix. 20 p. 34) suggests o)/rous' a(/nac, to avoid breaking a “law universal in Greek poetry from Homer to Nonnus.” But the exceptions to the rule in Homer are amply sufficient to justify the text; see H. G. § 367. 2, Hermann Orphica p. 693, van Leeuwen Mnemosyne, 1890, p. 265 and Ench.p. 18-22, Eberhard Metr. Beob. i. p. 23 f. The last word is usually of four syllables as in Il. 6.2 , *w 60, r 399= Od. 20.344, and here; or five, as in Od. 18.140 and h. Apoll. 36 (where however see note); very rarely of three, as in Od. 12.47. The law is more rarely broken in post - Homeric verse; examples are Theog. 23 *(elikw=nos u(po\ caqe/oio, Theog. 319 pne/ousan a)maima/keton pu=r, Scut. 222 w(/ste no/hm' e)pota=to. In Theog. 435 Köchly transposes a)gw=ni a)eqleu/wsin and in Op.693 for forti/) a)maurwqei/h one MS. has forti/a maurwqei/h. Sometimes, as in Od. 5.272 o)ye\ du/onta, Theognis 881, Tyrtaeus fr. 7. 1 qeoi=si fi/los, the two words are rhythmically one; but Theognis 931 ou)de\ qano/nt' a)poklai/ei, id. 981 lo/goisin e)mh\n fre/na qe/lgois are real exceptions; cf. id. 923. In later literature the following exceptions may be noted: verse ap. Phaedr. 252B, Hom. Epigr.vii. 1, Orph. h. liii. 3, lxxxv. 5; Evenus fr. i. 5 (Gaisf.); Pythag. xrus. e)p. 6, 37, and 70; ep.ap. Paus.iv. 1. 8(line 3); and often in Oppian (Ven. i. 190, ii. 60, 120, 202, 536, iii. 237, 244, iv. 232, 431). There are several exceptions in Diog. Laert. (Anth. Pal. vii. 96. 3, vii. 104. 1, vii. 126. 1); so Schol. ibid. vii. 568. 1.

*poluw/numos: first in Hesiod and h. Apoll. 82. Preller thinks the epithet specially appropriate to Pluto, whose titles were numerous; see Preller-Robert i.^{2} p. 804, Rohde Psyche 192 f. For the e)pwnumi/ai of Pluto cf. Paus.ix. 23. 4(on a hymn to Persephone by Pindar) e)n tou/tw| tw=| a)/|smati a)/llai te e)s to\n *(/aidhn ei)si\n e)piklh/seis kai\ o( xrush/nios, dh=la w(s e)pi\ th=s *ko/rhs th=| a(rpagh=|. So in h. Apoll. 82 Apollo is poluw/numos, i.e. has many titles in different lands. On such accumulation of titles see Lobeck Agl. i. p. 401, who quotes e.g. Ov. Met.iv. 11 f., Gruppe Culte u. Mythen i. p. 555 n. 44, Adami p. 222 f. (where many references are collected), viii. Introd. The primary meaning of the word may therefore stand, in the case of gods; but, as applied to inanimate objects, poluw/numos is simply “famous”; cf. Theog. 785 (u(/dwr), Pind. Pyth.i. 17(a)/ntron).
xruse/oisin: cf. Pindar's epithet xrush/nios from Paus. quoted above. o)/xoisin: in 375 o)/xesfin, which Voss and others needlessly read here.
i)a/xhse: so xxvii. 11; forms from i)axe/w do not occur in early epic; but cf. xxvii. 7 i)axei=, Callim. h. Del. 146 i)axeu=sa.
u(/paton kai\ a)/riston=Il. 19.258 (nom.).

e)lai=ai: this is usually held to be corrupt, but no emendation is at all satisfactory; the conjectures, apart from their graphical eccentricity, err in endeavouring to introduce a person or persons (Demeter or the nymphs). But the categories a)qa/natoi and qnhtoi\ a)/nqrwpoi are exhaustive, with the exception specified in 24. Any title of Demeter is peculiarly out of place: she heard the second and louder cry 38, 39, which sets her in motion. The reading of M e)lai=ai runs counter to the usual notions of Greek poetical taste. This, however, is no reason for suspecting the text. In late, especially Latin, poetry inanimate nature is often personified (e.g. Verg. Ecl.i. 38Verg. Ecl., x. 13, and many instances given by Forbiger). We have to learn that the idea was earlier than has been supposed. The sense here would be: “neither gods nor men heard her; and the trees were deaf” (J. H. S. xvii. p. 50). The nearest analogies in Greek poetry are Bioni. 31ta\n *ku/prin ai)ai=

l.quote: w)/rea pa/nta le/gonti kai\ ai( dru/es ai)ai=
*adwnin

div2.l: kai\ potamoi\ klai/ousi ta\ pe/nqea ta=s *)afrodi/tas and Theocr. vi. 74. So even in prose, Lycurgus 150 nomi/zontes ou)=n w)= *)aqhnai=oi i(keteu/ein u(mw=n th\n xw/ran kai\ ta\ de/ndra, dei=sqai tou\s lime/nas. If this view is thought untenable, we are thrown back on Ilgen's *(/eleiai or “Marsh-nymphs” (= nu/mfai e(leiono/moi Apoll. Arg. 2.821, 3. 1219). In favour of this, it may be noted that the Nymphs form a class apart from gods and men; cf. h. Aphr. 259. But, as Tyrrell notes, nu/mfai seems absolutely required; cf. Theocr. v. 17 ta\s limna/das *nu/mfas.

div2.p: *persai/ou: Hecate is daughter of the Titan Perses (=Persaeus here) and Asterie, according to Theog. 411, Apollod.i. 2. 4.Other poets give other genealogies; see Farnell Cults ii. p. 502, Preller-Robert i.^{1} p. 322, Roscher 1899.

a)tala\ frone/ousa: a)talo/s (the der. is doubtful) seems properly to refer to youthful merriment; cf. Il. 18.567 , l 39, Theog. 989 (others translate “tender”; so Rouse in K. Z. 1899, xxxv. p. 462, connecting the words with a priv. and ta/l-as, i.e. “not capable of endurance,” cf. E. M. 161. 47). The E. M. explains Il. 6.400 pai=d' a)talo/frona by a(palo\n fro/nhma e)/xonta, toute/sti nh/pion, a)no/hton. The sense “merry” does not seem particularly suitable to Hecate in this connexion. Baumeister, followed by Gemoll, understands “kindly,” i.e. to Demeter; but there is no authority for this meaning, nor is it easy to see how a)tala\ fronei=n could be appropriate to a kourotro/fos (a title of Hecate), as others assume; kourotro/fos is not the same as kou=ros. Possibly the author thought of Hecate as a young goddess “with youthful thoughts.” See also L. Meyer Griech. Et. i. s.v. a)talo/s “kindlich”; Prellwitz Et. Wört. p. 37 “jugendlich.”

e)*c a)/ntrou: cf. Apoll. Arg. 3.1213 keuqmw=n e)c u(pa/twn (of Hecate). No particular cave is meant. Whether Hecate was originally a moon-goddess, or, as Farnell supposes, an earth-goddess, a cave would be appropriate for her home. In this hymn, at all events, she is certainly a moon-goddess, as is shewn by the mention of Helios in 26. So Sophocles (fr. 480) associates Helios and Hecate as sun and moon. Hecate heard the cry, but did not see the rape, as it was daytime, and she was therefore in her cave; Helios heard (a)/i+en 25), and of course saw also (cf. on 70).
Zeus absents himself intentionally, in order that he may not appear to connive at the rape (cf. on 3).

de/gmenos: generally explained as a perf. part., without reduplication, and with irregular accent (from *de/gmai, probably an older form of de/degmai. See Leaf on Il. 2.794, H. G. § 23). But it may be a present form; Leaf remarks that there is no reason for supposing that the affection of x by m is confined to aor. and perf. stems. Cobet altered to de/xmenos.
mhte/ra . . fu=la are almost certainly objects, not (as Gemoll) subjects, of o)/yesqai.

e)/qelge me/gan *no/on: Il. 12.255 qe/lge no/on (in a bad sense). Gemoll does not accept Hermann's lacuna. He explains: “so long as she hoped that her mother and the other gods would see her, she trusted (that her cry would avail) and (she called out so that) the mountains echoed.” But if this is the meaning intended, the wording is most obscure. The lacuna seems necessary. The change in sense between 37 and 38, and the absence of protasis to d), require at least another line. The case is different from those noted on 127. The sense of the lost passage, as Francke saw, is “but when she saw the earth opening to swallow her, then she despaired and shrieked loudly.”
xai/tais: for the Attic dative cf. 205, 308, 441. Hermann reads xai/th|s a)mbrosi/h|s.
kua/neon de\ ka/lumma=Il. 24.93; see on 182.
e)*pi\ trafer/hn te kai\ u(*gr/hn= Il. 14.308 , u 98, imitated in later epic, as Opp. Ven. i. 11. For the omission of gh=n and qa/lassan cf. h. Aphr. 123.

*)/hqelen: (with neg.) “had no mind” (=had not the power). e)qe/lein implies a desire to do what is, or seems to be, in one's power to do, and so is often practically equivalent to du/nasqai. Cf. Il. 9.353 , *f 366.

Bücheler and Francke reject this line. The stress on oi)wnw=n is unusual, but Gemoll compares zw/ein h. Aphr. 221, with accent ´macr; ¯. There are various emendations which give a usual but characterless verse. The line is modelled on Il. 22.438.

e)*nn=hmar: it is generally assumed from this word that the fast at Eleusis lasted nine days. This is not improbable, and is supported by parallels; see Roscher die Enneadischen, etc. Fristen, 1903, p. 16 f. (Abhandl. Sachs. Gesellsch. xxi.), who compares a festival at Lemnos, where fire was put out for nine days ( Philostr. Her.19. 14); the Thesmophoria ( Ov. Met.x. 434); the fast of Clytia (ib. iv. 262); the Italian Bacchanalia (Livy xxxix. 9). Roscher is probably right in explaining the number as representing an ancient week, one-third of a lunar month (op. cit. p. 14 f.). There is, however, no other allusion to the length of the Eleusinian fast; and in the present passage e)nnh=mar may be purely conventional, to express a round number of days, with no special reference to the actual duration of the fast. A period of nine days or nights is common in Homer: Il. 1.53 , *z 174, *i 470, *m 25, *w 107, 610, 664, 784, h 253, i 82, k 28, m 447, c 314; Theog. 722, 724, h. Apoll. 91. The Sicilian festival of the two goddesses mentioned by Diod.v. 4 lasted for ten days.
*dhw/: first here for *dhmh/thr, then often in poetry. The form is usually regarded as hypocoristic (Mannhardt Myth. Forsch. p. 295, Preller-Robert i.^{2} p. 748, Pauly-Wissowa 2713).
strwfa=t)=Il. 13.557. The form is probably late; see Leaf on Il. 15.666.

ai)qome/nas . . e)/xousa=Od. 7.101 (e)/xontes). For the significance of the torches, which play so large a part in the myth and ritual of Demeter, see Introd. p. 10, Lenormant ii. p. 124 f. On the whole subject of fire-festivals see Frazer G. B. iii. p. 238-326, who thinks that the use of torches in such cases “appears to be simply a means of diffusing far and wide the genial influence of the bonfire or of the sunshine which it represents” (p. 313). He quotes many examples (p. 255, 313 f.) to shew that the avowed intention of torch-lighting is often to fertilise the fields, or to prevent blight, etc.
49-50. Compare the mourning of Demeter in Callim. h. Dem. 17 au)stale/a a)/poto/s te kai\ ou) fa/ges ou)d' e)loe/ssw. This, however, may be independent of the hymn.

ba/lleto: the editors quote Il. 11.536 and other passages where the act. ba/llein has the meaning of “sprinkle,” “wet.” No other instance seems to occur of the middle ba/llesqai in this sense, unless we accept Hermann's loutra/ t' e)pibalou= xroi+/ (for the corrupt e)pi\ xroi+\ ba/le or ba/lleu) in Eur. Or.303.

A formulaic line (only here) similar to Il. 6.175 a)ll' o(/te dh\ deka/th e)fa/nh r(ododa/ktulos *)hw/s, and Il. 24.785 (faesi/mbrotos). fainoli/s: Ruhnken compares Sapph. fr. 95 e)/spere pa/nta fe/rwn o)/sa fai/nolis e)ske/das' au)/ws.

se/las: for a torch, Apoll. Arg. 3.293, 4.806. Here it is probably collective, “torchlight,” as the regular attribute of Hecate is a torch in either hand; cf. the plur. xei/ressi. So da/os=dai+/das in the formula da/os meta\ xersi\n e)/xousai (Il. 24.647 and elsewhere). For the attribute of Hecate see Roscher 1900 f. Farnell (Cults ii. p. 549 f.) thinks that the torch was originally the symbol of Hecate as a chthonian deity, not as the moon, with which, however, the hymn-writer plainly identified her (see on 25). For the connexion of Hecate with Demeter and Persephone see on 440.
a)*ggele/ousa: Hecate (or Artemis) was called a)/ggelos at Syracuse (Hesych. s.v. and Schol. on Theocr. ii. 12), but it is unlikely that there is here any allusion to this title.

The “news” which Hecate gives is that she heard Persephone's cry—a circumstance which certainly was unknown to Demeter. Hence a)ggele/ousa needs no emendation, and the difficulties about this part of the narrative, and the inference based on them as to the composition of the hymn, are imaginary. Maass E. *)=iris, I. F. i. 164 accepts the continuity of the text (though reading a)gge/llousa, which is virtually the same as the future).

w(rhfo/re: the hiatus is legitimate in the bucolic diaeresis; H. G. § 382 (2). On the epithet, “bringer of the seasons,” see Mannhardt Myth. Forsch. p. 227, who compares Anth. Pal. vi. 98. 1 *dhoi= likmai/h| kai\ e)naulakofoi/tisin *(/wrais.
qew=n ou)rani/wn: not Homeric. For qeo/s a monosyllable cf. Od. 14.251 qeoi=sin. So Theog. 44 qew=n, and perhaps Il. 1.18 qeoi/. Below, 259, 325.

fwn=hs *ga\r *)/hkous): the exx. of ga/r lengthened by ictus are mostly before oi( or eu(: Il. 2.342 , *z 38, *i 377, d 826, etc. But cf. Il. 2.39 , *t 49, where ga/r before a vowel appears to be established. ga/r r() would be simple, and the collocation of the two words is confirmed by the metre in Il. 13.352 and other passages, although in other places r(a may have been inserted from mistaken metrical grounds. Of course me/n may have dropped out here, as perhaps in 122, in which case a)/kous) would naturally be altered to h)/kous).
o(/s tis e)/h*n: parenthetical; see 119, and note on h. Herm. 208.

w)=ka le/gw *nhmerte/a: the explanation given in J. H. S. xvii. p. 52 (=le/gw pa/nta soi\ w)=ka ei)=nai nhmerte/a) is improbable, as nhmerth/s must be closely connected in a predicative sense with le/gw; see Ebeling s.v. But the text may be correct: Hecate asseverates the truth of her statement by a common formula; cf. 433, Od. 11.137 ta\ de/ toi nhmerte/a ei)/rw; “I tell thee truly (all I know).” w)=ka is unusual with the present, but justified by the context, “and I tell it quickly.” Hecate wishes to spare Demeter disappointment, by confessing her ignorance at once. Hermann's lacuna (with le/goi) seems therefore unnecessary.
sta\n d' i(/p*pwn *propa/roiqe=Il. 24.286 , o 150.

su/ *per recurs 116, and Ludwich's conjecture is excellent on palaeographical grounds; cp. h. Herm. 308 e)ne/xwn de M=e(/nex' w(=de. The stroke to denote n in qea_ (=qean) was no doubt taken for a circumflex.

kou/rh*n t\hn e)/tekon: the antecedent is attracted to the case of the relative, as in Il. 10.416 , *c 75, 371. H. G. § 267. Cf. Verg. Aen.i. 573urbem quam statuo vestra est. This “inverse attraction” (for th\n kou/rhn) is slightly different from the attraction of a nominative absolute to the case of the relative, as in Il. 6.396 quga/thr . . . *)heti/wnos: *)heti/wn, o(\s e)/naie, a 50. In Od. 8.74 (oi)/mhs th=s) the gen. may be partitive, or due to either of these forms of attraction.

a)din/hn: see Leaf on Il. 2.87. The word is often used with verbs or substantives expressing grief, where it seems to mean “loud” or “vehement.” The derivation, and consequently the original meaning are obscure (Leo Meyer Handbuch der gr. Etymologie, 1902): Göbel's suggestion (a) intens. and &root;de ‘move’) is as probable as any. The primary sense would then be “quick” or “busy.” Prellwitz Et. Wört. s.v. suggests a connexion with a)dh/n.

di) ai)qe/ros a)truge/toio=Il. 17.425. Elsewhere a)tru/getos is applied to the sea. The derivation and meaning are unknown. The ancients connected the word with tru/gh, i.e. “unharvested,” “barren,” or with tru/ein, “unconquered” (by tempests), see Ebeling. Modern scholars have generally adopted one of these derivations. Prellwitz s.v. sees in -trug- the German Dorf, Eng. thorp, with the same general sense.

katade/rkeai a)kti/nessi: cf. Od. 11.16, where katade/rkesqai (here intrans.) is more naturally constructed with an obj. acc. katade/rketai in M is a common scribe's error (e.g. Il. 10.82 e)/rxeai e)/rxetai, 115 nemesh/seai nemesh/setai) assisted by the similar context in Od. 11.16, where the verb is in the third person. o)/pwpen followed naturally.
The writer has a reminiscence of Od. 3.93 kei/nou lugro\n o)/leqron e)nispei=n, ei)/ pou o)/pwpas (cf. 65 h)\ e)/pei h)\ e)/rgw| with Od. 3.99).

me/ga a(/zomai: unless with Ruhnken we insert s) there is an hiatus, which however may be justified by Theog. 532 tau=t' a)/ra a(zo/menos (this is practically the MS. tradition, as the only variant is a)/r) for a)/ra; see Rzach's note). Curtius Grundzüge p. 162, Prellwitz s.v., and Fortunatov K. Z. xxxvi. 46 assume an initial yod which would produce hiatus. The same explanation is sometimes given of w(s making position (H. G. § 397).

ou)de/ is suspected by Wegener and Gemoll. Puntoni (p. 52) defends the text. ou)de/ may be illogical for ou), but it is quite natural after the parenthetic clause dh\ ga/r ktl. (cf. 32). The sense of the passage is: “you shall know all (for I pity you); and you are to know that Zeus alone is to blame.” See further on vii. 56. Indeed ou)de/ is hardly to be distinguished from ou) in several Homeric passages; see Fränkel in Album Grat. to Herwerden p. 61 f., who quotes Il. 19.420 , *u 133 etc. (ou)de/ ti/ se xrh/). In Il. 16.225 (ou)de/ tis a)/llos) the de/ has force.
qaler/hn: the special epithet of a young husband or wife, like the “blooming” bride in English ballads; so with go/nos, h. Aphr. 104, and with ga/mos, z 66, u 74, h. Pan 35.

82-83. There is no reason to eject ou)de/ ti/ se xr\h . . xo/lon. Hermann altered *go/on to xo/lon on the ground that the formula oude/ ti/ se xrh/ introduces a repetition of a previous statement (Il. 7.109 , *t 67 etc.). But the duplication of xo/lon is intolerable; and as go/os is the expression of xo/los there would be no difficulty, even if the present passage were from the old epic.

a)mfi\ de\ tim/hn, “in respect of honour”; the wording, if somewhat prosaic, is correct. The order is like that of Hes. Op.74a)mfi\ de\ th/n ge. The proposed alterations (timh=| or timh=|s) rest on the analogy of h. Herm. 390 a)mfi\ bo/essin and ib. 172 a)mfi\ de\ timh=s (so MSS., timh=|s Gemoll). But for a)mfi/ with acc. cf. h. Herm. 57, viii. 1, xxii. 1, xxxiii. 1. These exx. are all of “speaking about,” but Pind. Isthm.vii. 8Pind. Isthm., 9 has both dat. and acc. in a wider sense.
toi=s: rightly explained by Franke as demonstrative: Hades dwells among those over whom he is lord.
88-89. Cf. Scut. 341-342. tanu/pteroi is to be taken with oi)wnoi/, not with i(/ppoi. Nothing is said in this poem about winged horses, although Gemoll compares Eur. El.466.
ai)*no/teron kai\ ku/nteron: cf. 305 f., Od. 11.427.
*nosfisqei=sa, “rejecting,” as in h. Herm. 562 and orac.ap. Hendess 119. 7 nosfisqei=sa ge/ra prote/rwn tima/s te palaia/s (of Deo).
a)maldu/nousa: not, as in Homer, “destroying,” but “disguising.” Baumeister compares Apoll. Arg. 1.834, 4.112.

baquzw/nwn, “low-girt,” i.e. girt over the hips. The epithet, which occurs in Il. 9.594 , g 154, is apparently not synonymous with baqu/kolpos, as the ancient grammarians and most editors assume; see on h. Aphr. 257.

*keleoi=o: this is the usual tradition for the king's name; cf. Paus.i. 39. 1(Pamphos), Apollod.i. 5. 3. schol. on Eq.695; see further in Roscher ii. 1026 f. The schol. on Nicand. Alex. 130 calls the king Hippothoon (the eponymous hero of the Attic tribe) with Metanira as his wife. For other accounts see Förster p. 12. There was a cult of Celeus and his daughters at Eleusis ( Protrept. i. p. 39), and a shrine of Metanira ( l.c.).

*parqeni/w| fre/ati: for the metre of fre/ati_ cf. 101, 248; La Roche Hom. Unter. i. p. 49, H. G. § 373. The local dative is amply supported by examples in H. G. § 145; it is here not harsher than trape/zh| “at table” (Od. 21.35). See further on 308 and h. Aphr. 173. Gemoll objects that the “Ionic” form is frei/ati (frh/ati), while in Attic fre/ati has a long. But Herodotus uses fre/ar, and the hymn - writer might naturally adopt the epic quantity (frei/a^ta *f 197). On the forms of the word see Brugmann Grundriss ii. p. 236, 342 f., Prellwitz s.v.

The “Maiden well” is not mentioned again in the hymn; it is most probably identical with the “Flowery well,” at which, according to Pamphos, Demeter sat; cf. Paus.i. 39. 1fre/ar e)sti\n *)/anqion kalou/menon. e)poi/hse de\ *pa/mfws e)pi\ tou/tw| tw=| fre/ati kaqh=sqai *dh/mhtra ktl. Frazer (l.c.) thinks it may be the spring called Vlika, about a mile and a half west of Eleusis, on the road to Megara. The well is not to be confused with the Callichorum, which was close to the precinct of Eleusis (see on 272), although the fame of this latter well led several ancient writers to identify it with the place where Demeter rested; cf. Callim. h. Dem. 16, Nicand. Ther.486, Apollod.i. 5. 1; in Orph. Arg. 729 a river in Asia is called both Parthenius and Callichorus, probably in view of this literary tradition. The accounts of Pamphos and the present hymn no doubt follow the ancient Eleusinian tradition; see further on 200. The last hemistich is a formula: Od. 7.131 , r 206.

*grhi+/ *palaigene/i+ e)*nali/gkios: the corn-spirit, in the form of the last sheaf, is often called the “Old Woman,” “Grandmother” etc.; see Frazer G. B. ii. p. 170 f. It has been suggested that in grhi+/ we have a survival of the otherwise nameless corn-spirit. Jevons even holds that the corn-goddess was known simply as grau=s, and her daughter as ko/rh, until the Athenians identified the two with Demeter and Persephone (p. 367, 378 f.). But it is difficult to believe that the Eleusinian goddesses were nameless until so late a period. Indeed, as far as regards the hymn, the metamorphosis of Demeter into an old woman need have no special significance; some disguise was necessary for the purpose of the story. Compare the account of Pamphos mentioned by Paus.i. 39. 1(grai+\ ei)kasme/nhn). For a similar disguise cf. Il. 3.386, of Aphrodite, which shews that the present passage may be due to epic influence.
*)eleusini/dao: son of Eleusis, the eponymous hero of the place, Paus.i. 38. 7.He was also called Eleusinus, Hyg. Fab.147, Serv. on Georg.i. 19, alibi.
eu)/hruton: (only here) formed, like kotulh/ruton *y 34, from a)ru/w which first occurs in Hesiod.

108-110. Pausanias causes a difficulty in this passage: in i. 38. 3 he states kalou=si sfa=s (the daughters of Celeus) *pa/mfws te kata\ tau)ta\ kai\ *(/omhros *dioge/neian kai\ *pammero/phn kai\ tri/thn *saisa/ran. Puntoni considers the lines interpolated, following Hermann, who, however, subsequently retained 108 reading trei=s w(sei/ te. The name *kallidi/kh in 146 would on this view have been substituted for another, unless the whole verse has been interpolated. An interpolation however is on general grounds highly improbable, and later than Pausanias' time out of the question; it would be more legitimate to suppose an early variant. Cf. n. crit. on 476. Gemoll thinks that the text of Paus. is corrupt, suggesting kalei= de\ sfa=s <ou)> kata\ tau)ta\ kai\ *(/omhros . . *dioge/neian ktl., the gap being filled with the names Callidice etc. Preller, Baumeister, and others suppose that Paus. may have made a slip of memory, which seems the most probable solution of the difficulty.
e)/g*nwn: for the Homeric e)/gnwsan. So Pind. Pyth.ix. 85(136). The correct form, however, seems to be e)/gnon which Cobet restores. Compare e)/ba^n, and e)/fa^n 118.
*palaigene/wn a)*nqrw/pwn: a variation of the Homeric ti/s po/qen ei)=s a)ndrw=n; Bücheler's xamaigene/wn is no improvement.

The form pilna=s given by M being transitive (pilna=| 3 sing. Hes. Op.510, pi/lnatai passive Apoll. Arg. 4.952), Voss's pi/lnasai, as preserving the sigma, seems preferable to Hermann's pilna=|, which rests only on the analogy of damna=| *c 199 (called Doric in schol. T ad loc.). The syllable ai was omitted, as in e)pibh/sesq) 332, from the effect of the hiatus.
ai<*>/ tine/s e)ste: parenthetical, as in 58. Demeter speaks as though she did not know their names.

*dwsw/: the name is uncertain; Fontein's *dhw/ is some way off dw/s, and as Demeter (called *dhw/ in 47) invents her story, it is natural that she should give a fictitious name. Brunck's *dw/s is not elsewhere found as a proper name, but=do/sis in Hes. Op.356.This, however, requires the insertion of me/n, and preference may be given to Passow's *dwsw/, where the vowel could easily have been lost before e)moi/. In either case there might possibly be a mystic allusion to the corn as a “gift” to men (see Pater p. 102).

*nu=n au)=te: for nu=n de/ as in Od. 22.6. Ruhnken's nu=n d' au)=te, though of course common, is therefore needless. *kr/hthqen: editors see an allusion to the early worship of Demeter in Crete, as if the writer wished to hint this fact, even in a fictitious story. For the Cretan cult see Diod.v. 77.The myth of Iasion (Od. 5.125) was localised in Crete, Theog. 970. Miss Harrison believes in Cretan influence at Eleusis (Proleg. p. 565 f.). But the explanation is unnecessary; the name of Crete would naturally occur to any one who wished to give a plausible account of his parentage or travels. In Od. 14.199 f. Odysseus invents a Cretan home. Cf. also Od. 13.256 f., Od. 19.172 f.

*qoriko/nde: the town and deme of Thoricus (Therikó) was N. of Sunium, with a harbour now called Mandrí. See Leake Demi of Attica p. 68. It was one of the twelve independent cities of Attica until the time of Theseus (Strabo ix. p. 397). For its history and remains see Frazer on Paus.i. 31. 3.
kate/sxeqon: the construction katasxei=n nhi+/ is not Homeric, but occurs in Herodotus and Attic (Francke).

Hermann's lacuna is perhaps unnecessary, considering the elliptical style of this hymn generally; cf. 317, 446. Of course a step in the narrative is omitted. For the Homeric custom of landing for meals cf. Od. 14.346 , i 85, k 56, o 499. This passage seems to be a reminiscence of that in c, where Odysseus escapes from the Thesprotian sailors.

e)*phrtu/nonto: Francke objects to the verb, on the ground that it is not used by Homer in the middle, and should mean “fix on.” But the simple verb a)rtu/nw is found in the middle, with the sense here required “prepare”: cf. Il. 2.55=Il. 10.302 h)rtu/neto boulh/n. Homer, however, has e)ntu/nesqai with a)/riston, dai=ta, dei=pnon.

do/rpoio: used in the proper sense of supper; cf. Od. 14.347 do/rpon e(/lonto with e(spe/rioi 344. dei=p*non in 128 must therefore be general for any meal, or perhaps for the principal meal of the day, here supper.
tim=hs (for w)/nou) is not Homeric ( Herod. and Attic).

Demeter feigns ignorance of the name of the country, although in 126 she mentions Thoricus. But Eleusis is sufficiently far from Thoricus to justify the word a)lalhme/nh and to give colour to her feigned ignorance of the place.

The key to this difficult passage is te/wn, which is of course interrogative. To follow oi)ktei/rate it would have to be relative. Therefore rather than write te/ws (un-Homeric in the sense of “until”) with Ruhnken, it seems better to assume a lacuna containing a verb to govern te/wn, e.g. (on the analogy of the corresponding line 149) tou=to de/ moi safe/ws u(poqh/kate, o)/fra pu/qwmai. The termination -wmai coming before i(/kwmai and e)rga/zwmai would account for the omission. The answer, 149 f., implies a question. Attempts have been made to give tokh=es its full metrical value, but the synizesis is probably genuine; cf. basilh=es Hes. Op.263, and perhaps i(pph=es *l 151. So e)phetano/s (quadrisyll.) Hes. Op.607, h. Herm. 113.

a)f/hlikos: not in Homer. Cf. Moeris p. 82 a)fhlikeste/ran, presbute/ran *)attikw=s. But a)ph=lic is found in Herod.iii. 14(in compar.). In Il. 22.490 (a late passage) panafh=lic has a different sense.

despo/sunon: first in Pind. Pyth.iv. 267(475). didask/hsaimi: for the form cf. Hes. Op.64e)/rga didaskh=sai. diaq[r]h/saimi and diaq[l]h/saimi are of course easier changes than Voss's didaskh/saimi, which also involves the alteration of gunaiko/s to gunai=kas. The sense, however, is very near, and the corruption not greater than some of those known in M (p. xviii). diaskh/saimi (cf. the variant in l.c.) would be little removed from diaqh/saimi.
148-9=216-7. Cf. Solon fr. 5. 64 dw=ra d' a)/fukta qew=n gi/gnetai a)qana/twn, Rhian. ap. Stob. 54 fe/romen de\ qew=n e(tero/rropa dw=ra
div2.l: a)frade/i+ kradi/h|. The early editors doubted the mood of te/tlamen, and Brunck's alteration was to suit an infin. (tetla/men). The indic. is certainly right; cf. Od. 20.311.

div2.p: Cf. Scut. 105 d\s *qh/bhs krh/demnon e)/xei r(u/etai/ te po/lha. kr/hdemna: applied to the walls of Troy, a ‘diadem,’ Il. 16.100 , n 388. Compare the epithet e)u+ste/fanos. So Il. 2.117 poli/wn ka/rhna. See also vi. 2.

*triptole/mou: for Triptolemus and the other princes cf. 474 f. According to Paus.i. 14. 2Triptolemus was the son of Trochilus or (the Athenian version) of Celeus. Apollodorus (i. 5. 2) calls him the eldest son of Celeus and Metanira, but mentions other genealogies, i.e. that of Panyasis (son of Eleusis and Demeter) and that of Pherecydes (son of Oceanus and Ge). Hyginus fab.147 and Serv. on Georg.i. 19 give a different parentage (Eleusinus and Cothonea or Cyntinia). For the later myth of Triptolemus see Preller-Robert i.^{2} p. 770 f., Harrison M. M. A. A. p. xlix f. (and Eumolpus). The derivation tri/s, polei=n must now be abandoned, as Triptolemus had no early connexion with the plough (Kern de Tript. Aratore, 1887; cf. Lehrs Aristarch.^{2} p. 459, von Wilamowitz Aus Kydathen p. 132); for the name cf. Neoptolemus etc.

For Dioclus cf. Plut. Thes.10(a king of Eleusis). In 474Plut. Thes., 477 the form is *dioklh=s; Ruhnken compares the double *)/ifiklos, *)ifiklh=s and others. Polyxeinus and Dolichus appear to be abstracted from titles of Pluto; for Polyxeinus (whose name is not elsewhere mentioned in connexion with Eleusis) cf. on 9 *polude/kth|. Dolichus is certainly an epithet of Pluto; cf. von Prott in Ath. Mitth. xxiv. p. 251 [plouto]ni d[oli]xoi. Elsewhere he is a son of Triptolemus (Dolichius), Eusth. 306 on Il. 2.625, Byz.Steph. ; Herodian (p. mon. le/c. p. 10) quotes a line *eu)/molpos *do/lixo/s te kai\ *(ippoqo/wn mega/qumos.
Eumolpus, like Triptolemus, is here only one of the Eleusinian chiefs; his fame as the first hierophant and founder of the priestly family is later than the hymn.
The genitives depend on a)/loxoi, tw=n pa/ntwn being explanatory.

a)mu/monos: as Pausanias in his citation (see crit. note) expressly says that Homer calls Eumolpus a)gh/nwr, Ruhnken and others would exchange the epithets in 154, 155, reading a)gh/noros *eu)mo/lpoio and patro\s a)mu/monos. But Pausanias' quotation is probably a casual error, influenced by the next line.
*porsai/nousi: probably intrans., “manage in the house.” Ruhnken takes dw/mata as an object, joining kata/ with the verb.

*prw/tiston is sound. For this feminine form in comparative and superlative adjectives cf. Od. 4.442 o)low/tatos o)dmh/, Theog. 408 (*lhtw\) a)ganw/taton e)nto\s *)olu/mpou, Pind. fr. 152 glukerw/teros o)mfa/. For exx. in prose see Kühner-Blass i. p. 554 n.

qeoei/kelos: the gods, when they are disguised as mortals, often shew a nobility which excites admiration; cf. the disguise of Apollo (h. Apoll. 464 f.), of Aphrodite (h. Aphr. 92 f.), and of Dionysus (vii. 17 f.).
ei) . . e)*pi/meinon=Od. 17.277, where of course e)qe/leis (the proper Homeric form) is found. Hermann is probably right in restoring it here; cf. 137. For the later qe/lw see on h. Apoll. 46.

thlu/getos: M. and R. on Od. 4.11 summarise Savelsberg's view (Rhein. Mus. 1853) that this word=adolescens, “grown big” (*th=lus “great”), and is applied to boys and girls from the age of about thirteen to twenty or more. Leaf on Il. 3.175 approves. This explanation takes no account of the present passage, where Demophon is quite an infant. Fick Wörterbuch i.^{4} 440 connects the word with ta=lis a bride: Prellwitz s.v. sees in the latter part the root of u)gih/s etc. It is of course possible that the writer was ignorant of the real meaning, and understood the word as referring to an only son, or to one born to his parents in old age, as the ancients variously explained. Francke and Gemoll think that the sense “lateborn” could not have been here meant, as o)yi/gonos follows; but pleonasms are quite in the manner of this poem; cf. polueu/xetos and a)spa/sios 165, and the synonyms in 124.
*polueu/xetos: only here, for polua/rhtos in Homer and below 220.
qrept/hria: see on 223. doi/h: sc. Metanira: cf. 223 doi/hn.
kudia/ousai: for the occasional retention of the original -a/w etc. see H. G. § 55. Instances in the hymns are h. Aphr. 266, vii. 14, 41.
w(|s, “according as”; so 295, 416. Ruhnken's o(/ss) is quite needless.

It is noticeable that here and in 401 M represents the diphthong ei by h; cf. also h. Apoll. 9. h)/aros may be a genuine form (i.e. a correct transcription of a prae-Euclidean E), or it may be a confusion with h)=ros, h)rino/s. Homer only uses e)/aros, *z 148, t 518 (but see Agar in J. P. xxviii. 1901, p. 80 f.). For h)=ros cf. 455.

The picture of girls raising their dress to run is not found in Homer or Hesiod. The action, as Francke notes, is commonly represented in art from the seventh century, and (although Gemoll rejects the idea) it is quite possible that the writer may have been influenced by such works of art (Francke p. 26). At all events, the pictorial touch is rather after the manner of a later poet. Baumeister compares Apoll. Arg. 3.873
a)\n de\ xitw=nas
leptale/ous leukh=s e)pigouni/dos a)/xris a)/eiron. (Compare this description of maidens running by the side of the chariot with the simple statement in Od. 13.84, 319.)
a)mfi\ . . a)i+/ssonto: borrowed from Il. 6.509 (of a horse). So kudio/wn *z 509=kudia/ousai 170, and Il. 6.400 pai=d' e)pi\ ko/lpw| e)/xousa=187 (u(po/).
krokhi+/w|: only here; for the form (=kroke/w|) cf. kourh/i+on (a)/nqos) 108, also a(/pac ei)r. For the colour cf. Ars amor. i. 530 croceas irreligata comas.

kata\ kr=hqen: Il. 16.548, where see Leaf, Od. 11.588, Theog. 574, and a)po\ krh=qen Scut. 7. The stem krh- appears in krh/demnon, krh/nh H. G. § 107, n. 5. The covered head, and the kua/neos pe/plos are, of course, signs of mourning; cf. Demeter *me/laina at Phigalia Paus.viii. 42, Pauly-Wissowa 2734.
qea=s may be restored, as in 210 M gives qea=|. For the confusion of h and a in the MS. see 147.
186=Od. 1.333 (sth= r(a) and elsewhere. te/geos, properly any roofed space, is here the me/garon.
u(*po/: we should expect e)pi/, as in Il. 6.400 (Gemoll). But the variation is trivial; in Od. 15.469 u(po\ ko/lpw| is used though with a slightly different sense.
188-211. Preller brackets these lines as interpolated, and others eject the whole or part of the passage. Preller's reasons are quite inadequate, as Baumeister, Gemoll and others point out.

188-189. Objection has been needlessly raised to this account of Demeter's miraculous entrance, in spite of which Metanira does not seem to recognize her divinity (cf. 213 - 215). She seems, indeed, to suspect that her visitor is something out of the common (190), just as Demeter appears qeoei/kelos, i.e. “noble,” to the girls (159). But when her momentary fear has gone, she is ready to accept Demeter as a mortal. Compare Anchises' original scruples (h. Aphr. 92f.), and his acceptance of Aphrodite's denial of divinity. Even more striking is the indifference to a miracle shown by the Tyrrhenian captain in the hymn to Dionysus; see vii. Introd. p. 228, and notes on h. Dem. 159, h. Apoll. 465.

mela/qrou ku=re ka/rh=h. Aphr. 173. Gemoll thinks that the present passage was borrowed from the h. Aphr. while Abel reverses the debt. In both places the words seem equally suitable. Gemoll argues that me/laqron is properly used of the roof-timbers in the h. Aphr., but improperly here for the lintel; but this is hypercritical. Indeed, we may suppose the goddess to have just crossed the threshold and to be standing actually in the me/garon.
*pl=hsen ktl.: miraculous light marks the presence of the gods: cf. h. Apoll. 444 (of Apollo), Eur. Bacch. 1083 (Dionysus), Ov. Fast. i. 94 lucidior visa est quam fuit antc domus; so infra 278.
klismoi=o: on the klismo/s see Helbig H. E. pp. 118, 122. It was more luxurious than the phkto\n e(/dos (=di/fros 198) which Demeter accepted. Matthiae compares Athen. v. 4 and Od. 19.55 f.

faeinou=: epithet of qro/nos, *l 645. The klismo/s is poludai/dalos *w 597, and poiki/los a 132, i.e. inlaid, or studded with silver (a)rguro/hlos). In Il. 8.436 the epithet xru/seos is ideal, for the chairs of gods.
The last hemistich=h. Aphr. 156. Cf. Verg. Aen.xi. 480oculos deiecta decoros.

*)ia/mbh: the episode of Iambe and Demeter is related by Apollod.i. 5. 1grai=a/ tis *)ia/mbh skw/yasa th\n qeo\n e)poi/hse meidia=sai. dia\ tou=to e)n toi=s qesmofo/rois ta\s gunai=kas skw/ptein le/gousi: Nicand. Alexiph. 130; cf. Diod.v. 4, E. M. and Hesych. s.v. The scholia on Nicand. l.c., Hephaest. p. 169, Eustath. p. 1684 attribute the invention of the iambic metre to Iambe. The connexion is absurd, although it may have been present in the mind of the writer of this hymn. As Gemoll notes, there is no proof that the Eleusinian raillery was uttered in iambic or any other metre; it was no doubt impromptu. The schol. on Nicand. Ther.484 mentions Ambas as a son of Metanira who laughed at the sacred rites; this suggests a connexion with Iambe, whose similarity to i)/ambos must be accidental. Iambe's jesting is here a mythological explanation of the banter which was a feature of the Eleusinia. No doubt the jesting was part of the primitive festival, although the literary references mostly mention the practice in connexion with the Athenian period of the Eleusinia. According to the schol. on Plut. 1014 the Athenian women abused one another, on their way to Eleusis in carriages; cf. also Suidas s.v. ta\ e)k tw=n a(macw=n. There was a similar custom at the sth/nia (Athens): see Preller-Robert i.^{2} p. 778. So Epidaurian women railed at each other at the parallel festival of Damia and Auxesia ( Herod.v. 83; cf. Frazer on Paus.ii. 30. 4). In these cases the raillery was peculiar to women, who were so intimately connected with agricultural rites. But at the Eleusinia there was also a custom known as gefurismo/s, in which men and women alike seem to have abused and jested with the procession at a bridge on the Eleusinian road. See Ran. 384 f., Strabo ix. p. 400, E. M. p. 229, Hesych. s.v. gefuristai/, Svoronos p. 297. There was a general ai)sxrologi/a in the Sicilian festival ( l.c.). The custom is probably due to the widespread idea that abuse of a person or his belongings brings good luck (by avoiding the fqo/nos qew=n or the evil eye, etc.). Frazer (G. B. i. p. 97 and on Paus.i. 37. 3) quotes, among other examples, Theophr. Hist. Plant. viii. 3, Quaest. Conv. vii. 2. 2; a Greek sower of cummin must curse to avoid failure of the crop.

The raillery of Iambe is akin to the indecencies associated with Baubo (Babo), who was actually worshipped at Paros (see inscr. quoted on 491) and certainly figured in the Eleusinian cult of Demeter ( Harp. s. v. *dusau/lhs, Protrept. ii. 77).
Cf. Il. 5.879 tau/thn d' ou)/t' e)/pei+ protiba/lleai ou)/te ti e)/rgw|.

a)*ge/lastos: this has been referred to the tradition that Demeter sat upon an a)ge/lastos pe/tra: Apollod.i. 5. 1, schol. on Eq.782, Suidas s.v. *salami=nos, Hesych. s.v. The situation of the stone cannot now be identified. Apollodorus places it by the Callichorum, but this is no authority, as he does not seem to follow the local tradition in regard to the resting-place of Demeter (see on 99). The stone is mentioned in a fourth-century inscr. (*)ef. *)arx. 1883 p. 115); it was probably near Athens, and unknown in the old Eleusinian myth; see Svoronos p. 247 f. In any case it should be noted that the word a)ge/lastos has no immediate connexion with the a)ge/lastos pe/tra, for Demeter is now sitting e)pi\ di/frou (198) in the house.
The latter hemistich=Od. 4.788.

a)/pastos: Callimachus (h. Dem. 8), who says nothing of Iambe, makes Demeter break her fast in the evening: e(/speros o(/s te piei=n *dama/tera mw=nos e)/peisen. This supports the theory that the Mystae fasted only till sunset (cf. the Mohammedan Ramadan; see Ramsay p. 126 n. 5).

202-205 bracketed by Matthiae and others, needlessly. Hermann (Epist. cv) objects to min followed by po/tnian a(gnh/n, but this apposition is quite Homeric; see Il. 21.249 , z 48, and cf. the frequent use of the pronominal o( in apposition with a proper name. He is also offended by the inelegancy of 204 and by o)rgai=s, 205. Francke thinks that pri/n g' o(/te dh/ in 202 was written by an imitator of 195; but the writer of 195 may surely have repeated himself.

i(/laon sxei=n qumo/n: Hes. Op.340w(/s ke/ toi i(/laon kradi/hn kai\ qumo\n e)/xwsin. The metre (with the last three feet spondaic) is not common, except in stereotyped endings, as in qnhtoi=s a)nqrw/pois (or the genitive of this formula) 11, 22, 29, 45, 55, 73, 403, and often in Homer. In 195, 202 *)ia/mbh ke/dn' ei)dui=a the older epic form was of course ke/dna vidui=a (Od. 1.428 etc.). In 302 canqh\ *dhmh/thr is formulaic (=Il. 5.500); so 452 kri= leuko/n =Od. 4.604. With the present line cf. 417, 421, 474. The number of “spondaic” verses (i.e. with the last two feet spondaic) is much greater in this hymn than the proportion in the first book of the Iliad (e.g.) or in the hymn to Apollo (see Schürmann de h. in Cer. aetate etc. p. 55 f., Francke p. 23, and see generally Eberhard Metr. Beob. i. p. 10 f., La Roche Wiener Studien xx. p. 70 f.).

o)rgai=s, “humour,” “mood,” a sense common both in sing. and plur. See L. and IambeS. , who was Demeter's companion as long as she remained in Celeus' house, “pleased her afterwards also,” not merely for the moment. The double dat. (oi( . . o)rgai=s) presents no difficulty; for the sxh=ma kaq' o(/lon kai\ me/ros in the dat. compare Il. 1.24 , *q 129, *n 82, Scut. 221, Herod.vii. 16.

ou) *ga\r qemito/n: cf. schol. on Nicand. Alex. l.c. h( de\ qeo\s ou)k e)de/cato, le/gousa mh\ qemito\n ei)=nai piei=n au)th\n oi)=non e)pi\ th=| qli/yei th=s qugatro/s. Jevons (p. 379 f.) thinks that wine is here a surrogate of blood and was for this reason excluded from the non-animal sacrifices to cereal deities. For wine as akin to blood see Frazer G. B. i. p. 358 f., and for bloodless offerings to Demeter or other deities of vegetation cf. e.g. Paus.viii. 42. 11.So the Eleans did not pour wine to the Despoinae. But Demeter and Persephone did not as a rule object to animal sacrifice: pigs were offered at the Attic Thesmophoria, and at Thebes ( Paus.ix. 8. 1); see Schömann Griech. Alterth.^{4} ii. p. 232 f. And, since human blood seems, at least originally, to have been shed during the Eleusinia (see on 265), the goddesses can hardly have objected to wine as its substitute. It need hardly be noted, in fact, that abstention from wine would be natural in any fast, such as took place in the Eleusinia.

The passage refers to the kukew/n, the institution of which the hymnwriter, according to his wont, ascribes to Demeter herself. The drinking of this mixture of meal and water was the actual means of communion with the goddess. and belonged therefore to the most sacred part of the ritual in the telesth/rion. The mystae received certain objects from the hierophant and answered e)nh/steusa, e)/pion to\n kukew=na, e)/labon e)k ki/sths, e)ggeusa/menos a)peqe/mhn ei)s ka/laqon, kai\ e)k kala/qou ei)s ki/sthn ( Protrept. 18, Arnob. v. 26; see Lobeck Aglaoph. i. p. 25, Harrison Prolegomena p. 155).

For the kukew/n in Homer see Il. 11.624 f., Od. 10.234 f. In the latter passage it is called si=tos, being compounded of a)/lfita. but it is always drunk (e)/kpion k 237). So Eusth. 870. 65 ei) kai\ metacu\ brwtou= kai\ potou= o( kukew\n ei)=nai dokei=, a)lla\ ma=llon oi(=a zwmo/s tis r(ofhto\s h)=n, comparing Il. 11.640 f. Cf. Ar. Pax712ou)/k, ei)/ ge kukew=n' e)pipi/ois blhxwni/an, schol. on Nicand. Alex. 128 f. (e)/pie).
On the sacramental eating of corn see Frazer G. B. ii. p. 318 f.

o(si/hs e(/neken, “to observe the rite,” as practised by the mystae. The expedients to bring the apodosis into this line are violent. e)pe/bh is far removed from e(/neken, which gives admirable sense and is defended by I. T. 1461 o(si/as e(/kati. Another suggestion, pi/e po/tnia, is equally rash. The lacuna has Puntoni's support; it must contain the verb of drinking. The missing verse may have run somehow as follows: e)/kpien: h( de\ labou=sa de/pas qe/to e)/nq' a)na/eire.

*polupo/tnia: not in early epic, but cf. Thesm. 1156, Apoll. Arg. 1.1125, Orph. h.xl. 16 (of Deo). The writer of this hymn is fond of compounds with polu-; cf. 9Orph. h., 17Orph. h., 18Orph. h., 28Orph. h., 31 etc.

xai=re: not here a salutation at meeting, but a courteous form of address or congratulation after some incident has occurred: Baumeister compares Od. 18.122 (after pledging a guest in wine, = “your health”), Od. 11.248 , q 408, 413.

e)*pei\ ou)/ se kakw=n ktl.; cf. h. Aphr. 132 ou) me\n ga/r ke kakoi\ toio/nde te/koien, and a close parallel in [Theocr.] xxv. 38
ou) se/ ge/ fhmi kakw=n e<*>\c
e)/mmenai ou)de\ kakoi=sin e)oiko/ta fu/menai au)to/n:
oi(=o/n toi me/ga ei)=dos e)pipre/pei (possibly an imitation of this passage; but kakw=n e)/c is in Il. 14.42 and for ei)=dos e)pipre/pei Gemoll compares Od. 24.252).
ai)dw/s, “dignity,” a sense not in Homer.

*zugo/s: only the neut. in Homer. For the phrase cf. Hes. Op.815e)pi\ zugo\n au)xe/na qei=nai bousi/, Theog. 1023 u(po\ zugo\n au)xe/na qh/sw, where the gender is indeterminate, but is probably neuter. Callimachus (fr. 467) is the first writer who certainly uses zugo/s in the sense “yoke,” but Plato (Tim. 63 B) has the masc. for “balance.”
221-223=166-168, with small variations.

doi/h*n is certainly to be retained; the mother would reward the nurse with qrepth/ria, when the child grew up. This is not to be confused with the qrepth/ria in Hes. Op.188, of the return made by the child to his parents in their old age; so qre/ptra (the Homeric form) in Il. 4.478 , *r 302.
kou)/: objections have been raised to the crasis, which, however, is perfectly tolerable; cf. n. on 13.

228-230. e)*phlusi/h, “witchcraft,” is certain (cf. h. Herm. 37), but u(potamno/n and u(loto/moio are puzzling. The former has been explained as a “cut herb,” used in sorcery, but the formation hardly allows such a meaning. Voss's ou)/te tomai=on (sc. fa/rmakon) is too violent. The same editor altered u(loto/moio to ou)loto/moio (a non-existing word), i.e. herbs cut for harmful purposes. In the Class. Rev. 1895, p. 13 it was suggested that u(potamno/n and u(loto/moio are superstitious paraphrases for the worm (e(/lmins or skw/lhc), and that Demeter knows of a remedy against this children's complaint. For such paraphrases cf. Aratus 959 skw/lhkes,
div2.l: kei=noi tou\s kale/ousi melai/nhs e)/ntera gai/hs, and Hesiod's fere/oikos “snail,” a)no/steos “cuttle-fish,” i)/dris “ant.” See A. Cook B. “Descriptive Animal Names in Greece,” Class. Rev. 1894, pp. 381 f., where a large number of similar substantives or epithets are collected. If this view is correct, the translation will be: “neither shall witchcraft hurt him, nor the Undercutter (Borer); for I know an antidote far stronger than the Woodcutter.” This involves the accentuation u(pota/mnon, a participle used as a substantive, like a)mei/bontes, a)mfifw=n, *)/empousa, kele/ontes. The objection is that u(loto/moio, the wood-cutter appears unsuitable as a paraphrase for the parasitic worm. In Hermath. i. p. 142 Davies retained u(potamno/n, and suggested ou)loto/moio from ou)=la “gums,” i.e. gumcutting. But as Tyrrell notes, these words are strangely formed if they denote a process. ou)loto/moio should be active, and mean “gum-cutter.”
div2.p: Davies is, however, probably right in seeing an allusion to “teething,” the first inevitable trouble of childhood. It may therefore be suggested that the u(pota/mnon and ou)loto/mos, or gum-cutter, is a worm, which, according to the belief of many peoples, causes toothache. Although teething itself could hardly be attributed to a worm, the incidental aches could be referred to that agency, i.e. the absence of a worm would result in easy teething. This explanation would be more certain, if we accept the correction ou)loto/moio, but it may still hold good with the retention of u(loto/moio (a general word for a worm), as suggested above.

For the worm as the cause of toothache cf. Shakespeare Much Ado iii. 2. 28; the belief is very common, e.g. in Scotland, County Folk-Lore iii. (Orkney), p. 140; India, Crooke Popular Religion and Folk-Lore of N. India i. p. 151 (where women of the gipsy tribes know charms to extract the worm); Finland, Abercromby Pre- and Proto-historic Finns i. p. 328. Dyer Folklore of Shakespeare p. 273 f. gives parallels from Germany and China. In the Geopon. xii. 27 and 35 the same remedies are assigned to worms and toothache.

The story of Demeter nursing Demophon has a parallel in Paus.ii. 5. 5: the children of Plemnaeus, a legendary King of Aegialea, in Sicyon, died at birth, until Demeter took pity and under the guise of a strange woman reared up a child named Orthopolis. On the close connexion between the growth of children and vegetation see the interesting chapter in Mannhardt Myth. Forsch. p. 351 f. “Kind und Korn.” For Demeter as a goddess of healing see Rubensohn in Ath. Mitth. xx. p. 360 f. In the hymn, Demophon is in no present danger; Demeter only promises to keep him in good health. According to Nicand. Ther.485 a lizard (a)skalabw/ths) had wounded Metanira's child; in Ovid Fast.iv. 446 f. the child (Triptolemus) is dying.

quw/dei+ de/cato ko/lpw|=Il. 6.483 (khw/dei+), of Andromache; hence quw/dhs does not refer to the divinity of Demeter, who sheds a superhuman fragrance only when she appears as a goddess (see on 277).
xersi/n t): the te, to which many editors object, seems genuine. Demeter receives the child in her bosom and her arms (not “places the child with her hands in her bosom”).

*dhmofo/wnq): Apollod.i. 5. 1 follows this version of the story. He mentions however Triptolemus as the elder son of Celeus, and relates the gift of the winged chariot. Demophon was finally ousted altogether by the greater fame of Triptolemus.
The abruptness of the text is impossible, and Hermann's supplement is recommended by the homoeoteleuton.

For the story cf. Apollod.i. 5. 1boulome/nh de\ au)to\ a)qa/naton poih=sai, ta\s nu/ktas ei)s pu=r kateti/qei to\ bre/fos kai\ perih/|rei ta\s qnhta\s sa/rkas au)tou=. Ovid Fast. iv. 487
inque foco pueri corpus vivente favilla
obruit, humanum purget ut ignis onus. Similarly Thetis wished to make Achilles immortal, but was prevented by Peleus: cf. Apollod.iii. 13. 6 and Apoll. Arg. 4.869 f.
(a passage which, as Ruhnken pointed out, may be derived from the hymn) h(\ me\n ga\r brote/as ai)ei\ peri\ sa/rkas e)/daien
nu/kta dia\ me/sshn flogmw=| puro/s: h)/mata d' au)=tc
a)mbrosi/h| xri/eske te/ren de/mas, o)/fra, pe/loito
a)qa/natos kai/ oi( stugero\n xroi+/ gh=ras a)la/lkoi.

katap*nei/ousa: cf. Ovid Fast. iv. 540
iungere dignata est os puerile suo.
pallor abit, subitasque vident in corpore vires.
tantus caelesti venit ab ore vigor.

kru/pteske: so Apollod.iii. 13. 6kru/fa *phle/ws ei)s to\ pu=r e)gkrubou=sa. For the purifying effect of fire on human beings cf. Rohde Psyche p. 29, Mannhardt A. W. F. p. 52f., Frazer G. B. iii. p. 312, who says “to the primitive mind fire is the most powerful of all purificatory agents.” He compares the custom of modern Greek women who leap over the midsummer bonfire, crying “I leave my sins behind me.” The myth of Demophon suggests, if it does not prove, that the Eleusinian children were purified by passing over fire (Jevons p. 365, Introd. p. 10). For such customs in the case of children see Frazer G. B. iii. p. 239 f. Modern Greeks still believe that newborn babies are protected from evil by the presence of fire; see Rodd Customs and Lore of Modern Greece p. 107 f. For the cognate idea of carrying fire over the field see on 48.

*)hu+/te dalo/n: this may mean “she hid him in fire as a brand is kept alight” (in the ashes); for which see Od. 5.488 f. and n. on h. Herm. 234. More probably, however, we should understand “she wrapt him in flames like a lighted torch.”

la/qra^ occurs only in a doubtful fragment of Euripides (1117 v. 28 Dind.); it is corrected in Hel.835(la/qr' ou)damou=). e(h=| for fi/lh| was read by Zenodotus in Il. 3.244, but the alteration seems too violent here; much more so kru/bda fi/lwn.
*proqal/hs, “early - growing,” only here; for the form cf. a)mfiqalh/s *x 496, and eu)qalh/s common in poetry after Homer.
The last hemistich = Il. 24.630 with ga/r (for de/) which Voss wrongly restores here. The sense requires de/, and the hiatus in the bucolic diaeresis is legitimate.
a)*g/hrwn: see on h. Aphr. 214.

e)*pithr/hsasa: she watched to see how the nurse made the child thrive, and thus broke the taboo. The magic could only be worked in secrecy, although the writer implies rather than expresses this (258 f.). In fact it is doubtful whether he understood the real nature of the taboo in the myth; he lays stress only upon Demeter's anger (251, 254), as if she renounced her design of her own will. In the Achilles legend, Apollodorus (l.c.) is more explicit: *qe/tis kwluqei=sa th\n proai/resin teleiw=sai. Apollonius vaguely states that Thetis left Peleus, as soon as she heard him cry, and rushed into the sea, xwsame/nh (Il. 4.877); the schol. on Nub. 1068 similarly says h( de\ lithqei=sa e)xwri/sqh. Curiosity in seeing a forbidden sight is punished in the classical myth of Cupid and Psyche; for other examples of this world-wide motive see Hartland Science of Fairy Tales pp. 270 f.

kw/kusen: the language of Apoll. Arg. 4.872 is similar:
h(=ke d' a)u+th\n
smerdale/hn e)sidw\n me/ga nh/pios
a)/mfw *pl/hcato mhrw/: cf. Il. 12.162 13. 198.
a)a/sqh: for the quantity of the first vowel cf. Od. 13.68 a_)/asan, *l 340 a_)a/sato de\ me/ga qumw=|. In 258 the a is short, for which cf. Il. 16.685 , *t 113, 136, h. Aphr. 253.

The trochaic caesura in the fourth foot is not uncommon, when the caesura is preceded by a monosyllable (me/n, de/, ge, etc). Instances like that in 17 (where see note) are different. For the quantity of the i in puri/ see on 99. No emendation is necessary.
e)/tikte: the omission of the mother's name is awkward, as Demeter is the subject of the main sentence; but there is no real difficulty, especially as th=s and th=| immediately precede.

a)*po\ e(/o q=hke: cf. Il. 12.205 a)po\ e(/qen h(=ke, i 461 a)po\ e(/o pe/mpe. Here Cobet reads a)po\ e(/qen h(=ke, which Gemoll approves, as qh=ke with -de is remarkable; it may be added that a verb expressing violent action would seem more appropriate to Demeter's anger: cf. Apoll. Arg. 4.674 to\n me\n a)/r' a(rpa/gdhn xama/dis ba/le keklhgw=ta.
e)*canelou=sa *puro/s: Apollodorus, seemingly following a different tradition, says to\ me\n bre/fos u(po\ tou= puro\s a)nhlw/qh. In Ovid's account, the mother takes the child from the fire.
kote/sasa: in Homer kotessame/nh.

The editors compare Orph. fr. xxxii.
mhdama\ mhde\n
ei)do/tes, ou)/te kakoi=o proserxome/noio noh=sai
fra/dmones, ou)/t' a)/poqen ma/l' a)postre/yai kako/thtos
ou)/t' a)gaqou= pareo/ntos e)pistre/yai te kai\ e)/rcai
i)/dries, a)lla\ ma/thn a)dah/mones a)prono/htoi. The resemblance can hardly be accidental, but it by no means follows that the Orphic poet read fra/dmones here, as Bücheler infers (so Tyrrell). For the quantity of the first syllable in a)fra/dmones cf. Od. 15.444 e)pifra/sset' o)/leqron: Hes. Op.655propefradme/na: Theog. 160 e)pefra/ssato: h. Apoll. 388 e)fra/zeto, and regularly *)afrodi/th. La Roche Hom. Unters. i. p. 10, H. G. § 370.

*n/hkeston: the reading of M mh/kiston might possibly be defended as a superlative of me/g' a)a/sqhs: cf. also Eur. Hipp.818ta\ ma/kist' e)mw=n kakw=n. But Voss's correction, based on Hes. Op.283, is easy and highly probable, if not certain.
i)/stw *ga/r ktl.: cf. Il. 15.36 -38, e 184-186 (with M. and R.'s note); Leaf on Il. 2.755. On the position of o(/rkos (the object of the oath) before *stugo\s u(/dwr cf. Apoll. Arg. 3.714 f.
qa/naton . . a(lu/cai=Il. 21.565, Od. 17.547 , x 66. Hence Huschke's gh=ras should not be received, although Apollonius has gh=ras a)la/lkoi (see on 237).

265-267. The text is certainly sound (with the sole correction of sunauch/sous) to suna/cous), for which cf. Il. 2.381 , *c 149, 448): “when Demophon is a man, the Eleusinians will always be fighting with one another.” Editors have assumed a lacuna before 265 and after 267, or at all events after the lines. It was supposed that the lost passage or passages referred to the death of Demophon, or to his leadership in the war, or mediation between the parties. This supposition is quite gratuitous; 265 simply marks the time, “when he has grown to manhood,” and has no closer connexion with the preceding or succeeding lines. There is no trace in myth or history of an Eleusinian civil war; hence Matthiae (followed by Baumeister) substituted *)aqhnai/oisi for e)n a)llh/loisi, assuming that Demophon was the leader of the Eleusinians in their war against Athens. The corruption is most improbable, not to mention the further difficulty that tradition made Eumolpus, not Demophon, the leader of the Eleusinians ( Thuc.ii. 15, Isocr. Paneg. 19, Apollod.iii. 15. 4, in Leocr. 24, Paus.i. 38. 3). There are so few allusions to early Eleusinian history in Greek literature, that it would not be surprising if mention of a civil war were found in this passage only. But Creutzer was no doubt right in explaining the lines by reference to the ballhtu/s, or sham fight, which is expressly connected with Demophon by Hesychius s.v., e(orth\ *)aqh/nhsin e)pi\ *dhmofw=nti tw=| *keleou= a)gome/nh. Lobeck (Aglaoph. p. 206) quotes an anonymous verse in Artemid.i. 8tau/rois e)n *)iwni/a| pai=des *)efesi/wn a)gwni/zontai kai\ e)n *)attikh=| para\ tai=s qeai=s e)n *)eleusi=ni: kou=roi *)<*>aqhnai=oi peritellome/nwn e)niautw=n; but it is not clear whether this line has any connexion with the ballhtu/s. According to A. Mommsen and Lenormant the ballhtu/s took place at the end of the festival. It may, however, have been a ceremony during the initial stage of purification (see Introd. p. 10). The rite was like that at Troezen ( Paus.ii. 32. 2, called liqobo/lia). See Gruppe G. Myth. p. 901. Similar customs are quoted by Bather in J. H. S. xiv. 253, Jevons p. 292. It need not be supposed that the origin of such liqobo/lia was always the same; in the present case the mystae may have stoned one another to draw blood as a means of communion with the Corn-goddess, or the blood may have been thought to increase the fertility of the land. The latter idea is probably at the root of some, if not all, of the numerous parallel examples which shew that fights, either sham or more serious, have taken place to ensure a good harvest. This, as a European custom, was first clearly demonstrated by Mannhardt B. K. p. 548 f.; for instances from savage tribes see Frazer on Paus.ii. 30. 4.As often, the meaning of the rite was lost at Eleusis, where the mock-battle was supposed to commemorate an early civil war.

w(/rh|sin: the editors (mostly adopting Fontein's tou= ge), understand this as “in his riper years.” But tw=| ge is to be retained and w(/rh|sin taken in the proper sense of the plural, “when the years revolve for him in their seasons.” Cf. h. Aphr. 102 w(/rh|sin pa/sh|si, infra 399, h. Apoll. 350.

ai)e\n . . *)/hmata *pa/nta: Baumeister, understanding the reference to be to an actual war, is obliged to explain this as an epic formula vaguely indicating a “long time.” But it has its regular meaning “for ever”; the ballhtu/s takes place every year.
tima/oxos: only here and in h. Aphr. 31, which Gemoll claims to be the original passage.

a)qana/tois is made necessary by similar formulas: e.g. 11, 21, 45, 403; hence Stoll's a)qana/twn must be rejected. There remains the difficulty of o)/neiar, which can scarcely be a disyllable with synizesis; in Hes. Op.462 the MSS. have ei)/ari polei=n, but Pollux (i. 223) rightly gives e)/ari (e_a_). The synizesis of he is no authority for that of eia (see on 137). It seems best therefore to remove the diphthong, with Ilgen, and read o)/near, the form accepted by Schulze Quaest. Ep. p. 228 and Solmsen K. Z. 32, 292, who calls it “sprachlich tadellos.” This could be a trisyllable by the correction of qnhtoi=sin to qnhtoi=s t); but it is nearer to the manuscript to read qnhtoi=si/ t' o)/near. For the synizesis compare (besides Hes. Op.462 quoted above) Hes. Op.492mh/t' e)/ar gigno/menon, Mimnerm. 2 and Chaerem. fr. 42 (e)/aros a trochee). If o)/neiar is to be retained, with its full value u--, it must contain the whole of the fourth foot; this involves the lengthening of the last syllable by position, as is done by the conjectures of Ruhnken and others. The legitimacy of this use was the subject of a discussion in the Class. Rev. Dec. 1896, Feb.-Apr. 1897. The result was entirely to justify the use in Homer and Hesiod, although undisputed examples are not common in early epic, and very rare in later hexameters. For the most recent discussion on the subject see Leaf Il.vol. ii. App. p. 634 f.

There is no proof that there was a “temple” of Demeter at Eleusis, apart from the hall of initiation, which cannot properly be called a nho/s. Strabo, it is true, speaks of a i(ero/n as well as the mustiko\s shko/s (ix. p. 395), but the word i(ero/n need not imply a building; it may=te/menos. As Frazer remarks (on Paus.i. 38. 6, p. 511) “no later writer” (than the hymn) “and no inscription yet discovered speaks of such a temple.” Various attempts have been made to identify this supposed temple with some of the pre-Persian remains discovered by the excavations of the Greek Archaeological Society. Frazer (l.c. p. 509) doubtfully suggests that it may have been on the site of the later hall of initiation, where walls of Eleusinian marble have been unearthed. Remains of another early building, probably a temple, have been discovered north of the hall, and separated from it by a rock-cut staircase, leading up to the terrace. This building has also been thought to be the old temple of Demeter. It is possible that the nho/s served also as a hall of initiation, which would of course be sacred to Demeter. In this case the building may be identified with the walls abovementioned, which belong to a building older than the age of Pisistratus; but it is impossible to judge of the form of this building from these scanty remains, or to conjecture how far it was a prototype of a later hall (probably built by Pisistratus), and of the enlarged Periclean hall. See Philios p. 65, 74, who also identifies the nho/s with the primitive telesth/rion; Svoronos (p. 345 f.) places the nho/s on the brow of the hill, but this seems negatived by u(pai\ po/lin.

*po/lin ai)*pu/ te tei=xos: i.e. the acropolis, the fortifications of which (tei=xos) have been traced on the low hill above the hall of initiation. The actual town lay at the foot of the hill, and extended to the sea.

*kallixo/rou: see on 99; this well was not identified until 1892, when excavations shewed it to be situated by the great Roman propylaea, just outside the precinct. The well-mouth is surrounded by concentric circles, which no doubt served as marks for the Eleusinian woman who danced round the water in honour of the goddess ( Paus.i. 38. 6). For references to the discovery see Philios p. 57 f., and Svoronos p. 252.

eu)age/ws: the adv. in Apoll. Arg. 2.699, etc. eu)agh/s is not found in early epic. For exx. of eu)agh/s, eu)age/ws in ritual see Dieterich de hymnis Orph. 1891, p. 34. i(la/skoisqe: for the opt. after u(poqh/somai cf. Od. 17.250, H. G. § 306. The mood expresses a less certain result than would be indicated by i(la/skhsqe, which Schäfer reads.
me/geqos kai\ ei<*>=dos=h. Aphr. 82.
*peri/ t' a)mfi/ te: cf. Il. 2.305 a)mfi\ peri\ krh/nhn, h. Apoll. 271 a)mfiperifqinu/qei, Theocr. vii. 142 peri\ pi/dakas a)mfi\ me/lissai.
ka/llos a)/hto: modelled on Hes. Sc.7 f. th=s kai\ a)po\ krh=qen . . . toi=on a)/hq' oi(=o/n te poluxru/sou *)afrodi/ths.
o)dm/h ktl. Fragrance is a sign of divinity: cf. Theognis 9, P. V. 115, Eur. Hipp.1391, Verg. Aen.i. 403, Ov. Fast.v. 375.
fe/g*gos: see on 189. With this passage cf. Bacchyl.xvii. 102a)po\ ga\r a)gla

l.quote: w=n la/mpe gui/wn se/las

div2.l: w(/ste puro/s (of the Nereids).

div2.p: katen/hnoqen: properly sing. Hence Ruhnken and others read canqh\ de\ ko/mh. But, as Franke well remarks, the writer may easily have taken the archaic form for a plural. There is no reason to suppose a genuine schema Pindaricum, with Baumeister.
au)*g=hs: for Ruhnken's simple correction cf. Soph. Phil.1190au)tai=s MSS., while the scholia preserve au)gai=s.
*gou/nat' e)/lunto: Il. 7.16 lu/nto de\ gui=a: Il. 13.85 gui=a le/lunto, and often lu/to gou/nata.

a)*po\ dape/dou: Hesych. ii. 253 quotes the parallel form za/pedon, which occurs in Xenophanes i. 1, and an inscr. from Paros (I. G. A. 401 = Roberts Epigr. 17); da/pedon therefore stands for the original dja/pedon (or for dva/pedon Prellwitz Et. Wört. s.v. da-) and the metre is not due to false analogy (as Gemoll supposes), but was, at least originally, justified by pronunciation. In Od. 11.598 Aristotle Rhet.iii. 11 read e)pi\ da/pedo/nde for the vulgate e)/peita pedo/nde. La Roche Hom. Unters. i. p. 49.

e)lein/hn: the Attic form is accepted by most editors after Ruhnken; it does not occur elsewhere in epic. Rutherford (New Phryn. p. 160) rejects e)leeino/s in Attic prose; the form is due to late usage.
eu)strw/twn: only here and in h. Aphr. 157 e)s le/xos eu)/strwton.

e)lou/eon: called an “impossible” form by Gemoll. It is a false formation, but is not to be ejected on that account. Cf. Schulze Quaest. Ep. p. 65 n. 1, Smyth Ionic Dialect p. 535, Solmsen l.c. p. 13, K. Z. 29, 98. Ludwich needlessly objects to the washing of the child. The women perform one of the duties of a nurse, in place of Demeter. It is perhaps unnecessary to press the phrase further, and to point out that the child would be covered with wood-ash. This motive, however, is expressly mentioned in a very similar passage (of the Nymphs and Bacchus), Anth. Pal. ix. 331 ai<*> *nu/mfai to\n *ba/kxon, o(/t) e)k puro\s h(/lato kou=ros,
div2.l: ni/yan u(pe\r te/frhs a)/rti kulio/menon.

div2.p: trofoi/ and tiq=hnai, “those who cared for and nursed him,” are here synonymous. Cf. tiqhnoi/mhn (142) used by Demeter in her disguise as a trofo/s (103). Tyrrell's suggestion h)e\ tiqh/nh is no improvement. Cf. Orph. h. x. 18 trofo\s h)de\ tiqh/nh.

*pan*nu/xiai: the origin of the pannuxi/s is almost certainly indicated in this word (Preller). Gemoll notes that the ignorance of Celeus as to what has happened until the morning points to a mystery. Most of the sacred ceremonies during the whole course of the Eleusinia were carried on at night. In the very earliest period the worship of Demeter Thesmophoros at Eleusis, as elsewhere, was probably confined to women (Foucart p. 78, Jevons p. 379, Ramsay p. 127); and the hymn clearly shews the important part played by the women, even in a later stage of the Eleusinian religion. For women as mainly or exclusively concerned in agriculture see Jevons p. 239-242. Even when a share in agriculture falls to the lot of the men, the place of women in festivals concerned with sowing, reaping, etc. is often predominant; for examples see Frazer G. B. i. p. 35, ii. p. 203, etc.
dei/mati *pallo/menai: the same phrase in an oracle ap. Herod.vii. 140(Hendess 111. 10).
*polupei/rona, “countless:” literally “with many boundaries,” formed on the analogy of a)pei/rwn. Cf. Orph. Arg. 33 polupei/ronas oi)/mous.

Matthiae thinks that the rest of the hymn, from this line, was put together from fragments of the hymn seen by Pausanias, but the vv.ll. in Paus. only point to natural and quasiclerical errors, see Preface p. xli.

*canq\h *dhm/hthr = Il. 5.500. The epithet may have originally referred to the colour of ripe corn, as the “hair” of Demeter (cf. 454 komh/sein a)staxu/essin, Euseb. P. E. v. 34 oi( de\ e)ko/mwn *dh/mhtri), although, of course, in the hymn Demeter is purely anthropomorphic; see Mannhardt Myth. Forsch. p. 234.

e)*pi\ xqo/na: for the accusative see on xxv. 3. The worship of Demeter and Cora in Triphylia was thought to be explained by the alternation of good and bad years (ta/xa dia\ ta\s u(penantio/thtas) according to Demetrius of Scepsis ap. Strab. 344 kai\ ga\r eu)/karpo/s e)sti kai\ e)rusi/bhn genna=| kai\ qru/on h( *trifuli/a: dio/per a)nti\ mega/lhs fora=s pukna\s a)fori/as gi/nesqai sumbai/nei kata\ tou\s to/pous.

a)rou/rais: for the local dat. (like ou)/resi etc.) cf. Il. 5.137 a)grw=|, and see on 99. Here the dat. is used with a verb of motion; H. G. § 145 (6). There is a different const. in Il. 10.353 e(lke/menai neioi=o baqei/hs phkto\n a)/rotron.
Cf. Hes. Op.180*zeu\s d' o)le/sei kai\ tou=to ge/nos mero/pwn a)nqrw/pwn.
qusiw=n: so 368. The word is not Homeric (for que/wn which Hermann gratuitously read).
*)=irin . . . xruso/pteron=Il. 8.398; see on h. Apoll. 107. Iris is here employed as a messenger to gods on earth, while Hermes is sent to the underworld (335). Cf. Maass *)=iris I. F. i. 157 sq.
*polu/hraton . . . e)/xousan= Theog. 908 (e)/xousa).
w(\s e)/faq): the use of this formula after an indirect speech is not Homeric, but occurs in Hes. Op.69, infra 448, Apoll. Arg.4.236, 1119. Wyttenbach's lacuna is not needed; cf. on 127.
Cf. h. Apoll. 108.
kuano/peplon: not in Homer, and in the hymns only here, and in 360, 374, 442 of Demeter. Theog. 406 it is a general epithet of Leto, with no special reference to mourning, as in this hymn (cf. 183).
a)/fqita ei)dw/s: only here, for a)/fqita mh/dea ei)dw/s h. Aphr. 43, where see note.

Valckenär's addition of path/r is preferable to the other suggestions, as it retains qeou/s in synizesi, which is probably the cause of its omission, unless this is simply due to “haplography” in -ta, pa-.

Hermann's e(/loito met' a)qana/toisi qeoi=si (on the analogy of 444) does not account for e)le/sqai in place of qeoi=sin. The suggestion bo/loito rests on Il. 11.319, where one family of MSS. (e) has dh\ e)qe/lei for dh\ bo/letai. e)qe/loi bo/loito might produce e)qe/loito which otherwise it is difficult to explain.

quw/deos: applied to Olympus in h. Herm. 322. It appears to be a favourite word with the writer of this hymn: cf. 231, 244, 288, 355, 385. The meaning here may be literally “fragrant with incense” (which ascends to heaven), or perhaps simply “sweetsmelling” as in 231. See further on h. Herm. 231.

a(*gn/hn: specially an epithet of Persephone: Od. 11.386, infra 439. She was worshipped as *(agnh/ in Messenia, Paus.iv. 33. 4; cf. the inscr. of Andania. a(gnh/ is also frequent with Demeter, Hes. Op.465, supra 203, Archil. 120.So a(gnai\ qeai/ of both goddesses C. I. G. 5431, 5643. Rohde Psyche p. 192, Roscher i. p. 1813 f., Pauly-Wissowa 2754.
a)*po/ may here be retained, though Voss pointed out that in the Homeric formula the prep. is u(po/: cf. Il. 21.56, Theog. 653.

metal/hceie: the spelling is philologically correct, as lh/gw makes position in Il. 9.191 , q 87. According to Didymus in schol. A, Aristarchus read the single liquid in the Homeric passages Il. 9.157, 261, 299. On the other hand it should be noted that M constantly neglects a double consonant; cf. 14, 40, 158, 313 in this hymn.

344, 345. Baumeister's despair at this passage still holds good. e)p' a)tlh/twn might possibly be construed “in such intolerable circumstances” if the neglected position a)tlh/twn is permissible (there is no instance in Homer except sxetli/h, La Roche Homer. Unters. i. p. 4 and 16; but cf. Pind. Ol.viii. 20 and 77, Emped. 14). But it is hard to believe that epic, or any Greek usage admits of the translation. Of the conjectures, a)pothlou= is the best; if written a)potlhou, the resulting word is not worse than M's other corruptions; e.g. e)phlsi/hsi for e)phlusi/h 228.

In the next line a word of the quantity uu- has perhaps fallen out, owing to qew=n in synizesi (cf. 325); this may have been xaleph/n (with boulh/n), the dative boulh=| having been written afterwards to ease the construction. mhti/seto is not a Homeric form for mhti/sato, which should probably be restored; cf. h. Apoll. 322, 325 a.
M's reading se is just possible, as a)/gein, e)ca/gein could mean “let go,” “turn out.” But the parallel passage 335 f. makes me practically certain.

*)ere/beusfi: Franke's correction is easy (cf. Il. 9.572, Theog. 669, where some MSS. have e)re/besfi), but perhaps unnecessary, if the peculiarities of our tradition of the hymn (katenh/noqen with plur. 278, pau/seien neut. 351) are to be preserved. So the form ei(sth/kei 452 is defensible.

*pau/seien is no doubt genuine although the act. for the middle pau/saito is remarkable. Compare, however, Hes. Sc.449pau=e ma/xhs. In Od. 4.659 there is overwhelming MS. support for mnhsth=res . . . pau=san a)e/qlwn, where most editors read mnhsth=ras. So Ran. 580 pau=e pau=e tou= lo/gou. Tyrrell considers the use to be a mark of lateness (p. 39).
xamaigene/wn a)*nqrw/pwn = h. Aphr. 108 (where see note).

mei/dhsen: Hades “smiled,” anticipating the success of his plan to keep Persephone (372 f.). o)fru/sin: generally with u(po/ or e)pi/ in Homer (neu/ein etc.), but cf. Od. 9.468 , m 194. So without a prep. Pind. Pyth.ix. 65.

The line is quite genuine, in spite of Bücheler's objection (imperite corrasa verba). Gemoll thinks that moi is required, but the sense is quite clear without it. The object of Persephone's anger is plain from 344 po/ll' a)ekazome/nh|. Hades carefully avoids saying “come back” (as Gemoll thinks he ought to say); Persephone will find out in due time the necessity of returning. She has not yet eaten the pomegranate, and he therefore uses the ambiguous futures e)/ssomai etc., which suit equally well the choice or the necessity of returning.
*periw/sion a)/llwn = Pind. Isthm.iv. 3.

despo/sseis: not in early epic. Like a)dikei=n (367) it is chiefly Attic, but also found in Herodotus. The word may be suggested, as Baumeister notes, by the title *de/spoina, under which Persephone was worshipped at many places, especially in Arcadia; Paus.viii. 37. 9, Immerwahr die Kulte u. Myth. Ark. i. p. 120.

sx/hshsqa: since there is no instance of the termination -sqa or -qa in a future, while the aorists ba/lhsqa, pa/qhsqa, ei)/phsqa are Homeric (KühnerBlass ii. § 209. 3), it seems better to keep the spelling of M and regard sxh/shsqa as the subjunctive of the otherwise late aorist e)/sxhsa. The subjunctive will be of the nature of the type du/somai ei)s *)ai/dao kai\ e)n neku/essi faei/nw (H. G. § 275 f.), which in Homer occurs constantly in combination with futures and is practically indistinguishable from them in meaning; see h. Apoll. 1. sxh/seisqa which most recent editors prefer is called a “verbildete Form” by Schulze K. Z. 33. 317.

tw=n d' a)dikhsa/ntwn: “those who have wronged thee” (by not paying due honour) will be punished all their days (i.e. by the Furies, for whose relation to Hades and Persephone see Il. 9.454 with Leaf's note and 571). There is no allusion to punishment after death, although the fate of the uninitiated is not happy in the underworld (cf. 481 f.); line 365 shews that the reference is here to the living.
qusi/aisi: the Attic form (for qusi/h|si) may well be original in this hymn.
au)to/s, (Hades) “himself,” in contrast to Persephone; or possibly “with his own hands.”

r(oi=hs ko/kkon e)/dwke: Apollodorus (i. 5. 3) follows: r(oia=s e)/dwken au)th=| fagei=n ko/kkon. In Ov. Met.v. 535 f. Persephone of her own accord picks the fruit in a garden, and eats seven seeds. There is a widespread belief that the living may visit the underworld and return safely, provided that they abstain from the food of the dead. The Finnish hero Wäinämöinen refuses to drink in Manala, the place of the dead (Kalevala xvi. p. 293). In Africa S. there is a similar story: a man visits spiritland and is warned to return before he meets one who will give him food (Leslie Among the Zulus and Amatongas p. 121). In New Zealand a Maori woman was thought to have come back from the dead, having by the advice of her father refused the food which the dead people offered her (Shortland Traditions of New Zealand p. 150).
