Del. 34 f., Strabo 485) the island is said to have floated until the advent of Leto. Gemoll thinks that Pindar had this passage in mind, and quite needlessly emphasises this doubtful supposition to prove that the hymn is older than Pindar. Better proofs can, of course, be given. In a different connexion Apoll. Arg. 2.679 f. says of an island visited by Apollo h( d' u(po\ possi\n
div2.l: sei/eto nh=sos o(/lh, klu/zen d' e)pi\ ku/mata xe/rsw|.
div2.p: a(lo\s e)*n *pela/gessin = Od. 5.335.
Compare Od. 5.432 poulu/podos qala/mhs e)celkome/noio.

oi)ki/a *poi/hsontai: cf. Il. 12.168 . a)khde/a is probably passive, “unheeded,” and so “safe.” But it has also been taken as active, “careless,” in which case the epithet would be transferred to the oi)ki/a from the fw=kai, to which it would more properly refer. Cf. Il. 21.123 ai(=m' a)polixmh/sontai a)khde/es.—The reading of the Paris family e(/kasta/ te fu=la nepou/dwn is recognised to be a late piece of patchwork, suggested by Od. 4.404 fw=kai ne/podes kalh=s a(losu/dnhs. The form nepou/dwn (= nepo/dwn) is quite barbarous, and the sense of “fish” or “sea-monsters” was not attached to the word before Alexandrine times. The variant was probably due to a “corrector,” who could make nothing of a)khde/a a)/xh tei+la/wn, or some similar corruption.

xrhst/hrion: not in Homer (Hes. fr. 39. 6, 48). For the oracle at Delos see (besides reff. in Gemoll) Lebègue Recherches sur Délos 1876, F. W. H. Myers Classical Essays p. 29 f., Dyer Gods in Greece p. 370. References in Pauly-Wissowa, art. Apollon, and s.v. *ku/nqios 57. Verrall (p. 18 f.) minimises the importance of the oracle, and rejects 80-82, with 132, as the work of a “compiler.” The passages, however, are genuine; the Delian oracle must have had some power, at least for the islanders, although its fame was obscured by Delphi. At all events, it is hard to follow Bouché-Leclercq (Divination iii. p. 13 f.) who argues that there never was an actual oracle at Delos, and that xrhsth/rion refers loosely to unattached diviners, who drew their inspiration from the goddess Brizo, or Glaucus.

Hermann is almost certainly right in marking a lacuna after this line. The sense is: “let him first make a temple here, and then <he may build temples> among all men, for he is destined to be famous.” But this meaning cannot be extracted from the passage as it stands.
*poluw/numos: see on h. Dem. 18. e)/stai: the future is necessary to the sense, and the corruption in xp is easy; see J. H. S. xv. p. 272.
qew=n me/gan o(/rkon = Il. 2.377, followed by au)ta\r e)pei/ r() o)/mosen ktl., as in 89.
84-86. Cf. Il. 15.36-38 = Od. 5.184-186 where see note in M. and R. on the oath of the gods. For the author's familiarity with e, see 79 (Gemoll).
o(/rkos is here not the oath (as in 83) but the object sworn by; so in Il. 2.755, Theog. 400, 784 and often.
quw/dhs bwmo/s: cf. h. Aphr. 59, orac.ap. Hendess 19. 1 bwmou/s te quw/deis.

*go/nw|: this should mean “offspring,” not “birth”; Aesch. Supp.171(144) has been quoted for gonw=| = gonh=|, but the passage is doubtful. (See Tucker ad loc.) Franke's gonh=| is supported by gonh/n 63.
e)*nn=hmar: a vague conventional number; see on h. Dem. 47.

e)/ndoqi, “in the island.” Cf. Callim. h. Del. 222 *lhtw/ toi mi/trhn a)nalu/etai e)/ndoqi nh/sou, an expression which Baumeister thinks may have been borrowed from the present passage. So Hes. fr. 93 e)/ndoqi nh/sou.

o(/ssai a)/ristai e)/san = Il. 17.377 (masc.). Wolf's e)/asi has been generally accepted, as the first syllable of *diw/nh is short in Homer and Hesiod (Il. 5.370, Theog. 17, 353); cf. also Theocr. xv. 106 *ku/pri *diwnai/a. e)/san may be due to e)/san in 92; Gemoll, however, retains it, comparing Diana in Latin. Schulze Q. E. p. 156 n. In Il. 17.429 the MSS. vary between *au)tome/dwn *diw/reos and ge *diw/reos a)/lkimos ui(o/s.

The choice of the goddesses who are here named is rather remarkable; they probably represent older, Titanic deities. Rhea and Themis are mentioned together as Titans by Hesiod (Theog. 135) and Apollodorus (i. 3), who adds Dione. Baumeister notes that, while these goddesses are very rarely found in Homer, they frequently occur in the Orphic poems; he therefore suggests that their names may have been interpolated by a follower of that school. But the influence may well have been Hesiodean rather than Orphic.

*)ixnai/h te *qe/mis: from Ichnae, a town in Thessaly famous for the cult of Themis; Strabo 435 *)/ixnai, o(/pou h( *qe/mis *)ixnai/a tima=tai, Hesych. s.v. *)ixnai/hn, Lycophr. 129. Preller-Robert i.^{2} p. 477. For such titles cf. Il. 4.8 *(/hrh t' *)argei/h kai\ *)alalkomenhi+\s *)aqh/nh.

a)*ga/stonos *)amfitri/th = Od. 12.97. Amphitrite was present at the birth of Athena (relief of Gitiadas, Paus.iii. 17. 3) and of Aphrodite (base of statue of Olympian Zeus by Pheidias, Paus.v. 11. 8); for extant monuments see Pauly - Wissowa 1966.

This line, omitted in M and two members of x, fell out from homoearchon with 98. The fact has no bearing upon its age or genuineness. For exx. of the former line of a pair being omitted cf. below 344, 345, h. Herm. 215, 216.
97-99 are apparently adapted from Il. 13.521 -524 ou)d' a)/ra pw/ ti pe/pusto . . a)ll' o(/ g' a)/r' a)/krw| *)olu/mpw| u(po\ xruse/oisi ne/fessin
div2.l: h(=sto, *dio\s boulh=|sin e)elme/nos. Virgil ( Aen.xii. 792) has a similar expression: (Junonem) fulva pugnas de nube tuentem.

div2.p: mogosto/kos *ei)lei/quia = Il. 16.187 , *t 103. We find the plural mogosto/koi *ei)lei/quiai in Il. 11.270, where see Leaf's note on the derivation of the two words. Schulze Q. E. p. 259 f.

xruse/oisi *ne/fessin: here and in Il. 13.523 La Roche (Homer. Unters. i. p. 57, 83) would read xruse/ois nefe/essin, as ne/fos and nefe/lh generally make position in Homer. So in h. Aphr. 67 meta\ nefe/essi. But there are exceptions to the rule; cf. Il. 17.243 and 372.

fradmosu/n|hs: the dat. plural is suggested by the reading of M, and would be liable to corruption; see J. H. S. xv. p. 274. Baumeister compares Theog. 626, 884, 891, Op.245.The singular fradmosu/nh| first occurs in Apoll. Arg. 2.649.
o(/ t), i.e. o(/ te (= o(/ti te); La Roche Homer. Unters. i. p. 122 f., H. G. § 269 (3).

The importance of Eilithyia must have been greater in the older versions of the legend, since her journey from the Hyperboreans to help Leto was the subject of Olen's hymn ( Herod.iv. 35, Paus.i. 18. 5Paus., viii. 21. 3Paus., ix. 27. 2). On Eilithyia see Farnell Cults ii. p. 608 f. “In the Delian worship, so far as the hymn of Olen expressed it, she was more than a divinity of childbirth: the poet invoked her as a primaeval goddess, older than Cronos, a dispenser of destiny, and the mother of Eros” (p. 610). Herodotus (l.c.) and Pausanias (i. 18. 5) testify to a regular cult of the goddess at Delos. See inscr. in B. C. H. vi. 100, xiv. 412; Baur in Philol. Suppl. viii. p. 475.

*)=irin: the Delians sacrificed to Iris ( Semus ap. Athen. 645 B) on the *(eka/ths nh=sos, an islet off Delos (Harpocr. and Suid. s.v.), and it is possible that the archaic Delian statue called the Nike of Archermus, really represents Iris (Sikes Nike of Archermus, see Gardner Greek Sculpture i. p. 117). But the introduction of Iris in the hymn may be due to epic influence. Cf. generally Maass I. F. i. 164 sq.

xrusei/oisi li/noisin e)erme/non: Barnes' xru/seon, h)le/ktroisin e)erme/non, which recent editors have accepted, is graphically quite unjustified; nor is there reason to suppose that the author slavishly imitated Homer (Od. 18.296). See J. H. S. xvii. p. 244. The manuscript tradition has been vindicated by a close parallel from a Delian inventory of 364 B.C. Cf. B. C. H. x. p. 464 ormos xrusous sun twi linwi kai tois ephrthmenois, C.I.A. ii. pt. ii. p. 18. v. 71, p. 128 vv. 1, 19. In Od. 15.460 xru/seon o(/rmon e)/xwn meta\ d' h)le/ktroisin e)/erto the chain was strung at intervals with amber beads or pendants; so here the necklace appears to have been ornamented with gold wire used like thread, or with actual thread gilded (xru/seioi). The latter explanation seems supported by B. C. H. vi. p. 50 ormos xrusous epi tainidiwi and p. 32 tainia perihrgurwmenh. The poet's description of the necklace may well have been based upon votive offerings which he saw at Delos. On these Delian o(/rmoi see Homolle B. C. H. vi. p. 123, 124.

*pod/hnemos w)ke/a *)=iris = Il. 5.368, and see Leaf on Il. 23.198, where the form w)ke/a, and the question of an originally digammated *)=iris are discussed. The epithet podh/nemos, taken in conjunction with xruso/pteros *q 398, *l 185, shew that Homer conceived of Iris as actually flying, but with foot wings, such as are generally found in archaic monuments of the winged female type. Flying figures were first represented by Greek artists in attitude of striding; cf. bh= r(a qe/ein. See Class. Rev. xiii. p. 463 (review of Studniczka's die Siegesgöttin).
to\ mesh*gu/: cf. h. Dem. 317.
a)*po/ seems preferable to a)pe\k (a)p' e)k), which is not found in Homer, although die/k, u(pe/k are common. For a)pe/k Baumeister quotes Q. Smyrn. iv. 540.

e)/pea *ptero/enta *proshu/da: the phrase is properly followed directly by the speech which it introduces; with the present passage Franke compares Od. 13.165, where two lines intervene; and Il. 24.142, where the speech precedes w(=s . . . e)/pea ptero/ent' a)go/reuon. But even these instances are hardly parallel, as here there is no actual speech recorded at all.

The line is interesting as being, in all probability, one of the rare passages in the hymns to which ancient authors refer. It seems to prove that Aristophanes knew the hymn; cf. Av.575 above. The schol. Rav. remarks o(/ti yeu/detai pai/zwn: ou) ga\r e)pi\ *)/iridos a)ll' e)pi\ *)aqhna=s kai\ *(/hras: ai(\ de\ ba/thn trh/rwsi peleia/si i)/qmaq' o(moi=ai (Il. 5.778, the origin of this line). The schol. Ven. , however, notes oi( de\ e)n e(te/rois poih/masin *(omh/rou fasi\ tou=to gene/sqai( ei)si\ ga\r kai\ u(/mnoi. The probability that the latter scholiast is right is much strengthened by Eq.1015dia\ tripo/dwn e)riti/mwn, which seems to be a quotation from 443 infra.
i)/qmaq): verbal subst., “goings.”
eu)=te: regularly with asyndeton in Homer; Il. 6.392 etc., infra 427.

Most editors follow Ilgen in reading dh\ to/te th/n, on the ground that greater stress should be laid on the time than on the person. But the MSS. are unanimous in giving th\n to/te dh/, and the emphasis laid on th/n is quite suitable.
For the palm at the birth cf. Theogn. 5 *foi=be a)/nac o(/te me/n se qea\ te/ke po/tnia *lhtw\
div2.l:
foi/nikos r(adinh=|s xersi\n e)fayame/nh, Callim. h. Del. 208
a)po\ d' e)kli/qh e)/mpalin w)/mois
foi/nikos pote\ pre/mnon. The sacred palm in the precinct of Apollo at Delos is mentioned in Od. 6.162; it was reputed to be alive in the time of Cicero ( Leg.i. 1) and Pliny (N. H. xvi. 89). The palm-tree was one of the types on Delian coins (Head Hist. Num. p. 413). According to Eur. Hec.458, Eur. Ion919, Eust. 1557, Leto clasped the palm with one hand, a laurel with the other. Euripides (I. T. 1097) adds an olive to the other trees. In the Delian hymn (B. C. H. xviii. p. 345 f., Smyth Melic Poets p. 533) the olive alone takes the place of the palm: o(\n e)/tikte *latw\ ma/kaira pa[ra\ li/mna|] kluta=| xersi\ glauka=s e)lai/as qigou=s). Cf. also Var. Hist. v. 4, Hyg. Fab.140, Catull. 34. 7. See Crusius die delph. Hymnen 1894 p. 74. In the Ephesian account of the birth, an olive, still shown in the time of Tacitus, helped Leto ( Tac. Ann.iii. 61). The names *)elai/a and *foi=nic were given to two streams near the temple of Apollo at Tegyra (see on 16).
div2.p: The legend suggests a Greek belief in the efficacy of the palm or olive to ensure a safe or quick delivery. Traces of the custom have survived in modern Greece, where an olive-branch, called the Virgin's hand, and sacred to Eleutherios St.or Panaghia Vlastike, is sometimes grasped by women (Bent Cyclades p. 182, Rodd Customs and Lore of Modern Greece p. 141). So Swedish women used to twine their arms round a venerated tree (Mannhardt B. K. p. 51). See also Frazer G. B. i. p. 196.

*gou=na d' e)/reise: for this position see Frazer on Paus.viii. 48. 7: “we may infer that in antiquity Greek women were often, perhaps generally, delivered on their knees.” He quotes Ploss das Weib^{2} p. 175 to shew that the attitude is still adopted in Greece and elsewhere.

mei/dhse de\ *gai=) u(*pe/nerqen: so Theognis 9 e)ge/lasse de\ gai=a pelw/rh, gh/qhsen de\ baqu\s po/ntos a(lo\s polih=s. The idea of earth “smiling” is Homeric, cf. Il. 19.362 ge/lasse de\ pa=sa peri\ xqw\n xalkou= u(po\ steroph=s, where, however, the original meaning of gela=n (= shine) may be predominant. As Leaf (ad loc.) notes, the two ideas pass naturally into one another. In the present passage as often in later Greek, the personification of smiling Nature is clear; cf. h. Dem. 14, P. V. 90, Apoll. Arg. 1.880 , *d 1169. For the joy of Nature at the birth of a god, compare also the Delphic hymn (quoted on 117) pa=s de\ ga/qhse po/los ou)ra/nio[s, a)nne/felos, a)glao/s, n]hne/mous d' e)/sxen ai)qh\r a)[ellw=n taxupet]ei=s [dro/]mous ktl. (of Apollo); paean to Dionysus (B. C. H. 1895 p. 393, Smyth Melic Poets p. 524) pa/ntes d' [a)ste/res a)gx]o/reusan, pa/ntes de\ brotoi\ x[a/rhsan sai=s], *ba/kxie, ge/nnais. For other exx. see Adami de poet. scaen. p. 232 f.

e)k d' e)/qore *pro\ fo/wsde: see on h. Herm. 12. For e)kqrw/skw in this sense cf. Theog. 281, Callim. h. Del. 255, h. Herm. 20, Panyas. ap. schol. Pind. Pyth.3. 177kai/ r() o( me\n e)k ko/lpoio trofou= qo/re possi\ *quw/nhs.

qeai\ d' o)lo/lucan: cf. Frazer on Paus.ix. 11. 3, where parallel examples are quoted of the cry uttered by women, probably as a signal that a birth had taken place. So Theocr. xvii. 64 *ko/ws d' o)lo/lucen (at the birth of Ptolemy); the whole passage (58-70) shews Theocritus' acquaintance with the hymn. Callimachus also appears to borrow: cf. h. Del. 255-258.

*)/hi+e: an obscure epithet of Apollo, only here and in Il. 15.365 , *u 152. L. Meyer (Griech. Et. i.) marks it as of uncertain derivation. Aristarchus connected it with i(/hmi, a derivation apparently accepted by Ebeling. Others compare the cry i)h/ (i)e/), which certainly produced i)h/i+os; for the double form cf. i)/oulos, ou)=los. Brunnhofer (Hom. Rätsel, 1899) translates hülfreich, comparing the Vedic avitar.

lo/on: the MSS. give the unmetrical form lou=on; so Nub. 838 katalou/ei for katalo/ei. Cf. Od. 10.361 lo/), Hes. Op.749lo/esqai, and variant in the Townley schol. on Il. 15.393 tine\s “e)/terpe lou/wn” (Nauck lo/wn i.e. lo/vwn), and see Schulze Q. E. p. 65 n., Smyth Ionic p. 535, Solmsen Untersuch. p. 13.

a(*gnw=s kai\ kaqarw=s: cf. Hes. Op.337, where each word has its proper sense, “with pure heart and hands.” Here, as Gemoll remarks, a(gnw=s is superfluous; the expression seems to have been blindly copied from Hesiod. So orac.ap. Hendess 1. 14, and 54. 3.

xrusa/ora: an epithet of Apollo in 395 (where see note), Il. 5.509 , *o 256, Hes. Op.771, fr. 227, Pind. Pyth.v. 104, Apoll. Arg. 3.1282; of Demeter, h. Dem. 4. In Homer and h. Dem. the nom. would be xrusa/oros, according to the MSS.; so xrusao/rou 395. Leaf on Il. 5.509 argues that forms from xrusa/wr should everywhere be restored; the hiatus in Il. 15.256 produced xrusa/oron for xrusa/ora.
q/hsato: only here in a causal sense, of the mother. In Homer and h. Dem. 236 the verb is used of the child. The prose form qhla/zw has a similar double use.
So the babe Aristaeus is fed on nectar and ambrosia, and is made immortal, Pind. Pyth.ix. 63.

e)*p/hrcato: for the Homeric formula e)pa/rxesqai depa/essin cf. M. and R. on Od. 3.340, Leaf on Il. 1.471. It seems established that in this phrase e)pa/rxesqai means to offer a “first portion” of the wine by pouring some drops into each cup successively (e)pi/). In the present instance, this force of the preposition has been lost, and the verb has come to mean “handsel with,” or simply “offer as an act of ritual,” without any notion of making a beginning. The word is no doubt chosen to express the reverence which Leto feels for the young god. For the acc. with e)pa/rxesqai cf. a similar construction with kata/rxesqai in Od. 3.445 xe/rniba/ t' ou)loxu/tas te kath/rxeto. There is no reason to alter a)qana/th|sin xersi\n to a)qana/tois xei/lessin (Eble, followed by Baumeister and Abel); the manuscript reading is perfectly intelligible.

Apollo, like Hermes in h. Herm. 15 f., shews his divinity by precocions strength and talent. For this idea, common in folklore, see II. App. p. 311. Later accounts make Apollo slay the monster when he was a mere child; see on 214.

desma/: this is the plur. of desmo/s in the hymns (h. Herm. 157, 409, vii. 12, 13) without variant; in Homer the form is de/smata. Here there is some force in the repetition of se, and this may induce us with Matthiae, to give the preference to p's reading. J. H. S. xv. p. 263.

131-132. Apollo here claims his prerogatives; he will be a god of music, an archer, and a prophet. Gemoll compares Callim. h. Apoll. 44
*foi/bw| ga\r kai\ to/con e)pitre/petai kai\ a)oidh/
kei/nou de\ *qriai\ kai\ ma/nties. For the ki/qaris of Apollo see on h. Herm. 450.
fi/lh: hardly an epithet, like kampu/la, but predicative with ei)/h, “for my own”; cf. 144.
xr/hsw: the active once in Homer, Od. 8.79 (absolute). For the oracle of Apollo at Delos see on 81.
e)*pi/: the manuscript a)po/ was defended in J. H. S. xvii. p. 244; but it is difficult to resist Matthiae's e)pi/. *e 13 o( d' a)po\ xqono\s w)/rnuto pezo/s is hardly parallel.

a)po/ might mean “off the ground,” i.e. in the air (cf. 186), but e)bi/basken suggests that Apollo “walked” on the earth; it is not equivalent to bh= r(a qe/ein (108). There is no resemblance between the symbols of a)po/ and e)pi/.

xrusw=|: the idea is borrowed and amplified by Callim. h. Del. 260 f.
xru/sea/ toi to/te pa/nta qemei/lia gei/nato, *dh=le,
xrusw=| de\ troxo/essa panh/meros e)/rree li/mnh,
xru/seion d' e)ko/mhse gene/qlion e)/rnos e)lai/hs:
xrusw=| d' e)plh/mmure baqu\s *)inwpo\s e(lixqei/s:
au)th\ de\ xruse/oio a)p' ou)/deos ei(/leo pai=da.
The author of the hymn probably, and Callimachus certainly, conceive of actual gold miraculously covering the island; Theognis 8 only speaks of an ambrosial scent marking the birth of the god.

136-139. This is the clearest case of the alternatives which are frequent in the text of the hymns (see p. xliii), since here the MSS. distinguish between them; 136-138 are found only in y (in *p they have accidentally crept into the text). Attempts to combine all four verses are not successful (Gemoll places 139 after 135, altering bebri/qei to bebri/qh|). Of the two versions, perhaps 136-38 is the later, since the construction of ei(/leto with gen. “preferred to” is un-Homeric ( Soph. Phil.1100). For w(s o)/te te without a verb cf. Il. 12.132; for the languageSoph. Phil., i. 8a)nqe/on u(/lh|.
khro/qi ma=llon: Agar in J. P. xxviii. (1901) p. 51 would everywhere restore kh=r) (i.e. kh=ri) e)/ti ma=llon, arguing that khro/qi is an impossible form.
au)to/s: probably resumptive, in contrast to Delos; but see on 181.

a)
 *n/hsous: D'Orville's correction (also made by Ilgen and accepted by Peppmüller and Tyrrell among recent critics) appears to be necessary. h)la/skazes might perhaps govern a direct accusative nh/sous, on the analogy of 175 strefo/mesqa po/leis, but the construction can hardly be extended to a)ne/ras. For the corruption cf. Il. 2.198 o(
 d' au)=, Eust. o(
 d' a)/n. The expression nh/sous te kai\ a)ne/ras is a sort of hendiadys for “inhabited islands” in contrast to the solitude of Delos, or rather, perhaps, of its mountain Cynthos. For a similar hendiadys (also with te kai/) cf. Theocr. xvii. 77 muri/ai a)/peiroi/ te kai\ e)/qnea muri/a fwtw=n “a thousand lands with their tribes” (Cholmeley). The alterations of either word are mistaken; cf. Pind. Ol.vi. 10ou)/te par' a)ndra/sin ou)/t' e)n nausi\ koilai=s.

On the variants between this passage in the MSS. and as quoted by Thucydides and Aristides see Pref. xliv f., J. H. S. xv. p. 309, 310. The view held by Gemoll admits of not much doubt, that the two versions are independent. In the present edition the text of the MSS. has been followed except in two places (165 and 171) where graphical corruption has evidently taken place.

a)lla\ su/: this suits the context, as it appears in the vulgate, better than a)ll' o(/te in the Thucydidean version. We cannot, of course, be sure that the form of the hymn known to Thucydides contained the lines immediately preceding, in their present condition. But, to assume that this was the case, there would be no absolute need to alter a)ll' o(/te to a)/llote, with Guttmann. The passage would mean: “but when your heart most rejoices in Delos, then do the Ionians gather,” a way of saying that the Ionians gather at the feast of Apollo in Delos. e)/nqa would thus be apodotic and demonstrative; in the manuscript text it is relative, “there.” Lines 143-145 are merely explicative of the range of Apollo's interests. Graphically, however, a)/llote would be an easy correction; for the omission of de/ Guttmann compares Od. 3.50, Hes. Op.552 etc.

Cf. *)ia/ones e(lkexi/twnes in Il. 13.685 (thought to be an Attic interpolation; see Leaf ad loc.). The long robes, especially associated with the Ionians, would be suitable for a solemn festival. See Thuc.i. 6. 3, Strabo 466. By the time of Thucydides this Ionic dress had become antiquated, and was only affected by older men. For the Delian festival cf. Introd. p. 66.

au)toi=s su
 *pai/dessi: Hermann's au)toi=sin pai/dessi is neat and idiomatic (cf. h. Herm. 94, where Demetrius corrects fa\s sune/seue for fasi
 e)/seue), but unnecessary; cf. Il. 12.112 , *c 498, n 118. The Thucydidean sh
 e)s a)guia/n is curious. a)guia/ can hardly mean “a sacred procession” as Baumeister suggests. Probably it is the “square” before the temple of Apollo, where the contests took place. The passages in Pindar quoted by L. and S. ( Pind. Ol.ix. 51, Pind. Nem.vii. 92) hardly prove that a)guia/ can be used as a poetic synonym of po/lis.
o)rxhqmw=|: both this form and o)rxhstui= are found in Homer, who uses o)rxhqmoi=o (Il. 13.637 etc.), and o)rxhstui= (Od. 8.253 , r 605). The dat. o)rxhqmw=| first occurs in Scut. 282, Theogn. 791.

151, 152. Thucydides leaves us here. In 152 the reading is established by Martin's brilliant conjecture; the only difficulty, the alteration of oi(/ into o(/s is made necessary by the verbs in 153. The emendations a)pantia/sai (Barnes), e)nantia/sei) (Ilgen) and u(pantia/sei) (Abel) are superfluous. Though e)pantia/zein does not occur elsewhere, there is force in the preposition, “light upon them.” In 151 M reads a)qa/natos, and this was part of Martin's conjecture; a)nh/r in x is perhaps connected with this reading. The construction is possible: “he would believe himself immortal, who was present when,” etc. There can be little doubt, however, that a)qana/tous is right; the poet glorifies the appearance of the Ionians with a direct compliment. For the variant cf. Il. 24.499 au)tou/s and au)to/s.

ai)ei/: supported by Il. 12.323 (with a)gh/rw t' a)qana/tw te), and by the numerous instances in which the two adjectives are followed by h)/mata pa/nta *q 539, e 136, h 94, 257, y 336, verse ap. Paus.x. 24. 3.

*pa/ntwn: probably masculine. te/ryaito de\ qumo/n is best joined with ei)soro/wn; there is nothing to be gained by taking it as parenthetical, in which case i)/doito would go closely with ei)soro/wn.
au)tw=n: here emphatic, contrasting the people themselves with their ships and other material possessions. Cf. Od. 7.43 qau/mazen d' *)oduseu\s lime/nas kai\ nh=as e)i+/sas
div2.l: ai)tw=n q' h(rw/wn a)gora/s, b 154 h)/i+can dia/ t' oi)ki/a kai\ po/lin au)tw=n, q 574 au)tou/s te po/lia/s t' e)u+\ naietaw/sas, i 40 po/lin e)/praqon w)/lesa d' au)tou/s. The heaviness of the line would be relieved by the (doubtless original) resolution w)kei+/as; see on 31.

div2.p: o(/ou kle/os ou)/pot' o)lei=tai=Il. 2.325; cf. orac.ap. Paus.x. 6. 7.<*> On the false form o(/ou (for o(/o) see H. G. § 98.

kou=rai *dhlia/des: for this chorus see Homolle in B. C. H. xiv. p. 501 f.; it was called xoro\s tw=n gunaikw=n, e.g. ei)s tog xoron tog gunaikwn tog genomenon tois apoll[wniois]. The Delian women took part, as a chorus, in various festivals: Apollonia, Letaea, Artemisia, Britomartia, Aphrodisia, and on the occasion of qewri/ai from Cos, Rhodes, Siphnos, and Carystos. For the lastmentioned festival cf. also Dion. Perieget. 527 r(u/sia d' *)apo/llwni xorou\s a)na/gousin a(/pasai (sc. ai) *kukla/des) i(stame/nou glukerou= ne/on ei<*>aros. The imitation of dialects (see on 162) was probably to please the qewroi/ (so Lebègue p. 13 and 257, Homolle l.c.). The *dhlia/des, a play of Cratinus, may have referred to such a chorus. Euripides H. F. 687 f. calls their song a paia/n; cf. also Hec.462 f., Wilamowitz-Möllendorff Herakl. i. p. 140. Compare the chorus of *ludw=n ko/rai at Ephesus: Nub. 599 f., Aelian V. H. xii. 9, Ion fr. 22, Diog. fr. 1, Kock F. C. A. i. p. 806.
qera/p*nai: Homer uses only the masc. qera/pwn.

a)*ndrw=n te *palaiw=n ktl.: usually explained as a reference to the Hyperboreans, for whom see Müller Dorians i. p. 294, Frazer on Paus.x. 5. 7, Roscher s.v. 2810 f. But we should expect some mention of their name; and the more obvious explanation is that the chorus of women, like the rhapsodists, sang of heroes and heroines, after a prelude to the gods.

krembaliastu/n: the alternative bambaliastu/n is not elsewhere found, but it can hardly be a graphical corruption, and may be justified by bambai/nwn *k 375, bambalu/zw schol. ad loc., and other forms: see J. H. S. xv. p. 301. It would mean “rattling,” and so be an equivalent of krembaliastu/s, “playing on castanets.” The sense of the passage is evidently that the Delian singers reproduced the speech and the musical accompaniment of the various pilgrims; but there is no other reference to this curious mimicry of (apparently) different dialects. krembaliastu/n cannot mean “dancing,” as some suppose; but there was no doubt a dance during the song, in the “hyporchematic manner.” See Smyth Melic Poets p. lxix f. The hyporcheme was properly sacred to Apollo, and was kept up in Delos in the time of Lucian (de salt. 16 pai/dwn xoroi\ sunelqo/ntes u(p' au)lw=| kai\ kiqa/ra| oi( me\n e)xo/reuon, u(pwrxou=nto de\ oi( a)/ristoi prokriqe/ntes e)c au)tw=n). It is impossible to say whether this chorus of boys took the place of an older chorus of women, or whether Lucian is only describing one out of several kinds of Delian u(porxh/mata existing in his day; as there were numerous festivals at Delos (see on 157) the latter explanation is more probable.
Peppmüller's au)th\ e(ka/sth entirely misses the point.

mimei=se): mimicry was the essence of the hyporcheme; cf. Athen. 15 D e)sti\n h( toiau/th o)/rxhsis mi/mhsis tw=n u(po\ th=s le/cews e(rmhneuome/nwn pragma/twn. Smyth p. lxxii. But the mimicry mentioned by Athenaeus is of course different from the Delian imitation of dialects.

The reading of M is intelligible as far as it goes, but necessitates a lacuna to contain a verb (as Martin and Barnes proposed); that of the other MSS. will not construe. The probability is very great that the manuscript text is a direct corruption from a reading the same as the Thucydidean. a)ll' a)/ge, a)/geq), etc. are liable to corruption; cf. h. Dem. 490, and lhtw/ (through lhtoi=) is not, for an ancient error, far from -lh/koi. So Dion. Perieget. 447 a)ll' o( me\n i(lh/koi; the second person is common. *)apo/llwn *)arte/midi *cu/n=Od. 15.410. The cults of the two deities were closely connected at Delos, as at many other places; their temples were side by side, and they had common offerings. Farnell (Cults ii. p. 465 f.) thinks that it was from Delos that the idea of the close relation between Artemis and Apollo was diffused. References in Farnell, Cults ii. p. 577, Pauly-Wissowa 33. For their common cult at Delphi see on xxvii. 13 f.

The lines seem to be practically a request by the poet to be awarded the prize; for the mousikh=s a)gw/n see p. lix. In J. H. S. xvii. p. 245 (after Ilgen) it was pointed out that this passage must be taken in connexion with Hes. fr. 227 e)n *dh/lw| to/te prw=ton e)gw\ kai\ *(/omhros a)oidoi\
div2.l: me/lpomen, e)n nearoi=s u(/mnois r(a/yantes a)oidh/n,
*foi=bon *)apo/llwna xrusa/oron, o(\n te/ke *lhtw/.
The coincidence of subject and place is remarkable.
div2.p: For de/ in asking a question cf. Il. 6.123 etc.

eu)= ma/la *pa=sai: Baumeister quotes examples of eu)= ma/la (Od. 22.190) and ma/la pa/ntes etc. (Il. 13.741 etc., so h. Dem. 417 and in late epic as Aratus 17, 805, 952); and, for the whole phrase, Theocr. xxv. 19 eu)= ma/la pa=si.

u(*pokri/nasqai a)f/hmws: here again the reading of the MSS., whether a)f' h(me/wn or a)f' u(me/wn cannot be original to them. The lection of the younger Thucydidean MSS. eu)fh/mws (adopted by Ruhnken and subsequent editors) must be later than a)f-, which survives in the MSS. of the hymns (a and eu in minuscule are alike). Therefore the reading of Thucydides' older MSS. a)fh/mws seems the origin of the others. This word (either with or without the aspirate) was accepted by Bergk (Geschichte d. gr. Lit. i. p. 750 n.), in the sense of “with one voice.” The Thucydidean scholiast glosses the word h(su/xa, a)qro/ws. The latter meaning may stand if the prefix is connected with a(/ma. So a)fh/toros in Il. 9.404 was explained by Aristarchus as =o(mofh/toros (approved of by Prellwitz B. B. xxii. p. 85). See J. H. S. xvii. p. 246.
For the reference of the poet to himself and his country cf. Theog. 23 f. In “personal” poetry (e.g. Hes. Op.639 f., fr. 227, quoted above) the autobiography is of course natural.

*paipaloe/ss|h: epithet of Chios, Od. 3.170. This line was, at least partly, the origin of the tradition that Homer was blind, and lived in Chios ( l.c.); Simonides of Ceos (or Simonides of Amorgos) fr. 85 e(\n de\ to\ ka/lliston *xi=os e)/eipen a)nh/r. See Jebb Homer p. 87 f. The legendary Thamyris and the Phaeacian Demodocus were also blind; indeed it was natural that the blind should have recourse to the profession of the a)oido/s, just as the lame found employment as blacksmiths (cf. the lame smith-god Hephaestus). This explanation (suggested by Bergk) is opposed by Fries Rhein. Mus. 57. 2 (1902), p. 265 f., who curiously thinks that the idea of blind poets is a folk-tale of Egyptian origin, and even throws doubt on the genuineness of this passage as a personal narrative. Cf. also Brugmann I. F. iii. 257 n., who compares Servian epos.
For Cynaethus, who, if the tradition is true, must be the speaker here, see Pref. p. lii and Introd. p. 65.

a)risteu/ousin: the alteration a)risteu/sousin is needless; the poet claims that his songs are famous as soon as he has sung them (meto/pisqen). His merits are recognized during his lifetime; cf. 70. u(me/teron also in 174 is clearly correct; he makes a bargain with the *dhlia/des, just as the minstrel in Hom. Epigr. xiv. bargains with the potters.

strefo/mesqa *po/leis: the acc. denotes the goal, as often after i(kne/omai etc.; see H. G. § 140 (4). Cf. Od. 6.114 po/lin h(gh/saito, o 82 a)/stea d' a)nqrw/pwn h(gh/somai. The exx. quoted by Hermann, Od. 13.325 (a)nastre/fesqai), Od. 17.486 (e)pistrwfa=n), are not parallel in construction, as the verbs are compound, in which case the acc. is common; cf. 216. The statement suits the profession of rhapsode in general, and Cynaethus in particular, who rhapsodized the Homeric poems at Syracuse.

179-81. These three lines do not appear to belong to the Delian part, although their connexion with it could be defended (see Introd. p. 62, and on 181). On the other hand the abrupt change of person (a)na/sseis 181, ei)=si 182), inadequately explained by Gemoll as due to the “strophic” nature of the lines, seems to separate them from 182 f. They may therefore be regarded as a fragment (no doubt of genuine antiquity), apparently introduced to give some sort of transition from the Delian to the Pythian parts.
The enumeration of a list of places in which a god was worshipped is common in poetry from Homer onwards; cf. Il. 1.37 f., and many exx. quoted by Adami de poet. scaen. p. 227 f.

*luki/h*n: on the Lycian Apollo see Pauly-Wissowa 58 f. and 83, Preller Robert i. p. 254 f. Apollo was thought to spend six months, in summer, at Delos, the other six at Patara in Lycia (Serv. on Verg. Aen.iv. 144; cf. Od.iii. 4. 65). According to another tradition, he absented himself from Delphi during the three winter months ( Pind. Pyth.iv. 5, de EI 9). Such periodic migrations are natural for gods of the sun or vegetation; but they are not confined to such deities. If a god was worshipped in different lands he might readily be supposed to spend the year in his various temples. See further Frazer on Paus.ii. 7. 8.
*m|honi/h*n e)ratein/hn: cf. Il. 3.401 , *s 291; for the Lydian cult (especially at Magnesia, near Sipylos) see PaulyWissowa 82.
*mi/lhton: for the cult of Apollo *didumeu/s at Branchidae, near Miletus, see Pauly-Wissowa 49, Preller-Robert i. p. 283 f.
e)/nalon: of a town on the sea; cf. Pind. Ol.ix. 150ei)nali/a *)eleusi/s.

au)to/s: the word may emphasize the bodily presence of Apollo at Delos. There can be no contrast between Apollo and another, as there may be in 140, 337. But au)to/s seems to be not infrequently used as a kind of title of Apollo, without any antithesis: “Apollo himself”=great Apollo; see note on h. Herm. 234. If this line formed part of the hymn recited at Delos, it must be intended as a final compliment to the island.
*periklu/stou: cf. Hedyp. fr. 27 (corp. poet. ludib. p. 153) e)n periklu/stw|
div2.l: *dh/lw|.
div2.p: 182-206. This passage (or 179-206) is considered by some editors as a separate fragment, or short hymn to Apollo; by others as the exordium of a “Pythian” hymn. As, however, a new poem obviously cannot begin with 182 ei)=si de/ ktl., Hermann, Baumeister and others assume that the opening of the “Pythian” hymn has been lost.

tequwme/na: Barnes' conjecture is supported by Cypria fr. ii. 8 tequwme/na ei)/mata e(/sto. eu)wde/a (Pierson) is about on a level with tequwme/na in point of similarity to tequwde/a (t' eu)wde/a in the Oxford text was an error).
kanax\hn e)/xei: so Il. 16.105, 794. Cf. Il. 18.495 boh\n e)/xon.
w(/s te *no/hma: for the simile see note on h. Herm. 43.

Cf. Il. 1.604 , w 60. Apollo's connexion with the Muses is as old as the first book of the Iliad. For later references see Pauly-Wissowa 38, PrellerRobert i. p. 279 f. Compare especially the dance of the Muses, to the sound of Apollo's phorminx in Pind. Nem.v. 22 f., inscr. on the chest of Cypselus ( Paus.v. 18. 4) *mou=sai d' a)mf' au)to/n, xari/eis xoro/s, ai(=si kata/rxei (*)apo/llwn). Gemoll thinks that Pindar imitated the hymn; but there is nothing in his theme or treatment which may not be independent.
Compare M. Arnold's description of Apollo and the Muses: First hymn they the Father Of all things: and then The rest of Immortals, The action of men. (Callicles beneath Etna.)
dw=r): prerogatives, i.e. the immortality of the gods (Franke). qew=n dw=ra in h. Dem. 147, 216 is different.
a)frade/es: cf. h. Dem. 256, nh/i+des a)/nqrwpoi kai\ a)fra/dmones.

For the connexion of the Charites with Aphrodite see n. on h. Aphr. 61, and for the Horae n. on vi. 5. With the line cf. Panyas. ap. Athen. ii. 38 *xa/rite/s t' e)/laxon kai\ e)u+/frones *(=wrai; Plat. Symp. vii. 5(dance of Charites, Horae, and Nymphs). For the conjunction of Charites and Muses cf. Theog. 64 f., Sappho fr. 22 deu=te/ nun, a)/brai *xa/rites kalli/komoi/ te *mou=sai. The Charites are associated with Apollo in literature ( Pind. Ol.14. 10) and art ( Paus.ix. 35. 1, of the Delian Apollo).

197-199. Artemis is “divinely tall and most divinely fair” beyond the other goddesses. Cf. Od. 6.107 f., where she is conspicuous among her attendant nymphs. In xxvii. 15 f. Artemis leads the Muses and Charites in the dance. metame/lpetai: not loosely used of dancing only; the goddess sang as she danced, according to the regular practice; cf. Il. 16.182 melpome/nh|sin e)n xorw=| *)arte/midos. So the Phaeacian girls sang as they played ball, Od. 6.100 f.
Cf. ix. 2.

*pai/zous): the verb is often used =o)rxei=sqai: Il. 8.251 , y 147, h. Aphr. 120. There is certainly no idea of ungainly or ludicrous motion, as O. Müller (quoted by Baumeister) imagines, as if the two gods played the part of kubisthth=res (Il. 18.593 f.); the dance may however be thought of as “hyporchematic” (for this see above 162).

kala\ kai\ u(/yi biba/s=516. Apollo keeps time to his own music, cf. his title o)rxhsth/s Pind. fr. 125, and perhaps skiasth/s in Laconia, which the scholiast on Lycophr. 561 explains as “the dancer.”

marmarugai/: only here and in Od. 8.265 marmaruga\s qhei=to podw=n. Schneidewin and Baumeister emend to marmarugh=s, unnecessarily; the te is explanatory: “brightness shines around him, even the twinklings of his feet and chiton.” Possibly ai)/glh, rather than marmarugai/, may be mentally supplied to xitw=nos.

For the pride of Leto, with whom Zeus is here associated, in her children, cf. Od. 6.106, h. Apoll. 12, 126. qumo
 me/gan; Baumeister compares h. Dem. 37 me/gan no/on, adding quippe deae. But of course such expressions are not confined to the gods; cf. Il. 9.496 a)ll), *)axileu=, da/mason qumo
 me/gan, and the common megalh/tora qumo/n. For the construction cf. h. Pan 45 pa/ntes d' a)/ra qumo
 e)te/rfqen.

ei)soro/wntes governs ui)=a; there is no difficulty in the intervention of the explanatory subjects *lhtw/ and *zeu/s. Peppmüller's transposition of 205 and 206 is bad; Gemoll's punctuation e)pite/rpontai, qumo\n me/gan ei)soro/wntes (ui)=a in apposition to qumo/n) is very clumsy.

208-213. The passage is very obscure, but it needs explanation rather than “higher criticism.” Gemoll rightly points out that it is certainly not a separate hymn, and that the theory of interpolation is simply a confession of inability to understand.

mn*hst*=|hsin appears to be sound, being explained by mnwo/menos; for the use of mnhsth/ absolute (=Homeric a)/loxos mnhsth/) cf. Apoll. Arg. 1.780. It forms a kind of zeugma with filo/thti: “am I to sing of thee in thy love of brides?” mnhsth=rsin does not seem to be an improvement, and mnhstu=sin is a doubtful form, mnhstu/s being only known in sing. a)ei/dein tina e)n filo/thti may be unusual, but it is not impossible Greek, as Gemoll (after Matthiae) contends.

mnwo/menos is Martin's brilliant conjecture. We may suppose that mnwo/menos first lost the n, and o(/ppws became o(/ppos (cf. the variants on 19), when a was added to give the necessary syllable (cf., however, Plat. Rep. 401C a)nemo/menoi for nemo/menoi).

*)azanti/da: the next line makes it almost certain that the reference here is to Coronis. According to Hes. fr. 125 and Pind. Pyth.3. 55Ischys, the son of Elatos, was Apollo's rival in his love for Coronis (see also Paus.ii. 26. 5). Elsewhere, however, Coronis is called the daughter of Phlegyas (xvi. 2 and see reff. in Pauly-Wissowa 30; Isyllus Inscr. Pelop. et insul. vicin. 1902, i. 950). It is not impossible that here another legend is followed, in which she is the daughter of Azan (so Preller-Robert i.^{2} p. 520 n. 3). Martin reads *)azani/da, i.e. Arcadian; but Phlegyas is not known to have any connexion with Arcadia. For the various references to his home see Gemoll; according to one version ( Paus.ix. 36. 3) he was a Phocian; hence *)abanti/da (from Abae) has been suggested, but the first vowel should be short. According to another version the mother of Asclepius, by Apollo, was not Coronis but Arsinoe, whose father Leucippus was descended from Atlas ( Apollod.iii. 118, cf. 110, Paus.ii. 171). This would support M's *)atlanti/da, which seems, however, either a conjecture or a graphical corruption of *)azanti/da. Moreover, the legend of Ischys is not associated with Arsinoe, but with Coronis; so in the recently discovered fragments of the Hecale of Callimachus (col. iv. v 6. 7, Gomperz 1893, Ellis in J. P. xxiv. 148 f.) o(ppo/te ken *flegu/ao *korwni/dos a)mfi\ qugatro\s *)/isxui plhci/ppw| spome/nhs miero/n ti pi/qhtai. See further reff. in Roscher ii. 359.
*)elationi/d|h: son of *)elati/wn (=*)/elatos), cf. l.c. *ei)lati/dhs. For Elatus cf. Paus.viii. 4.On the long i_ (-i_on-) cf. Solmsen p. 58.

*triope/w| *ge/nos: the person intended by trio/pw ge/nos of the MSS. might be another mnhsth/, in which case ge/nos would be objective acc., “child” (an echo of which might be trio/pew go/non, the reading of one MS. Callim. h. Dem. 24). But as Phorbas was the son of Triopas ( Paus.viii. 26. 12, Hyg. Astr. ii. 14) ge/nos is certainly acc. of respect, “by descent,” for which cf. Il. 5.544, 5.896 etc. The two words therefore balance *)elationi/dh| in 210, and the dative of a patronymic form must be extracted from trio/pw or triopo/w. The latter points to a synizesis, and the couditions are satisfied by *triope/w|, which must be the dative of *trio/peos, formed direct from *tri/oy (=*trio/pas, Apollod.i. 7. 4. 2*tri/opa, 3 *tri/opos gen.), since the actual adj. in use from *trio/pas is *trio/peios; cf. C. I. Sic. et It. 1890, no. 1389. This would be parallel to *)agamemnone/hn a)/loxon g 264, *deinome/neie pai= Pind. Pyth.2. 18 and other formations; see Leo B. B. iv. 1-21 die homer. Vaternamen, Kuhner-Blass l.c., Zacher in Diss. Phil. Hal. 1878, p. 59 f.
Phorbas is here the rival of Apollo; according to l.c., Plut. Num.4 he was beloved by the god. Schneidewin's alteration of a(/ma to w(s is not justified.

*)ereuqei=: nothing is known of an Ereutheus, and there is much probability in y's a)maru/nqw, which has nearly all elements in common with a(/m' e)reuqei=. But any connexion of Apollo and Amarynthus is merely a matter of inference from this passage (Wernicke in Pauly-Wissowa 28 denies it). D'Orville conjectured and some of the earlier editors printed *)erexqei=, after M; but this is not supported by any known myth of Erechtheus.

a(/ma *leuki/p*pw|: the allusion is to Daphne, who was loved by Leucippus and Apollo. Paus.viii. 20. 3 f. says that Apollo was angry with Leucippus, who e)s fili/an i)sxura
 e)pa/getai th
 *da/fnhn, under the guise of a woman. Daphne and her other companions discovered his sex and slew him. This account does not justify Gemoll in giving da/mar its proper sense of “wife,” but there may have been another version, in which Daphne actually became the wife of Leucippus. In any case the dative da/marti is remarkable; if the reference is to Apollo's love for Daphne, we should expect the accusative as in 209. It is possible that *leuki/ppw| has taken the place of some other name, owing to the proximity of *leuki/ppoio. Ilgen's a(/ma *)arsi/ppw| th
 *leuki/ppoio qu/gatra would refer to Arsinoe, daughter of Leucippus (see on 209). The passage seems incurable.

The line is hopeless; it is very possible that there is a lacuna, before or after this verse, or before and after (Hermann). Owing to the obscurity of 212, it is not clear whether a new achievement of Apollo is mentioned in the words, pezo/s, o( d' i(/ppoisin which seem to refer to some contest between Apollo, on foot, and a rival, in a chariot. Schneidewin's idea that this contest is between Apollo and Idas, for the love of Marpessa, does not suit the following words ou) mh\n *tri/opo/s g' e)ne/leipen, which he has therefore to eject as a gloss on 211. His explanation that e)ne/lipen or e)ne/leipen is a corruption of a scribe's marginal note e)llei/pei, although quoted with approval by Baumeister and Verrall (p. 8), cannot be accepted. The Greek, as it stands, can be construed; “he (Apollo's rival) fell not short of Triops”; for *tri/oy=*trio/pas see on 211, otherwise the nom. *trio/pas might be read as subject. But the uncertainty of the context makes explanation mere guesswork.

Apollo starts from Olympus in search of a place for his oracle. It is to be noted that there is no mention of Delos as a starting-point; the continental poet has no interest in the island. Later, when the Delian and Pythian myths were systematised, Apollo was supposed to have journeyed from Delos to Delphi (first in Pind. fr. 286 = schol. on Aesch. Eum.11); Pindar made Apollo alight at Tanagra. This was thought a mistake for Tegyra (see on 16) by O. Müller Orch. p. 161; but Pindar no doubt referred to the district *dh/lion on the Tanagraean coast ( Thuc.iv. 76, Paus.ix. 20. 1) which was a religious colony from Delos (Strabo 403). According to Aesch. Eum.9 f. and the Delphian hymn (B. C. H. xviii. p. 345 f. v. 14 f.) Apollo started from Delos and landed at Athens; thence he travelled by the sacred road of the qewroi/ (cf. on 280, Eum.12 f., Ephorus ap. Strab. 422); see Preller-Robert i. p. 239 n. 1, Pauly-Wissowa 24.

In the hymn, the age of Apollo at the founding of the oracle is indeterminate. In later times, after the connexion with the Delian myth, Apollo was a child, or was even carried to Delphi in his mother's arms ( I. T. 1250, Clearch. ap. Athen. 701 C); he slew the Python when four days' old ( Hyg. fab.140), or while still a youth (Apoll. Arg. 2.707).
*pieri/h*n: the acc. is necessary; the gen. (x) and dat. (p) seem corrections. For the sense cf. Il. 14.225 f. li/pen r(i/on *ou)lu/mpoio,
div2.l: *pieri/hn d' e)piba=sa kai\ *)hmaqi/hn e)rateinh/n ktl. See Od. 5.50. Pieria is strictly N. of Olympus, whereas Apollo was coming south. The poet appears to have borrowed from *c without due care (in *c the geography is right, as Hera is going to Thrace).

div2.p: *le/kton t' *)hmaqo/enta: no *le/ktos is known in Europe and the Trojan promontory of that name is out of the question; but, with the example of *au)toka/nh in 35, it would be rash to assume that the MSS. are here corrupt, and therefore the conjectures (of which Baumeister's *la/kmon is the best) may be neglected. Since Lectus may have been a town or harbour, or even a river, h)maqo/enta may also stand, in spite of the ingenuity of Matthiae's *)hmaqi/hn te, which rests on Il. 14.226, quoted supra 216. The same critic, with equal brilliance, mended the rest of the line. *ai)*ni=hnas: this form may be preferred to *)enih=nas (M's a(gnih/nas is nearest; cf. Hes. Op.394a(gnh=| MSS., ai)nh=| a quotation; in the other MSS. the tradition was obscured, though a trace of it remains in y). *)enih=nes is found only in Il. 2.749 (where the Bodl. pap. class. Ms. gr. a. i (P), Oxyrhynch. pap. ii. xxi. and the quotation ap. schol. on Soph. El.706 read ai)neih=nes) and Herod.vii. 132, where one MS. “R” gives ai)nih=nes. In Eur. (I. A. 277), Thuc. , and later the form is generally ai)n-. The e is called Ionic, although neither Smyth Ionic § 141 nor Hoffmann p. 266 give the form under the head of Ionic e=ai. The spelling may be merely an itacism, helped by a desire to avoid the synizesis -ih, which is not harsher than the Homeric sxetli/h, *ai)gupti/h, *(isti/aia. Fick Iliasp. 417 calls *)enih=nes doubtful. The people are coupled with the Perrhaebi in Il. 2.749, as dwellers about Dodona and by the Titaresius and Peneius; both of these rivers are S. of Olympus.

The geography is here accurate. From Iolcus (N. of the gulf of Pagasae) Apollo passes, either along the coast of Phthiotis or across the gulf, to Cenaeon, a promontory at the extreme NW. of Euboea (see Soph. Trach.752). He thus reaches the Lelantine plain, which lay between Chalcis and Eretria. This district became famous about 700 B.C. as the bone of contention between the two cities. See Duncker iii. ch. viii., Holm i. ch. xxi. Chalcis was situated on the narrowest part of the Euripus, over which Apollo crosses to the mainland.

The omission of the name of the mountain is unusual; perhaps, as Baumeister suggests, the poet was not only familiar with the locality, but also assumes the same knowledge on the part of his hearers. The mountain is no doubt the Messapius opposite Chalcis; see Aesch. Ag.284, Paus.ix. 22. 5, Strabo 405.

*mukalhsso/n: a town at the foot of Messapius; it was in ruins by the time of Pausanias (ix. 19. 4). See Frazer ad loc. who identifies it with the modern Rhitzona. Between this place and Teumessus was Harma, where puqaistai/ allowed the qusi/ai to proceed to Delphi, or prevented them, according to the result of divination by lightning (Strabo 404).

*teumhsso/n: Mesovouni, a village or small town on the slopes of a low hill, about five miles from Thebes. See Frazer on Paus.ix. 19. 1.The hill itself is bare and rocky, and the epithet lexepoi/h*n seems quite inappropriate. Frazer suggests that the ancients may have extended the name Teumessus to include the hills on the south (now called Mount Soros), which are less bare. Nonnus (Dionys. v. 59 f.) and Statius ( Theb.i. 485) speak of Teumessus as grassy and wooded; Antimachus (ap. Aristot. Rhet.iii. 1408 a 1) as h)nemo/eis o)li/gos lo/fos, which Strabo 409 thinks unsuitable. There is the same variant telmhsso/n in the MSS. of Eur. Phoen.1100.On the etymology see Wackernagel K. Z. xxviii p. 121, Bechtel B. B. xxvi. p. 148.

Baumeister, who holds the poet (of this part of the hymn) to have been a Boeotian, understands the reason for the supposed non-existence of Thebes to be due to feelings of patriotism. A Boeotian could not allow the chief city of his country to be passed over by Apollo without honour. Possibly, however, the poet wished to lay emphasis on the extreme antiquity of the Pythian oracle by claiming for it a greater age than for Thebes, which was itself reputed to be a very ancient city. Tradition held that there were other inhabited towns in Boeotia before the foundation of Thebes (cf. Conon 's dihgh/seis ap. Phot. Bibl.137b 27). The Catalogue (Il. 2.505) mentions *(upoqh=bai only. In historical times Apollo *)ismh/nios was worshipped as an oracular god at Thebes; Herod. i. 52, 92, viii. 134; Paus.ix. 10.
u(/lh for u(/lhn is an admirable conjecture of Barnes. The accusative must have arisen from a tendency to be influenced by the nearest apparent construction.

*)ogxhsto/n: the precinct of Poseidon at Onchestus was famous from early times; cf. Il. 2.506 *)ogxhsto/n q' i(ero/n, *posidh/i+on a)glao\n a)/lsos, Hes. fr. 41 (Rzach), Pind. Isthm.i. 33Pind. Isthm., iii. 19.Pausanias (ix. 26. 3) saw the ruins of the town, temple (with statue of Poseidon still standing) and precinct; Strabo (412) speaks of the grove as bare and treeless in his day. On the site see Frazer on l.c.

231-238. The custom at Onchestus is puzzling, as the account in the hymn is obscurely worded, and is our sole authority. Most scholars have followed Böttiger in explaining the custom as a mode of divination: if the horses entered the a)/lsos the omen was favourable; see Bouché-Leclercq Divination i. p. 150. This and similar views, however, depend on Barnes' emendation a)/gwsin, which cannot be accepted (see on 235). Ilgen first gave a clue, by a suggestion that there is a reference to Poseidon tara/cippos. A bolting or shying horse was often thought to be panic-stricken by that god (see Paus.vi. 20. 15 with Frazer's note). The present editors have discussed the passage in J. H. S. xvii. p. 274 f. (T. W. A.) and J. H. S. xix. p. xxxix f. ( S. ). It is possible that the custom was the ordinary rule of the road: Poseidon was offended at wheeled traffic which passed his home; but the horses were allowed a chance; if they bolted and broke the carriage, the driver had to leave the wreckage in the precinct. In any case the owners kept the horses (see note on kome/ousi 236).

It is hard to believe, however, that this inconvenient practice was a regular “rule of the road”; moreover neodmh\s pw=los is forcible and scarcely looks like a poetic expression for any horse. The custom may rather have been practised with newly broken colts. All horses belonged to the horse-god Poseidon, who might refuse to allow his sacred animals to bear the yoke. The colts were passed before the god; if they drew the carriage safely through, or past, his precinct, they might be driven by men; if they broke away from the chariot, Poseidon claimed them for his own. The owners could indeed retain them, but not for the indignity of a yoke; the chariot was left in the grove, as being marked by Poseidon's displeasure.
a)*nap*ne/ei, “gains new life,” through the inspiration of the horse-god.
o(do\n e)/rxetai: Martial iv. 55. 23 et sanctum Buradonis ilicetum
div2.l: per quod vel piger ambulat viator has a verbal similarity (ambulat=o(do\n e)/rxetai); but there the reason for walking is obscure; Martial may refer to the beauty of the scenery or the sanctity of the grove.

div2.p: kei/n' o)/xea krote/ousin=Il. 15.453; cf. Il. 11.160.
a)*naktori/h*n: not in Homer, and only here of “driving,” but a)/nac=“master” of a horse etc. is Homeric; for the general sense “lordship” cf. Apoll. Arg. 1.839, v. ap. Paus.x. 12. 6.

a)*g*=|hsin: this is practically the manuscript reading, and is certainly right. Barnes' a)/gwsin should not have been accepted by Baumeister and others. As Gemoll sees, e)n a)/lsei+ dendrh/enti cannot follow a verb of motion; we should have expected e)s a)/lsea dendrh/enta. The meaning of a)*g*=|hsin may be either “broken to fragments” or more probably, “broken off at the end of the pole”; cf. Il. 6.40 , *p 371.

kome/ousi: the subject can only be the owners of the horses. komei=n means to “groom,” “look after” horses in Il. 8.109, 113; but, more generally, to “keep” animals, as in Od. 17.310, 319, Anth. Pal. vii. 717. 3. There can be no reference to the consecration of the colts to Poseidon as a)fetoi/.

kli/nantes: probably the carriage was propped against the temple-wall; cf. Il. 8.435 , d 42 a(/rmata d' e)/klinan pro\s e)nw/pia pamfano/wnta. e)w=sin almost certainly implies that the chariots were left permanently as a)naqh/mata, or possibly were sold; in the latter case di/fron de\ qeou= to/te moi=ra fula/ssei is rather euphemistic. The sale of duplicate or damaged objects from temple treasures is known from inscriptions; cf. Homolle in Daremberg and Saglio s. v. Donarium p. 381. 2.
eu)/xontai: the prayer was apparently to propitiate the god's wrath.

240 sq. The geography here is difficult. Haliartus lies between Onchestus and Ocalea, and the Cephissus or Melas flowed across the northern part of the Copais lake, and would not be crossed at any point by the road from Thebes to Panopeus. We can hardly with Ilgen suppose Apollo to have gone round the whole lake (e.g. to Tegyra) turning N. at this point; and the transpositions and excisions of other editors are even less available. The writer, like the author of the Catalogue, was indifferent to the order of places on a route (cf. his lists of places 30 f., 422 f.), and may therefore be allowed to have transposed Haliartus and Ocalea; but it is hard to imagine a poet whom there are grounds for calling Boeotian (Introd. p. 67 f.) making the stream which actually separates Onchestus and Haliartus (usually identified with the Lophis) into the Cephissus. By the date of the hymn no doubt the old Minyan system of drainage had broken down, and Copais had become, as it remained till a few years ago, in the winter a sheet of water, in the summer a dry swamp intersected by various rivers and canals. It may therefore be suggested (1) that the writer meant *khfiso/s for the lake, somewhat as in 280 he locates Panopeus *khfisi/dos e)ggu/qi li/mnhs, while it was in reality near the river; (2) or that the entire water-system, rivers and canals, may have been considered branches of the Cephissus, and that the southernmost canal with its tributaries (which came close to Haliartus and Onchestus, and actually joined the Melas at the NW. corner of the lake) may have been known by that name. Strabo 407 says distinctly that the Melas flows through the land of Haliartus. There was much confusion of names in this submerged country; even a resident antiquary like Plutarch (Sulla 20, Pelop. 16) mistook the Cephissus for the Melas, and Strabo 412 accuses Alcaeus of misplacing Onchestus and misspelling the name of a river. Cf. Frazer Paus.vol. v. p. 110 f., with his map.

The line is quoted by a schol. on Il. 2.523 as from Hesiod: o( de\ *khfiso\s potamo/s e)sti th=s *fwki/dos, e)/xwn ta\s phga\s e)k *lilai/as, w(/s fhsin *(hsi/odos o(/s te *lilai/h|si proi+/ei kalli/rroon u(/dwr. See Eusth. ad loc. (p. 275), who quotes the line in the form given by the MSS. here. Baumeister most improbably supposes that the scholiast took the line from the hymn, which he thought to be Hesiodean. The Homeric scholia uniformly ignore the hymns. Probably there was actually a Hesiodean line, which the author of the hymn has borrowed, with or without variation. For Lilaea and the source of the Cephissus see Frazer on Paus.x. 33. 5.
*)wkale/h*n: Il. 2.501; it was near lake Copais, and 30 stadia from Haliartus (for which cf. Il. 2.503 poih/enq' *(ali/arton). Strabo ix. p. 410. For Haliartus see Frazer on Paus.ix. 32. 5.

*polu/purgon: the word does not occur elsewhere; but cf. e)u_/purgos of Troy, Il. 7.71. It must be confessed, however, that the title is strange, for a small and unimportant town, and Barnes' polu/puron is attractive; cf. Il. 11.756 etc., and Od. 16.396 *doulixi/ou polupu/rou poih/entos (so poih/enta 243).

*telfou/shs: here and in 247, 256, 276 the MSS. vary between the forms telfou=sa and delfou=sa. Other spellings are found: *tilfw=ssa Pindar in Strabo 411, Herodian ap. Byz. There Steph. was a temple of Apollo *tilfw/ssios at that place; in Dem.xix. 141, 148, Theopomp. fr. 240 it is called to\ *tilfwssai=on; cf. Ephor. fr. 67 *tilfwse/wn o)/ros e)n *)alalkomeni/a|, Apollod.iii. 7. 4. 3*tilfou=ssa. Pausanias uses the forms *tilfou=sa, *tilfou/sion o)/ros (ix. 33. 1). In Arcadia we find the name of a town and local nymph *qe/lpousa ( Paus.viii. 35; coins with *qe*l, Head Hist. Num. p. 382). All these forms are doubtless connected with the root qa/lp-, i.e. “warm-spring” (Pott K. Z. viii. p. 416). As to the MS. delfou/shs, while there is no evidence for a local form in d, Androtion fr. 2 speaks of *delfou=sa in Arcadia, and Byz. Steph. calls the stream at Delphi *delfou=sa. The interchange of t and d is not uncommon, e.g. dru/faktos tru/faktos, da/pides ta/phtes (see Kretschmer K. Z. xxxiii. p. 467). It is therefore possible that *de/lfousa is a real form; otherwise it must be a scribe's error due to the association of *delfoi/, *delfi/nios etc.

The spring at Telphusa has been identified at the foot of Mt. Tilphusius, “a spur of Helicon which advances to within a few hundred paces of what used to be the margin of the lake,” i.e. Copais (Frazer on l.c.).
a)*p/hmwn, “peaceful”; the word is not applied to places in Homer, but cf. no/stos a)ph/mwn d 519. So Hes. Op.670(po/ntos). The idea is explained by 262.
*pelopo/n*nhson: not in Homer; but cf. Cypria 6. 3 nh=son a(/pasan
div2.l: *tantali/dou *pe/lopos. For Hesiod cf. schol. A on Il. 9.246 th\n o(/lhn *pelopo/nnhson ou)k oi)=den o( poihth/s, *(hsi/odos de/. On compounds in -nhson see Fick B. B. xxii. p. 29.

div2.p: *eu)rw/p*hn: “Europe” here apparently means N. Greece. It is quite reasonable to suppose that the geographical term, like *)asi/a and *(ella/s was gradually extended, as men's knowledge of the world widened. Byz. Steph. and E. M. 397. 45 derive *eu)rw/ph from *eu)/rwpos, a Macedonian city ( Thuc.ii. 100). The etymology is so far valuable, in that it points to a belief among the ancients themselves, that “Europe” was once a term for N. Greece; Hegesippus (fr. 6, F. H. G. v. 422 f.), a native of Mecyberna, states that Europe was used in the narrow sense: a)f' h(=s (sc. Europa) kai\ h( h)/peiros pa=sa h( pro\s *bore/an a)/nemon *eu)rw/ph ke/klhtai. Fick (B. B. xxii. p. 225) explains the meaning by “flatland,” opposed to stenwpo/s. M. Arnold's paraphrase “Wide Prospect” rests on an explanation (of Hermann) that Europe was the broad expanse of land stretching from Thrace to the Peloponnese, as it appeared to the Greeks in Asia Minor.

Byz. Steph. (s.v. *)asi/a) observes that Homer does not know *eu)rw/ph. But the substitution of h)/peiron (Reiz, Gemoll), on this ground, is quite unjustifiable. It is true that Stephanus considers the hymn to be Homer's (cf. on 224); but he may easily have overlooked the present passage, and he could not fail to be struck by the absence of the word in the Il.and

qemisteu/oimi: Ilgen reads k) for t) in 252, but the concessive optative may stand. The sense is “I am willing to prophesy”; cf. H. G. § 299 (d). Lines 252, 253=292, 293, where M has a)/r), the rest a)/n.

die/qhke: the verb is not found in Homer or Hesiod, and does not seem to occur elsewhere in serious poetry, though common in Attic prose. Cf. Callim.h. Apoll. 57 au)to\s de\ qemei/lia *foi=bos u(fai/nei.

Editors commonly punctuate with a colon at qh/sw, assuming an aposiopesis or change of construction after 260. The punctuation in the text seems to avoid all difficulty. Peppmüller places a colon at qh/sw, but reads a)/ll) for a)ll), comparing the common a)/llo de/ toi e)re/w su\ d' e)ni\ fresi/ ktl. But a)/llo here is scarcely appropriate.
e)/pos ti ktl.=Il. 19.121.

ktu/pon: a)kou/ein must be mentally supplied, from ei)sora/asqai. The zeugma here is very similar to that in Od. 9.167 (e)leu/ssomen) kapno/n t' au)tw=n te fqoggh/n. For w)kupo/dwn ktl. cf. Il. 10.535.
e)*n *kri/s|h: for the place see on 439.
This line seems to prove that the hymn (or at least this part of it) is older than the introduction of the Pythian games. See Introd. p. 67, and note on 542.

a)lla/ toi seems an improvement on the vulgate a)lla\ kai/, since Telphusa's argument is to present the advantages of Crisa throughout: at Telphusa the horses and chariots will divert men's attention from the temple; but at Crisa there will be no disturbance, and so men will bring gifts to Apollo. In x and p the familiarity of kai\ w(/s ousted toi.
The optatives prosa/goien and de/caio are best taken as expressing the acquiescence of the speaker as in 253 (=293), where see note: “they may bring gifts, and thou mayest receive their sacrifices.”

*)ih*pai/honi: here a title of Apollo as in Apoll. Arg. 2.704. In 500, 517 infra the word is used of the song to Apollo. Compare the paean of Aristonous (Smyth Melic Poets p. 527), with the repeated formulae i)h\ i)e\ *paia/n, w)= i)e\ *paia/n, Timotheus Pers.218; the latter (fr. 25 Wilamowitz) has also i(/e paia/n, the aspirate being due to the supposed connexion with i(/hmi (be/los), for which see Athen. 701 C. With the origin of the word from this refrain cf. the similar history of the Linus -song, the hymenaeus, and the iobacchus; the last, like *)ihpaih/wn, was a title of the god, as well as the name for the hymn. On *paia/n and *paiw/n see Preller-Robert i. p. 241 n. 2, p. 277 n. 2, Pauly-Wissowa Apollon 62, Smyth Melic Poets p. xxxvi f., and further on 500.

a)mfigeg*hqw/s: a)mfi/ is not intensive (“exceedingly” L. and S. ) but is to be connected with fre/nas, as often, in the sense “on both sides,” i.e. throughout the mind. Compare Il. 1.103 me/neos de\ me/ga fre/nes a)mfi\ me/lainai
div2.l: pi/mplant): Il. 17.83, 499, 573: Peppmüller reads a)mfi\ geghqw/s divisim, comparing Mimnerm. Il. 9.7 ai)ei/ min fre/nas a)mfi\ kakai\ tei/rousi me/rimnai and Theog. 554 (Schoemann) xw/sato de\ fre/nas a)mfi/, xo/los de/ min i(/keto qumo/n. But although a)mfigeghqw/s is a(/p. leg. the compound verb is supported by Il. 3.442 e)/rws fre/nas a)mfeka/luyen, *z 355 po/nos fre/nas a)mfibe/bhken. On this use of a)mfi/ see H. G. § 181.

div2.p: de/cai): the opt. is strongly supported by prosa/goien.
au)t*=|h=mo/nh|, as in Il. 8.99 , *n 729. Cf. the parallel line 381 (oi)/hs).
For the phrase o)/fra . . kle/os ei)/h cf. a Rhodian inscr. (Ath. Mitth. xvi. 117 and 357) sama toz idameneus poihsa hi.na kleos eih.

*flegu/wn: the godless Phlegyae (or Phlegyes, Eusth. 933. 15) are like the mythical Cyclopes; cf. Od. 9.275 f. ou) ga\r *ku/klwpes *dio\s ai)gio/xou a)le/gousin. But the Phlegyan hostility to Apollo is not mythical: the tribe attacked Pytho, from which they were repulsed by the god, only a few survivors escaping to Phocis; Paus.ix. 36. 2Paus., x. 7. 1, Pherecydes in schol. A on Il. 13.302, schol. Pind. Pyth.x. 55.For their city Panopeus see Paus.x. 4. 1 f. with Frazer's note. It lay 20 furlongs W. of Chaeronea.

*khfisi/dos li/mn*hs: lake Copais is so called in Il. 5.709; so in Pind. Pyth.xii. 27.Pausanias (ix. 24. 1) says that the lake was called by both names; he himself uses the name Cephisis by preference. The verse has been suspected on the ground that Panopeus is some distance from the lake, whereas Haliartus and Onchestus are near it. The objection would be hypercritical, even if the geography of the hymn were otherwise strictly accurate; see on 240. The road from Athens to Delphi by Panopeus seems to have been a sacred way; see Frazer on Paus.x. 4. 3.

*prose/bhs=a)ne/bhs, as often. The verb is followed by a direct acc. in Homer; so in 520, h. Herm. 99. Mommsen, quoted by Gemoll, calls the construction prosbai/nein pro/s prosaic; cf., however, O. C. 125 (with e)s).
qu/wn: a forcible word expressing violent motion. Hermann's qei/wn and other emendations are no improvement.
*parn*hso\n *nifo/enta: Baumeister compares Panyasis (ap. Paus.x. 8. 9), Callim. h. Del. 93. For the situation of Crisa, which is correctly described, see Frazer on Paus.x. 37. 5.
kn*hmo/n: only plur. in Homer.
tekm/hrato with inf. is postHomeric; cf. Apoll. Arg. 4.559 (nosth/sein).
a)/r): a)/n here rests upon xp, and cannot be defended by 252, since k) there is only Ilgen's conjecture.

*nhw=|: bwmw= p (but in 253 nhw=| without variant). The same variant occurs in Od. 6.162 bwmw=| codd. naw=| de soll. an. 283 E and in Apollod. ap. schol. O. C. 56. Here nhw=| is necessary (with xre/wn e)ni/), and bwmw=| may be due to z; the altar must have preceded the temple. See Frazer on Paus.i. 30. 2.

Building of Apollo's temple. On Delphi and the temple see Homolle B. C. H. xx. p. 641, 677, 703, xxi. p. 256, Pomtow Rhein. Mus. li. p. 329 f., Philippson and Hiller von Gärtringen in Pauly-Wissowa 2517 f.

Of the first temple, burned in ol.58. 1(=B.C. 548), and rebuilt by the Alcmaeonids (see Pauly-Wissowa 2550 f.), no traces have been found, nor any sign of a conflagration. The site was not the same as that of the later temple, but nearer the temple of Ge and the Muses.

The families have each diverged from the parallel line 255, M taking kala/ for makra/, and xp diampere/s for dihneke/s. So in Od. 12.436 kaloi\ for makroi\ is quoted by Apoll. Lex.diampere/s may be a correction of dihneke/s, which as an adverb is not Homeric, though it occurs in Alexandrine verse.

Either this passage, or the Telegonia of Eugammon (Kinkel Ep. gr. fragm. i. p. 57) is the first mention of Trophonius and Agamedes as early builders; see Kern in Pauly-Wissowa art. “Agamedes.” For other accounts of their parentage and relationship see Paus.ix. 37. 3, Charax ap. schol. Nub. 508=F. H. G. iii. p. 637. They occupy a position in architecture similar to that of Daedalus in sculpture. For buildings attributed to them cf. Paus.viii. 10. 2(wooden temple of Poseidon), id. ix. 11. 1 (qa/lamos of Alcmena), l.c. (golden treasury of Augeas, or of Hyrieus, at Elis; and, by Trophonius, his own shrine at Lebadia).

According to Paus.x. 5. 9 f. it was the fourth temple that was built by Trophonius and Agamedes. The hymnwriter knows nothing of the later Delphian tradition that the earliest temple was of laurel-wood, the second of bees' wax and wings, and the third of bronze.

la/i+*non ou)do/n: the ou)do/s built by the sons of Erginus is here distinguished from the nho/s built by “the tribes of men” (298). The ou)do/s may therefore be the adytum as opposed to the cella; cf. Byz. Steph. *delfoi/: e)/nqa to\ a)/duton kateskeu/astai e)k pe/nte li/qwn, e)/rgon *trofwni/ou kai\ *)agamh/dous. Probably, however, the two architects laid the first courses (ou)do/s) of the whole temple, on the plan traced by Apollo; the building was then finished by other workmen. In this case a)mfi/ (298) would mean “all round,” i.e. over the whole of the foundations. la/i+nos ou)do/s is applied to the temple at Pytho in Il. 9.404 , *q 80; in the latter passage, at all events, ou)do/s must be the threshold (u(pe/rbh la/i+non ou)do/n).
For the building of the temple by Trophonius and Agamedes cf. also Pind. ap. Plutarch. consol. ad Apollon. 14, [Plato] Axioch. 367 C, Strabo 421, Cic. Tusc.i. 47.
*)ergi/nou: the “workman” or “builder.”

fi/loi a)qana/toisi qeoi=sin: Baumeister refers to the story of their death, caused by Apollo in answer to their prayer for a reward after building the temple. Plutarch op. cit. relates the similar story of Cleobis and Bito.
e)/nassan: only here in the sense of “build.” The causal use is rare and confined to the epic aorist; cf. Od. 4.174 kai/ ke/ oi( *)/argei+ na/ssa po/lin, “gave as a home.”

ktistoi=sin: apparently “wrought.” Empedocles (139) uses ktisto/s of trees, but it is very doubtful whether kti/zw could be applied to the material of a temple. cestoi=sin and r(utoi=sin are graphically impossible; in J. H. S. xvii. p. 249 tuktoi=sin was suggested.
a)oi/dimon e)/mmenai ai)ei/: the temple was therefore standing at the time (see Introd. p. 67).

300-304. The slaying of the dragon. If the account of Typhaon is an insertion (see on 305 f.) line 304 would be naturally followed by 356. The episode of the dragon is doubtless part of the original myth; but the hymn-writer turns it to account, in order to explain the supposed etymology of puqw/ (372 f.), which he may have himself invented (Pauly-Wissowa 2527).

The dragon is now generally supposed to represent an earlier Pythian cult, dispossessed by Apollo. As a snake is regularly the symbol or actual embodiment of earth-deities, it is probable that it here stands for the older cult of Gaea (followed, according to some ancient traditions, by that of Themis). For this early oracle of Pytho cf. Aesch. Eum.2th\n prwto/mantin *gai=an, Paus.x. 5. 5fasi\ ga\r dh\ ta\ a)rxaio/tata *gh=s ei)=nai to\ xrhsth/rion, Plutarch de Pyth. or. 17. 402 C, I. T. 1245 f. See e.g. Preller-Robert i. p. 240 n. 1, Pauly-Wissowa 2529, Harrison in J. H. S. xix. p. 222 f. The snake was no doubt originally the giver of the oracle (Miss Harrison compares the oracular snake at Epirus, de nat. anim. xi. 2), and afterwards became merely the guardian of the well; for the latter idea cf. l.c. 1249, Paus.x. 6. 6e)pi\ tw=| mantei/w| fu/laka u(po\ *gh=s teta/xqai, Apollod.i. 4. 3o( frourw=n to\ mantei=on *pu/qwn o)/fis e)kw/luen ktl. In later times the Python reappears as profh/ths; cf. Hyg. fab.140, Hesych. and Suid. s.v. pu/qwn, Lucian astrol. 23. On the grave of the Python see Harrison l.c. p. 225 f.
For the common idea that the water of a spring or well is guarded by a serpent see Frazer on Paus.ix. 10. 5.In many cases, of course, there is no suggestion that the snake was oracular, as at Delphi.

The conflict between a dragon or other monster and a god, hero, or saint is too wide a subject for discussion in a note. Here, again, the causes of the myth may be various; see Crooke (“The Legends of Krishna” in Folk-Lore xi. p. 11 f.) who accepts the view that the Pythian myth represents a conflict of cults. The subject is exhaustively discussed by Hartland Legend of Perseus (in iii. p. 66 f. he rejects the common theory that these stories are traditions of gigantic saurians). It may be conceded that some cases are pure nature-myths (e.g. the struggle of Indra with Ahi or Vitra).

kr/hn*h: the identification of the fountain is not clear. The editors assume that it is the Castalian spring, for the situation of which see Frazer on Paus.x. 8. 9.The great fame of this spring and its close connexion with Apollo make it probable that it would be regarded as the scene of the conflict with the dragon. Frazer, on the other hand, identifies the krh/nh with the spring called Cassotis by Pausanias (x. 24. 7), which is just above the temple, or with another fountain, below the temple (see his notes on x. 24. 7 and x. 12. 1).

dra/kainan: the fem. form is not Homeric. The poet follows what is doubtless the original myth, in which Apollo, like George St., kills a nameless “dragon” or “worm.” In I. T. 1245 (poikilo/nwtos oi)nwpo\s dra/kwn), Paus.x. 6. 5 the monster is still unnamed, but its sex has changed to the male. This, as Miss Harrison suggests (l.c. p. 222) may be due to a desire to provide Apollo with a worthier foe; but the present passage proves her to be wrong in supposing that the change of sex probably originated “at the coming of Apollo” (to Delphi). The confusion of sex persisted when names were given to the dragon in later times: the most usual name was *pu/qwn (first in the euhemeristic version of Ephorus, Strabo 646; cf. Paus.x. 6. 5 f.) as in Apollod.i. 4. 3, Clearchus ap. Athen. 701 C (=F. H. G. ii. 318); for other references, see Preller-Robert i. p. 239 n. 2. Other names were *delfu/nh (fem.) or *delfu/nhs (masc.): in Apoll. Arg. 2.705, Dion. xiii. 28 the gender is doubtful; possibly the masc. is a fiction of grammarians; but see Kern in PaulyWissowa s.v. *delfu/nhs. According to the schol. on Apoll. l.c. Callimachus (fr. 364) used the feminine, which the scholiast thinks more correct; so Perieg. 442. On the name generally see de Witte Le Monstre gardien de l'oracle de Delphes.

305-355. The episode of Typhaon is reasonably suspected by most commentators, as foreign to the context. The connexion of the dra/kaina with Typhaon is very forced; nothing is said about the fate of this monster, for it is the dragon that is slain by Apollo, 356 f. The passage should not be called a “later addition,” for, as Farnell (Cults i. p. 183) remarks it is “a genuine though a misplaced fragment.” The snake-form of Typhoeus (see PrellerRobert i. p. 65 n. 1) would help to associate or confuse him with the dragon. In Apollod.i. 42Delphyne aids Typho against Zeus.

*tufa/ona: so 352, but in 367 *tufweu/s. The two names are confused in Theog. 306 (Typhaon), 821, 869 (Typhoeus). *tufw/s and *tufw/n are other forms; see Preller-Robert i. p. 63. For his parentage cf. E. M. p. 772. 50 *(hsi/odos au)to\n gh=s genealogei=, *sthsi/xoros de\ *(/hras mo/nhs kata\ mnhsikaki/an *dio\s tekou/shs au)to/n. It is to be noticed that the E. M. quotes Stesichorus, not the Homeric hymn (see Pref. p. liii). So the schol. on Apoll. Arg. 4.1310 quotes Stesichorus as the first to describe the birth of Athena full-armed. He neglects xxvii. The parentage here given is evidently later than the Hesiodean account, from which, however, the author of the hymn is not altogether free, as Hera asks for a son from Earth and Heaven and the Titans, but especially from the Earth (cp. 340 f.). On the connexion of Hera and Typhoeus see Farnell Cults i. p. 183 f., who rightly explains it as due to the character of Hera, the jealous goddess of the epic drama. She is not here to be regarded as a Chthonian deity. So Hera nourished (qre/ye) the Lernaean Hydra and the Nemean lion, in her wrath against Zeus ( Theog. 314, 323). There was a *tufao/nion near Thebes, Scut. 32.
h(/nex) M (which the scribe saw was a mistake) is not for ou(/neka, but h(ni/ka, as in Od. 22.198.
e)*n koruf*=|h: Barnes' e)k korufh=s has been generally accepted; cf. Theog. 924, xxviii. 5. But e)k korufh=s implies e)n korufh=|, which may therefore stand.

The birth of Athena from the head of Zeus is Homeric (Il. 5.875, 880). Homer, it is true, does not mention the head, but Il. 5.880 e)pei\ au)to\s e)gei/nao almost certainly refers to the myth. It is quite in the Homeric manner to pass over in silence the most irrational and grotesque part of the myth. See Lang Myth Ritual and Religion ii. p. 242 f., Farnell Cults i. p. 280 f. Cf. further on xxvii. (Introd.).
311=Il. 8.5 , *t 101. qe/ainai: in Homer only in this phrase; cf. Il. 8.20 , q 341. Callimachus, however, uses the word without qeo/s; cf. h. Art. 29.

Compare the similar passage Od. 8.308 f. w(s e)me\ xwlo\n e)o/nta . . . ai)e\n a)tima/zei. The writer, as Gemoll observes, had a reminiscence of the passage in *q. So h)pedano/s (316) is taken from Il. 8.311.

*prw=tos: apparently for pro/teros; cf. Il. 4.67 a)/rcwsi pro/teroi. Baumeister compares Il. 13.502 , *s 92, but in neither case is the exact force of prw=tos certain (see Leaf ad locc.). e)*pei/ must be elliptical “(as he should not do) since I am his wife.” See L. and S. s.v. Il. 2.4.

r(ikno/s: not Homeric; cf. Apoll. Arg. 1.669 , *b 198. The lameness of Hephaestus is accounted for by Aen.viii. 414quia per naturam numquam rectus est ignis. Modern mythologists of the older school have accepted the explanation (e.g. Preller-Robert i. p. 175). It seems more reasonable to suppose that, as the trade of the smith was particularly suited to the lame, the divine smith was himself imagined to be lame. The Norse Völundur and the Teutonic Wieland were lame.

o(\n te/kon au)t/h: an emphatic amplification of pai=s e)mo/s, “my very own child.” There are two traditions as to the parentage of Hephaestus: according to Theog. 927 Hera was his sole parent, having borne him to avenge herself for the birth of Athena. Matthiae assumed that the hymn followed this version, and translated au)th/ “alone.” But Franke replied that in this case Hera would have already been even with Zeus, without the birth of the monster. Clearly the hymn adopts the other version, that Hephaestus was the son of Zeus, as well as of Hera (Il. 14.338); he speaks of two parents also in Od. 8.312, a passage probably in the poet's mind (cf. n. on 312 supra). On the birth of Hephaestus see Usener Rhein. Mus. 1901 p. 180 f.

After this line a lacuna, as Demetrius saw, seems required. It could indeed be avoided, by placing a full stop at au)th/, and taking r(i/y) as an asyndeton; the abruptness might be thought to suit Hera's rage (cf. h. Dem. 227). But the style would be so extremely harsh that this view is unlikely. The words o(\n te/kon au)th/ are not to be touched, and to read de/ for a)na/ in 318 (with the correction of *g followed by Abel) is to give up the problem. In J. H. S. xv. p. 278 a line was suggested ai)=sxos e)moi\ kai\ o)/neidos e)n ou)ranw=|, o(/n te kai\ au)th/, it being there assumed that the line was lost through assonance; but of course such lacunae may be due to other causes.

With regard to the fall of Hephaestus there are again two versions, both Homeric: in Il. 1.590 he is thrown from heaven by Zeus; in Il. 14.395 this is done by Hera, in disgust at his lameness. (So Paus.i. 20. 3, Mythogr. Graec. ed. Westermann p. 372.) The latter account is followed by the hymn; cf. also on 319.
In Il. 18.395 Hephaestus is saved by Eurynome and Thetis. *nhr=hos quga/thr: cf. Theog. 244. This line is repeated by Conr. Att. 33 (h)=lqe de/).

xari/ssasqai: the aorist is more appropriate than the present; the fact that the double s hardly occurs in this word is scarcely an objection, since aorists in -ss- are common (e.g. fra/ssasqai 415), and there is authority for e)xari/ssato in an inscr. ap. Preger 126. 3 (fifth cent.).

Cf. Od. 13.293 sxe/tlie, poikilomh=ta. mhti/seai: it is difficult to see why mh/seai has been generally preferred by editors. mhti/seai is supported by 325a, h. Dem. 345, and is Homeric; mh/seai may be a graphical corruption, MH(TI)CEAI, and e)/ti was added by p, perhaps from Od. 11.474. There is no objection to mh/seai in itself; cf. oracl. ap. Hendess 14. 4 ti/ nu mh/seai w)= mega/le *zeu=;
