Editors, after Demetrius, have read h)=n a)/r), as third person; “even if I had borne her, she would have been called thy daughter.” The sense is excellent, but there are two serious objections: (1) ken or a)/n would be required, (2) the MSS. are unanimous in reading h)= (with variations of accent). This can hardly be the Attic 1st person; we must rather read h)=a/ r() e)n with Matthiae. Cf. Hartel Hom. Stud. i. 73. If Hermann's objection to r() is valid (r() does not seem to be used after a vowel which can be elided), it would be possible to write h)=) a)/r. “I was called, at all events, yours in heaven,” i.e. “I had at least the title of your wife, (although I have been neglected).” keklh=sqai here seems to be emphatic, not merely an equivalent of ei)=nai as it is in Il. 4.60=Il. 18.365 ou(/neka sh\ para/koitis ke/klhmai, which, however, may have been the origin of the present passage. sh/ may be said of a wife as well as of a daughter, although a)/loxos or a similar word is usual; cf. Il. 3.138, h. Aphr. 148, h. Dem. 79.

325a was omitted in Mxp, possibly on account of its resemblance to 326. This is perhaps enough to decide in favour of M's reading of that line kai\ nu=n me/n toi, between which and p's kai\ nu=n toi ga\r there is little to choose. Cf. Il. 22.358 fra/zeo nu=n mh/ toi/ ti qew=n mh/nima ge/nwmai.

ou)=sa: the form occurs in xix. 32 (w)/n), xxix. 10 (w)/n), but both hymns are no doubt later. In h. Herm. 106 the reading is uncertain. Here Hermann is perhaps right in correcting thlo/q' e)ou=sa, cf. Il. 8.285 , *f 154 etc. See Agar in J. P. xxviii. (1901) p. 78. A difficulty has been found in the line: according to the text, Hera threatens to be “far from Zeus,” but to mingle with the other gods (mete/ssomai). Yet she departs from the gods 331, and spends a year in her temples. In the seclusion of his own temple a deity was thought to be withdrawn from all intercourse with fellow-gods; cf. h. Dem. 304, where Demeter stays for a year in her temple maka/rwn a)po/nosfin a(pa/ntwn. Hence Gemoll reads kote/ssomai; other emendations are less satisfactory. However, mete/ssomai may very well be sound; Hera certainly has some relations with the other gods, for she leaves Zeus to invoke Gaia, Uranos, and the Titans; and a)po\ sei=o is the only emphatic part of her threat. In any case, if there is strictly a contradiction in 330 and 347, it may be due to the author's carelessness.
a)*po/nosfi: a)po\ no/sfi is preferred by many editors for Homer; see La Roche Hom. Unters. i. p. 88.

xwome/n*h *per: Barnes, followed by recent editors, emended per to kh=r, as per is commonly joined to participles in an adversative or concessive force. But the original sense of per must have been “very”=dh/; cf. the Latin per-, and peri/. As Leaf on Il. 1.131 remarks, the sense of “though” properly belongs to the participle itself, not to per; see also van Leeuwen Ench.p. 586. For the use in strengthening a participle cf. Il. 23.79 geino/meno/n per “at my very birth,” Od. 17.13 , r 47 (where schol. H notes to\ pe/r a)nti\ tou= dh/), and perhaps Od. 1.314. Similarly per strengthens an adjective, as Il. 24.504 e)leeino/tero/s per, or an adverb, as Il. 1.416 mi/nunqa/ per “quite a short time.” The editors have been misled by the fact that the use is un-

xeiri\ kataprh*nei==Il. 16.792 , n 164. The Homeric formula explains the position of de/ (Hermann). e)/lase xqo/na: to call the attention of the gods below: the action shews that her prayer is really addressed to Earth and the Titans, although she calls upon all the powers of Nature, including Heaven. For this manner of invoking chthonian deities or ghosts cf. Il. 9.568 , *c 272 f., Aesch. Pers.674 f., Troad. 1293 f., Plat. Crat. 423A, Plutarch Moral. 774 B, v. Soph. ii. 1. 10, Diog. Laert.vii. 26, Anth. Pal. vii. 117, Coluth.47 f., Cic. Tusc.ii. 25. 60, Livy vii. 6. 4, Aesch. Theb.54 f., Val. Flacc. vii. 312, Macrob. Sat. iii. 9. 12; Sittl Gebärden p. 190 f., Rohde Psyche p. 111, 693, Headlam in Class. Rev. xvi. 53.
For modern times cf. Lang Transl. Hom. Hymns; “the action was practised by the Zulus in divination, and, curiously, by a Highlander of the last century, appealing to the dead Lovat” (p. 121).

moi: the dative is defended by Il. 5.115 , *k 278, *w 335, Theognis 4 and 13, Solon 13. 2, Hom. Epigr.xxi. 1.So a)kou/ein with dat. Il. 16.515. The dat. expresses the idea of “turning a favourable ear to,” and is used in prayer to a god. H. G. § 143 n. 3.
*tit=hne/s te qeoi/: the addition of qeoi/ is common (in Il. 14.279 oi(\ *tith=nes kale/ontai follows qeou\s tou\s u(potartari/ous): cf. Theog. 424, 630, 648, 668, 729.

toi\ . . *naieta/ontes: toi/ is of course a relative pronoun. Matthiae explains the construction intended as toi\ . . . naieta/ontes a)/ndras te qeou/s te e)fu/sate. Ilgen's naieta/ousin is quite impossible. Peppmüller with greater probability assumes a lacuna, suggesting the Hesiodean line h(/at' e)p' e)sxati/h| mega/lhs e)n pei/rasi gai/hs, which follows u(po\ xqoni\ naieta/ontes in Theog. 622. But we may regard the sentence as an example of the analytic conjugation with ei)=nai (for which see Kühner-Gerth i. § 353 n. 3), with the auxiliary ei)si/n omitted; for this latter use cf. Hes. Op.357, Scut. 302, P. V. 568, Pers.1000, Eur. Ion517, I. T. 194, 208.

tw=n e)\c a)/ndres te qeoi/ te: cf. Hes. Op.107w(s o(mo/qen gega/asi qeoi\ qnhtoi/ t' a)/nqrwpoi, where, however, the Titans are not mentioned; in Pind. Nem.vi. 1e(\n a)ndrw=n e(\n qew=n ge/nos, e)k mia=s de\ pne/omen matro\s a)mfo/teroi, the mother is Earth, who bare the Titans. Cf. also Orph. h. xxxvii. 1 f. *tith=nes, *gai/hs te kai\ *ou)ranou= a)glaa\ te/kna,
div2.l: h)mete/rwn pro/gonoi pate/rwn. See Mayer die Giganten p. 57.

div2.p: au)toi/: the emphatic pronoun may be resumptive, after the parenthesis; or it may mark a contrast between the gods of Olympus, whom Hera neglects, and the chthonian powers. Gemoll's au)tou= nu=n gives a very doubtful meaning to au)tou= in Homer (in Il. 15.349 it is local not temporal). Peppmüller's au)ti/ka would not have been corrupted to au)toi/.

e)/stw: Hermann's ei)/h is perfect in sense, but e)/stw is nearer to e)stin in M, which has certainly kept the original in o(/son, and may have done so, approximately, in e)stin. For the confusion cf. Il. 10.41 e)/stai e)sti ei)/h, *l 366 e)sti ei)/h h)=.
i(/mase: a vivid word, stronger than e)/lase in 333. Cf. Il. 2.782 gai=an i(ma/ssh|, *i 568 gai=an polufo/rbhn xersi\n a)loi/a, Theog. 857 au)ta\r e)pei\ dh/ min da/mase plhgh=|sin i(ma/ssas.

kin/hqh: Typhaon is in some mysterious way the child of Earth, though actually borne by Hera. In other legends, similar monsters are only “nursed” by Hera, in her jealousy; and it is possible that there was an older myth of an earth-born Typhaon, nursed by Hera (see on 306), unless the whole of this myth is the invention of the poet.
fere/sbios; un-Homeric, but five times in the hymns, and in Theog. 693. It is quoted as Homeric (par' *(omh/rw|) by Apollodorus ap. schol. Genevens. Il. 21.341; see Preface p. l.

i)dou=sa: M's reading allows the digamma; in 255, however, M agrees with the other MSS. in neglecting it (e)sidou=sa). For similar alterations, due to a desire of scribes to avoid (supposed) hiatus, see J. H. S. xv. p. 279, and (from papyri) Il. 23.198 w)ke/a d' *)=iris for w)=ka de\ *)=iris, *z 493 pa=sin, e)moi\ de\ ma/lista toi\ *)ili/w| for pa=si, ma/lista d' e)moi\ toi\ *)ili/w| (as Epict. iii. 22. 108).
telesfo/ron ei)s e)*niauto/n: see on xx. 6.

Baumeister, Gemoll, Abel eject the verse, which Hermann also suspected. But ei)s qw=kon may very well depend on e)fezome/nh; the preposition takes the place of the regular dative with e)fe/zesqai owing to the idea of motion, “coming to sit.” Possibly we should take h)/luqe with ei)s qw=kon, and fraze/sketo with w(s to\ pa/ros per (removing the comma). The objection to this, as Hermann noted, is that w(s to\ pa/ros per is properly used without a verb; but cf. Od. 19.340 kei/w d' w(s to\ pa/ros per a)u+/pnous nu/ktas i)/auon.
*polulli/stoisi: cf. h. Dem. 28. The similarity between the two passages is striking; te/rpeto oi<*>=s i)eroi=si 348= de/gmenos i(era\ kala/ h. Dem. 29.

=Od. 11.294 f., Od. 14.293 f., where the MSS. give mh=nes, a hysteron proteron. nu/ktes is less effective, of the passing of a year, and introduces the unessential contrast of light and dark. Cf. Theog. 58 a)ll' o(/te dh/ r() e)niauto\s e)/hn peri\ d' e)/trapon w(=rai,
div2.l: mhnw=n fqino/ntwn, peri\ d' h)/mata po/ll' e)tele/sqh.

div2.p: Cf. Theog. 295 f. h( d' e)/tek' a)/llo pe/lwron a)mh/xanon ou)de\ e)oiko\s
div2.l: qnhtoi=s a)nqrw/pois ou)d' a)qana/toisi qeoi=si. Gemoll suggests that the reminiscence of Hesiod accounts for the introduction of de/ in the hymn, where it is used in apodosi.
div2.p: The assonance at the end of 351, 352 did not trouble the author of this hymn; cf. 230, 231 and 537, 538.
kakw=|; i.e. to the dra/kaina, who acts as the foster-mother.

Nothing more is said of Typhaon. If lines 305-355 had been original in their present context, we should have expected an account of his fate; instead of this, the poem returns to the dragoness, by a very abrupt transition (355-356).
fe/reske/ min: “would carry him off.” The use of fe/rein with h)=mar is more metaphorical than in the older epic, where the kh=res literally carry off a doomed man; cf. Il. 2.302 , *i 411, c 207.
On the indicative after pri/n, of which this line is the earliest instance, see Sturm, Schanz's Beiträge zur historischen Syntax ii. 47.
e)*nop/h: the noise of the writhing dragoness (cf. kulindome/nh . . . e(li/sseto). The word is used of various inarticulate noises, as well as of the human voice; see L. and

lei=pe de\ qumo/n: suspicion of the text is quite unwarranted. Various emendations are mentioned by Gemoll. In Homer qumo/s would have been the subject, but the text is justified by Pind. Pyth.iii. 180(quoted by Matthiae) to/cois a)po\ yuxa\n lipw/n; Verg. Aen.iii. 140linquebant dulces animas.

foino/n: in Homer only Il. 16.159 parh/i+on ai(/mati foino/n, “blood-red.” So probably here; “she left her soul, breathing it forth blood-red.” The rhythm shews that foino/n is to be taken closely with a)popnei/ous). The soul is thought to pass out with the blood from the wound; Ilgen well compares Verg. Aen.xi. 349purpuream vomit ille animam. Others translate “murderous,” in which sense foino/s is used in late epic: Nicand. Ther.140 Ther. 675; so dafoino/s in Scut. 250. Ruhnken took foino/n to be a subst., as in Nicand. Alex. 187, “breathing forth blood.” But the object of a)popnei/ousa is almost certainly qumo/n, cf. Il. 4.524=Il. 13.654 qumo\n a)popnei/wn.
e)*phu/cato: usually altered to e)peu/cato, as, according to Moeris p. 175, the augment in this word is
e)*ntauqoi= *nu=n: u(bristikw=s, to a conquered foe; cf. Il. 21.122 , s 105, u 262. So e)ntau=qa nu=n in Attic; P. V. 82, Vesp. 149, Thesm. 1001, Plut. 724.
zwoi=si: the phrase zwo\s broto/s occurs in Od. 23.187, so that zwoi=si may stand here as an amplification of brotoi=si. Ilgen's correction zw/ousa has been generally accepted.

dushlege/): cf. Il. 20.154 (po/lemos), Od. 22.325 (qa/nato/n ge dushlege/a, as here); Theog. 652, Op.506; on the derivation see Leaf on Il. 20.154 (probably from a)/lgos with e developed from the liquid, and h due to the ictus).

*tufweu/s: this form for *tufa/wn is in itself no proof of different authorship (see on 306); but it may be noted that the author of the fragment 305-352 uses only the form *tufa/wn. M's *tufwneu\s is a mixture of *tufweu/s and *tufw/n, and as Baumeister notes is not justified by the mistaken or corrupt gloss of Hesych. *tufwnei= ( leg.*tufwei=).

*xi/maira: daughter of Typhaon and Echidna in Theog. 306, 319. Gemoll suggests that the dra/kaina may here be identified with Echidna, Chimaera being thus the daughter of Typhoeus and the dra/kaina. Possibly Chimaera is simply mentioned as a similar monster, who might be expected to help the dragon.

*)hle/ktwr *(uperi/wn=Il. 19.398 (h)le/ktwr alone, Il. 6.513). The phrase is evidently very ancient, h)le/ktwr being an archaic title of the sun. Curtius' etymology (cf. Sansk.arkas, the sun) may stand; h)/lektron is certainly cognate, In Emped. 263 h)le/ktwr=fire, as an element.
i(ero\n me/nos is a necessary correction, being the Homeric phrase; the corrupt i(/meron is difficult to explain, but cf. F. L. (ii.) ch. 10 i(erei/as with v.l. ap. schol. *(imerai/as.
*puqw/: for this etymology see Paus.x. 6. 5(quoted on 300). Later, the word was connected with pu^qe/sqai; cf. O. T. 603 *puqw=d' i)w\n
div2.l: puqou= ta\ xrhsqe/nt), Apollod. ap. Strabon. 419, Plutarch de EI 2. The real derivation cannot be recovered; but it may refer to some local peculiarity, perhaps in the stone; Mommsen (Delph. p. 14) compares the Swiss Faulhorn. *puqw/ is here the place, not, as Franke and Baumeister supposed, the dragon (*pu/qwn), which is nameless in the poem (see on 300).

div2.p: *pu/qion kale/ousin: this appears to be unmetrical; in Pind. Ol.xiv. 16*pu/qion corresponds to ko/lpoisi in the antistrophe; Ahrens reads *puqw=|on, but in any case the syllabic correspondence is unnecessary (see the metrical analysis in Christ l.c.). The simplest correction would be *pu/qeion (which form is however doubtful, and is hardly supported by de/lfeios 496 as the latter is probably corrupt); so Schulze Quaest. Ep. p. 254 (accented *puqei=on). In Anth. Pal. x. 17 th\n e)pi\ *puqei/ou r(u/eo nautili/hn, *puqei/ou is apparently a place; cf. Suid. *puqei=on: to\ mantiko/n, E. M. 696 *pu/qeia kai\ *puqai=os: o)/noma e(orth=s *)agame/mnonos tw=| *)apo/llwni. Schneidewin suggests *puqw=|on, a form attested by Byz.Steph. , like *lhtw=|os, *sapfw=|os. *puqai=os has little authority (C. I. G. 1877 of a stream, and in E. M. l.c.). But *pu/qios is the regular and official title, prevailing in literature and inscriptions (see PaulyWissowa 65 f.), and seems most suitable here; Danielsson p. 58 n. 4 defends *pu/qion with z Hermann prefers *pu/qion a)gkale/ousin.
kei=qi au)tou=, “on that very spot.” Baumeister compares Od. 10.271 su\ me/n' au)tou= tw=|d' e)ni\ xw/rw|, a passage which justifies au)tou= following kei=qi. Cf. also h. Herm. 169 and note.
me/nos ktl.= Hes. Op.414.

kai\ to/t) ktl. Apollo realised the nymph's treachery after he had seen and killed the dragon. The “deceit” of course lay in her advice to choose Pytho. She presumably knew that this was the home of the dragon, and hoped that the monster would overcome Apollo, and relieve her of a rival, of whom she was jealous (275 f., 381).

*prore/ein: the transitive use, though rare, seems established by Apoll. Arg. 3.225 h( d' a)/r' u(/dwr prore/eske, Orph. Arg. 1137. Barnes' proxe/ein is supported by 241, Il. 21.219; the two words are variants in Il. 21.366.

*pe/tr|hsi *proxut*=|hsin: not governed by e)pi/, but a dative of circumstance: “pushed a crag over, with a shower of stones.” Such a shower would naturally follow the dislodgement of a mass of earth or rock from an overhanging cliff. See J. H. S. xvii. p. 250 (after Matthiae). Ruhnken's emendation petrai/ais proxo/h|sin, “pushed a crag against the waters which fell from the rock,” is not to be adopted, although far better than Gemoll's r(o/on for r(i/on. There is a reminiscence of this passage in Callim. h. Del. 133 f.
a)lla/ oi( *)/arhs
paggai/ou proqe/lumna karh/ata me/llen a)ei/ras
e)mbale/ein di/nh|sin a)pokru/yein de\ r(e/eqra.

If (as Frazer on Paus.ix. 33. 1 supposes) Telphusa is to be identified with a spring which now issues from the foot of Mt. Telphusius (see on 244), a landslip would be probable enough, as the overhanging cliff, now called Petra, is very steep. The words a)*pe/kruyen de\ r(e/eqra are not to be pressed; the spring was not annihilated, but only “spoilt” (h)/|sxune 387) by the landslip.
e)fra/zeto: for the quantity of the first syllable see on h. Dem. 256.

o)rgi/onas: the form and accent are uncertain. The Attic nom. is o)rgew/n; Antimachus fr. 2 has an acc. o)rgi/wnas. The dat. o)rgeiw=ni in Hermesianax ap. Athen. 597 D is simply a correction (o)rgeiw=ni no/mw| Hermann for orgiwnanemwi). See W. Headlam in Class. Rev. Nov. 1901, p. 403, where the word is discussed at length; it is there suggested that o)rgeiw/n or o)rgi/wn is a metrical extension of o)rgew/n (cf. a)ndrw/n a)ndrew/n a)ndreiw/n). Headlam also argues that the proper Ionic accent of these words is paroxytone in the nominative; we might thus adopt the form and accent o)rgei/onas. Schulze Quaest. Ep. p. 255 also requires this, explaining o)rgei/onas as=*o)rgh/onas= Attic o)rgew=nas; so Fick B. B. xvi. p. 27. Gemoll also is inclined to reject o)rgi/onas.
a)/ra o(rmai/nwn: Schneidewin inserts o(/ g), to avoid the hiatus, which may be tolerated in this place.
The remark of the scribe of M i)/sws lei/pei sti/xos ei)=s was no doubt due to the corruption h)maqo/hn. It was rightly crossed out by the later hand, which corrected to nh=a qoh/n.

*kr=htes a)*po\ *knwsou=: the writer expressly localises the original home of the cult of Apollo delfi/nios in Crete. There was a temple of the god at Cnossus (C. I. G. ii. 2554, Il. 3.98) as delfi/nios. The cult is also testified by Cnossian inscriptions at Delos, where the form of the title is delfi/dios (B. C. H. iii. 293, iv. 355). There was a Cretan month Delphinius (B. C. H. iii. 293, C. I. G. ii. 2448), and a Delphinion at Drerus in Crete (Rhein. Mus. 1856, 393). See Preller-Robert i. p. 257 n. 4, Pauly-Wissowa “Apollon” 47, Wide Lakon. Kulte p. 87 f. For the supposed Cretan origin of the cult see on 495.

394-6. The transposition of these lines, with the futures r(e/cousi, a)ggele/ousi (first made by Matthiae), to follow 390 would be plausible but that 393 is left incomplete, which involves further violence. Moreover the present a)gge/llousi is well established by M and x, and the change of r(e/cousi to r(e/zousi is graphically almost imperceptible, and constant in MSS. of the Iliad. The lines may therefore stand as a parenthesis. Gemoll's parallel a 23, 24 is in point: the function of the Cretans as priests of Apollo is mentioned by anticipation.

*foi/bou *)apo/llwnos xrusao/rou =Il. 5.509. For the form xrusao/rou see on 123. The sword as an attribute of Apollo is unusual, at least in later times; hence arose the theory, which cannot be accepted, that the a)/or may be the sword-belt or even the lyre of Apollo (see schol. A on Il. 15.256). Apollo carries the sword in his contest with Tityos and in scenes from the gigantomachy; e.g. on the vase of Aristophanes and Erginus (Wiener Vorlegebl. i. 5); other references in Pauly-Wissowa “Apollon” 111. In early literature and archaic art the attributes of the various gods were less stereotyped than was afterwards the case. Even Demeter has the sword; cf. n. on h. Dem. 4.

e)k da/fn*hs: so Callim. h. Del. 94 a)po\ da/fnhs, perhaps a reminiscence. The precise allusion in e)k da/fnhs may be doubted; the tripods (see on 443) are perhaps meant: cf. schol. on Plut. 39 oi( tri/podes da/fnh| h)=san e)stemme/noi. Ilgen, with more probability, sees a reference to the laurel-tree which appears to have grown in the temple; cf. Plut. 213 *puqikh
 sei/sas da/fnhn and schol. fasi
 w(s plhsi/on tou= tri/podos da/fnh i(/stato h(
 h( *puqi/a, h(ni/ka e)xrhsmw/|dei, e)/seien. So the paean of Aristonous , xlwro/tomon da/fnan sei/wn, where the adjective implies that a cut branch was shaken. The laurel was closely connected with the Pythian cult; the first legendary temple was built of laurel ( Paus.x. 5. 5); there were branches at the entrance ( Eur. Ion80Eur. Ion, 103) and laurel-trees in the te/menos ( Eur. Ion76). The priestess of Apollo chewed laurel before delivering the oracles (Lucian Bis Acc.1, Tzetzes on Lycophr. 6), and fumigated herself with burning laurel before descending into the cavern (Plutarch de EI 2). Frazer on Paus.x. 5. 5 gives parallels for this fumigation. On the laurel see further Pauly-Wissowa “Apollon” 110, Preller-Robert i. pp. 285, 291, Murr die Pflanzenwelt in d. griech. Myth. pp. 92 f., Mannhardt B.K. p. 296.
*gua/lwn u(/po *parn*hsoi=o= Theog. 499 (gua/lois); similarly *parnassou= gua/lwn in the paean of Aristonous.
*puloigene/as: Fick's correction may be accepted; in Il. 2.54 pulhgene/os and puloigene/os are variants.
The Leprean Pylos is meant, as appears from 424.
delfi=ni e)oikw/s: stories of animals guiding people to a new town or country are very common; see Frazer's exhaustive note on Paus.x. 6. 2.For Apollo's connexion with the dolphin see on 495.

402, 403. The difficulty in these two lines is so great that Gemoll may be pardoned for giving up the passage as hopeless. We have first to decide between ou)/ tis . . . e)pefra/sato of M and and o(/s tis . . . e)pifra/ssaito of other MSS. The objection to the reading of M is that it is hard to understand how the sailors could have failed to see the dolphin, which lay on the deck; in fact lines 415 f. distinctly state the contrary. This seems to dispose of Matthiae's e)pefra/sat' ou)d' e)no/hse, apart from the graphical difficulty of that emendation. We must therefore accept o(/s tis e)pifra/ssaito noh=sai, which can mean “whoever thought to observe the dolphin.” e)pifra/zesqai takes an infinitive, Od. 5.183 e)pefra/sqhs a)goreu=sai. With this reading it would be just possible to dispense with the theory of a lacuna; we might understand “whoever observed him, him he threw down, and shook the ship.” The dolphin would upset any one who approached him. But pa/ntos' a)nassei/aske will hardly bear this interpretation. The verb seems to mean “shake up” or “shake to and fro,” and the object must be the ship or the dou=ra. Hermann's lacuna may therefore be accepted, the sense being “whoever saw the dolphin [tried to throw it overboard, but the monster] made [the ship] rock all ways”; e.g. we may supply a verse like e)kba/llein e)/qelen delfi=n), o( de\ nh=a me/lainan.
a)*nassei/aske is an anomalous form, but may be defended by Il. 8.272 kru/ptaske, *o 23 r(i/ptaskon, q 374 r(i/ptaske.

405, 406. The sailors were at first too much afraid to stop the ship, as they afterwards attempted to do (414). Hence e)/luon is right in both lines. The repetition of the verb, to which Baumeister objects, is not more offensive than that of nh=a, nho/s. Baumeister's e)/lkon would give a wrong sense, “hoist sail,” cf. Od. 2.426 , o 291; the sails were already set. e(/lkein could not mean “change sail,” as he explains.
lai=fos: not Homeric in this sense; cf. Alcaeus fr. 18. 7, for early poetry.

katest/hsanto, “fixed it,” sc. lai=fos. No precise parallel to this use occurs in Homer; but cf. Soph. El.710kate/sthsan di/frous, “they stationed the chariots.” So Od. 12.402 i(sto\n sthsa/menoi, “fixing the mast.”
e)/pleon: for the quantity of the first syllable see H. G. § 370. We are not to suppose a synizesis, with Hermann.

e)/peige: Ruhnken's correction, which is very slight, must be accepted, as the verb is constant in this connexion; Od. 12.167 (see note on 411), Soph. Phil.1443, Arg. Il. 4.1769. The exx. given of e)gei/rein in J. H. S. xvii. 250 refer to quasi-animate or material objects.

a)liste/fanon: Matthiae's correction *(/elos t' e)/falon, from Il. 2.584, is brilliant, and has been generally adopted; but it is hard to suppose a rare and poetical word, like a(liste/fanon, either the result of a corruption or the invention of a scribe. Moreover *(/elos is at the head of the Laconian gulf, and it is difficult to see why the *no/tos carried the ship first N. and then S. again to Taenarum instead of crossing the mouth of the gulf from point to point. This latter argument cannot, however, be pressed; for (1) the hymn-writer is careless on points of geographical accuracy (see 239 f., 419 f., 425), and (2) the ship might be said to pass Helos, even if it kept a fairly straight course from Malea to Taenarum.

With the manuscript reading, ptoli/eqron would refer to Taenarum: “first they went by Malea, and then past the Laconian land they arrived at the seagirt town and fields of the sun.” Paus.iii. 25. 9 mentions a town once called Taenarum, in his own day *kainh/polis, forty stades from the cape; so Byz. Steph. *tai/naros . . . a)f' ou)= kalei=tai h( po/lis kai\ h( a)/kra kai\ o( limh/n. The hymn-writer may either have identified the cape and town, or may refer to the town only. The epithet a(liste/fanos is true of the Taenarian peninsula; cf. Pind. Pyth.i. 18a(lierke/es o)/xqai, of Cumae, between two seas. The nearly identical a(listefh/s seems to have been common in hymnal literature; cf. Arg. 145, 186, 1208.
In favour of Matthiae's emendation, it should be noted that the hymn-writer is evidently familiar with the passage in B; cf. on 422, 423.
teryimbro/tou *)heli/oio=Od. 12.269, 274. In Homer the epithet occurs only in m, a part of the Odyssey no doubt familiar to the author; see n. on 408 (e)/peige) and below, 412.

412, 413. Groddeck quite unreasonably ejects these verses. There is no other record of the sacred flocks at Taenarum, but there were cults of Helios in various parts of Laconia, e.g. at Taleton (Taygetus) where horses were sacrificed, Paus.iii. 20. 4.Other reff. in Wide Lakon. Kulte p. 215 f. Herodotus (ix. 93) mentions sacred flocks of Apollo at Apollonia in Epirus. In any case, the author had in mind the herds and flocks of the Sun in Thrinacria, Od. 12.128 f. The subject is discussed by O. Müller Proll. pp. 224, 368; H. D. Müller Myth. ii. 338; v. Wilamowitz Hom. Unters. p. 168; Tümpel Lesbiaka i.; Philologus N. F. ii. 124 (quoted by Wide); PrellerRobert i.^{2} p. 430.

The meaning of the flocks or herds of the Sun has exercised commentators from the time of Eustathius, who gives Aristotle's explanation that they are an allegory of the lunar year (see Roscher Hermes p. 43 f.). Modern “solar” mythologists see a reference to physical phenomena—the clouds, or rays of the sun; see reff. in Preller-Robert i. p. 394, n. 1. That there is a physical basis to the idea of divine flocks, at least in the case of Helios, is very probable. The cattle of Apollo may also be “solar”; but it should be remembered that Apollo was the protector of all cattle, and, as *no/mios, he would naturally have his own peculiar herds. See further on h. Herm. 71.
For the harbour, where the Cretans wished to land, see Frazer on Paus.iii. p. 396, Weil Ath. Mitth. i. p. 160 f.
dape/doisi: only here, apparently, of a ship's deck. The plural (which does not occur in Homer) probably expresses the two decks, fore and aft (i)/kria).

*polui+/xquon: not in Homer, for i)xquo/eis. a)mfi/s: there is great difficulty in supposing that au)=qis (Pierson; au)=tis Hermann), one of the commonest words in Homer, could have been corrupted into the comparatively rare a)mfi/s. For the latter word the sense “apart,” “away” (Od. 22.57 , w 218, Apoll. Arg. 3.1070, oracl. ap. Herod.i. 85) is well established. There seems, however, to be no certain example of its use with a verb of motion, “to dart away”; but cf. Theog. 748 a)mfi\s i)ou=sai (paraphr. xwrizo/menai) with vv.ll.

This passage, together with the enumeration of Nestor 's possessions in the Catalogue (Il. 2.591-602) and the description of Telemachus' return-journey from Pylos to Ithaca (Od. 15.295-300) is the earliest authority for the geography of the W. coast of the Peloponnese. (Cf. also Il. 7.133 -5, *l 711 f., Pherecydes fr. 87.) Much of Strabo's seventh book (especially from 337 onwards) is taken up with identifying the Homeric sites. Strabo travelled through this country from N. to S. , Pausanias (ch. v.), who is less occupied with Homer, in the reverse direction. Many of the sites are uncertain, and one name, *)argufe/h, occurs only in the hymn.
The writer had little sense of relative position; Pylos, Cruni, and Chalcis were certainly S. of the Alpheus, but he mentions them after Thryon, and Dyme, though N. of Elis, appears before it.

e)/xousa, “holding on.” For this use cf. Od. 3.182 au)ta\r e)gw/ ge *pu/lond' e)/xon, where nh=a is the implied object; there is, however, no difficulty in making the ship itself the subject. Baumeister's e(kou=sa is misplaced.
o(do/n: cogn. acc. with h)/i+e, as in 233.
*)ar/hn*hn: from Il. 2.591, cf. Il. 11.722; for the place see Frazer on Paus. vol. iii. p. 481. Strabo 346 identifies it with *sa/mos or *samiko/n.

*)argufe/h does not occur in Il. 2.591 f. and is unknown. Ilgen wished to substitute *)amfige/neian (ib. 593), but the example of *au)toka/nh (see on 35) forbids alteration. On the etymology see Fick B. B. xxv. p. 123.
423=Il. 2.592 . *qru/on: cf. Strabo 349 kalei=tai de\ nu=n *)epita/lion th=s *makisti/as xwri/on. It is certainly identical with the *qruo/essa po/lis of Il. 11.711.
The singular mistake e)u+kti/menon for e)u+/ktiton is found in several MSS. of Il. 2.592, Q. Smyrn. xii. 91, and in all copies of the hymns, except M.
For *ai)=pu see Frazer on Paus. vol. iii. p. 476, who identifies it with the later *ai)/pion ( Herod.iv. 148); cf. also Strabo 349.

*pu/lon: the difficulty of identifying the Homeric Pylos is well-known; references are given by Leaf on Il. 2.591. It seems probable that in the present passage and in B the Triphylian Pylos is meant, as that place is near the Alpheus; cf. h. Herm. 398 e)s *pu/lon h)maqo/enta e)p' *)alfeiou= po/ron i(=con. Leaf objects that the epithet h)maqo/eis implies a situation on the sea-shore, whereas the Triphylian town was on a hill. The town, however, was not far from the sea. Strabo 344 explains the epithet by the nature of the coast below the Triphylian Pylos: qinw/dhs de\ kai\ steno/s e)stin o( th=s qala/sshs ai)gialo/s, w(/st' ou)k a)\n a)pognoi/h tis e)nteu=qen h)maqo/enta w)noma/sqai to\n *pu/lon. On the quicksands at Samicum see Paus.v. 5. 7, and 6. 3 dia\ xwri/ou ta\ plei/ona u(po/yammou, and for the actual condition of the coast Frazer Paus.vol. iii. p. 473 and 481. The whole of Triphylia may have been called Pylos from the chief town; see Strabo 339, and cf. Il. 5.545 *)alfeiou= o(/s t' eu)ru\ r(e/ei *puli/wn dia\ gai/hs.

Strabo in two places (350, 447), speaking of the return journey of Telemachus from Pylos, quotes a line ba\n de\ para\ *krounou\s kai\ *xalki/da kallire/eqron (in 447 petrh/essan). This line is not in any MS. of the Odyssey, where it should naturally come before Od. 15.296 or (see Monro ad loc.) after 297. Strabo throughout ignores the hymns, and says that *du/mh is not in Homer (Strabo 341). There is therefore the less reason to suppose that he is quoting this hymn; in view of the recent additions in papyri, he probably read the line in a copy of the Odyssey. Cf. Preface p. liv.

For *krounou/s and *xalki/da see Strabo 343, 351, where he calls them o)xetoi/ rather than rivers (like the Iardanus of Il. 7.135 which he styles a pota/mion 342). They were small streams (Chalcis was also a katoiki/a) in the district of Macistia S. of the mouth of the Alpheus, and seem to have been obliterated by the lagoon which now stretches from the Alpheus past Macistus, part of which (that formed by the Anigrus at Arene) is mentioned by Strabo 347, Frazer Paus.vol. iii. p. 478.
*du/mh*n: the Achaean Dyme is mentioned out of its proper place. The ship would of course pass it after Elis. The author again disregards the proper sequence of landmarks; cf. on 239 f.
426, 427. In the Odyssey these lines stand in the reverse order; in 427 the Homeric MSS. have h( de\ instead of eu)=te, and e)peigome/nh for a)gallome/nh.

*)epeioi/: the old name for the inhabitants of Elis; Il. 2.619 , *l 688 (but in Il. 11.671 *)hlei/oisi), etc. Cf. Strabo 340 u(/steron a)nti\ *)epeiw=n *)hlei=oi e)klh/qhsan. The change of name has been thought to be due to the Dorian and Aetolian invasion.
eu)=te: for the asyndeton see on 115.

*fera/s: in Od. 15.297 Aristarchus and Strabo (350) read *fea/s; nearly all the MSS. read *fera/s, as here. Monro accepts *fea/s, identifying the place with the *feia/ of Il. 7.135 (where, however, Didymus after Pherecydes read *fhra=s, schol. A ad loc.), Thuc.ii. 25.Pheia is N. of the prominent headland Ichthys (Katákolo), and would be a natural landmark. It is, however, S. of Elis; so that, by adopting the reading of Aristarchus, we should be charging the author with another geographical inaccuracy. Gemoll wisely retains *fera/s, as there may very well have been a place of that name in W. Greece, as well as in Thessaly (Il. 2.710 , d 798). Byz. Steph. s.v. mentions a Pherae in Aetolia; or more probably the hymn-writer may have meant the Achaean Pharae ( Paus.vii. 22, Strabo 388) which is not much east of Dyme, and not further from the sea than Elis. It is in fact the last place (as he does not mention Patrae) before Rhium, where he seems to have made the ko/lpos a)pei/rwn begin. The quantity varies in this placename; cf. Il. 2.711 oi(\ de\ *fera\s e)ne/monto with 763 *fhrhtia/dao.

kai/ marks the apodosis, with eu)=te, as in Od. 13.79. Reading *fera/s, we need not question the possibility of Ithaca being in sight; it is visible from Patrae (Frazer Paus.vol. iv. p. 144), and therefore from the coast of Pharae (if that place is intended). Even if *fea\s is read, the statement will still hold good, in spite of Baumeister's objections; according to Frazer Paus.vol. iii. p. 475 Cefalonia is visible from the coast near Lepreum, and even from a hill above Cyparissia, much farther south (ib. p. 463).
429=Od. 1.246 , i 24, p 123. Neither Dulichion nor Same can be identified; for ancient and modern theories see M. and R. on Od. 1.246.
*pareni/sato: the aor. of ni/ssomai does not occur in Homer; but the imperf. pareni/sseto is far less appropriate.

e)*pi\ *kri/shs: as the whole Corinthian gulf is meant (see below), e)pi/ must here be “in the direction of,” not (as Ilgen translates) “in the neighbourhood of.” For the latter meaning cf. Od. 3.171 nh/sou e)pi\ *yuri/hs “close by” Psyria. Herodotus vii. 115 has ko/lpon to\n e)pi\ *posidhi+/ou the bay at (“of”) Posideion, but this is not conclusive for the hymns. For e)pi/=“towards” cf. Il. 3.5 , *e 700, *l 546, *y 374. The text is satisfactorily defended by Peppmüller, against Schneidewin, who reads ta/x' e)fai/neto, connecting e)pi/ with the verb. But *kri/shs cannot go with ko/lpos; the epithet a)pei/rwn would suit the Corinthian gulf, but not the bay of Crisa; nor could the latter be said to “separate Peloponnesus.” For kate/faineto cf. Apoll. Arg. 4.1231, Theocr. vii. 10.
434-435 are adapted from Od. 15.293 , 294. a)*nu/seie: with u(/dwr; cf. Od. 4.356 o(/sson nhu=s h)/nusen, h. Herm. 337 polu\n dia\ xw=ron a)nu/ssas.

e)s lime/n): for the repetition of e)s cf. h. Aphr. 58-59; so Il. 11.479 -480, *x 503-504, *w 614-615. The harbour of Crisa was Cirrha, which may well have been in existence and have been known by that name to the hymnwriter, although he calls it simply the “harbour.” Cirrha was destroyed with Crisa, after the First Sacred War, but (unlike Crisa) was subsequently rebuilt. For the two places, which were confused by later writers, see Frazer on Paus.x. 37. 6.
e)xri/myato: no example occurs in Homer or Hesiod of a short vowel before xr in the same word; La Roche Homer. Unters. i. p. 10.

441, 442. The passage is certainly imitated from Il. 4.75 f., where Athene descends to earth like a meteorite; the exact form which she assumed is doubtful (see Leaf ad loc.). In Il. 4.77 tou= de/ te pollai\ a)po\ spinqh=res i(/entai, the present tense shews that the sparks are only mentioned as attending the meteor; it does not follow that Athene was wrapped in fire. Here, however, the imperfects pwtw=nto and i(=ken prove that fire actually streamed from the god; ei)do/menos implies a complete metamorphosis as in 449, 494.

dia\ tripo/dwn e)riti/mwn: there is perhaps a reminiscence of this in Eq.1016i)/axen e)c a)du/toio dia\ tripo/dwn e)riti/mwn; see Preface p. liii, and n. on 114. The plural seems to prove that the oracular tripod is not meant: Apollo passes through the collection of tripods in the nho/s to the a)/duton. Votive tripods were also placed in the open air before the nho/s; cf. Bacchyl.iii. 18tripo/dwn staqe/ntwn pa/roiqe naou=. In the Eq. l.c. the voice of Apollo or the Pythia comes through the tripods to the inquirers in the temple; the same explanation may serve for the paean of Aristonous e)/nq' a)po\ tripo/dwn qeo

l.quote: kth/twn xlwro/tomon da/fnan
sei/wn mantosu/nan e)poi

div2.l: xnei=s, i)h\ i)e\ *paia/n, where, however, the use of a)po/ for dia/ suggests that Aristonous confused the votive tri/podes with the tri/pous, or used the plural loosely for the singular. For the dedicated tripods which formed part of the wealth of Apollo at Delphi and elsewhere see Wieseler Fleckeis. Jahrb. 75, p. 692 f., Preller-Robert i. p. 291. They were sometimes of gold, as at Thebes; cf. Pind. Pyth.xi. 4 with schol. The collection at Delphi is mentioned by Suppl. 1197 f. (other reff. given by Wieseler); cf. h. Herm. 179.

div2.p: *pifaucko/menos ta\ a(\ k=hla=Il. 12.280 (of a snowstorm sent by Zeus). The shafts of light are the “weapons” of Apollo, just as the snowflakes are the weapons of Zeus. Theog. 708 the kh=la of Zeus are thunder, lightning, and the thunderbolt. The manifestation of light is appropriate to the sun-god, but is also a mark of other divinities (see on h. Dem. 189).

me/ga *ga\r de/os e)/mbal' e(ka/stw|: for this reading (of M) cf. Il. 11.11 me/ga sqe/nos e)/mbal' e(ka/stw|. There is no reason to prefer the variant ei(=len e(/kaston, which appears to be an independent reading.
a)=lto *pe/tesqai: the inf. is not found with this verb in Homer; but cf. h. Dem. 389. Windisch's w)=rto is needless. For the simile see on 186.
449=Il. 16.716 (ei)sa/menos).
Compare vii. 4.
kata\ *pr=hcin, “on business,” for “trading”; cf. prhkth=res “traders,” “factors,” Od. 8.162, and e)pi\ prh=cin plei=n l. 397.

a)la/lhsqe, “rove,” suits mayidi/ws better than kata\ prh=cin, for, as M. and R. (on Od. 3.73) remark, “roving” cannot properly be applied to a voyage “on business.” For the question as to whether strangers were pirates cf. Thuc.i. 5.

*(=hsqon tetiho/tes: the use of the dual for the plural seems quite established for this hymn; cf. 487 ka/qeton lu/sante, 501 i(/khsqon. Zenodotus, with Eratosthenes and Crates (schol. A on Il. 24.282) recognised this use in Homer (e.g. Il. 1.567 , *e 487, *q 74, *o 346), while Aristarchus denied its possibility, arguing that in the text of Zenodotus such dual forms had their proper force, or that the readings were incorrect. Some modern scholars, following Buttmann, have sided with Zenodotus; but general opinion agrees with Aristarchus. The false readings in Homer probably arose, as Monro (Odyssey vol. ii. App. p. 438) explains, from the fact that the dual number disappeared from the koinh\ dia/lektos. Hence dual forms in Homer came to be considered as “poetic licences,” mere equivalents of the plural. Late poets, e.g. Aratus 968, 1023, Apollonius Arg. 3.206 (see below 487) and perhaps Il. 1.384, and the author of the Hom. Epigr. iv. 8, imitated the use; so perhaps h. vi.12. As the duals in the three passages of this hymn cannot be emended without great violence, we must assume that the writer, like Aratus and others, regarded the dual as an archaic variety of the plural.
to\n kai/: kai/ of course qualifies the whole sentence, “also,” as in 525, Il. 9.195 , d 59 etc.
*krhtw=n a)*go/s: later accounts give a name to the leader (Castalius, according to Tzetzes on Lycophr. 208; Icadius, Serv. on Verg. Aen.iii. 332).
e)*pei\ ou) me\n *ga/r ti: the collocation of e)pei/ and ga/r is remarkable; as Baumeister notes, there is a combination of ou) me\n ga/r ti (Od. 1.78 etc.) and e)pei\ ou) me/n ti (Od. 5.364 etc.).
Cf. Od. 7.210 . ou) de/mas ou)de\ fu/hn: perhaps “neither in form (general appearance) nor in stature,” but the distinction between de/mas and fuh/ is not very evident; see Leaf on Il. 1.115.

After this line several editors assume a lacuna; A. Matthiae supplies i(/lhq): ei) de/ tis e)ssi\ kataqnhtw=n a)nqrw/pwn, objecting to the words qeoi\ de/ toi o)/lbia doi=en in their present context, as the Cretans took the stranger for a god. If the speaker really believed that he was addressing a god, it would be a sufficient defence of the text to point out, with Gemoll, that the Homeric phrase qeoi\ de/ toi ktl. has been transferred from its appropriate context to a less suitable place. But lines 464, 465 are merely complimentary; Apollo is now disguised as a young man of noble appearance (449), and the Cretans do not know that he is a god, or that he has any connexion with the previous miracles. For the nobility of the gods, even in their disguises, see h. Dem. 159, h. Aphr. 81 f.

466-472. This passage is almost a cento from the Odyssey: 466, 467=Od. 24.402, 403; 468=Od. 13.233 ti/s gh=, ti/s dh=mos, ti/nes a)ne/res e)ggega/asin; preceded by kai/ moi tou=t' ktl.; 471=Od. 1.182 (kath/luqon h)d' e(ta/roisi); 472=Od. 9.261 (oi)/kade). Baumeister objects to 472, which, however, seems quite in place. Their no/stos should have been “by another way and other paths.” They had already passed Pylos, their destination (cf. 398, 424), and were now going away from, instead of towards, their home.
a)mfine/mesqe: imperfect (cf. to\ pri/n); Cobet's a)mfene/mesqe is easy; in Il. 2.521, 634 there is authority for the augment.

tetime/non: Hermann is not justified in emending this to tetime/noi on the ground of the repetition of the idea in 483 ti/mion, which indeed seems rather to confirm the accusative here. With tetime/noi there would also be a repetition in 485 timh/sesqe.
tim/hsesqe: Homer does not distinguish a passive future from the middle; see Leaf on Il. 5.653 , *k 365. So ei)rh/setai *y 795.

e)*gw/: Gemoll follows Matthiae in writing e)gw/n, on the ground that there is no “living” digamma in the hymn. Even on this assumption, the later poets certainly tolerated the hiatus which often resulted after the loss of a digamma. On the question of a living digamma see Preface p. lxix f.

For the dual see on 456. The alterations here proposed to get rid of the dual are kaqe/men lu=sai de/ (Cobet) and ka/qete lu=sai/ te (Ilgen). Both are too violent. Apollonius seems to have read the dual here, as in Arg. Il. 3.206 kateilu/sante boei/ais he almost certainly imitates the usage from this passage. Kühner (G. G. ii. p. 64) defends the dual by the forced interpretation that the sailors are divided into two groups, sitting at the oars on either side of the ship.

a)*n' e)*p): the addition of a)n) seems required, as the hiatus e)pi\ h)pei/rou is scarcely tolerable. As Agar notes, the similarity of a)n) to the termination of qoh/n would easily account for its loss. If a)na/ followed e)pi/ (as Baumeister suggested) the loss would be difficult to explain.
e)/ntea: not in Homer for the “tackle” of a ship (o(/pla).

*pu=r e)*pikai/ontes: the addition of d) (Ilgen, followed by recent edd.) is made very probable by 509; if de/ is absent, the participles must be taken with poih/sate, i.e. the fire is kindled and the sacrifice is offered while the altar is being built, which, Ilgen says, is absurd. However, the tense of the present participles need not be pressed; in strict logic they are hardly more applicable to what follows them than what precedes.

delfini/w|: the cult of Apollo delfi/nios is certainly old, but its original home is uncertain. The hymn points to a Cretan starting-place, and many scholars have accepted its authority, as the Cnossian cult of Apollo *delfi/nios (locally *delfi/dios) is established by inscriptions (see on 393). “Mycenean” remains have been found at Delphi; and these have been thought to support the theory of a Cretan origin, as such remains are common in Crete (Homolle B. C. H. xviii. p. 195; for Mycenean buildings in Aegina in connexion with the traditional Cretan origin of Aphaea see Bosanquet J. H. S. xxi. p. 347). Even if the particular cult of Apollo *delfi/nios were proved to be Cretan, it would by no means follow that the worship of Apollo at Delphi was introduced by Cretans; they may have found the god, and have merely added a title. However, it seems improbable that Apollo *delfi/nios was originally Cretan; A. Mommsen (Heortologie i.) believes that the cult was Chalcidian; and this view has won favour (see v. Wilamowitz in Hermes xxi. p. 105, Maass ibid. xxiii. p. 71, Preller-Robert i. p. 257 n. 4, Frazer on Paus.x. 5. 5).

We may assume that there is no historical truth in the Cretan theory; as Verrall (p. 11) remarks, the probabilities of migration are all the other way. There were Dorian settlers both at Delphi and in Crete, and the origin of rites or customs, common to both places, would naturally be assigned to Crete, the home of a very old civilization. Probably the Dorian paean, which was well-known as a form of Cretan art, suggested the story of Cretans at Pytho (see 518; cf. Pauly-Wissowa 2542).

o( bwmo/s: Pausanias does not mention any altar, and there appear to be no remains on the site. In literature the only reference seems to be Plutarch de soll. animal. 984 A (=c. 36) kai\ mh
 *)arte/mido/s ge *diktu/nnhs *delfini/ou t' *)apo/llwnos i(era\ kai\ bwmoi\ para\ polloi=sin ei)si
 *(ellh/nwn: o(
 d' au)to\s e(autw=| to/pon e)cai/reton o( qeo\s pepoi/htai . . . *krhtw=n a)pogo/nous oi)kou=ntas h(gemo/ni delfi=ni xrhsame/nous: ou) ga o( qeo\s proenh/xeto tou= sto/lou metabalw
 to\ ei)=dos, w(s oi( muqogra/foi le/gousin, a)lla\ delfi=na pe/myas toi=s a)ndra/sin i)qu/nonta to
 plou=n kath/gagen ei)s *ki/rran. He then tells a story of two persons in the time of Ptolemy Soter, who were driven by a storm off Malea, e)n decia=| *pelopo/nnhson e)/xontes (i.e. the same route as the Cretans), and were led by a dolphin to Cirra, where they offered an a)nabath/rion (presumably on the bwmo/s). Plutarch's muqogra/foi may be writers who borrowed from the hymn, or perhaps may refer loosely to the hymn itself.
For the altar on the seashore cf. Apoll. Arg. 2.659, where the Argonauts erect a bwmo\s e)pa/ktios on the island where Apollo appeared.

delfi/nios: de/lfeios is an unknown word, the form of which is hardly supported by a Thessalian inscr. tes belfaio=ta es delfaio (Ath. Mitth. xxi. p. 249); it may be explained as due to the metrical difficulty in delfi/nios, just as in Nicand. Ther.238qami_no/s has become qameio/s. With regard to delfi/nios the editors raise two objections: (1) that it is unmetrical, (2) that it is unsuitable to the context, and cannot be paired with e)po/yios. There are two possible solutions of the first difficulty. We may assume delfi^/nios, in spite of the preceding delfi_ni/w|: adjectives formed from nouns with gen. in -i=nos vary in quantity; *)eleusi^/nios is short, as in h. Dem. 266, Soph. Ant.1120; cf. h. Dem. 105 *)eleusi^ni/dao, while *salami_/nios *traxi_/nios appear to be always long (see Schulze Quaest. Ep. p. 11). The doubtful quantity of delfi_^/nios is not therefore impossible; the Doric form is presumably delfi^/dios, and, although this can hardly be substituted, it may help to account for delfi^/nios. More probably, however, the i preserves its length, as in 495, and there is a synizesis of -io-, which is not very uncommon; cf. Il. 2.811 po/li_o_s (as in Anth. Pal. ix. 569. 4) and other exx. in Christ Metrik p. 29. In 495 delfini/w| is no doubt quadrisyllabic, as the synizesis forming the quantity - - would be very harsh in the fourth foot, before a pause; but the variation in the two lines is not worse than qeo/s, qe^ou/s in the same line of Euripides (Troad. 1280).

(2) delfi/nios and e)po/yios are not incompatible in sense: the latter is usually translated by “conspicuous,” but it may rather be active, the “over-seer,” a title transferred from Apollo himself to his altar, like delfi/nios. Cf. proo/yios as a title of Apollo Paus.i. 32. 2, e)po/pths of the Sun C. I. G. addend. 4699. The wording of the passage suggests that the altar is to have the same name or names as the god. A harbour of Oropus was also called delfi/nios (o( i(ero\s limh\n o(\n kalou=si delfi/nion Strabo 403, see Lolling in Ath. Mitth. x. p. 350 f.), which is a further argument for applying the adj. to the altar on the shore.

On Apollo Delphinius see PrellerRobert l.c., Pauly-Wissowa art. “Apollon” 5 and 47, art. “Delphinios” 2513 f. There can be little doubt that the title is here rightly connected with the dolphin. Apollo, as the patron of mariners and colonization, travelled over many seas in the form of a dolphin; cf. oneir. ii. 35. As *delfi/nios he reached Pytho, which drew its later name Delphi from the title. Dolphins playing in front of a vessel are a familiar sight in the Mediterranean, as in ancient times; cf. Anth. Pal. ix. 83. 1 nho\s e)peigome/nhs w)ku\n dro/mon a)mfexo/reuon
div2.l: delfi=nes.

div2.p: Cf. Od. 24.489. The commoner formulaic line (po/sios kai\ e)dh/tuos) occurs at 513.

i)*hpai/ho*)n: for the word see on 272. The paean formed the germ of the later Pythian games; before the First Sacred War it was sung at a competition of cithara-players every eighth year; Strabo 421, Paus.x. 7. 2, schol. on Pyth. argum., Censorinus de die nat. 18, Mommsen Delphika p. 153 f.

Compare Il. 1.433 f., a passage which appears to have been abbreviated by the writer of the hymn. 504=Il. 1.434; 505=Il. 1.437. In A l.c. the ship is moored, not drawn on to land, as described in 506, for which cf. Il. 1.485 f. (a different occasion).
507=Il. 1.486 (with u(po/ instead of *para/). e(/rmata, “shores” (probably large stones) to keep the ship upright; cf. Il. 2.154. Hes. Op.624nh=a d' e)p' h)pei/rou e)ru/sai puka/sai te li/qoisi
div2.l: panto/qen, where li/qoisi=e(/rmasin and panto/qen “all along the sides” explains para/ in the present passage.

div2.p: On the variants of this line see p. xix. a)gato/n, which long was printed, does not exist, and was evidently a correction of the singular lacuna in x.
kala\ kai\ u(/yi biba/s=202.

r(/hssontes, “beating time,” the verb being perhaps connected with a)-ra/ss-w, not with r(h<*>gnumi. Cf. Il. 18.571 toi\ de\ r(h/ssontes a(marth=| . . . e(/ponto (where see Leaf), and is borrowed by Apollonius (Il. 1.539) who uses it with an object, pe/don r(h/sswsi po/dessin. On the derivation see Siebourg in Rhein. Mus. 57. 2 (1902), who compares r(a/ssw.

oi_=oi/ te *krhtw=n *pai/hones: the paean was not exclusively Dorian in the earliest times; it was sung by the Achaeans to Apollo (Il. 1.472 f.) and as a general triumphal hymn (Il. 22.391). But in early post-Homeric times it was specially Dorian (Crete, Sparta, Delphi) and connected with the cult of Apollo; see Smyth Melic Poets p. xxxvii.
a)/kmhtoi: the form is found in Nicand. Ther. 737.Cobet needlessly read a)kmh=tes (the Homeric form).
e)/mellen may be retained, the subject being Apollo, who, like his temple (479, 483), would be “honoured.” The editors read e)/mellon (Pierson), and tetime/noi, comparing 485.

The reading of y a)/duton za/qeon is unexceptionable and perhaps the better, but the vulg. au)tou= da/pedon is not impossible; cf. Preger inscr. metr. gr. 89 nu=n de/ me *lhtoi+/dou qei=on e)/xei da/pedon; au)tou=, however, is rather awkward.
524=Od. 20.9 (tou=). w)ri/neto may refer to mingled feelings of joy and fear (Baumeister); perhaps it rather expresses the doubts of the Cretans.

bio/mesqa: there is no variant in the MSS. on this word. In Il. 22.431 several families of MSS. have bi/omai, the vulgate bei/omai. Wolf altered it to beo/mesqa but Schulze Quaest. Ep. 246 n. retains the iota, as if the vowel had been assimilated to bio/w. Fick on Od. 16.852 also argues for bi/omai in Homer, on the ground that the form bei/omai (Il. 22.431) merely represents bi_omai, with ictus, and was afterwards transliterated into be/omai. Aristarchus' preference is uncertain; see Ludwich on Il. 22.431. See Solmsen l.c. p. 91, 92.

The barren soil of Delphi became a reproach to its priests: cf. the story of Aesop, schol. Vesp. 1446, Pax129o(/n fasin e)lqo/nta pote\ ei)s tou\s *delfou\s a)poskw=yai au)tou/s, o(/te mh\ e)/xoien gh=n a)f' h(=s e)rgazo/menoi diatre/fointo, a)lla\ perime/noien a)po\ tw=n tou= qeou= quma/twn diazh=n.

e)*p/hratos has been suspected, but the construction, though rather harsh, is supported by Od. 13.246 ai)gi/botos d' a)gaqh\ kai\ bou/botos, i 27 trhxei=) a)ll' a)gaqh\ kourotro/fos, Hes. Op.783a)ndrogo/nos d' a)gaqh/, ib. 794, Dicaearch.i. 13kai\ i(ppotro/fos de\ a)gaqh/ (of Thebes). “This land is not to be desired as vineland or pasturage.” e)ph/ratos and eu)lei/mwn occur in Od. 4.606, 607, a passage which seems to have suggested this line.

o)*phdei=n with a(/ma must mean “to help,” cf. Od. 7.165 , t 398. It is not clear in what sense the Cretans think of “helping” men. Matthiae translates suppeditare; i.e. the Cretans would not have enough food for themselves or for pilgrims. Lang (after Franke) translates “wherefrom we might live well and minister to men,” and this is perhaps preferable; the labourers are worthy of their hire.
Compare Od. 11.146.
ma/la is not elsewhere joined to e(/kastos, but often strengthens similar adjectives of quantity (polloi/, pa/ntes, mu/rioi etc.).

For the offerings of sheep at Delphi cf. Pind. Pyth.iii. 27e)n d' a)/ra mhlodo/kw| *puqw=ni, Eur. Ion228.Croesus offered 3000 sheep, Herod.i. 50.For the general sense cf. the lines on Delos supra 59, and (for Delphi itself) Eur. Ion323bwmoi/ m' e)/ferbon ou(piw/n t' a)ei\ ce/nos, I. T. 1274.
Hermann and Abel read o(/ssa t' e)moi/, to avoid the hiatus; Gemoll, o(/ss' a)\n e)moi/ g). Eberhard Metr. Beob. ii. p. 11 also condemns the hiatus.

*profu/laxqe: according to Buttmann G. G. ii. p. 320 this is a syncopated present. Schneidewin reads pefu/laxqe to correspond with the perfect de/dexqe. Gemoll objects to the use of the perfect here as meaningless; but such imperative perfects are common in Homer; see H. G. 28.

Either the latter half of the line is corrupt, or there is a lacuna. i)qu/n is no doubt genuine; it means “direction,” either locally or tropically (cf. Il. 6.79 , d 434, p 304). The simplest emendation proposed is that of Matthiae kat' e)mh\n i)qu/n ge ma/lista, where, however, ge ma/lista is very feeble; Verrall's ta\ ma/lista (anticipated by D'Orville) is equally weak. Baumeister's kai\ e)mh\n i)qu/nte qe/mista (a syncopated imperative like fe/rte) is ingenious, but the substitution of qe/mista for ma/lista is hardly justified. On the whole it is preferable to assume a lacuna; in J. H. S. xvii. 251 f. a line was supplied such as dei/knusqe qnhtoi=si, su\ de\ fresi\ de/co qe/mista (a homoeoteleuton may have caused the omission).

540-41. The sense is again obscure. Matthiae Ilgen and Hermann connect these lines with 539; i.e. receive (expiate the sin of) men, if any crime by word or deed, shall have been committed. But this is plainly wrong; h)e/ cannot stand for ei), as Baumeister saw, and moreover the threat in 364 certainly refers to some crime committed, not by the visitors to the temple, but by the priests themselves. Instead of h)e/ Franke and Baumeister read ei) de/ which makes good sense: “but if there shall be any vain word or deed (annoy you) and insolence, as is common among men.” We must either accept this alteration, or assume that the lacuna after 539 contained a hypothetical clause (ei) with a future). If we may suppose a lacuna of two lines, the latter may have run e.g. ei) de/ tis a)fradi/h|s ou) pei/setai, a)ll' a)logh/sei (cf. Il. 15.162).
thu+/sion: on the derivation and meaning see Brugmann I. F. xi. 105 sq., Solmsen Untersuchungen p. 38.

This verse no doubt contains a “prophecy after the event,” but the precise allusion has been disputed. It would be natural to see (with Franke) a reference to the First Sacred War. This ended in the destruction of Crisa and its port Cirrha (586 B.C.); see Frazer on Paus.x. 7. 2 and x. 37. 5. But athletic games were then added to the old musical contests (see on 517) by the Amphictyonic League, who assumed the management of the Pythia; and it is scarcely credible that these later games should have been so completely ignored, if they had been known to the hymnwriter. Indeed lines 264 f. prove that chariot-races were then unknown at Delphi. We must therefore either assume that the passage was a later addition to the hymn, or look for some other parties to a conflict. It is possible that there may be an allusion to quarrels between the inhabitants of Delphi (reputed Cretans) who served the temple, and the Crisaeans. According to Strabo 421, in early times the temple was managed by the “Delphians”; and probably their place was gradually usurped by the Crisaeans, who finally roused the wrath of the Amphictyons, by levying excessive tolls on pilgrims.

Ilgen supposes that the shma/ntores were the Amphictyons, who had relations with the Delphic oracle at a time certainly preceding the First Sacred War, although the actual date of the beginning of their influence is not recorded; see Holm i. ch. xix. The “prophecy” would then refer to the loss of prestige and power sustained by the priests, through the interference of the League.

div1.head: HYMN TO HERMES

listBibl.head: BIBLIOGRAPHY
listBibl.bibl: A. LUDWICH, Hymn. Hom. in Mercur. (Acad. Alb. Regimontii, 1890, iii.).
Hymn. Hom. Mercurii Germanice versus (Acad. Alb. Regimontii, 1891, i.).
A. LANG, The Homeric Hymns (Translation) p. 35 f., 1899.
ROSCHER AND SCHERER, art. “Hermes” in
Roscher's Lex.
PRELLER-ROBERT, Griech. Myth. i. p. 385 f.

div1.p: I. Subject and motive.—The theme is more varied than those of the other great hymns. There is a unity of time, for the action is continuous, taking place in the first two days of Hermes' life; but there is no close unity of subject: the several episodes are not integral parts of a single myth, and the commentators have vainly puzzled themselves to discover one underlying motif to connect the different parts of the hymn. The connexion lies simply in the fact that the episodes all deal with the first exploits of the infant god, and shew how, by his cunning and dexterity, he vindicated his birthright, and won the attributes which distinguished him in maturity.See II.App. , where the explanation is given at fuller length. Hermes has perhaps the most complex character of any deity in Greek mythology, and the poet has tried to do justice to some, at least, of the god's many qualities. Of these, one of the most characteristic was thievishness. To the Greeks, who too often prided themselves on successful deceit, and who had made lying a fine art, a patron-deity of cunning came natural. Even in the later parts of the Iliad Hermes is known as the Thief; cf. Il. 24.24, where the gods urge him to steal the body of Hector. Autolycus is in Homer (Il. 10.267) the human representative of the Masterthieves who figure largely in folk-tales; but he learnt his craft from the divine thief Hermes (cf. Od. 19.395 f. o(\s a)nqrw/pous e)ke/kasto

l.quote: kleptosu/nh| q' o(/rkw| te: qeo\s de/ oi( au)to\s e)/dwken

div1.l: *(ermei/as. See also Hes. Op.67Hes. Op., 78, fr. 130, Hippon. fr. 1, Plut. 1139 and often). Additional force is given to these stories of trickery and mendacity, when the rogue is a new-born babe, or is otherwise insignificant; and Mr. Lang well remarks that “the poet chiefly revels in a very familiar subject of savage humour (notably among the Zulus), the extraordinary feats and tricks of a tiny and apparently feeble and helpless person or animal, such as Brer Rabbit.”See II. App. p. 311. Roscher derives the thievishness from the wind, with which he identifies Hermes (Lex. i. 2369 f.; Hermes d. Windgott, 1878, Nektar u. Ambrosia 1883); but most of his arguments are of little weight (see on 19, 146, 512), and the origin of Hermes is still a mystery. For the hymn-writer, at all events, Hermes had no connexion with any natural phenomenon; he is purely anthropomorphic. The poet emphasises the deceitful ways of Hermes at the outset of the hymn, in a string of epithets, polu/tropon, ai(mulomh/thn . . . nukto\s o)pwphth=ra, pulhdo/kon (13 f.). In the same language he sums up the god's character at the end: pau=ra me\n ou)=n o)ni/nhsi ktl. (577 f.).
div1.p: The theft of the cattle of Apollo was the most striking myth which exemplified these knavish tricks; and the poet takes this to form the main thread of his narrative. But Hermes was by no means a mere thief; in his higher and more Olympian province he was the messenger of the gods, and a great pastoral deity, especially in local cult. These divine conceptions are recognised at the beginning of the hymn (2 f. *kullh/nhs mede/onta kai\ *)arkadi/hs polumh/lou,
div1.l: a)/ggelon a)qana/twn; and 331 fuh\n kh/rukos e)/xonta). Again, Hermes was not always untrustworthy in his dealings with men; he was also the luck-bringer, e)riou/nios (3, 28, 551). The finding of the tortoise is the first e(/rmaion (30 f.).
div1.p: But, while Hermes had many specific attributes which differentiated him from all other deities, he had also many points of contact with one member of the Olympian circle—Apollo.See note on 508. Both were pastoral gods; both were patrons of music, and had prophetic powers, although in this respect the place of Apollo was superior. This close connexion undoubtedly impressed the poet, who gave an explanation common in Greek mythology, that the similarity of attributes was due to an exchange of gifts. Apollo presented Hermes with cattle, and in his turn received the cithara (498 f.). The poet, too, felt that all forms of prophecy rightly belonged, under Zeus, to the Lord of Delphi. But he knew that, in common superstition, certain processes of divination were under the patronage of Hermes, the god of luck.On Hermes as a god of divination see Paus.vii. 22. 2Paus., vii. 22. 3Paus., ix. 11. 7.Preller-Robert i. p. 399 n. 3, Roscher i. 2379 f.: on the Thriae see III. He App. therefore naturally assumed that these lower powers had been delegated to Hermes from the abundance of Apollo's higher prerogative. Apollo still remained the keeper of the knowledge which Zeus possessed; but he transferred to Hermes the Thriae, with whom he had served an apprenticeship in prophecy (533566).

II. The theft of the cows of Apollo.—The myth was very ancient, and has been assigned by the “solar” school of mythologists to the stock of Indo-European stories belonging to the undivided Aryan race.Compare the Vedic parallel, in which Ahi steals the cattle of Indra; PrellerRobert i. p. 394 n. 1. For representations of the theft in art see Roscher i. 2429. It is known to have been related by Hesiod, in the *mega/lai *)hoi=ai, but no fragment is preserved. Alcaeus handled the same story in a hymn to Hermes, of which only one stanza is extant (fr. 5; cf. Hor. Od. I. x.). In later Greek, the most important version of the myth is in Apollodorus iii. 10. 2. The mythographer deals with an account much resembling the hymn; for the events are the same, although not in the same order. He differs from the hymn in the following details:—
(1) Hermes eats some of the flesh: ta\s me\n bu/rsas pe/trais kaqh/lwse, tw=n de\ krew=n ta\ me\n kathna/lwsen e(yh/sas, ta\ de\ kate/kause.
(2) Hermes finds the tortoise after stealing the cows. He makes the strings of the lyre e)c w(=n e)/quse bow=n, not from sheep-gut, as in the hymn.
(3) Apollo inquires at Pylos, not Onchestus.
(4) Apollo discovers the thief e)k mantikh=s.
(5) Maia shows Hermes to Apollo.
(6) Apollo desires the su=rigc also, and exchanges it for th\n dia\ yh/fwn mantikh/n.

Apollodorus names no authority, and his precise debt to the hymn has been disputed. According to the general view (see Gemoll p. 191), he used the hymn, but supplemented its account from another (unknown) source. Greve (de h. in Merc. Homerico p. 37) thinks that Apollodorus drew little from the hymn. Some scholars, on the other hand, argue that the hymn was the sole ultimate authority, and that the variations of detail are the invention of the mythographer. Gemoll, who supports this view, believes that these variations partly proceed from carelessness, as (3), partly from a desire to explain or amplify the hymn; e.g. the variant (2) is due to Apollodorus' wish to utilise the cows, and so connect the two incidents of the cithara and the cattlestealing. Gemoll also assumes, with no adequate reason, that Apollodorus used a text with the present lacunae in the hymn. The differences between the two accounts seem too wide to admit the theory that Apollodorus used no other source; indeed, it may be doubted whether he was even at all acquainted with the actual text of the hymn, although he may have borrowed from sources (written or oral) which were ultimately drawn from the Homeric version.

The version of Antoninus Liberalis 23 is confined to the incident of Battus. Hermes steals 12 po/rtias, 100 bo/as a)/zugas, and a bull from Apollo, and ties branches (u(/lh) to the tail of each, w(s a)\n ta\ i)/xnh tw=n bow=n a)fani/sh|. Battus, who was paid by Hermes not to tell, proved false, and was changed into a stone. Ovid ( Met.ii. 676 f.) also narrates the story of Battus. The popularity of the myth (in its different forms) is shewn by the list of sources quoted by Antoninus: *ni/kandros e(teroioume/nwn a/, *(hsi/odos e)n mega/lais h)oi/ais, *didu/marxos metamorfwse/wn g/, *)anti/gonos e)n tai=s a)lloiw/sesi, kai\ *)apollw/nios o( *(ro/dios e)n e)pigra/mmasin.

The geographer Philostephanus, a disciple of Callimachus, dealt with the subject in his peri\ *kullh/nhs (F. H. G. iii. 28), a book which might have given us much information of which we stand in need. Another Alexandrian, Eratosthenes, in an unnamed work, narrated the birth of Hermes and his theft of his mother's and her sister's clothes, and of Apollo's cows (schol. on Il. 24.24), and interpreted the Homeric *(ermei/as a)ka/khta (Immerwahr l.c. p. 72).

The geography of the two versions represented by the hymn and Antoninus Liberalis is quite different. In the hymn, Hermes passes Onchestus, where he finds the nameless old man corresponding to Battus; thence, by an undefined route, he reaches the Alphean Pylos (139, 398), near which place he slaughters the cows. Antoninus gives a long itinerary, starting from Phthiotis and ending at the Messenian Pylos; there Hermes hides the cattle in a cave at Coryphasium in which Nestor had housed his booty (Il. 11.677, Paus.iv. 36. 2). The meeting with Battus took place near Maenalus. Thus a Pylos is mentioned in both versions as in the neighbourhood of Hermes' cave. Probably the original account referred to the Triphylian place of that name; the neighbourhood of the Alpheus is a natural route along which to retire to Cyllene.Cf. Anth. Pal. vii. 390, where a traveller from Pisa to N. Greece is killed by lightning on Cyllene. The view that the Messenian Pylos is original (Preller-Robert i. p. 392 n. 2) rests on O. Müller's very doubtful theory that the stalactites in a cave at this place were thought to be the skins of the beasts slaughtered by Hermes (see on 124 f.). The cave, on the northern slope of Coryphasium, is described by Frazer (who accepts Müller's explanation) on l.c. But it is clear from 398 that Hermes' cave was near the Alpheus. The cave of Hermes is mentioned also in Lithica 18 and 55.

The site of the Triphylian Pylos is unidentified, but is defined by Strabo 343 fin. kata\ tau=ta de/ pws ta\ i(era\ [that of Poseidon at Samicum and of Athena at Scillus] u(pe/rkeitai th=s qala/tths e)n tria/konta h)\ mikrw=| plei/ous stadi/ois o( *trifuliako\s *pu/los o( kai\ *lepreatiko/s, o(\n kalei= o( poihth\s h)maqo/enta. The coast south of the Alpheus is sandy and largely covered by lagoons (see the references given on h. Apoll. 424), and this suits the wording of the hymn.If the poet was a Boeotian, or an Eretrian, his geography of the northern part of Greece ought not to be merely imagination: and the “sandy shore of the sea” along which Hermes passed after leaving Olympus should correspond to something in reality. The coast between Pieria and the sea southward to the Peneius appears from Leake Northern Greece iii. c. 30 to possess quicksands and lagoons in places. The description, however (in the hymn), would suit any flat coast; see on 79 f. The town, with its cave, was obscured in later days by the Messenian Pylos.

III. Place of composition.—As in the case of nearly all the hymns, the place of composition is doubtful. There are a certain number of Atticisms, and usages of forms and words which approach to the style of the Attic tragedy.Baumeister (p. 203) and Gemoll (p. 193) quote, amongst others, o)/rh 95, e)ma/rane 140, e)/doca 208, e)du/nw 405, filw= 382. None of these forms need be exclusively Attic; at least one (qa=tton 255) is known to be also Boeotian; see note ad loc. Some of these forms may be due to scribes familiar with the Attic dialect; others may be common to other dialects, and only testify to a comparatively late time of composition. There is really nothing in the hymn which suggests Athenian composition, and much which distinctly negatives such an idea. Besides numerous reminiscences of Homer, which are a feature in all the hymns, there are many lines which show the influence of Hesiod in a marked degree (cf. 10, 19, 30, 36, 67, 76, 80, 98, 106, 110, 120, 124, 236, 243, 415).

Possibly the commentators have been too chary of suggesting a locality; at all events, a very good case can be made out in support of a Boeotian origin. The influence of Hesiod points in this direction, although of course this fact is inconclusive, as Hesiod, like Homer, early became the property of all the Greeks. But the part played by Onchestus, which does not appear in the other versions, is more striking; the mention of this place seems motiveless, except on a supposition of Boeotian influence. There appear to be traces of local dialect in a)qro/a^s 106, the elision of i in per' i)gnu/si 152, qa=tton 255, and in h(xou= 400, on the analogy of h(xoi= in an Oropian inscription.See Pref. p. lxxiii, where this theory is advanced on philological and other grounds. Fick B. B. xxii. 272, principally on account of h(xou=, calls the writer an Euboean Ionian.

In any case we may reject Fick's earlier suggestion (B. B. ix. p. 201) that the poem was originally composed, in old Ionic, at Colophon in Asia, for the festival of Apollo Clarius. His view that Apollo, not Hermes, is the real “hero” utterly misconceives the spirit of the hymn.

IV. Date.—The date is equally uncertain, but there is every reason to believe, with the consensus of scholars, that the poem is later than the rest of the longer hymns. Hermann and Baumeister point out that there is no living digamma, although, as usual, there is often hiatus in the case of words originally digammated (Hermann Orph. p. 689). See also Eberhard die Sprache der hom. Hymn. ii. p. 34 f., and n. on 92; Pref. p. lxix. Definite evidence of date has been sought for in the mention of the seven-stringed cithara (51). The adoption of seven in place of four strings is usually ascribed to Terpander (see Flach Gr. Lyr. i. 195), who was an old man in Ol.26=676 B.C.; Smyth Melic Poets p. 165 (but see Timotheus Pers.237). Even if this form of the cithara is older than Terpander, who probably only modified the scale (Smyth l.c.), it is highly probable that the hymn is much later than that poet. As Gemoll remarks (p. 193), the hymn-writer could not have attributed the seven strings to Hermes, had not the cithara been long established in that form. On the other hand, the hymn does not approach the childishness of the Batrachomachia (attributed to Pigres, circ. 480, by Plutarch and Suidas), nor to the comic effects of fourth-century parody; still less is it Alexandrian. It is excellent and vigorous literature of an early period, and its cynical and quasi-parodic style make it unique. Its language is in places prosaic,See on 313, 316. but a high flight of poetic fancy would be foreign to the theme. The moral tone appears low when judged by modern standards—as low, perhaps, as that of the Lay of Demodocus (see h. Aphr. Introd.). But this was no stumbling-block to the average Greek, who acquiesced in gods made after his own image. The hymn-writer, in fact, frankly represents the popular religion; he is no opponent of it, like Euripides, nor scoffer, like Lucian. His Hermes may be akin, in some respects, to the gods of Comedy; but the character is far removed from the sorry figure of the Aristophanic Hermes in the Plutus.

V. Influence on later literature.—With all its merits, the hymn seems to have made little or no impression on later Greek literature, and it is rarely cited as an authority, even where some reference might be expected. Pausanias, who quotes from the hymns to Apollo and Demeter, ignores it, and in referring to the myth of cattle-lifting, mentions only the hymn of Alcaeus (viii. 20. 4). The silence of Apollodorus is still more significant; it appears that the authority of the Homeric hymn was overshadowed by Alcaeus and Hesiod in the Eoae. The account of the invention of the cithara is equally neglected.See also on 24 f., 47 f. Euripides speaks of the lyre as the gift of Hermes to Apollo; it by no means follows, however, that he knew the hymn, as Gemoll supposes (see on 416). In Alexandrian times, Aratus and Nicander mention the myth, but their accounts seem independent of the hymn, and the scholia on Nicander make no allusion to it. Callimachus, who certainly knew the hymn to Apollo, appears to owe nothing to the style and language of the present hymn.Ruhnken ep. crit. i. p. 28 instances 524 (where see note); Guttmann de h. Hom. historia p. 7 f. can only add 20, which has practically no resemblance to Callim. h. Art. 25. The direct citation of a line (51) by Antigonus of Carystus (iii.-ii. cent. B.C.) is quite exceptional.

As an example of modern appreciation, it may suffice to mention Shelley's well-known translation, which, of course, does full justice to the poetry of the original, although, as Prof. Mahaffy remarks (Greek Lit. i. p. 150), it perhaps accentuates the comic element too strongly.

V. State of the Text.—The usages of its language make the hymn very difficult; there are a certain number of verbal corruptions, but not a single line need be omitted or transposed. The ingenuity of the higher criticism is largely wasted, although the commentators have been particularly active in dissecting the document. On the other hand, the interruption of sense in several places requires lacunae; and this is in itself more probable on graphical grounds than theories of interpolation or addition, not to say transposition.
1-9. These lines, with a few unimportant variations, form a short hymn to Hermes (xviii), where see note.

div2.p: *(erm=hn: only the contracted form is found in this hymn; it occurs also in Il. 20.72 , e 54, c 334, 435, w 1, for the older Homeric *(ermei/as.
*maia/dos: so Od. 14.435, Simon. fr. 18, Semon. fr. 20 etc.; the form *mai=a (3) is not Homeric; in Theog. 938 *mai/h.
*kull/hn*hs: for the numerous references to the Cyllenian cult of Hermes see Immerwahr die Kulte u. Myth. Ark. i. p. 73 f., Roscher Lex. i. 2342 f., Preller-Robert i. p. 389.

6=xviii. 6 a)/ntrw| naieta/ousa paliski/w|, but the parallel is without effect on the reading of the older hymn. It is unnecessary to read a)/ntrou, with Baumeister, or to alter nai/ousa into a verb of motion, with the older critics. nai/ein here governs the accusative, as often in Homer, and e)/sw is to be taken absolutely, “within.” For e)/sw=e)/ndon, with a verb of rest, cf. Il. 13.553 , h 13, s 96, f 229. Zenodotus (on Od. 7.13) denied the use, and Ebeling follows; but the exx. in Homer can hardly be explained away.

*nukto\s a)molgw=|: the meaning is no doubt the “dead” or “blackness” of night, although the derivation is still disputed (see Ebeling). Forchhammer (die Kyanen etc. 1891) curiously returns to the ancient etymology “milkingtime,” on the ground that Mediterranean goat-herds still milk their flocks in the middle of the night. Meyer (Griech. Et. i.) rejects this derivation; the connexion with Dan. mork Eng. mirk etc. is also doubtful.

o)/fra . . . e)/xoi: Gemoll explains the mood as the optative of indefinite frequency, comparing Od. 7.136 w)=| puma/tw| spe/ndeskon, o(/te mnhsai/ato koi/tou. But o)/fra is not equivalent to o(/te, and must here be final, i.e. “until,” or “in order that”; see H. G. § 307. Zeus waited till the dead of night, until Hera should be asleep (or, as often, with an indistinct notion of time, “that Hera might be asleep”).

*dio\s *no/os e)*cetelei=to: probably borrowed from Theog. 1002 mega/lou de\ *dio\s no/os e)cetelei=to. So Il. 1.5, Cypria fr. 1. 7 *dio\s d' e)telei/eto boulh/. Gemoll objects to the imperfect here, which he thinks has been blindly copied from Hesiod. But the tense is quite appropriate: “the will of Zeus was coming to fulfilment.” Cf. h. Apoll. 349 a)ll' o(/te dh\ mh=ne/s te kai\ h(me/rai e)ceteleu=nto (followed by e)ph/luqon w(=rai). *dio\s no/os is Hesiodean; cf. Op.105, Theog. 51, 537, 613 al.
t*=|h d): de/ probably marks the apodosis (te in 12 being connective), as in the similar passage h. Apoll. 349 quoted above. For this use in the hymn cf. 108, 116.

mei/s: the form mh/s is perhaps accidental in M; it was read in the Chian ed. on Il. 19.117, and is found in the MS. Barocci 203; also in the Heraclian tables (Cauer Delectus^{2} 40. 1, C. I. G. 5774. 5). Smyth Ionic § 543, Solmsen K. Z. 29, 61, Herwerden Lex. s.v.

e)st/hrikto: more properly the moon, which marks the months, is “fixed in heaven,” as in Aratus Phaen.10au)to\s ga\r ta/de sh/mat' e)n ou)ranw=| e)sth/ricen. The editors compare Il. 19.117 th=| d' e(/bdomos e(sth/kei mei/s, where, however, e(sth/kei doubtless means “had begun”; cf. mh\n i(sta/menos. The hymn-writer may have misunderstood the meaning, or he may have varied the expression consciously.

ei)/s te fo/ws a)/gagen: apparently modelled on Il. 19.118 e)k d' a)/gage pro\ fo/wsde, where the subject is Hera, taking the place of the *ei)lei/quiai. Cf. also Il. 16.188 (of Eilithyia). Here both the subject and object of a)/gage are obscure. Gemoll understands <*zeu\s> a)/gagen <e)/rga>, i.e. “Zeus revealed the deed, and everything was made known.” He compares pro\s fw=s a)/gein etc. in Plato. This view is most improbable; the object, at all events, can hardly be anything but pai=da. The subject is probably Maia, the passage being a clumsy and inaccurate reminiscence of the Homeric descriptions of childbirth. The fact that ei)s fo/ws a)/gagen is an exact equivalent of kai\ to/t' e)gei/nato pai=da presents no great difficulty in this hymn; nor need we suspect interpolation. Compare the diffuse style of 24, 25; 34, 35.

*(/hg/htor' o)*nei/rwn: the other epithets in 13-15 refer to the deceit and thievishness of Hermes; hence Gemoll reads h(gh/tora fwrw=n. But the god of elusive and often deceitful dreams is near akin to the god of thieving. This is perhaps the first reference to Hermes as a dream-god; in Od. 7.138 the last libation is probably offered to him as e)riou/nios, protector of the house, not as the sender of dreams; in Od. 5.47 f. (Od. 24.343 f.) he is the giver of sleep to men, but this appears to be not ordinary sleep, but a trance. See Nitzsch on Od. 7.138. In Homer Zeus is the sender of dreams; cf. Il. 2.6.

o)*pwp*ht=hra, “watcher for the night,” connected with o)/pwpa, from which o)pwpe/w was coined (Orph. Arg. 181, 1020). Matthiae compares Tac. Ann.ii. 40speculati noctem. The word suits a thief-god, who is h(mero/koitos ( Hes. Op.603). Hoffmann (Hermes und Kerykeion p. 41) understands “the eye of night,” but his view that Hermes was a moon-god, and so patron of thieves, is improbable. The converse is no doubt the truth, i.e. Hermes owes his connexion with the night to his character as a thief. No emendation is required.
