*pulhdo/kon (only here): the context shews that there is no reference to Hermes as propu/laios. Here he is the god who pries about the door, ready to pilfer. Cf. o(doido/kos, a highway robber ( Dioof Prusa iv. 95, and reff. in L. and S. ).

17-19. Most editors, after Ilgen, eject these lines on the ground that bou=s kle/yen is inconsistent with 20, where o(\s kai/ should introduce a new idea. But the kai/ serves to mark a particular achievement (the theft of the oxen), after the general statement of Hermes' precocious deeds, of which one was the cithara - playing (17). Gemoll rightly defends the passage.

e)*gkiea/rizen: the compound verb implies playing before an audience (cf. h. Apoll. 201); either the writer supposed some attendants to be present (a)mfipo/lous 60), or he mentally supplied e)n a)qana/toisi qeoi=si from the previous line, perhaps with a reminiscence of the scene at Apollo's birth (h. Apoll. 130 f.). See on 61. The emendations proceed from a standard of exactness foreign to the hymn. On the hiatus see Eberhard Metr. Beobacht. ii. p. 11.
*)apo/llwnos: for the ownership of the cows see on 71.

tetra/di t*=|h *prote/r|h: i.e. tetra/di mhno\s i(stame/nou. As Baumeister saw, the month is here bipartite, as in Hesiod ( Op.780mhno\s d' i(stame/nou triskaideka/thn). Hesiod also knows of the tripartite month (cf. Op.782 Op., 820), but this division would require prw/th| for prote/rh| here; cf. Op.785h( prw/th e(/kth.

For the birthday of Hermes on the fourth of the month cf. Plutarch Symp.ix. 3. 2, Theophr. Char.14 and other reff. in Lobeck Aglaoph. i. p. 430, PrellerRobert i. p. 391. Baumeister derives the four-sided figure of Hermes from this day; the converse is more probably the case, as the tetra/gwnon sxh=ma is certainly old; possibly the numerical coincidence is accidental. Roscher (Lex. i. 2370, 2386), who thinks Hermes to be a wind-god, explains the birthday as due to the idea that the fourth day of the month prognosticates the weather for the rest of the month (Theophr. sign. pluv. 8, Aratus 1148-1152, Georg.i. 432, N. H. xviii. 348). But the origin of Hermes is very problematical. The fourth day was also sacred to Aphrodite, Procl. on Hes. Op.800.
bo/as: in 116 the MSS. give the contracted form, at the same place in the verse; in 18 bou=s is proved by the metre.

Apollodorus (iii. 10. 2) makes the episode of the tortoise follow the theft of the cows, which provided Hermes with strings for his lyre: kai\ eu(ri/skei pro\ tou= a)/ntrou nemome/nhn xelw/nhn. tau/thn e)kkaqai/ras, ei)s to\ ku/tos xorda\s e)ntei/nas e)c w(=n e)/quse bow=n kai\ e)rgasa/menos lu/ran eu(=re kai\ plh=ktron. According to Paus.viii. 17. 5 the tortoise was found on Chelydorea, a mountain adjoining Cyllene (for its probable identification see Frazer ad loc.). In Pausanias' words (e)/nqa eu(rw\n xelw/nhn *(ermh=s e)kdei=rai to\ qhri/on kai\ a)p' au)th=s le/getai poih/sasqai lu/ran) there is nothing to indicate an acquaintance with the hymn.

The line has been ejected by most editors as a gloss on 24. But the repetition in 24, 25 is characteristic of the writer's narrative style; so 12, 13. With 25 cf. the similar expression in the hymn of the Delphian Boeo ( Paus.x. 5. 7) prw=tos d' a)rxai/wn u(/mnwn tekta/nat' a)oida/n (of Olen).
The cave of Maia is fitted up like an Homeric house; cf. mega/roio 146, proqu/roio 158, mega/loio do/moio 246. It has an au)lh/ in front, like the cave of Polyphemus, Od. 9.462.

sau=la: the word is applied to a horse (Sim. Am. fr. 18 kai\ sau=la bai/nwn i(/ppos w(s korwni/hs), and to maidens ( Anacr.55*dionu/sou sau=lai *bassari/des). So Eur. Cycl.40a)oidai=s barbi/twn saulou/menoi, Vesp. 1173 sauloprwktia=n, fr. 522 diasaulou/menon. The meaning of the adj. may be “moving delicately,” “mincing,” or (of a horse) “high-stepping.” The slow and deliberate movement of the tortoise's feet might be called “delicate” or “languid,” as Ruhnken explains; cf. Hesych. kou=fa, h(/suxa, trufera/. But the grammarians also took the word to express a kind of rolling or swaggering gait; cf. E. M. 270. 45 a)po\ tou= salou=sqai, o(/ e)stin a)kribw=s diabai/nein kai\ oi(onei\ sei/esqai. So sala/kwn, a swaggerer.

su/mbolon: like su/mbolos, an omen, which a person meets or sees on his road. There is no doubt a reference to the “godsend” which was proper to Hermes, the god of luck. The tortoise was the first e(/rmaion. For e(/rmaia see PrellerRobert i. p. 403 n. 3.
ou)k o)*nota/zw: sc. de/xomai to\n o)/rnin. For o)nota/zw cf. Hes. Op.256(elsewhere only in Aesch. Supp.11 in middle); o)nota<s>to/n h. Aphr. 254.
xoroi/tupe: only here in passive sense, “played in the chorus.” For the wrong accentuation of the MSS. cf. 56 where M has parai/bola for paraibo/la, and see on xix. 11.
daito\s e(tai/rh: cf. Od. 17.271 (fo/rmigc) h(\n a)/ra daiti\ qeoi\ poi/hsan e(tai/rhn, q 99 fo/rmiggo/s q' h(\ daiti\ sunh/oro/s e)sti qalei/h|. So nukto\s e(tai=re infra 290.

32, 33. e(/sso, which Tyrrell has lately proposed, was thought of by Matthiae, who, however, gave up his conjecture on account of the neglected digamma. This is no objection to the word, cf. Il. 3.57 la/i+non e(/sso xitw=na; and it does away with the great awkwardness of the construction, which had induced Hermann and others to take to/de=huc. Gemoll's punctuation (po/qen to/de kalo\n a)/qurma; ai)o/lon o)/strako/n e)ssi) gives a very weak sense. e(/sso suits the tone of the hymn admirably; the form is rare enough to he easily corrupted, especially in the neighbourhood of e)/ssh| 34.

35, 36. Both these verses have been unjustly suspected; 35 does not indeed add anything to the sense expressed in 34, but such repetitions are common in the hymn; see on 12. Line 36 occurs in Hes. Op.365, where it may refer to the advantage of having substance stored in the house; more probably, however, it is an isolated aphorism, advising women to stay at home and so avoid slander. Whatever the original Hesiodean context, the line is here a palpable parody, the humour of which is quite in keeping with the hymn. Hermes tells the tortoise “there's no place like home.” There may be additional point to the irony, as the tortoise was proverbially a “stay-at-home”; cf. coniug. praecept. vii. p. 421 th\n *)hlei/wn o( *feidi/as *)afrodi/thn e)poi/hse xelw/nhn patou=san oi)kouri/as su/mbolon tai=s gunaici\ kai\ siwph=s. Cf. id. Is. et Osir. 75, Aesop fab.154.The marginal note in some MSS. (see p. lv n. 1) only shews that the scholiast considered the hymn, as the work of Homer, to be older than Hesiod.

With the line cf. h. Dem. 230. e)/xma: Ruhnken's correction is certain; cf. the same error in Hesych. ai)/xmata: kwlu/mata, and Apoll. Arg. 4.201, where ˙e)/˙ cod. Laur. 32. 9 has ai)=xma. The mistake is due to the early identity of sound of e, when accented, and ai. Cf. the echoing sound (n)ai/xi=e)/xei in Callim. Ep. 29.

For the tortoise as a charm cf. N. H. xxxii. 4 terrestrium (sc. testudinum) carnes suffitionibus propriae magicisque artibus refutandis et contra venena salutares produntur. Pliny (l.c.) mentions a number of complaints, such as headache or toothache, which were thought to be cured by the blood, flesh, or gall of the various kinds of tortoises (see Pauly-Wissowa, art. “Aberglaube” 77). The above-mentioned superstitions refer to the animal when dead; for the protective power of a living tortoise (as here) cf. Geoponica i. 14. 8 (from Africanus), where the tortoise is a charm against hail for the vineyards; it must be carried in the right hand, on its back, round the vineyard, and then be left alive, in the same position, upon the ground in the middle of the land. For other such charms, by carrying a victim round a vineyard etc., see Frazer on Paus.ii. 34. 2.

a)*nap*hl/hsas: usually considered vox nihili, although retained by some of the older commentators, who explained it variously (=a)mpepalw/n from *a)naphlei=n, for a)napa/llein, Ilgen, as qhlei=n qa/llein, cf. Herwerden Lex. s.v.). The difficulty is increased by the uncertainty of the sense required for the participle: it may express either the preliminaries to killing the tortoise (i.e. throwing it upon its back), or the actual killing. Line 42 does not settle the question, as the process of cutting out the flesh might be either the cause of death, or might refer to the subsequent clearance of the flesh from the shell.

None of the emendations can be entertained. a)napilh/sas has found favour; pilei=n is used of pounding a polypus, to make it tender (Arist. fr. 235; and the verb is epic, cf. Apoll. Arg. 4.678). But the proper meaning of pilei=n is to “compress” or “squeeze,” e.g. “knead” bread, Anth. Plan. iv. 337, and this is quite inapplicable to a tortoise.

ai)w=*)n e(*ceto/rhsen, “cut” or “gouged out” the marrow; cf. 119. The verb expresses the action denoted in the other accounts by e)kkaqa/ras (Apollodorus), e)kdei=rai (Pausanias). The phrase (both here and in 119 tetorh/sas) is too definite to mean vitam perforando eximere (Ilgen), and shews that ai)w/n must have a more concrete sense than “life.” There seems no difficulty in understanding “marrow,” with probably a wider signification, for “flesh” generally. The material sense is established by Hesych. s.v. ai)w/n: tine\s de\ tw=n newte/rwn to
 nwtiai=on muelo
 (me/lo MSS.; corr. Musurus) a)pe/dwkan, w(s *(ippokra/ths, to
 ai)w=na/ tis nosh/sas e(bdomai=os a)pe/qane (Epidem vii. 7, p. 1240 D); cf. Erotian p. 49 (Klein), E. M. s.v. So also it was taken in Il. 19.27 e)k d' ai)w
 pe/fatai: cf. schol. D h)/toi a)nh/|rhtai o( bi/os . . . h)\ w(s oi( glwssogra/foi, ai)w
 e)/fqartai, o(/ e)stin o( nwtiai=os muelo/s. The Homeric glwssogra/foi, though wrong, must have based their interpretation on the usage of their own day. Pindar fr. 77 (Boeckh) ai)w
 de\ di) o)ste/wn e)rai/sqh almost certainly has this meaning, and probably Hippocr. peri\ a)gmw=n ii. 21 h)
 sfakeli/sh| to
 ai)w=na pa/nta a)ntisxei=n to\ no/shma, where Galen interprets to
 o(/lon bi/on. For the change of meaning from abstract to concrete cf. the Latin vitalia, “vitals”; still nearer is the Italian vita for the “back,” and, by a further transference, even the “body” of a dress.
o)reskw/|oio; see on h. Aphr. 257.
For the simile of no/hma cf. Il. 15.80 f. w(s d' o(/t' a)\n a)i+/ch| no/os a)ne/ros, o(/s t' e)pi\ pollh\n

l.quote: gai=an e)lhlouqw\s fresi\ peukali/mh|si noh/sh|

div2.l: “e)/nq' ei)/hn h)\ e)/nqa.” For the abbreviated (and therefore doubtless later) simile w(/ste no/hma see Od. 7.36 (quoted on 45), h. Apoll. 186, 448, Theogn. 985; so Thales ap. Diog. Laert.i. 35ta/xistos nou=s: dia\ panto\s ga\r tre/xei.

div2.p: qami_*nai/, though unusual, seems established; cf. Nicand. Ther. 239ai( de\ qaminai/ (xamhlai/ one MS.), and qameinai/ is recognised by Choeroboscus ap. Cramer An. Ox. ii. 180. So u(dati_nou/s Matro 79, u(dateinai/ Hippocr. Acr. c. 15, 19. Ruhnken, who defended the word, quoted forms in -rinos, o)pwrino/s etc. See Schulze Q. E. p. 253.

*)\h o(/te: M's reading has been rejected on the ground that it involves a double comparison to illustrate the same aspect, whereas in Homer accumulated similes are generally supposed to express different pictures or views; see Il. 2.144 f., 455-483, with Leaf's notes, and Jebb Homer p. 31; so Sout. 402-405. But passages like Il. 23.366 w)/s te ne/fos h)e\ qu/ella, h 36 w(s ei) ptero\n h)e\ no/hma shew that alternative similes can refer to the same aspect; cf. also Il. 19.374 (unnecessarily suspected), and see on 147. Apollonius also uses the alternative simile: e.g. Arg. Il. 4.877 pnoih=| i)ke/lh de/mas, h)u+/t' o)/neiros, 1298 f., 1452 f.; in the two last instances the second simile is introduced by h)\ o(/te, as here. For the simile drawn from the “twinkling of an eye” cf. 1 Ep. Cor. 15. 52 e)n r(iph=| o)fqalmou=; see on 279.

Baumeister's correction ai( de/ te rests on x ai(\ o(/te, but the corruption would be difficult to explain. There would be a single comparison, the passage of a thought in the brain being marked instantaneously by a movement of the eyelids. This sense is intelligible, although no improvement on M's reading; there appears to be no parallel nearer than the lines of Tennyson (quoted by Tyrrell): As when a great thought strikes along the brain, And flushes all the cheek.

Cf. Il. 19.242 au)ti/k' e)/peiq' a(/ma mu=qos e)/hn tete/lesto de\ e)/rgon, Apoll. Arg. 4.103 e)/nq' e)/pos h)de\ kai\ e)/rgon o(mou= pe/len e)ssume/noisin. So in prose, Herod.iii. 135tau=ta ei)=pe, kai\ a(/ma e)/pos te kai\ e)/rgon e)poi/ee.

47-51. Invention of the lyre. The word lu/rh, which is not Homeric, only once occurs in the hymn (423), which elsewhere uses ki/qaris (499 etc.) and fo/rmigc (64, 506). Moreover the expression in 423 lu/rh| d' e)rato\n kiqari/zwn shews that at this time the three names could be applied indifferently to one instrument. For the difference between the lyre and cithara see Guhl and Koner (Engl. Trans. p. 201 f.), Smith Dict. Ant., art. “Lyra” (Monro). The later cithara seems to have been developed about the time of Pindar. It is curious that the more recent word lu/ra was afterwards confined to the primitive tortoise-shell instrument; according to Monro, “the later form of the cithara was developed gradually, retaining the original name, which therefore included all varieties, until the new word lu/ra came into vogue for the commoner and more primitive kind.”
For Hermes' invention of the lyre cf. Nicand. Alex.560 f. a)/llote d' ou)rei/hs kutishno/mou, h(/n t' a)ka/khta

l.quote: au)dh/essan e)/qhken a)nau/dhto/n per e)ou=san
*(ermei/hs: sarko\s ga\r a)p' ou)=n no/sfisse xe/leion
ai)o/lon, a)gkw=nas de\ du/w paretei/nato pe/zais

div2.l: , Phaen.268 f. kai\ xe/lus h(/ t' o)li/gh: th\n ga/r t' e)/ti kai\ para\ li/knw|

l.quote: *(ermei/as e)to/rhse, lu/rhn de/ min ei)=pe le/gesqai

div2.l: . Neither account need have been borrowed from the hymn; and Lucian's version (dial. deor. vii.) is almost certainly unconnected with it, as he makes Apollo a lyre-player before Hermes found the tortoise. Bionix. 8w(s xe/lun *(erma/wn, ki/qarin w(s a)/nus' *)apo/llwn, also differs from the hymn; so Callim. h. Del. 253, where the seven-stringed lyre is invented by Apollo. For the invention as represented in art see Roscher i. 2432.

div2.p: do/nakes: explained by Pollux as equivalent to the ke/rata, or ph/xeis of the lyre: do/naka de/ tina u(polu/rion oi( kwmikoi\ w)no/mazon w(s pa/lai a)nti\ kera/twn u(potiqe/menon tai=s lu/rais (iv. 62). This is certainly wrong, the mistake being probably due, as Gemoll points out, to a misunderstanding of Ran. 232 proste/rpetai d' o( formigkta\s *)apo/llwn e(/neka do/nakos, o(\n u(polu/rion e)/nudron e)n li/mnais tre/fw. The right explanation (first given by Matthiae) is that the reeds were cut in different lengths (e)n me/troisi), and fixed in the shell; they thus served as a framework for the oxhide which was stretched over them, to form a sounding-board.

*peir/hnas should mean “fastening by the ends” (pei/rata): cf. Od. 22.175 , 192 seirh\n de\ plekth\n e)k au)tou= peirh/nante. Here Ebeling translates efficere ut per totum transeat, i.e. Hermes passes the do/nakes (which must then be the obj.) through the shell from end to end. But the sense “pierce” seems clearly required. It is possible that the verb may be equivalent to pei/rw, for which Baumeister compares Manetho ii. 106. Matthiae's correction tetrh/nas has been usually adopted, and this is supported by the variants suntetrai/nontas sumperai/nontas Herod.ii. 11.

dia\ r(inoi=o is unanimously made into an adjective; but if one dia/ has expelled anything, it is more likely to have expelled another preposition: cf. Il. 10.54 r(i/mfa qe/wn para\ nh=as: e)gw\ d' e)pi\ *ne/stora di=on; for para/ various MSS. read e)pi/. So Il. 10.141 kata\ nh=as a)na\ strato/n, where kata\ strato/n is also found; on Il. 10.298 a)\m fo/non, a)\n ne/kuas, dia/ t' e)/ntea, Eust. quotes a)na/ t' e)/ntea. Cf. also the MS. reading in h. Apoll. 452, h. Herm. 453. Here dia/ cannot be original in both places, and as dia\ r(inoi=o is clearly the more appropriate, kata\ nw=ta may be suggested; cf. Od. 7.40 e)rxo/menon kata\ a)/stu dia\ sfe/as, Apoll. Arg. 4.1002 kata\ sto/ma kai\ dia\ pe/tras. There is a simple exchange of kata/ and dia/ in Il. 13.383 , s 341.
*p/hxeis: the arms, made either of wood or goats' horns; see Guhl and Koner fig. 237. Cf. dial. deor. vii. 4 ph/xeis ga\r e)narmo/sas kai\ zugw/sas ktl.; dial. mar. i. 4.

*zugo/n: the crossbar which joined the two horns; cf. Il. 9.107, where it was of silver. There is here no mention of the ko/llopes, pegs by which the strings were fastened to the bar. For the stringing of a lyre cf. Od. 21.406-08.

On the variant in Antigonus of Carystus qhlute/rwn see Pref. p. xlv. The fem. of this word in Homer is only used of goddesses or women, with the exception of the variant nh/swn qhlutera/wn for thledapa/wn in Il. 21.454. Apollodorus substitutes the entrails of the cows; see on 24. On the seven-stringed lyre see Introd. p. 133. The invention of seven strings is attributed to Hermes by Lucian (dial. deor. vii. 4) and Ovid ( Fast.v. 106), but to Apollo by Callim. (h. Del. 253), and to Amphion by Paus. (ix. 5. 7). According to Timotheus Persae 233 f., Orpheus invented the xe/lus, Terpander the tenstringed lyre.

*teu=ce fe/rwn, which has given offence, is supported by 63 kate/qhke fe/rwn: in both cases the present participle contains the action antecedent to the aorist verb, the sense here being “when he had brought and fashioned his plaything.” For a similar vague use of the participle cf. h. Apoll. 491. Gemoll's punctuation teu=ce, fe/rwn is preferable to the conjectures, but the rhythm requires that fe/rwn ktl. should be taken with the preceding rather than the succeeding verb.
53, 54 are the model of 419, 420 and 501, 502.
kata\ me/ros: (each string) in turn. me/ros is not Homeric. On the lengthening see Hartel Hom. Stud. 35, 38; Eberhard Metr. Beob. ii. 26.

suerdale/on: so all MSS. here and in 420, and M in 502 (the rest i(mero/en). The sense is quite suitable, as smerdale/os is from &root;smerd, Lat. mordeo, Engl. smart (Doederlein gl. 589, Prellwitz Et. Wört. s.v.), and the primary meaning is therefore “acute,” “penetrating,” “clear.” Cf. h. xxxi.9 smerdno\n d' o(/ ge de/rketai o)/ssois, of acute vision. The adverb smerdale/on (a) is frequent in Homer with boa=n, etc., where the physical sense may be retained.
h)u+/te: rightly defended by Gemoll; Matthiae's oi)=a/ te would imply that the songs of Hermes were similar in subject to the jests at the banquet. The comparison of course lies in e)c au)tosxedi/hs.

*paraibo/la=parablh/dhn (first in Il. 4.4), the meaning of which, however, is doubtful (see Ebeling s.v.). Apollonius (Arg. Il. 2.60 , 448, *g 107) seems to use parablh/dhn for “in answer,” or “by retort.” This cannot be the original meaning of adverbial forms derived from paraba/llw, nor does it suit the Homeric passage. Leaf on Il. 4.4, comparing Il. 9.322 yuxh\n paraballo/menos, suggests “by way of risking one's self,” hence “provokingly.” Probably the adverb is connected with paraba/llw in its literal sense, i.e. “with side-thrusts,” “maliciously.”
For the custom, which was especially Dorian, the editors compare Pind. Ol.i. 22, Herod.vi. 129, Apoll. Arg. 1.458 (quoted on 454).
a)mfi/, as Baumeister notes, suggests the exordium of a hymn in praise of Zeus and Maia; see on h. xix.1.

o(/n appears to be the internal accusative with w)ri/zeskon, sc. o)/aron. Cf. h. xxiii.3 o)a/rous o)ari/zei, and for the omission of the substantive (commoner with feminines) the proverbs o( lagw\s to
 peri\ tw=n krew=n tre/xei, sc. dro/mon, ap. Diogen. vi. 5, Zenob. iv. 85, and non posse suaviter c. 2 kai\ to
 (th
 Bernadakis) peri\ tw=n krew=n e)pa/cein; Synes. Ep. 5 to
 u(pe yuxh=s qe/omen, schol. Plato Leg.739A, 820 C kinh/sw to
 a)f' i(era=s (sc. petto/n). Of the conjectures w(s is inadmissible graphically, and oi(\ is awkward.
e(tairei/|h: not in Homer. The adjective gives a certain dignity to filo/ths, “in the comradeship of love.” With the line cf. h. xxiii.2, 3.
For the repetition o)*nomakluto\n e)*conoma/zwn cf. Od. 4.178 e)k d' o)nomaklh/dhn *danaw=n o)noma/zes a)ri/stous.
e)*phetanou/s: whatever the derivation and original meaning may be, the sense “abundant” is quite clear in this passage and in 113.

The line can only mean that Hermes had other plans in view while he was singing; i.e. he was devising the theft of the cattle, while he pretended to be occupied with other themes. This implies that he sang to an audience (see on 17).
kreiw=n e)rati/zwn=Il. 11.551 , *r 660 (of a lion).
a)=lto (M): w)=rto xp. The same variant occurs Il. 20.62 (a)=lto vulg., w)=rto Massaliotic ed.).
Cf. Od. 4.843 fo/non ai)pu\n e)ni\ fresi\n o(rmai/nontes.

fhlhtai/: the correct spelling fh- is almost entirely the property of p; in 175, however, the family also reads fi-. This is not only the result of itacism, but of the authority of Herodian and Tryphon (in An. Ox. ii. 2712); in Hes. Op.375 the MSS. are divided, but elsewhere the iota prevails (Archil. fr. 46, Aesch. Cho.999, Soph. fr. 672, Rhes. 217, Callim. Hecale col. iv. 11 Gomperz). Photius has fhlou=n: a)pata=n in the series fh; and e)fh/lwsen Aesch. Ag.497 with schol. We may accept the common derivation from the root of sfa/llw, fallo. The word is not Homeric (=lhi+sth/r, as in 14). In Rhes. l.c. Hermes is fhlhtw=n a)/nac, C. I. G. 2299 (Kaibel Ep.1108) *(ermh=n to\n kle/pthn ti/s u(fei/leto; qermo\s o( kle/pths
div2.l: o(\s tw=n fhlhte/wn w)/|xet' a)/nakta fe/rwn.

div2.p: qe/wn: the variant qew=n came from qew=n 71, and should not have been retained by Gemoll. There is the same variation in Il. 20.53, where qew=n is certainly required. Hermes' haste is marked throughout this part of the hymn; cf. 86, 88, 94, 142, 150.

The hymn-writer calls the cows indifferently the property of the gods (cf. the use of u(me/teros 276, 310), or of Apollo (18, 22 etc.). On the analogy of the Vedic hymns (see Introd. p. 130) it might appear probable that in the oldest form of the myth the cattle belonged to the Sun, and afterwards to Apollo as Sun-god. In Homer Apollo has no herds of his own; the oxen slaughtered by the comrades of Odysseus belong to Helios (Od. 12.127 f.). In Apollodorus the actual ownership is left vague (kle/ptei bo/as a(\s e)/nemen *)apo/llwn). The Sun is specified in schol. Dion. Thrac. (Bekker Anecd. i. p. 752). See on h. Apoll. 412 f.
a)/mbrotoi: often of property belonging to the gods, “divine,” not necessarily “immortal”; indeed Hermes kills two of them (though such inconsistency would not be serious in this hymn).

a)khrasi/ous: Curtius' derivation from kei/rw suits this passage, and many examples of the similar form a)kh/ratos: Choerilus fr. 1 o(/t' a)kh/ratos h)=n e)/ti lei/mwn, Ibycus fr. 1 ka=pos a)kh/ratos, Eur. Hipp.73e)c a)khra/tou leimw=nos. But in Il. 15.498 , r 532 kth/mat' a)kh/rata, the form a)kh/ratos seems to mean “intact,” like a)kh/rios, from kh/r. In Od. 9.205 a)khra/sios is applied to oi)=nos, and in Il. 24.303 a)kh/ratos to u)/dwr. This suggests a connexion with kera/nnumi, but the use in these two passages may be due to false etymology, aided by a)/krhtos. If, as seems probable, a)khra/sios and a)kh/ratos properly mean “unharmed,” a similar false etymology (kei/rw) would readily adapt the words to leimw/n etc.
73, 74. The construction, with a double genitive, is grammatically rather complicated, but the sense is clear; cf. 82.

*planodi/as: for the lengthening of the first syllable (of three short syllables) see Schulze Q. E. p. 187 f. The word has been understood by some as a cogn. acc. from a subst. planodi/h, but it is probably an adj. of three terminations. So Hesych. plhnodi/a|: th=| peplanhme/nh| th=s o)rqh=s o(dou=. Schneider's plhnodi/as is recommended also by F. D. Allen Harvard Studies iv. 1893.
i)/xni): the MSS. give this form in 218, 220, 342, 351. a)*postre/yas, “turning their footsteps aside”; cf. Il. 22.197 tossa/ki min propa/roiqen a)postre/yaske parafqa\s
div2.l: pro\s pedi/on. The words explain planodi/as, not a)nti/a poih/sas ktl. doli/hs d) ou) ktl. = Theog. 547; cf. Od. 4.455, 529, Theog. 560.
div2.p: 77, 78. Matthiae and others condemn these lines, objecting to kata\ d' e)/mpalin ktl., which they translate “walking backwards”; they argue that Hermes' sandals were a sufficient disguise. But O. Schulze points out that kata\ d' e)/mpalin is only relative to the cows: “he walked the reverse way (to them)”; cf. katenanti/on. That the explanation is correct is proved by 211 e)copi/sw d' a)ne/erge ka/rh d' e)/xon a)nti/on au)tw=|. Ilgen compares the behaviour of Commodus, Herodian v. 6. Again, Hermann very needlessly objects to the cows walking backwards, as they were driven “by crooked ways.” However the “backing” of the cows is undoubtedly genuine; cf. 211, 221, 345. Hermes is trying to make assurance doubly sure. For this device cf. the story of Cacus, Verg. Aen.viii. 210, Livy i. 7, Auct. orig. gent. vi. 2, Ov. Fast.i. 550, Prop.iv. 9. 12, Mart.v. 65. 6.

79, 80. The principal difficulty in these lines is that the MSS. give two finite verbs (e)/riyen 79, and die/pleke 80) without connexion. To introduce this, au)ti/ka has usually been attacked, as it was omitted in the archetype of x; the lacuna, however, is purely clerical, and gives no ground for suspicion. e)/riyen is further difficult to explain, for Hermes was not now casting off his shoes, as in 139, but putting them on. Hence Matthiae conjectured e)/rayen, an excellent word, were it not identical with die/pleke. Postgate's brilliant suggestion r(iyi/n supplies a word very suitable to the context, and at the same time abolishes the first verb. The Homeric form is r(i/pessi, e 286. The word and form are sufficiently rare to make corruption easy. These skis had a real use along the sandy coast between the mouth of the Alpheus and the Triphylian Pylos (for this district see on h. Apoll. 424). So on his return journey (139) Hermes throws them into the Alpheus. The writer, however, whether from imperfect geographical knowledge or from natural epic vagueness, imagines the route between Pieria and Onchestus (79) and the neighbourhood of Cyllene to be sandy; and Apollo states that the first part of Hermes' journey was dia\ yamaqwde/a xw=ron (350). By this he may have meant the coast below Olympus or nearer Boeotia (Introd. p. 132). For a historical parallel see Arrian quoted on 83.
qaumata\ e)/rga=440, h. vii.34, Scut. 165. qaumato/s is not Homeric.
81, 82. The editors compare Il. 10.467 summa/ryas do/nakas muri/khs t' e)riqhle/as o)/zous.

mursinoeide/as: the latter half of the compound is practically otiose (=mursi/nous), the word being coined on the false analogy of i)oeidh/s etc. Schäfer, indeed (quoted by Baumeister), on Dion. comp. verb. 170 explains “myrtlelike,” ramos de genere myrtorum.
a)/gkalon: only here, for a)gkali/s, a bundle, armful. M's corruption neoqhle/an a)gkalwrh/n may, as Hermann thinks, contain a variant w(/rhs for u(/lhs. See J. H. S. xv. p. 284.

a)blabe/ws, “securely,” i.e. so as to walk safely, by disguising his footprints (cf. 222 f.). This somewhat proleptic sense, which Hermann and Schneidewin intended, may be extracted from the text without violence. Pierson quotes Suidas s.v. lu/gos (from Arrian) oi( de\ ku/klous e)k lu/gwn toi=s posi\ periarmo/santes au)toi/ te a)blabw=s e)ph/rxonto kata\ th=s xio/nos piezome/nhs u(po\ tw=n ku/klwn.

a)legu/nwn, “preparing” or “busying himself about” his journey; this correction seems necessary to the sense, and is justified by the variants in 361, 557. Hermann retained a)leei/nwn, but his explanation “avoiding footprints” is impossible, as o(doipori/hn cannot mean i)/xnia. The only conceivable rendering would be “avoiding (the toil) of walking,” i.e. through the sand (347), where his sandals might serve the purpose of snow-shoes; but, if this is the meaning, it is very obscurely expressed.

The syntax of the line is fixed by Demosth. xix. 165 th
 au)th
 o(do
 . . . kaqh/menoi, ... o(/te de\ ... e)peigo/menoi, Anth. Pal. ix. 83. 1 nho\s e)peigome/nhs w)ku
 dro/mon. The first four words of the line therefore go together. dolix/hn is not to be altered into doli/hn; Hermes made haste, for he had a long journey before him; cf. 143 dolixh=s o(dou=. The remarkable words au)totroph/sas and au)topreph\s w(/s should not be abandoned with the facility of most editors. au)totroph/sas by its form should be an aorist of au)totropei=n, for which the lexica give the parallel forms a)llotropei=n, a)lloiotropei=n, e(terotropei=n. If these words mean to “vary” or “be like another,” au)totropei=n may mean to “keep the same” or to “resemble one's self,” i.e. be original. au)tognwmonei=n from au)tognw/mwn is a similar formation. au)topreph/s, cf. a)rxaiopreph/s, doulopreph/s, may have much the same sense: “like one's self, not like any one else.” Either word refers to the “original” or unique appearance of Hermes. As he invented fire and one musical instrument, so he introduced this monstrous, awful (pe/lwra, ai)na/ 225, 226) mode of progression. This interpretation is perhaps strengthened by the fact that the variants are synonyms. It is therefore unnecessary to suppose that one is a corruption of the other, although such corruption would be easy, cf. Plat. Soph. 219C a)
 diapre/yeien, a)ntre/yeien.
Of the conjectures Tyrrell's au)toporh/sas is alone possible; but the sense is weak. How should Hermes lift cows if not on foot?

de/mwn a)*nqou=san a)lw/hn: this reading of M was defended in J. H. S. xv. p. 285 against Gemoll's objections. The old man's occupation is more specifically stated 90 o(/s te futa\ ska/pteis and 207 e)/skapton peri\ gouno\n a)lwh=s oi)nope/doio. His work was somewhat like that of Laertes, Od. 24.227 listreu/onta futo/n, i.e. he was digging about his vines in bud (a)nqou=san), clearing the spaces between the rows, and making trenches round the roots. This process was called gu/rwsis by Greek agriculturists, cf. Xen. Oec.xx. 20, Geopon. v. 20 gurw/somen de/, toute/sti periska/yomen; cf. iv. 1. 5, 13. 1 etc. and v. 25 ska/ptein de\ xrh\ pro\ blastou= probolh=s. A later time for this operation is mentioned by Columella iv. 28 pubescentem vero et quasi adulescentem convenit religare foliisque omnibus nudare, tum et crebris fossionibus implere. This passage amply justifies a)nqou=san. Add Hesiod Op.570-72 to/te dh\ ska/fos ou)ke/ti oi)ne/wn; Pallad. iv. 7 Op., iv. 20, Aeschines ii. 156, Menand. Georg.64, Mosch.iv. 100, Theocr. xxv. 27 futoska/fos, and Luke xiii. 8. The verb de/mein may very well be used of this work, “stablishing,” i.e. building up or tending a vineyard to which the epithet e)u+ktime/nh is applied, Od. 24.226. In Homer de/mein is confined to the building of walls or other edifices, but Herodotus uses it for road-making. Fick perversely alters de/mwn to ne/mwn here, and ne/monta to de/monta 187 (B. B. xxii. p. 269).
On the site of Onchestus see h. Apoll. 230. The place appears only in this version of the story; see Introd. p. 133.

e)*pikampu/los w)/mous: cf. Od. 24.242 h)= toi o( me
 kate/xwn kefalh
 futo
 a)mfela/xaine. Ruhnken quotes Lucian Tim.7ska/ptei de\ oi)=mai e)pikekufw/s. The reading of M e)pikampu/la cu/la is unmetrical; it may point to a variant e)pikampu/la ka=la, borrowed from Hes. Op.427.Cf. 112 infra. cu/la would be a gloss on ka=la. l.c. Proclus explained ka=la by cu/la e)pikamph= o)/nta ta\ a)mfide/a. The “bent wood” might be in apposition to futa/, of the crooked woody stem of the vine; cf. Eur. Cycl.572to\ cu/lon th=s a)mpe/lou.

*poluoin/hseis: Ilgen's correction (after M) is certain. That the futa/ were vines appears from oi)nope/doio 207. fe/r|hsi, absolutely, “bear,” is well attested; see L. and S. s.v. Il. 1.5. Hermes begins by a compliment, no doubt in a bantering spirit; at all events poluoini/a, polu/oinos have a double meaning, and the verb may be intended ambiguously. But the exact point of 91 is obscure, perhaps owing to the lacuna which Groddeck saw to be necessary after the line. The missing verse or verses must have contained a principal verb to govern ei)=nai. The sense may be “(if you are asked questions remember) not to see when you have seen” etc. In this case there will be no close connexion between the ironic poluoinh/seis ktl. and 92, 93. It is possible, however, that the results of the vindemia are described in the two latter lines; poluoinh/seis will then mean only “you will be full of wine,” and so “are not like to see when you have seen,” and to be deaf when you have heard, and to hold your tongue (i.e. suffer aphasia from over-drinking) unless your own interests are harmed. This would be a covert hint not to inform on Hermes. (So Matthiae explains; see also J. H. S. xvii. p. 255, but the sense can hardly be deemed satisfactory.)

kai/ te i)dw
 m\h i)dw/n: it is clear from the inconsistency that the digamma was not felt in mh\ i)dw/n, and that there is a real hiatus in te i)dw/n. The poet knew the latter collocation from Homer (e.g. Il. 4.279), but had no Homeric justification of the metre. See Windisch de hymn. Hom. maj. 1869 p. 40. For the expression cf. P. V. 463 oi(\ prw=ta me
 ble/pontes e)/blepon ma/thn, “eyes have they, but they see not,” Sept. c. Theb. 246 mh/ nun a)kou/ous' e)mfanw=s a)/kou) a)/gan, Plaut. Mil. Glor. ii. 6, 88, Demosth. xxv. 89 oi( me
 ou(/tws o(rw=ntes ta\ tw=n h)tuxhko/twn e)/rga w(/ste, to\ th=s paroimi/as, o(rw=ntes mh\ o(ra=n kai\ a)kou/ontes mh\ a)kou/ein, Plutarch de liberis educ. 13 E w(s e)/nia tw=n prattome/nwn o(rw=ntas mh\ o(ra=n kai\ mh\ a)kou/ein a)kou/ontas.

katabla/pt|h: probably passive, “unless you are hurt on your own part,” to\ so\n au)tou= being then accusative; it might be nominative, “unless your own affairs hurt you,” cf. Eur. Phoen.990mh\ to\ so\n kwlue/tw, but this seems less suitable. The general sense is obviously a request to the old man to “mind his own business.”
sune/seue: an excellent conjecture of Demetrius; Hermes now drives the cows in a body, not straggling, cf. 106. bow=n ktl.=Il. 23.260.
au)lw=nas: not in Homer, who also does not use keladeino/s of places.
e)*pi/kouros: either general, “that gives help” (rest), opposed to dhmioergo/s, or aider of Hermes in his theft.
daimoni/h: for the Homeric a)/mbrotos, l 330.

The editors find difficulties in these lines, and eject either 97, 98 or 99, 100. Gemoll objects that morning cannot be breaking while Hermes has still so much to do: he steals the cattle at sundown 68, comes to the Alpheus at moonrise 99, and finally reaches home in the early morning 143 (cf. 155 po/qen to/de nukto\s e)n w(/rh| e)/rxh|;). Moreover, the German scholars argue that one of these two pairs of verses must be spurious, as the moon would not rise in the early morning on the fifth of the month, the day after Hermes was born (cf. 19). This minute criticism may be chronologically and astronomically correct, but it is of no great value in dealing with a hymn in which the blame for such inconsistencies is to be laid on the writer, rather than on a supposed interpolator. Wolfe's poem on The Burial of Sir John Moore affords an exact parallel: the line By the struggling moonbeam's misty light has been shewn to be inaccurate, as the moon was invisible at the time of the burial (Ball Story of the Heavens p. 51); but it has yet to be suggested that the line was “interpolated.” See further on 141.
*(h *plei/wn: cf. Il. 10.252 parw/|xhken de\ ple/wn nu\c
div2.l: tw=n du/o moira/wn, trita/th d' e)/ti moi=ra le/leiptai.
div2.p: o)/reros: for the Homeric h)w/s, first in Hes. Op.577, and Ibycus fr. 7.
dhmioergo/s: the morning starts men on their work; cf. Hes. Op.580h)w/s, h(/ te fanei=sa pole/as e)pe/bhse keleu/qou
div2.l: a)ne/ras, Callim. Hecale col. iv. 8 f., Orph. h. 78. 6, Verg. Aen.xi. 183, Ov. Met.iv. 663.So Tennyson In Memoriam 121 Bright Phosphor, fresher for the night, By thee the world's great work is heard Beginning. Hesychius' explanation dhmiourgo/s: o( h(/lios o(/ti pa/nta pe/ssei kai\ qe/rei is mistaken.

div2.p: The genealogy of Selene, daughter of Pallas, the son of Megamedes, is confined to this hymn. According to Theog. 371 f., Selene is the daughter of Hyperion and Theia.

With regard to Pallas, Gemoll rightly rejects a connexion with Arcadian myths, in the person of Pallas the founder of Pallantium ( Paus.viii. 3. 1). This hero was son of Lycaon ( Apollod.iii. 8. 1), and could scarcely be related to Selene. The Hesiodean Pallas (a Titan) was son of Crius (Theog. 375 f.) and grandson of Uranus (Theog. 134). The brother of this Pallas, Perses, was father of Hecate (cf. Theog. 377 and 409), and Gemoll suggests that, if Pallas is related to Hecate, he may also be readily connected with Selene. This is probable enough, although the two goddesses are quite distinct in Hesiod. Nothing is known of Megamedes, who here takes the place of the Hesiodean Crius, but there seems no reason to deny his existence; see Mayer die Giganten p. 67.

The description is very elliptical. Hermes first drives the cows to the river (i.e. to the ford, as 398, Thryon or Epitalion) and thence to Pylos (first named at 216). On his return (139) he throws his shoes into the river, when they ceased to be useful. The mention of the Alpheus fixes Pylos as the Triphylian or Lepreatic. The site of this place was lost even in antiquity, but it is generally placed on the hills looking over the lagoons and sandhills which extend from the mouth of the Alpheus southwards. See Introd. p. 132, h. Aph. 424.

a)dmh=tes, “unyoked”; cf. Ant. Lib. 23. 3 e(kato\n bou=s a)/zugas (a)pelau/nei). The form (for the more common a)/dmhtoi ) occurs Hom. Od. 4.637, of mules. There is no objection to the adjective here used adverbially with i(/kanon .
e)s: here used loosely for e)pi/, “to” (not “inside,” as the context shews; see on 106).
au)/lion: for the Homeric staqmo/s. It is used of the cave itself = la/i+non a)/ntron 401.

kai/: in apodosi. e)s au)/lion: here the preposition implies actual entrance. Any vagueness here and in 103 is due to the hymn-writer, and is not to be pressed as a mark of interpolation, with Hermann, who ejects 103-105.

a)qro/as ou)/sas: however we account for -as, the word is not to be disturbed. The influence of Hesiod is probably to be traced here, as elsewhere in the hymn; cf. Theog. 60 kou=ras o(mo/fronas, Op. 564 tropas h)eli/oio; other exx. Theog. 267, 401, 534, 653, 804, Op. 675, fr. 190.
ou)/sas: the latter form is defended by h. Ap. 330, where, however, emendation is easy; see note ad loc.

The line is probably modelled on Hom. Il. 2.776 lwto\n e)repto/menoi e)leo/qrepto/n te se/linon (of horses standing by the chariots). Here the writer presumably describes the cows as feeding while they are driven towards the stall; or, possibly, they feed again in the stall. At any rate it is needless to transpose 106, 107 (Matthiae), or to press the line.

e)pemai/eto with acc. seems established by 511 sofi/as e)kma/ssato te/xnhn, as against the Homeric use with gen., Hom. Il. 10.401 dw/rwn e)pemai/eto qumo/s. M's tu/nh is probably a meaningless corruption, and does not authorise the conjecture of the dative te/xnh|. Some part of te/xnh is certainly required, as the invention of the art of making fire is significant in the myth.
On this primitive method of fire-making in classical times cf. schol. on Apoll. Arg. 1.1184, Sen. quaest. nat. ii. 22, Plin. N. H. xvi. 40, Hesych. s. v. storeu/s. Kuhn Herabkunft des Feuers p. 36.
da/fnhs: the hard wood of the bay-tree was used as the tru/panon or “borer”; Plin. l.c. sed nihil hedera praestantius, quae teratur, lauro quae terat.

e)pe/leye, “prune to a point,” “sharpen,” of the tru/panon. This sense of e)pi/ in composition is recognised by the lexx. in e)piko/ptein, e)pite/mnein For the simple verb, of ordinary pruning, cf. Hom. Il. 1.236 peri\ ga/r r(a/ e( xalko\s e)/leye | fu/lla te kai\ floiou/s. e)ni/alle, M's reading, may very possibly, as Postgate thinks, be a transposition of lei/aine, for which cf. Quintus xii. 136 d' a)/p' a)p' o)/zous lei/ainon.

As Kuhn pointed out, it is clear that a line in which the actual friction is described has been lost; otherwise the “hot blast” would have been the result of “trimming a laurel branch, held firmly in the hand, with a knife.” Moreover, the words a)/rmenon e)n pala/mh| are appropriate, not to the tru/panon, but to the storeu/s, which need to be kept steady. The missing line must have contained a word to indicate the stroreu/s (perhaps kisso/s, cf. Pliny l.c., or r(a/mnos, an alternative word in Hesych.) and a verb like tri/bein.
pala/mh|: the plur. pala/mh|s is not necessary, although read by Schneidewin from Hom. Il. 18.600, Hom. Od. 5.234.
a)/mpnuto: the correct quantity (cf. Schulze Q. E. 324) shews the exactness of M's reading, against the other MSS.
qermo\s a)u+tmh/= Hes. Theog. 696. On the citation ap. schol. on Hom. Il. 18.222 see p. li n. 1.

The editors eject the line as a gloss, but it may be genuine as is, no doubt, the similar line 25. a)ne/dwke, “gave forth,” cf. a)ne/kaie 115; not “gave back,” for Baumeister is surely wrong in seeing an allusion to Hes. Op. 50 to\ me\n au)=tis e)u+\s pai=s *)iapetoi=o | e)/kley' a)nqrw/poisin. According to the usual tradition it was, of course, Prometheus that gave men fire, or restored it when hidden by Zeus. The present line does not necessarily imply a different tradition: Hermes does not discover fire, but only invents one method of ignition by “fire-sticks,” and (so) “gave fire.” Fire was also produced by the flint (Sen. quaest. nat. ii. 22), and by the burning-glass or crystal (see Blaydes on Aristoph. Cl. 768); this was particularly used for sacred fire, Orph. Lith. 184 f.; and the myth of Prometheus is specially concerned with the preservation of fire in the fennel-stalk, although in one account ( Diod. v. 67) the invention of purei=a is also attributed to Prometheus; Sikes and Willson on Aesch. P. V. xvi. f.

ou)=la: Gemoll's au)=a (from the similar passage Hom. Od. 18.308) cannot be accepted; ou)=la is sound, though the meaning is not certain. The Homeric sense of vou=los is “close,” “thick,” but it is applied to wool or hair only. In later Greek the word has a wider extension, of plants or trees (see L. and S.). Here it might be roughly equivalent to e)phetana/, “in thick bundles,” or possibly “bushy,” with leaves, twigs, and all. Ebeling, however, is probably right in connecting with o(/los/ (for ou)=los in this sense cf. Hom. Od. 17.343, Hom. Od. 24.118 and infra 137), i.e. “whole” branches; so Meyer (Griech. Et. s.v. o(/los i.e. o)/lvos).
e)phetana/: with synizesis, as in Hes. Op. 607, Orph. *)erg. kai *(/hm. 11, 10, Maximus 465; cf. basilh=es Hes. Op. 263, tokh=es h. Dem. 137. The word has open vowels in 61.
The MSS. form fu/zan may be dialectal; cf. e.g. Herwerden Lex. s.v. Z.

u(pobruxi/as: the adjective elsewhere means “submerged,” but as two verbs u(pobruxa/omai and u(pobru/xw exist, in the sense of “roaring in a low tone,” u(pobru/xios may exist in the same meaning. There is, however, the difficulty that the u in bruxa/omai and cognates is long; hence Ludwich with some probability writes u(pobru/xous. But a synizesis of -ia is possible.

The manuscript reading seems satisfactory and complete in sense; e)gkli/nwn, to which objection has been taken, certainly means much the same as e)ku/linde, but the action thus pleonastically expressed is clear: the cows being on their backs (118) Hermes “turned them round and rolled them over” in order to reach their ai)w=nes or backbones. These he pierced with his glu/fanon, a process essentially similar to the modern method of pole-axing; cf. Il. 17.520 f. See J. H. S. xv. p. 286. Gemoll's a)gkli/nwn, from Orph. Arg. 314 f. sfa/zon a)nakli/nas kefalh/n, does not suit the context; Hermes would not throw back the cows' heads to strike at their backbones. M's e)kkri/nas can hardly be given a meaning. tetor/hsas: it is curious that the editors have rejected the manuscript reading here. The form is quite justified as a “reduplicated aorist”; see Leaf on Il. 10.267. So Fick (B. B. xxii. p. 269), comparing Pax381tetorh/sw. The aor. tetorei=n is quoted by Hesych. The usual reading te torh/sas must involve a lacuna, which is here unnecessary.
e)/rgw| d) ktl.: cf. Hes. Op.382e)/rgon de/ t' e)p' e)/rgw| e)rga/zesqai.
*gera/smia: not in Homer; explained by 129.

O. Müller thinks that the writer refers to a stalactite cave, now called to\ sph/laion tou= *ne/storos, near the Messenian Pylos, the formation of which suggested the skins. The view is attractive, and is accepted by Baumeister and Frazer. In one of the caves at Cheddar there is a stalagmite configuration which closely resembles a curtain; at Adelsberg (Austria) there are stalactites in the form of drapery. But the theory breaks down if the reference is to the Triphylian, not to the Messenian Pylos (see Introd. p. 132); at least there is no known stalactite cave in that region. D'Orville first suggested (see J. P. xxv. p. 254) that these were actual skins, preserved as relics. As Gemoll notes, the skins were probably exhibited outside the cave, which would negative the theory of stalactites (see below). Instances of such relics are quoted in J. H. S. xvii. p. 257 (e.g. the skin of Marsyas, Herod.vii. 26); to these may be added Quaest. Rom. 4 (the horns of a cow dedicated by Servius Tullius in the temple of Diana on the Aventine), Paus.iii. 16. 1(Leda's egg)Paus., vi. 22. 1(bones of Pelops)Paus., ix. 19. 7(plane-tree at Aulis), schol. T on Il. 15.21 (mu/droi shown by guides). The list could be amplified, especially for relics which served as talismans (see Frazer on Paus.viii. 47. 5). The hymn-writer seems to refer to a local Triphylian legend; but nothing is known of the cave where the skins were preserved.

In regard to the disposition of the skins of victims in actual ritual, the practice was to sell them (Ath. Mitth. vii. 72, Dittenberger 566, 620; the proceeds were called dermatiko/n), or they became the perquisites of the priests (Ath. Mitth. xiii. 166, xxiv. 267 f., C. I. G. G. S. 235, Dittenberger 595, 599 f., 734 § 4 etc., Paton and Hicks Inscr. Cos 37, 38).

katastufe/lw|: first in Theog. 806; Hesych. explains by kata/chros. e)*ni/: Barnes' e)pi/ is from 404, but is not absolutely necessary here; as e)ni/ can be taken as a loose equivalent of e)pi/. At all events the skins were probably hung outside the cave; cf. 404 pe/trh| e)p' h)liba/tw|.

The line was left hopelessly corrupt until O. Müller (Hyperbor. Röm. Stud. p. 310, quoted by Baumeister) accepted M's me/tassa. Previous critics had combined ta/met), ta/nuq) etc. The neut. plur. me/tassa is recognised in Cramer An. Ox. i. 280 w(/sper para\ th
 e)pi/ gi/netai e)/pissa ou(/tw kai\ para\ th
 meta/ me/tassa. The fem. occurs Od. 9.221 xwri\s me
 pro/gonoi xwri\s de\ me/tassai. See Smyth Ionic p. 305 n. 3, Schulze K. Z. xxix. 263. The neuter may no doubt be used adverbially, so that it is unnecessary with Schneidewin and Baumeister to write me/taze. The meaning of ta\ me/tassa may be “in the time intervening.” (from then till now), or, more probably, “thereafter” simply. The sense is further emphasised in the next line by meta\ tau=ta, just as the idea of poluxro/nioi is repeated by dhro
 kai\ a)/kriton.

a)/kriton: adverbial, as in 577 to\ d' a)/kriton, and h. xis. 26 a)/krita. Gemoll's objection to the word is quite unfounded. The sense is “without bounds,” i.e. continually. Hermann compares Georg.iii. 476nunc quoque post tanto.
xarmo/frwn: the true reading is again preserved by Hesychius, who quotes it as a title of Hermes.
*pi/ona e)/rga: elsewhere of rich fields; Gemoll compares Il. 12.283 , d 318. Here the phrase suggests a parodic style, “the rich works of his hands.”

dw/deka moi/ras: this is the first reference to a system of twelve gods, of whom Hermes is one. As Gemoll rightly explains, Hermes is consciously claiming his prerogative, and is himself instituting the ritual which is hereafter to be observed by men.

klhropalei=s: a(/pac leg. *ge/ras: cf. 122 nw=ta gera/smia, and Od. 4.66 where also the back is the portion of honour. The word was technical in worship for the portion set aside whether for gods or priests; see Dittenberger index s.v.
o(si/hs krea/wn: cf. h. Dem. 211 o(di/hs e(/neken. The “rite” of course lay in eating sacrificial meat.
o)dm\h . . . e)/teire: from Od. 4.441 f.

M's e)pepei/qeto is the conjecture of a scribe for metrical reasons, after the loss of oi(, with a reminiscence of Od. 2.103 h(mi=n d' au)=t' e)pepei/qeto qumo\s a)gh/nwr. For similar instances see J. H. S. xv. p. 287.

The reason why Hermes, although kreiw=n e)rati/zwn (64), refrains from eating is not evident. Robertson Smith (Rel. Sem. rev. ed. p. 306) remarks that Hermes is called boufo/nos (436, where see note), and that “the story seems to be one of the many legends about the origin of sacrifice.” The present passage, however, appears only to allude to the institution of sacrifice to the twelve gods, with special reference to Hermes' inclusion in the number (see on 128). Further, although Robertson Smith proves the sanctity of oxen in early times, it does not seem that the idea is present here. The sanctity would be violated by killing as well as by eating oxen; whereas Hermes has no scruple in killing, but only refrains from eating. The passage may imply that Hermes was unwilling to eat the flesh of any animal; he was honoured libanwtoi=s kai\ yaistoi=s kai\ popa/nois Theopomp. ap. Porphyr. de abst. ii. 16 (at Methydrion); milk and honey were offered to him (cf. Anth. Pal. ix. 72, 318 and 744). It is true that animals were also sacrificed to Hermes, e.g. a ram (Sauppe die Myster. von Andania, ausgewählte Schrift. p. 274), and a goat at Eleusis (C. I. A. i. 5), cf. a vase in the B. M. (Cat.ii. B 362), and victims were offered at Cyllene (Gemin. elem. astr. i. 14); so in Homeric times Od. 19.398 (lambs and goats); but the local ritual recorded by the writer may have demanded a bloodless sacrifice. Otherwise we must accept Gemoll's explanation that Hermes is humorously placed in an awkward predicament: he has sacrificed to the twelve gods, and is now about to begin his meal, like a human sacrificer; but he remembers in time that he is himself one of the twelve, who have to be content with the savour of sacrifice, without its substancc.
Apollodorus (iii. 10. 2) does not follow the hymn; see Introd. p. 130.

†*per=hn†: the scribe who wrote this (and perhaps pe/rhn) also) intended to read perh=nai from perai/nw; but neither this verb nor pera=n (Barnes' conjecture usually accepted) are suitable to the act of eating. Perhaps pe/rhn may be retained as an adverb, pe/rhn kata/ meaning “across (the e(/rkos o)do/ntwn) and down the throat.” This would imply a lacuna, with a verb like kaqi/hmi, cf. Il. 24.642 laukani/hs kaqe/hka, and Il. 19.209. The proposal in J. H. S. xvii. p. 258 i(mei/ronti/ per ei(=n) would introduce this verb, but the metre seems decisive against the emendation. For the throat in this or similar contexts cf. also Eur. Ion1037, Eur. Orest.41, Nicand. Alex. 131.

There has been doubt about Hermes' arrangement; but it seems clear that the two cows were divided into three parts: the skins were left outside on a flat rock (124); the flesh, chines, and tripe, etc. (122), which had been cooked on spits and then divided into twelve portions, were now brought into the cave (134), and put away; lastly the heads and feet were burned. ta\ me/n (i.e. dhmo\n kai\ kre/a) is answered by e)pi\ de/. There is no question of a lacuna, as Schneidewin and Baumeister suppose.

met/hora ktl.; Hermes stowed the portions higher up in the cave (? on a ledge of rock), “to be a memorial of his childish theft.” Here again, some of the commentators see allusion to the natural configuration of the cave, whose stalactites, in what way is not clear, suggested the “twelve portions.” It is more probable that Hermes was initiating some piece of ritual which was afterwards observed inside the cave, in honour of the twelve gods.
fwr=hs: Hermann's neat emendation depends on 385, where M (which is wanting here) alone has fwrh/n; see there on the word.

a)ei/ras: a)gei/ras, which is usually accepted, is not necessary: Hermes lifted, i.e. piled, fresh wood upon his old fire. The repetition of the verb is no objection. The fire was allowed to burn down to hot embers, before the meat could be roasted (121), as it was held directly over the fire on spits (cf. Il. 9.212 f.); Hermes now needs a blazing fire to burn the heads and feet.

ou)lo/pod' ou)loka/rh*na: there was now nothing left of the cows except the heads and feet; Ruhnken is therefore right in understanding these words as substantival, “all the feet and heads.” Gemoll compares o(lo/pteros, o(lo/sxoinos. The words may belong to ritual (as Gemoll suggests); cf. o(lokautw=. In any case ou)lo- is here from ou)=los, Ion. for o(/los, in spite of the fact that in Od. 19.246 ou)loka/rhnos means “with curly hair.”
kata\ xre/os: for the Homeric kata\ moi=ran. So Apoll. Arg. 3.189.
e)ma/rane: for the form in a Hermann compares Il. 21.347 a)nchra/nh|. a)ma/qune apparently = “dusted,” “sanded,” like a)/maqos.

The line is ejected by Matthiae and others. Gemoll considers it inconsistent with 99, 100, but genuine if 97, 98 are an interpolation. There seems to be no serious difficulty (see on 97 f.). *pan*nu/xios: all the rest of the night; Gemoll compares panhme/rios in Il. 1.472; add Od. 2.434 pannuxi/h and Il. 18.453 pa=n h)=mar. M's pannu/xion is less idiomatic, but could stand adverbially.
e)*pe/lampe: cf. Il. 17.650; but it is an open question whether kate/lampe (M) should not be preferred, as although not Homeric it is a very suitable word; see L. and
ou)de/: co-ordinate with ou)de/ tis 143; the translation “not even” (Edgar) is wrong.

*dio\s . . . *(erm=hs: the expression is not very common, but perfectly good Greek in poetry from Homer onwards: cf. Il. 2.527 *)oi+lh=os taxu\s *ai)/as, Hippon. fr. 21 A *kullh/nie *maia/dos *(ermh=, Soph. Aj.172*tauropo/la *dio\s *)/artemis, ibid. 1302, Anth. Pal. vi. 334. 3 *maia/dos *(erma=, Anth. Plan. i. 11. 3 *maia/dos *(erma=n.

The cave had an au)lh/ in the open air (see on 26), but the me/garon, through the keyhole of which Hermes passed, must be identical with part, at least, of the a)/ntron. There is thus a tautology in saying “he passed through the keyhole of the hall, and made straight for the cave.” But this repetition does not warrant us in suspecting 148, 149 with Baumeister, or in seeing two recensions with Hermann.
The temple of Hermes was on the summit of Cyllene; it was in ruins by the time of Pausanias (vii. 17. 1). There is no record of the cave.

doxmwqei/s: the use of doxmo/s, do/xmios in Homer (Il. 12.148 , *y 116) shews that the verb means “turning sideways,” not, as Baumeister translates, incurvata cervice; so of a boar turning suddenly Scut. 389. The passage is no doubt a reminiscence of Od. 4.802 e)s qa/lamon d' ei)sh=lqe para\ klhi+=dos i(/manta. There the subject is an ei)/dwlon which is unsubstantial; here doxmwqei/s and h)=ka posi\ probibw=n 149 shew that there is no metamorphosis of Hermes, as some commentators suppose; the god only “squeezes through sideways,” like (i.e. as quickly or easily as) a wind or mist. The passage is no support to Roscher's theory of a wind-god.

Cf. Od. 6.20 h( d' a)ne/mou w(s pnoih\ e)pe/ssuto de/mnia kou/rhs (of a dream). For the double comparison cf. Apoll. Arg. 4.877 au)th\ de\ pnoih=| i)ke/lh de/mas, h)u+/t' o)/neiros (of Thetis). Here two aspects may be illustrated, “as quick as the wind, as invisible as air”; probably, however, the comparison refers simply to the unsubstantial quality of wind and air; see on 45. au)/r|h o)*pwrin*=|h: cf. o)pwrino\s *bore/hs, *f 346, e 328, and, for o)pwrino/s, Schulze Q. E. 474, Danielsson p. 60. Quintus iv. 111 has au)/rh| u(phw/h| e)nali/gkion.
i)qu/sas: governing a)/ntroio “making straight for the cave”; cf. Il. 15.693, and the gen. after i)qu/s, a 119, g 17.

*pi/ona *nho/n: not the cave generally, but the inner part, which was the nymph's special dwelling-place; cf. the use of nao/s=the cella of a temple. The word recognizes her divinity, and perhaps alludes also to a later cult in the cave; cf. 247.
*probibw=n: for the form see on 225.

w(/s *per e)*p' ou)/dei, “as (might be expected) on the floor”; i.e. there was no echo in the cave; cf. the common Attic use of w(s in ou)de\ a)du/natos, w(s *lakedaimo/nios, ei)pei=n Thuc.iv. 84, etc. This sense seems quite satisfactory, though there is neatness in Fick's w(/s per e)pwdh=| (B. B. xxii. 269).

It is doubtful whether there is an asyndeton here or at 153. Gemoll punc-tuates at a)qu/rwn, but that participle and ei)lume/nos seem logically to depend on kei=to rather than on e)pw/|xeto. In either case, there is no need to suppose a lacuna, with Schneidewin. The asyndeton is a marked characteristic of this hymn; cf. 17, 25, 111, 237, 438, 447, 478, 482, 512.
ei)lume/nos: there is of course no difficulty in the accusative spa/rganon, although the dative is Homeric with this verb, and occurs in 245.

*per' i)*gnu/si: peri/, “about his thighs,” is required by the sense, as in Theocr. xxv. 242 per' i)gnu/h|sin e(/lice ke/rkon (where there are similar variants); para/, of p, is less good, as we should expect par' i)gnu/as. The question whether peri/ can admit elision, is raised on Pindar Ol.iv. 265 Ol., vi. 38, and (in composition) Pyth.iii. 52, Nem.xi. 40, fr. 122. In composition there are exx. in Hesiod (Theog. 678 peri/axe, 733 peroi/xetai), and even in Attic ( Aesch. Ag.1144pereba/lonto, Aesch. Eum.637pereskh/nwsen, recognised by scholia). For the evidence of inscriptions cf. C. I. G. 1064 per' e)mei=o (Megara), 1688 pe/rodos=peri/odos (Delphi). Schulze Q. E. 133 n. 7, Smyth Ionic § 683 allow no exceptions; Kühner-Blass i. § 53 give the exceptions to the general rule; van Leeuwen Ench.p. 540 defends the elision in Aeolic and Doric. See further La Roche Hom. Unters. i. p. 121, schol. A on Il. 15.651 where Hellanicus took per e(tai/rou for peri/, *ai)olikw=s. The possibility of the elision in Pindar seems clearly established, and the licence may very well be allowed in a hymn which admits forms like a)qro/a^s 106. M‘Daniel's non-Ionic pala/mh|s peri\ would remove the elision.

lai=fos a)qu/rwn: both words seem sound; “playing with the bed-clothes” is evidently the meaning required. lai=fos is not found elsewhere in this sense. The construction is hard; a)qurome/nh (485) is of a musical instrument, the pass. of a cognate like mou=san a)qu/rwn, h. Pan 15. Other exx. in L. and S. , whether material or figurative, are cognate. But the construction is essentially similar to pai/zein with acc. of person, “play with,” Anth. Pal. ix. 49 pai/zete tou\s met' e)me/, ib. x. 64 and 70, Lucian Nigr.20.Possibly, however, the original was a dat. lai/fei, or better lai/fes) (with i again elided). Gemoll's lai/fea su/rwn is flat. Matthiae's exchange of a)qu/rwn and e)e/rgwn is negatived by the objection that xe/lun a)qu/rwn should mean (with an instrument) playing on his shell; but Hermes is simply holding it like a toy (418 is different).

ti/pte . . . *po/qen: the double question does not “indicate the haste of the speaker” (Baumeister), but is the usual succinct idiom, like the familiar ti/s po/qen, etc. to/de, “in this way,” or “hither,” as not infrequently in Homer, especially in the Odyssey; see M. and R. on Od. 1.409. Only the singular occurs in this local sense; the corruption of the MSS. (ta/de) is paralleled by one MS. (N) in Od. 1.409.
a)*naidei/h*n e)*pieime/ne=Il. 1.149.

157-159. The passage is usually considered corrupt; Matthiae's laqo/nta has been accepted, but this would not account for labo/nta, much less fe/ronta. The latter can be retained in the sense of “raiding”: for the absolute use (common in combination with a)/gein) cf. Pind. Ol.viii. 14ei)/ tis e)k do/mwn fe/rei, Eq.205o(/ti a)gku/lais tai=s xersi\n a(rpa/zwn fe/rei, Demosth. v. 12 a)rgu/rion . . . oi)/xetai fe/rwn. The alternatives are that Hermes will either be caught by Apollo, or (if he escapes) he will live an outlaw's life in the glens, eked out by occasional raids. metacu/ may thus stand: Hermes would “rob by whiles,” when necessity should compel; cf. 287 o(po/tan kreiw=n e)rati/zwn a)nth=|s ktl. metacu/ might also be “meanwhile,” i.e. “until you are finally caught,” opposed to ta/xa 157, and this would give equally good sense. The substitution of me/taze is possible; the word is corrupted into metacu/ in Hes. Op.394.The meaning will then be “you will live a robber's life ever afterwards.” For wooded hills as the resort of brigands cf. 287, Dicaearch.i. 8(geogr. min. i. p. 100 Müller), Anth. Pal. vii. 544, Juv.iii. 307 with Mayor's note.

Whatever the reading or translation of 159, there are certainly two co-ordinate alternatives; h)/ (159) cannot stand for ma=llon h)/, as Matthiae and Gemoll suppose (i.e. “I think you will be caught sooner than you will have another chance of stealing”). The particle in 157 is therefore disjunctive, and should be accented with Barnes h)/.
*lhtoi+/dou: the patronymic is not found in Homer; the older form would be *lhtoi+/dew, which Hermann needlessly restores.

*pa/lin should not be supplanted by Ruhnken's ta/lan. Maia wishes to escape the responsibility, and bids her son “go back again,” to the scene of his depredations. Cf. pta=sa pa/lin, of Persephone's forced deparature, h. Dem. 398.

titu/skeai: if this word is to be kept it must bear the sense of titu/sketo qespidae\s pu=r *f 342 and of the cognate tetu/konto/ te dai=ta etc., but with a figura tive application: “why do you give me this dressing?” In Greek this is conveyed by plu/nein, which properly applies to things, clothes, tripe, etc., and has the parallels lavata di testa, laver la tête in the Romance languages, “dust his jacket,” “dress him down” in English. A legitimate construction is also provided for tau=ta. Of course there is no other instance of this sense of titu/skesqai or teu/xein. Pierson's conjecture dedi/skeai is strongly supported by the very similar passage Il. 20.200 f. *phlei+/dh, mh\ dh/ m' e)pe/essi/ ge nhpu/tion w(\s

l.quote: e)/lpeo deidi/cesqai, e)pei\ sa/fa oi(=da kai\ au)to\s

div2.l: h)me\n kertomi/as h)d' ai)/sula muqh/sasqai. The change from t to d, however, is improbable, for the instances given on h. Apoll. 244 (dru/faktos tru/faktos etc.) are phonetic rather than graphical. It should be noted that deidi/cesqai is fut. of deidi/ssomai “frighten,” whereas dedi/skeai should mean “welcome” from dedi/skomai. The correct form would therefore be dedi/sseai, which, however, is further from the MSS. Later writers seem to have confused the two verbs; cf. Lys.564e)dedi/sketo “scared.”

div2.p: *pau=ra and ai)/sula are undoubtedly the best readings, the latter word being supported by the Homeric passage quoted above, where schol. B gives the correct sense ai)/sula ta\s para\ to\ kaqh=kon legome/nas a)peila/s: “like a child who knows few words of blame.” M's reading polla\ . . . a)/rmena would imply much the same thing conversely, but the negative pau=ra is more effective, and to protest against a child possessing “fit thoughts” is perhaps too cynical. The point is that Hermes can blame as well as be blamed.
kai\ mhtro/s ktl.: added as a kind of afterthought, as the acc. tarbale/on precedes.

boukole/wn: this correction may be accepted; for the error of the MSS. cf. Il. 13.445, where, for boukole/onti, the ko pap. B. M. 732 has bouleonti. The older attempts, either to make bouleu/ein govern an accusative, or to take it absolutely, e)me/ following e)pibh/somai, are impossible. For the metaphor cf. the use of poimai/nw in Pind. Isthm.iv. 12, Aesch. Eum.91.

Of the two readings, a)/listoi is the better; throughout the hymn Hermes makes a point of being recognised as a god, to whom gifts and prayers belong. Moreover, a)/pastoi is unsuitable; Hermes and his mother were not starving, with a)mfi/poloi, and stores of nectar and ambrosia (248). Ridgeway (J. P. xvii. p. 109) need not have objected to the form a)/listos, although a)/llistos is elsewhere found (see L. and S. ); for the double form cf. polu/listos and polu/llistos.
au)tou= t*=|hde: Matthiae quotes Herod.vii. 141au)tou= th=|de mene/omen. Add Hom. ep. iii. 5. In Hermes' mouth the words are contemptuous, “in this hole and corner.”

a)mfi\ de\ tim=hs: for a)mfi/ with genitive=de cf. Il. 16.825 pi/dakos a)mf' o)li/ghs, q 267 a)mf' *)/areos filo/thtos. Gemoll's timh=|s does not seem indispensable. In h. Dem. 85 the accusative is used in the same phrase. See H. G. § 184.
ka)*gw/: in Homer only kai\ e)gw/ without crasis. For crasis with kai/ see on h. Dem. 13.

The quantity of fhlhte/wn (even if we write it filhte/wn) requires the omission of de/, but the punctuation is uncertain. Demetrius down to Franke, inclusive, read peirh/sw: du/namai fhlhte/wn o)/rxamos ei)=nai. Bothe and Schneidewin, followed by Baumeister, Gemoll, and Ludwich, take du/namai parenthetically, which is far more elegant here. Cf. the parenthetic safe\s d' ou)k oi(=da 208, ta\ de/ t' oi)=de kai\ au)to/s 376, e)rath\ de/ oi( e(/speto fwnh/ 426. This frequent use of parenthesis is akin to that of asyndeton (see on 151), and is in keeping with the staccato style of the hymn. For fhlhth/s in connexion with Hermes see on 67, and cf. infra 292.

ei) de/ m' e)reun/hsei: there is here hardly any distinction to be drawn between this use of ei) with the future and of ei)/ ke with the subjunctive 174. Strictly, the former use should imply greater probability or necessity; see H. G. § 292 b, and § 326. 5.

me/gan do/mon a)*ntitor/hswn: cf. Il. 10.267, where for a)ntitorh/sas Döderlein (Gloss. 672) reads a)ntetorh/sas. This is probable, as the preposition a)nti- seems out of place. There is, however, no reason why the real form should not have been forgotten by later imitators, and the false a)ntitore/w a)ntito/rhsis coined. The fact that the hymn-writer seems to have known the form tetorei=n (see on 119), and that Aristophanes has tetorh/sw, need not tempt us to conjecture a)ntetorh/swn.
tri/podas ktl.=Od. 13.217. 181=Il. 8.471 , w 511; cf. Il. 4.353. For the wealth of the temple at Pytho see h. Apoll. 536 and infra 335.
M's mh/thr seems to be not so much a gloss on *mai=a as a reminiscence of the familiar Homeric phrase; on the other hand it is of course possible that mh/thr is original, and *mai=a a gloss.

For the precinct of Poseidon see on h. Apoll. 230. The accent on the placename Onchestus varies between oxytone and proparoxytone in the MSS. at Il. 2.506 and here; at h. Apoll. 230 they all have the proparoxytone. The genitive, however, is uniformly -oi=o, and the paradosis prescribed the oxytone (Herodian i. 223. 29 Lenz). We have therefore written the word oxytone in both hymns.
e)risfara/gou: not in Homer; cf. Bacchyl.v. 20*zhno\s e)risfara/gou.

If this line is corrupt, as is usually supposed, no convincing emendation has yet appeared. The commentators (except Gemoll) assume that knw/dalon disguises an adjective, with ge/ronta, or a substantive, as object of a participle after eu(=re. With regard to this participle, it is clear that ne/monta will stand if knw/dalon is sound; if not, some other verb is required, as ne/mein e(/rkos makes no sense. In J. H. S. xvii. p. 259 the manuscript reading was defended: knw/dalon usually connotes some sort of monster (e.g. a serpent), but it is used of beasts in general in Theog. 582, and of beasts of burden or draughtanimals in P. V. 478, Pind. Pyth.x. 36.It is not out of keeping with the style of this hymn to take it here of “his ox or his ass,” probably of the latter. While the old man was at work (batodro/pe 190, e)/skapton 207), he let graze (ne/monta) his “beast” by the roadside Pind. Pyth., i.e. outside the a)lwh/. There would still be e(/rkos a)lwh=s to explain; and here perhaps lies the main difficulty. Gemoll, who alone of the editors defends the text, understands ne/mein to take a double acc., “letting his beast graze on the fence,” which may have been a hedge (cf. batodro/pe), although in Od. 24.224 the e(/rkos a)lwh=s is a stone-wall; but the construction ne/mein tina/ ti seems impossible, and Xen. Cyr.iii. 2. 20 is no parallel. The alternative (suggested in J. H. S. l.c.) is to take e(/rkos a)lwh=s metaphorically, in apposition to knw/dalon, “the stay of his vineyard.” This would be a parody of the Homeric e(/rkos *)axaiw=n, of Ajax; cf. pu/rgos *)axaioi=s, e(/rma po/lhos, and e(/rkos *)olu/mpou viii. 3, of Ares. The parody is not a more violent perversion of Homeric usage than pi/ona e)/rga 127. Possibly, however, e(/rkos is a corruption of e)kto/s (cf. h. Aphr. 159 a)/rktwn, e)k tw=n). Otherwise we must assume a corruption in knw/dalon, which, however, though found in Hom. , Hes. , and Attic poetry, is too unfamiliar to be readily substituted.
batodro/pe: cf. the description of Laertes in the vineyard, Od. 24.230 xeiri=da/s t' e)pi\ xersi\ ba/twn e(/nek).
kera/essin e(likta/s: apparently equivalent to the Homeric e(/likas, which the hymn-writer must have understood to mean “with crumpled horn.” See Leaf on Il. 9.466.
*)hu+/te fw=tes, o(mo/frones, “clever as men, and one in heart” (Edgar).
o(\ d\h . . . te/tuktai: cf. Il. 18.549 to\ dh\ peri\ qau=ma te/tukto, which disposes of Wolf's me/ga for peri/ here.
kataduome/noio: for the metrical lengthening of the u see Schulze Q. E. p. 136 f.

i)/doito: the omission of tis, though rare, is here amply justified by Il. 13.287 ou)de/ ken e)/nqa teo/n ge me/nos kai\ xei=ras o)/noito, *x 199 w(s d' e)n o)nei/rw| ou) du/natai feu/gonta diw/kein; so in Theog. 741, and (with a participle) Op.12 Op., v. l. 291, h. xxix.6, and Il. 14.58 (gnoi/h Aristoph. ). See Kühner-Jelf § 373. 6, L. and S. s.v. tis. In later poetry cf. e.g. Theocr. xvii. 41; for prose cf. Plat. Symp.i. 8, Rep. Ath. i. 10. The indefinite third person is preferable to M's i)/doimi, which, however, is not necessarily a correction.
*pro/pan . . . katadu/nta: a common formula; Il. 1.601 etc.
*gouno\n a)lw=hs oi)*nope/doio=Od. 1.193 , l 193; cf. also Il. 9.534 , *s 57.

e)/doca (in Homer e)do/khsa): qualified by the parenthetical safe\s d' ou)k oi)=da; o(/s tis ktl. is only loosely connected with pai=da, not governed by oi)=da: “whoever the boy was that . . .” For this use of o(/s tis cf. 277, 311, h. Dem. 58, 119, and often in Attic poetry (Blaydes on Nub. 883).
e)*pistrofa/dh*n: from side to side, as he followed the oxen; cf. Hippocr. Mochlikon 20 o(doipore/ousi de\ peristrofa/dhn w(s bo/es, and vv. 226, 357.

e)/xen, “held,” “kept” their heads facing him (see on 77). Hermann's e)/xon, changing the subject, is not necessary. a)*nti/on au)tw=|: the dative with this adverb is not Homeric. The old man is not here said to tell Apollo that Hermes went in the direction of Pylos, though this information is implied in 354 f. to\n d' e)fra/sato broto\s a)nh\r
div2.l: ei)s *pu/lon eu)qu\s e)lw=nta, and in 216 Apollo starts for Pylos. We need not, however, suppose a lacuna; if there is any inconsistency, it may be attributed to the hymn-writer.

div2.p:
oi)wno
 . . . tanusi/pteron: it is disputed whether this refers to the old man's obscure hinting, which Apollo interprets like an “omen,” or whether the god actually saw a bird, which helped to clear up the mystery. Baumeister and Gemoll take the former view, understanding tanusi/pteron as a mere epitheton ornans, here inappropriate to oi)wno/s. This explanation seems highly improbable, and it is clear that an actual bird of omen is intended, which informed Apollo that the thief was Hermes (214). This view is also supported by Apollodorus (iii. 10. 2, 5) oi( de\ i)dei=n me
 pai=da e)lau/nonta e)/faskon, ou)k e)/xein de\ ei)pei=n, poi= pote h)la/qhsan dia\ to\ mh\ eu(rei=n i)/xnos du/nasqai. maqw
 de\ e)k th=s mantikh=s to
 keklofo/ta, pro\s *mai=an ei)s *kullh/nhn paragi/netai.
On the route taken by Apollo (Onchestus—Pylos—Cyllene) see Introd. p. 131.
The first mention of Pylos; the Alpheus was the only geographical indication given in the account of the actual journey (101).

Cf. Il. 16.360 and 790. The dark cloud here makes the god invisible, as in Il. 5.186. In Il. 15.153 a)mfi\ de/ min quo/en ne/fos e)stefa/nwto the “fragrant cloud” is rather for adornment than concealment; so in Od.i. 2. 39nube candentes humeros amictus

The reference to the centaur's foot-prints does not help to determine the date of the hymn, as the writer does not explain his conception of the centaur. This verse leaves the question open, whether he regarded the centaur as a hairy wild man, with nothing equine in form (probably the original and Homeric conception; see Mannhardt A. W. F. p. 79 f.); or as having two human and two equine legs (as in archaic art, e.g. the chest of Cypselus); or, finally, with four horse's legs (the fifthcentury type). On the centaurs see reff. in Roscher Lex. s.v.
e)/lpomai ei)=nai, “I guess they are not,” livelier than e)sti\n o(moi=a, but there is no difficulty about the construction of the latter; they are alternatives.

biba=|: the form is supported by 149 probibw=n, h. Apoll. 133 e)bi/basken, Pind. Ol.xiv. 25bibw=nta. In Il. 3.22 , *h 213 Aristophanes (followed by most edd.) restored the forms from biba/s for the vulgate bibw=n.

ai)*na\ me/n ktl.: according to some editors, ai)na\ me/n refers to the cow's footprints, ta\ d' ai)no/tera to those of Hermes. This view is quite possible, as, although Apollo recognises the tracks of the cows, their backward direction might strike him as “strange.” But it is better to understand that Apollo's astonishment refers here to Hermes' unearthly spoor, “strange here, and stranger there”—wherever Apollo looked from one side of the road to the other, Hermes floundered, e)pistrofa/dhn e)ba/dizen 210, or bustled across the road, diapurpala/mhsen o(dou= to\ me\n e)/nqa, to\ d' e)/nqa 357.
o)/ros kataei/menon u(/l|h: see on h. Apoll. 225.
a)mbro/sios: not in Homer as epithet of persons; the hymn-writer obviously takes it as equivalent to a)/mbrotos.
e)lo/xeuse: also a post-Homeric verb, though frequent in later poetry.

o(dm/h ktl.: the “pleasant smell” may be a reminiscence of Od. 5.59 f. (the scent of Calypso's fire); but the hymnwriter leaves it doubtful whether he refers (1) to Maia's fire, or (2) to a miraculous scent betokening a deity (cf. on h. Dem. 277), or (3) to the fresh smell of natural earth; cf. Mosch.i. 92leimw=nos e)kai/nuto laro\n a)u+tmh/n (of a flowery meadow); Mart.iii. 65. 4gramina quod redolent quae modo carpsit ovis and 7 gleba quod aestivo leviter cum spargitur imbre), and may be correct, although parallels from early poetry appear to be wanting. Atalanta's cave ( V. H. xiii. 1) is fragrant with flowers. The analogy of quwde/os *ou)lu/mpoio (322), and perhaps a)/ntrw| e)n eu)w/dei (xxvi. 6), rather supports the second explanation.

au)to/s: in h. Aphr. 151 (e(khbo/los au)to\s *)apo/llwn) au)to/s is forcible, “Apollo's self.” Here the word has been suspected, as the emphasis is not clear. Baumeister rightly gave up his idea that the meaning was “in his own person”; Apollo had not assumed another form. Possibly the antithesis is in a)/ntron e)s h)ero/en: the bright Far-darter went into the dim cave. More probably the writer uses au)to\s *)apo/llwn as a fixed formula, “great Apollo,” without antithesis; cf. Il. 1.47 with Leaf's note, and h. Apoll. 181; so 406 infra, Mosch.iv. 13.In any case au)to/s is sound; Baumeister's criticism “au)to/s saepe turbas fecit” is not justified by h. Dem. 371, h. vii.22, where it needs no emendation.
Cf. Scut. 12 xwsa/menos peri\ bousi/.

u(/lhs spodo/s: o(lospodo/s is one of M's corruptions (see p. xviii); it may be partly due to ou)lo/pod' ou)loka/rhna 137. u(/lhs spodo/s seems original; spodo/s includes “dust” generally, and the defining genitive of material “wood-ash” is not otiose. In 140 the fire is extinguished with ordinary dust, ko/nis me/laina. The simile is modelled on Od. 5.488 f. where Odysseus keeps up his spark of life in a covering of leaves, just as a man hides a smouldering brand under a heap of ashes. Cf. Theocr. xi. 5, xxiv. 88, Callim. Ep. 44, and perhaps h. Dem. 239.

a)*neei/le) e(\ au)to/n: a)le/einen is evidently impossible; a word parallel to a)mfikalu/ptei is required by the simile. Ilgen's a)le/ainen would naturally mean “warmed himself,” which is unsuitable, and Ludwich's a)le/gunen, “took heed to himself” quite misses the sense; this is correctly given by a)neilei=n “cuddled himself up,” which Lohsee suggested, although his form a)ne/eilen should be corrected to a)neei/lei or a)neei/le). The latter gives a completer metathesis. For the uncontracted form cf. kateko/smee *d 118, metefw/nee q 201 (-ei Ar.), prosefw/nee p 308, 354, Smyth § 665, Hoffmann p. 467. For the sense cf. Plat. Symp. 206D suspeira=tai . . . kai\ a)nei/lletai (v.l. a)neillei=tai).
sune/lasse: not meaningless, as Gemoll thinks; it is vivid and quite appropriate: “he forced together head, hands, and feet, into a small space.”

f/h: this brilliant emendation of Barnes (who accented it fh=) was made again by Hermann; it is confirmed by the reading of y qh=ra. f and q are easily exchanged in MSS.; fhsi/n qhrsi/n *a 268, au)to/fi au)to/qi *m 302. For fh/ in Homer and later poets see Leaf on Il. 2.144. It is now found in Callim. Hecale col. iv. 4 Gomperz. For the derivation see Prellwitz B. B. xxii. 76 f., and Et. Wört. s.v.

The comparison is evidently to “a newborn infant asking only for sleep.” The sense is given by neo/lloutos (i.e. newly washed after birth); Martin B. (Varior. lect. ed. 2, 1755) quotes Theocr. xxiv. 3, Lycophr. 321, Callim. h. Del. 6, Jov.16, Plaut. Amphitr. v. 1. 50. The reading of y ne/on loxa/wn cannot be explained.

*)/hdumon: the form recurs infra 449; in h. Aphr. 171, xix. 16 the MSS. give nh/dumos. Probably h(/dumos is the older word (from h(du/s, as ka/llimos from kalo/s), nh/dumos being a later mistaken form, due to the n e)felkustiko/n of preceding words, as in Il. 2.2 (Buttmann Lex. i. 173 f.). The history of the form would therefore be like “a nickname” for “an ekename” etc. Meyer (Griech. Et. i.) rejects this view, holding nh/dumos to be original, in which case h(/dumos would be due to a false connexion with h(du/s. Brugmann also (I. F. xi. 277 sq.) returns to nh/dumos, and (after schol. Il. 2.2) explains nh=down, -dumos from du/w “that into which one sinks,” cl. nhdu/s. In the MSS. of Homer nh/dumos prevails, but there is some authority for h(/dumos in Il. 2.2 , d 793, m 311. Here and in 449 the form is proved by the metre; but the certainty of h(/dumos in this hymn is no reason for rejecting nh/dumos in the two other hymns in which the word occurs.

In this line Martin has successfully emended a)/grhs: ei)n- into e)grh/sswn, for which compare Hipponax 89 *(ermh= ma/kar kaq' u(/pnon oi)=das e)grh/ssein. For the confusion of a)g, e)g cf. Il. 17.660 where some MSS. give a)grh/ssontes; so one MS. in Od. 20.53 . e)teo/n is also certain; the word is corrupted in Il. 20.255. The nearest approach to the MSS. would be e)grh/sswn e)teo\n de\ without a stop (a reading suggested in J. H. S. xvii. 260); but Hermann's punctuation, with the addition of de/, is preferable, as giving a clearer antithesis; for e)teo/n ge cf. Il. 8.423 (one MS. te as here), Il. 12.217 , g 122 etc.
*gnw= d' ou)d' *)hg*noi/hse= Theog. 551.

e)*ntropi/|hsi: the sense required is obviously “tricks,” “twists.” The word can bear this meaning, as the cognate e)ntropali/zomai=“turn round again and again”; cf. the English “dodge.” Baumeister's translation “shame” (ficto pudore) cannot stand. eu)tropi/a (Gemoll) is not known for early Greek.
