a)*na/: for this preposition with paptai/nein cf. Il. 12.333, Apoll. Arg. 3.1284. The direct accusative is also possible (cf. Il. 4.200); but a)na/ seems forcible here, of an exhaustive search, and a)/ra may have been corrupted from it; cf. 514.

a)du/tous: only here known to be masculine; in Homer (Il. 5.448, 512) the gender is doubtful, as in Pind. Ol.vii. 59, though presumably neuter. Elsewhere the word is applied only to sacred “recesses,” and here also it is probably complimentary, as suitable to the home of a goddess; cf. 148. The a)/duta of temples served as treasuries.
e)*cere/eine: cf. Od. 12.259 po/rous a(lo\s e)cereei/nwn. The hymn-writer favours the verb: see on 313.
kata/keiai: on the form see Schulze Q. E. p. 443, Smyth Ionic § 713.

255-257. A reminiscence of Il. 8.12 f. (Leaf ad loc. suggests that the Homeric passage may be borrowed from the hymn; but this seems improbable, although *q may be a late book). So infra 466= Il. 8.40.

qa=tton: if the hymn is Boeotian (see Pref. p. lxxiii), this form is probably a survival of the Boeotian dialect remaining in the hymn. The form e)/latton occurs in the same Oropian inscr. which supports h(xou= in 400 (where see note). On tt=ss in Boeotian see Meister die griech. Dialekte i. p. 264 f. Baumeister retains qa=tton as an Atticism, but in that case it must have ousted an original qa=sson, as the hymn must be earlier than the use of tt for ss in
e)*pei/, “or else,” as in Il. 15.228.

labw/n: so Ilgen for balw/n, which can hardly be tolerated with r(i/yw. The metathesis is of course common. labw/n is supported by the equivalent e(lw/n in the Homeric parallel Il. 8.13, and h. Apoll. 218 r(i/y' a)na\ xersi\n e(lou=sa.

o)li/goisi: Hermes will have to be content with the leadership of “little men,” i.e. children, like himself. There is no parallel to this use of o)li/goi a)/ndres, but the expression seems to suit the serio-comic style of the hymn. o)li/goisi is defended by Boissonade and Tyrrell; the latter interprets “for all your primacy among little folk,” but in this case per would seem necessary. Matthiae also keeps the word, but understands it of the dead generally, “feeble folk.” But o)li/gos should bear the same sense as in 245, 456, of a child; cf. e.g. Anth. Pal. vii. 632. 1 o)li/gon bre/fos, Theocr. i. 47 o)li/gos tis kw=ros. For the place of children in Hades cf. Verg. Aen.vi. 427.There is a coincidence of language in Perses' epigram on Hermes Anth. Pal. ix. 334 ka)me\ to
 e)n smikroi=s o)li/gon qeo
 h)
 e)pibw/sh|s
div2.l: eu)kai/rws teu/ch|: mh\ mega/lwn de\ gli/xou (B. C. H. xxii. 614). The emendations of o)li/goisi are at best unconvincing.
div2.p: *(hgemoneu/wn: not in Homer with a preposition (461 infra is corrupt). Here meta/ and e)n seem equally good; for the latter cf. Plat. Rep.474 c.
kai/: not to be altered to h)= (Matthiae, who afterwards restored kai/, and Baumeister); the sense is “why do you speak so sharply and come in quest of cows?”

265, 266. The MSS. give ou)/te 265, ou)k 266. It is therefore open either to alter ou)k into ou)/te, or to change ou)/te to ou)de/, ou)k being retained. The latter alternative is perhaps more effective, in view of the asyndetic character of Hermes' words. Hermann's ou)/ti for ou)/te is also possible.
*pa/ros, “before that,” i.e. rather than steal cattle; for this use of pa/ros Ilgen compares Il. 8.166 pa/ros toi dai/mona dw/sw. Add Il. 16.629 (not “till now”).
*(hmete/rhs: Gemoll suggests that the word marks the dignity of the offended Hermes; cf. 465.

271, 272. Hermes remarks that it would be strange for a child to come in through (dia/) the door with (meta/) cows. This sense seems quite possible, as Apollo expected to find the cows inside the cave (246 f.). According to the general view, Hermes speaks of going out of doors (dia/ for die/k), to fetch the cows. This explanation seems to involve the substitution of e)pi/ for meta/.
qe/leis: for the form see on h. Apoll. 46.
m\h . . . u(*pi/sxomai: for the construction of mh/ with indic. in an oath cf. Il. 10.330 , *o 41, and occasionally in later poetry (Goodwin M. T. § 686).
Cf. Il. 2.486 kle/os oi)=on a)kou/omen.

o)fru/si r(ipta/zesken, “kept lifting his eyebrows.” The intransitive use of r(ipta/zein has been suspected, and Hermann's o)fru=s has found favour. But the verb is intrans. in Hippocrates (e.g. Acut.ii. 18) of patients tossing in bed, and r(i/ptei appears to be intrans. in Eur. Hec.1325.The verb is not elsewhere used in this context, but r(iph/, which is doubtless cognate, is frequent of any quick motion (of wings, eyes, etc.). The hymnwriter is fond of allusions to quick glances or vibrations of the eyelids; cf. 45Eur. Hec., 387.
o(rw/menos e)/nea kai\ e)/nea = Hes. fr. 4 (176). 2, of Argus.
a)*posuri/zwn: to shew his indifference; not as Baumeister understands, ad indignationem simul et fiduciam declarandam.

a(/lion to\n mu=eon a)kou/wn certainly presents a difficulty, which has probably caused the variant w(s. The adverb a(li/ws ( Soph. Phil.840) is possible, but E 715 a(/lion to\n mu=qon u(pe/sthmen *menela/w| fixes the words, which must mean “listening to those words as if they were senseless.” For the further predicate with a)kou/w cf. 443, a passage which justifies the text. The construction may be dialectal; cf. Suid. and E. M. (s.v. xai/rw) xai/rw se e)lhluqo/ta: *)orwpikoi\ ou(/tws le/gousin. The corrections of a)kou/wn are improbable, and rest on the unnecessary belief that mu=qon refers to the words of Hermes.

e)*p' ou)/dei+ . . . kaei/ssai, to “strip,” “plunder”; the expression is no doubt drawn from popular speech, but no close parallel is quoted, and the origin of the phrase is doubtful. Baumeister suggests that it is used by thieves who strip a house to the last chair. Ernesti compares Theocr. i. 51 e)pi\ chroi=si kaqi/zein, where, however, the meaning is obscure. The best illustration is perhaps the proverb attributed to Stesichorus (Aristot. Rhet.ii. 21) ou) dei= u(brista\s ei)=nai, o(/pws mh\ oi( te/ttiges xamo/qen a)/|dwsin; cf. Anth. Pal. vii. 723 oi)wnoi\ de\ kata\ xqono\s oi)ki/a qe/ntes. In both cases the reference is to a country devastated by an enemy; this is analogous to a house “stripped to the boards.”

The future kaqi/sein is suggested by a)kaxh/seis (286), but is not necessary: Apollo regards Hermes as a practised thief, who has already stripped more than one house, and has a wider career before him (cf. 159).

skeua/zonta: hardly “making all ready” as Passow and L. and S. , but “carrying off the skeu/h,” i.e. ransacking the house. Cf. suskeua/zesqai = vasa colligere, and skeuwrei=sqai ( Plut. Caes.51th\n *pomphi+/ou oi)ki/an) in the sense of “plunder.”
oi)=) a)*goreu/eis: i.e. Hermes is and will be as deceitful in deeds as he is in words; the cleverness of his defence marks him as an accomplished thief.

The variants give exactly the same meaning; it is hard to see how one is preferable to the other. Cf. Hollander l.c. p. 27. a)/nthn seems a corruption; Gemoll's a)nth=|s is nearer to a)/nthn than a)nta=|s, but h is doubtful (Smyth Ionic § 637 n.).
*pu/mato/n te kai\ u(/staton = X 203, Od. 20.116.

295-303. The incident is quite in keeping with the general tone of the hymn; see Introd. p. 134. But the precise meaning of the two “omens” is doubtful. Both are clearly intentional (cf. su\n d' a)/ra frassa/menos); but it is uncertain whether the second omen is merely a reduplication of the first, or whether Hermes intended to supplement the original oi)wno/s. The further question arises, whether the omens refer to Hermes or Apollo. According to Hermann, Mercurius, katapardw\n *)apo/llwnos, significabat parum se ira Apollinis moveri. So Baumeister, who adds that the sneeze is also intentional, ut inhonestius augurium honestiori callide occultaret, although Apollo is not to be deceived. This explanation is not satisfactory; and Gemoll is probably right in understanding that Hermes intends both omens to confirm Apollo's prophecy a)rxo\s fhlhte/wn keklh/seai. The first omen is, in Gemoll's view, a mere piece of impudence; this is no doubt correct, but the editors do not notice that it is a parody of a favourable omen from Zeus u(yibreme/ths. Cf. Eq.639(with Neil's note). An accidental sneeze would also be lucky; the humour lies in the fact that it is intentional. For the omen of sneezing cf. Od. 17.541, 545, Herod.vi. 107, Xen. Anab.iii. 2. 9, and other exx. quoted by Bouché-Leclercq Divination i. p. 162 f. and Blaydes on Av.720ptarmo/n t' o)/rniqa kalei=te. Apollo of course is not deceived by Hermes, but ironically interprets the “omens” in his own way.
a)*ggeliw/th*n: elsewhere only in Callim. Hecale col. i. 4.
e(/zeto: perhaps to interpret the omen ex cathedra, with mock gravity (Gemoll).
kai\ e)/peita, “in the end,” “after all,” as in Il. 8.520.
*kull/hnios: first in Od. 24.1, where Aristarchus objected to the epithet as post-Homeric.

spoud*=|h: in Homer the usual sense is “hardly,” but in Od. 15.209 spoudh=| nu=n a)na/baine the adv. certainly= “quickly”; so perhaps in Il. 2.99 (Ariston. e)n ta/xei), v. 279. This sense suits the passage: Hermes now wishes to get done with the business; cf. 320. The words could not imply his haste in keeping pace with Apollo, non passibus aequis; at least in 321 Hermes leads. Possibly, however, spoudh=| may mean “seriously,” no longer in jest, as often in post-Homeric Greek; cf. spoudai=on (332), a “serious” thing.

305, 306. The lines are difficult; e)ligme/nos is a vox nihili, and e)elme/nos cannot be regarded as certain. The editors mostly correct to e)elme/non or another acc. partic., agreeing with spa/rganon; but it is most improbable that an original acc. should become a nom. It is just possible to take e)elme/nos absolutely: Hermes “pushed with his hands the clothes up to both his ears, round his shoulders, huddled up” (in the wraps). The clothes had fallen off his head while he was being carried by Apollo; they are now rearranged. On the whole it seems almost necessary to alter e)elme/nos. The variant e)ligme/nos points to a corruption; the original may have been ei)lume/nos, which, however, has escaped alteration in 245, h. Apoll. 450; spa/rganon would be taken a)po\ koinou= with e)w/qei and ei)lu/menos. In any case par) must mean “up to”; not, as suggested in J. H. S. xv. p. 290, “down past,” as if Hermes now uncovers his head. This sense of para/ is not justified by such passages as Plat. Symp. iv. 23para\ ta\ w)=ta a)/rti i)/oulos kaqe/rpei, where the meaning is really inherent in the verb.

It would be possible to suggest that par' . . . e)w/qei = parew/qei, governing a)/mfw ou)/ata, i.e. he “pushed back both his ears,” by rubbing his cheeks; cf. Od. 18.199 th\n de\ gluku\s u(/pnos a)nh=ken
div2.l: kai/ r() a)pomo/rcato xersi\ pareia\s fw/nhse/n te (see below 361). But the expression, if physically accurate (the flat of the hands being moved away from the eyes across the cheeks), is at least curious, without some further explanation to shew that rubbing the eyes is intended. Otherwise the sense would be excellent: Hermes now pretends to wake up at last. With this translation spa/rganon must be governed by the participle ei)lume/nos (e)elme/nos would be less suitable); for the construction cf. 151.

div2.p: fe/reis: either “carry,” as in 293, although Hermes is no longer in Apollo's hands; or=e)lau/neis 330.

o)rsolopeu/eis: rare and poetic; cf. Hesych. o)rsopolei=tai: diapolemei=tai, tara/ssetai: *ai)sxu/los ( Pers.10); so o)rso/lopos, of Ares, Anacr. fr. 74. Hesychius' explanation, i.e. “harry,” no doubt gives the sense, but the derivation is quite unknown, and the suggestions (mentioned by Gemoll) are not convincing: Müller-Strübing's derivation (o)/rros and lopeu/ein, lopi/zw “skin”) would suit the humour of the hymn; but a word of such suggestions could not have been used by Aeschylus unless he was ignorant of its original meaning. Prellwitz s.v. suggests o)/rnumi and o)lo/ptw; see also Fröhde B. B. xx. p. 222 who compares the German verran, wirren.
311 = 277 with slight variation. Epic usage would prefer an exact verbal repetition, but later poets are careless of the rule; Gemoll compares 264, 364.
diarr/hdh*n, “expressly,” elsewhere, apparently, only found in Attic prose.

e)re/einon, “questioned,” has been suspected, but is better than Schneidewin's e)ri/dainon, which does not suit diarrh/dhn. There is no real difficulty: Apollo and Hermes had “questioned” one another explicitly. Perhaps, however, the writer uses the word vaguely in the sense of “speak.” The verb occurs in the hymn with several shades of meaning: e)cere/eine muxou/s 252 “explored,” e)cereei/nh| 483, e)reei/nh| 487 “questioned,” “made trial of” the lyre, e)cereei/nein 547 “question” the prophetic art.
oi)opo/los: by anticipation; Hermes is to be a shepherd-god; cf. 570 f. Matthiae's explanation “dwelling alone” (of a thief) is quite impossible.

Gemoll makes the apodosis begin at this line (reading fwnw=n 315). This is almost certainly wrong; the line clearly contains the subject of e)re/einon; there is a parenthesis in o( me/n ktl. (315), and the apodosis is marked by dh\ e)/peita (320), after an epanalepsis au)ta\r e)pei/ (319).

fwn/hn: the words as handed down give no connexion; hence fwnh\n has been altered to fwnw=n, fwnei=n, fwnh=| (nhmerte/i+), none of which would have readily passed into fwnh/n, In Goodwin's edition, fwrh/n was conjectured, on the analogy of 136, 385; this is a graphical change (r=n), but it involves the construction la/zusqai *(ermh=n fwrh/n “convict Hermes of a clear theft,” which can hardly be defended by the Attic e(lei=n tina/ ti. It is also an argument against fwrh/n that in 385 M (which here reads fwnh/n) has fwrh/n uncorrupted. Tyrrell accepts fwrh/n, with Baumeister's e)kdedaw/s, for ou)k a)di/kws; but the latter is not to be disturbed. The alternative therefore seems to be a lacuna of one line, and this is made probable (1) by the excellent sense of nhmerte/a fwnh/n, “a true utterance,” opposed to ai(muli/oisi lo/goisi; (2) by the homoeoteleuton between 315, 316. The lacuna will then have contained a participle (e.g. i(ei/s) governing fwnh/n.

ou)k a)di/kws: prosaic; see Introd. p. 134. e)*pi\ bousi\n e)la/zuto, “was haling Hermes for (on account of) the cows.” e)pi/ here expresses the cause or occasion; commonly e)pi\ bousi/ would mean “in charge of cattle”; cf. 200, 556, 571, Od. 20.209 etc.

On the variants see J. H. S. xv. p. 311 f. It may be doubted whether te/rqron and kh/rhna are due to independent reciters, or whether ka/rhna is a gloss on the comparatively rare te/rqron. The word (which is generally a nautical term) is not elsewhere used as a mountain-top, but it is equivalent to te/rma in Eur. fr. 372 (cf. Erotian Gl. Hipp. p. 366 te/rqron ga\r e)/legon oi( palaioi\ to\ e)/sxaton kai\ e)pi\ te/lei); so of the tip of a nose, Emped. 346.
quw/deos *ou)lu/mpoio=h. Dem. 331 (where see note), and cf. supra 231.

di/khs kate/keito ta/lanta, “the scales of justice were set”; cf. Bacchyl.xvii. 25di/kas r(e/pei ta/lanton, Aesch. Ag.250di/ka e)pirre/pei, Anth. Pal. vi. 267. 4 e)k *dio\s i)qei/hs oi)=de ta/lanta di/khs. In Homer Zeus balances the scales of destiny; Il. 8.69 , *p 68, *t223, *x 209. With the language of the present passage the editors compare Il. 18.507 f. kei=to d' a)/r' e)n me/ssoisi du/w xrusoi=o ta/lanta,
div2.l: tw=| do/men o(\s meta\ toi=si di/khn i)qu/ntata ei)/poi, where the reference is to talents of gold, probably deposited as a court fee (see Leaf ad loc.). Ridgeway (J. P. xvii. 1888, p. 111) argues that in this hymn also the ta/lanta are “talents” (not “scales”) deposited with Zeus as judge. In that case the expression would be metaphorical, for Apollo and Hermes have of course deposited no fees. But it is far more probable that the hymnwriter, while possibly imitating the language of Il. 5.507, either misunderstood or consciously perverted the meaning of ta/lanta there; he was, no doubt, familiar with the other sense of the word=scales.

div2.p: The word eu)mili/h or eu)muli/h is not known to exist; in J. H. S. xvii. p. 261, the latter form was defended, as probably connected with mu\ mu= Eq.10, mulio/wntes Hes. Op.530.mu/w moimu/llw etc., of a muttering sound produced by closing the lips. The sense suggested was “a pleasant hum,” which, however, does not seem particularly suited to the present context. Pending the production of fresh evidence, another attempt may be made to derive the word. o(/milos, formerly connected with o(mo/s, is now divided o(/-mil-os, as cognate with Sanscr. milati, Lat. miles, mille (Johansson I. F. ii. 34 n., Fick Wörterbuch^{4} i. 177, 723, iv. 235, Stokes B. B. xi. 293, Petr B. B. xxv. 143). From the same stem a formation eu)mili/a would not be impossible, and the sense “good fellowship” or merely “company” would be equivalent to h)gere/qonto in the next line. For the metre cf. Anth. Pal. ix. 573 klaiwmili/h and gelowmili/h. This attempt preserves the spelling of M, as the derivation from mu/llw, etc., that of the other MSS. Either meaning seems in accordance with the light tone of the scene, which D'Orville recognised by conjecturing stwmuli/h. On the other hand, if there is corruption, no emendation commands assent; of the conjectures, those which depart from the letters of the MSS. are too violent, while those that resemble them (eu)meli/h e)mmeli/h) do not account for the loss of such familiar words. A rare word is required, and perhaps eu)khli/h satisfies the conditions (the confusion of k and m is common in minuscules). This would involve a rare synizesis, which may have helped the corruption. eu)khli/a is attested by Hesychius, and the sense is excellent: the “quiet” of dawn held Olympus— zeus was not thundering. Cf. Theocr. ii. 166 eu)kh/loio nukto/s, “stilly night”; and for the stillness of a mountain, Callim. h. v.72 mesambrina\ d' ei(=x' o)/ros a(suxi/a; ib. 74.

a)/fqitoi: this cannot be quasiadverbial, as a)dmh=tes d' i(/kanon 103, for the word makes nonsense if joined closely with h)gere/qonto. Hence Groddeck's a)qro/oi has been generally accepted; cf. Od. 2.392 , w 468. But there is no great difficulty in taking a)/fqitoi as an adjective with a)qa/natoi (=qeoi/ as often), i.e. the deathless immortals. Gemoll compares qnhtoi\ brotoi/ g 3.

meta\ xruso/eronon *)hw=: this seems preferable to the variant poti\ ptu/xas *ou)lu/mpoio, as Olympus has just been mentioned. The reading in the text seems to be a reminiscence of Il. 1.493 f., where the gods assemble on Olympus in the morning; cf. also Od. 5.1 f.

fu\hn k/hrukos e)/xonta: how the infant Hermes had “the look of a herald” is not clear; there can be no allusion to Hermes' speed, as Baumeister supposes. Probably the hymn-writer is merely anticipating the later functions of Hermes as kh=ruc; cf. on oi)opo/los 314.
spoudai=on to/de xr=hma: ironical “a serious matter,” or “a fine thing,” rather than “a costly booty” as Gemoll understands. The adjective is not Homeric.
ou)k a)lapadno/n: with sqe/nos *e 783 etc., but not in Homer as epithet of mu=qos.

filol/hi+os: no doubt with special reference to the wealth of Delphi. Baumeister compares Lycophr. 208 *delfini/ou par' a)/ntra kerdw/|ou qeou=. Apollo's love of gain appears in 495, see also 179; in 549 the idea is probably different.

diapru/sion: the proper meaning appears to be “piercing,” “penetrating.” The sense suits h. Aphr. 19, of a piercing noise; cf. dia/toros, and the adverb diapru/sion in Homer, who does not use the adjective. Here the word is applied to a robber; cf. 178 a)ntitorh/swn, 283 a)ntitorou=nta do/mous. Voss's translation “manifest” is unlikely.
*polu/n ktl.: cf. Hes. Op.635polu\n dia\ po/nton a)nu/ssas.

ke/rtomon: first in Hes. Op.788, for the Homeric kerto/mion. The word is needlessly suspected here; the meaning may well be “cheating,” “tricky,” as in Eur. Alc.1128(other exx. in L. and S. ), or rather, perhaps, “cheeky.”
lhsi/mbroton: only here, on the analogy of teryi/mbrotos.
*gai=an: the accusative is to be retained; it is not uncommon with e)pi/, chiefly in the Odyssey, without any idea of motion; cf. Od. 4.417 , h 382, r 386, y 371, H. G. § 199. 4.
eu)eu/: first here, for the Homeric i)qu/; cf. 355 ei)s *pu/lon eu)qu\s e)lw=nta, which confirms *pu/lond) in this line.

doia/: Barnes' conjecture (usually accepted) rests upon 349, but there, and in 225, toi=a has not been corrupted. In J. H. S. xv. p. 265 di=a was proposed; there is, however, no good reason why doia/ should not be accepted. The reading of p (di+a) may be paralleled by Od. 4.526, where one MS. has dia/ for doia/. The sense is “there were double footprints, wonderful,” i.e. those of the cows (me/n 344), and of Hermes (d) 346). This was the view of Hermann and Schneidewin. The i)/xnia are therefore the footprints of both Hermes and the cows; Gemoll's remark, that pe/lwra is only applied to the tracks of Hermes, prejudges the question.

345, 346. The construction is intricate, and there is some probability in Schneidewin's lacuna; he conjectures i)/xni) a)pe/strapto in the missing line (cf. 76). But the passage may be translated as it stands: the dative th=|sin bousi/n is “ethic,” loosely equivalent to the genitive, but rather belonging to the whole sentence than to bh/mata (see Goodwin G. G. § 184. 5): “As for the cows, the black dust held and shewed their footprints facing towards the meadow,” i.e. the pasture from which they had been stolen; cf. 221 pa/lin te/traptai e)s a)sfodelo\n leimw=na. The construction a)nti/a e)s is unique, for Od. 17.333 is no parallel, but cf. e)nanti/on pro/s Plat. Phaed. 60 B and a)/xri, pe/ran ei)s (a)/xri and pe/ran with gen. are analogous to a)nti/os with dat.); possibly the meaning is not simply “facing towards,” but “reversed, in the direction of.” Cf. 77 a)nti/a poih/sas o(pla/s, “reversing the feet.” On ko/ni_s see Schweizer I. F. x. 205 n.

Since neither e(kto/s sixth, e(kto/s from e)/xw, nor e)kto/s (=“outsider,” Aristoph. and Plato) can be entertained, and a connexion with e)xqo/s = e)xqro/s (Wackernagel K. Z. xxxiii. 40, 41) is improbable, Bothe's o( dekto/s seems the slightest and most satisfactory correction. dekto/s appears not to be found before the N. T. (see Stephanus), and is always passive (as Bothe intended it). That verbals of deponents may be active, however, appears from the exx. in K. B. ii. 289 (mempto/s, dunato/s, fqegkto/s, planhto/s, lwbhto/s). dekto/s may mean either “receptive,” sc. thievish (as de/kths of a beggar, Od. 4.248), or “watcher” in the sense of pulhdo/kos; cf. on 15.

In sense some compound of o(do/s (= o(/dios, e)no/dios) would be acceptable, but o(dai=os (Ludwich) and o(douro/s are too far from the tradition. A negative adjective also to balance a)mh/xanos might be thought possible; this is given by Hermann's a)/i+ktos (=a)pro/sitos Hesych.), but the resemblance is slight.

die/tribe: according to Gemoll this refers to the trailing or “rubbing” tracks of Hermes: it is more probably to be explained by tri/bos, a “beaten” track. For the short vowel before tr see La Roche Homer. Unters. i. p. 9; cf. a)pe/kruye 394.
toi=a *pe/lwr): either agreeing with ke/leuqa, or an accusative defining the whole expression die/tribe ke/leuqa= bai/nei; the latter view is supported by 225 toi=a pe/lwra biba=|.

drusi/: the instrumental dative is as good as possi/n and xersi/n in 346, 347. For similar datives cf. Il. 12.207 pe/teto pnoih=|s a)ne/moio, Solon xi. 5 a)lw/pekos i)/xnesi bai/nei. The editors explain drusi/ as oak-branches, for which there is no parallel. This translation also neglects the force of a)raih=|si, which is not otiose: Hermes seemed to be walking on “young trees.” As a matter of fact, he had used o)/zoi, branches (81); but Apollo did not know the details.

352, 353. The repetition of sti/bon and sti/bos seems inelegant, but the hymnwriter is careless on this matter; cf. the repetitions in 340, 342 (e)lau/nwn, e)la/wn), 365 (a)/r) twice), 385 (pot), pote/) 398, 400 (i(=con, e)ci/konto), and see further on 424. sti/bos must mean “path” in 352, “footprints” in 353; so e)p' a)ristera/ is used in different contexts 418, 424.
kratero/n: not elsewhere of hard ground; but Ilgen compares Od. 23.46 kratai/pedon ou)=das.
kate/erce: this reading is right, as Apollo did not know that any cows had been killed (kate/rece); for the confusion cf. Il. 5.650 e)/rcanta r(e/canta, *i 535 e)/rc' e)/rec' r(e/c).

diapurpala/mhsen, “juggled.” Ilgen's correction is certain, and should have been recognised by L. and S. , although the compound verb is elsewhere unknown. Eustathius 513. 30 has purpalama=sqai: kakotexnei=n kai\ oi(=on dia\ puro\s i)e/nai th=| kakotexni/a|. (The explanation is no doubt wrong; Ilgen sees an allusion to juggling with torches, which may be correct; cf. Archil. fr. 87.) Photius and Suidas preserve a substantive purpala/mhs, explaining o( taxe/ws ti e)pinow=n kai\ palamw/menos i)/sa tw=| puri/. Hesychius attests an adjective purpa/lamos. For similar disintegrations of rare words cf. Hippocr. Mochl.11katanaisimou=tai (Galen, Erotian) katateine: simou=tai etc. MSS., Hipp. 638. 42i)sennu/ousi (Galen, lexx.) i)/sai nu=n e)/ousai MSS. The excellence of M is clearly demonstrated in this line.
o(dou= to\ me/n ktl.: cf. 226.
melai/n|h *nukti\ e)oikw/s: i.e. invisible; cf. Il. 1.47.

la/wn: only here in the sense of ble/pwn; but Hesychius recognises another (lost) passage: la/ete: skopei=te, ble/pete. Cf. a)lao/s. In Il. 19.229 , 230 la/w can hardly bear this sense but must rather mean “seize,” “grip.” Possibly the hymn-writer may have misinterpreted the Homeric passage; more probably a verb la/w was used in both senses, which might be derived from the root la (labei=n etc.). Aristarchus explained the verb in Homer by a)polaustikw=s e)/xwn, “devouring,” as usual neglecting the hymn.

w)mo/rgaze: a brilliant emendation. The form does not recur, but for the radical verb (in the same context) cf. Od. 18.199 th\n de\ gluku\s u(/pnos a)nh=ke, kai/ r() a)pomo/rcato xersi\ pareia/s. Baumeister notes that au)gai/ for “eyes” is elsewhere first found in Attic tragedy.
a)legu/nwn: the reading is settled by a)glai+/as a)le/gune 476; for the variants cf. 85, 557. In Homer a)legu/nein is found only in the Odyssey, of preparing a meal.
a)*phlege/ws a)*go/reuen: cf. Il. 9.309 , a 373. The old derivation of a)phlege/ws from a)po/ and a)le/gw, “outright,” “bluntly,” seems still to obtain.
For the repetition of a)/ra Hermann compares Od. 16.213, a very similar passage.

On the alternatives see Hollander p. 26, J. H. S. xv. p. 302. There is no peculiarity in either version to give it a distinct preference. a)/llon mu=qon, “another story,” i.e. his account of the affair.

dei/cato d' eis *kroni/wna, “pointed to Zeus” to call his attention; the gesture, as Gemoll remarks, shews Hermes' audacity, and perhaps the feigned simplicity of childhood. Baumeister's translation ad Iovem convertit orationem cannot be right; Il. 19.83 e)ndei/comai is different. qew=n shma/ntora *pa/ntwn: so Scut. 56.

*nhmert/hs: Gemoll repeats Greve's erroneous statement that this word is only applied to things, not persons, in Homer. It is a constant epithet of Proteus, Od. 4.349, 384 etc., and of Nereus in Theog. 235.
*)=hlqen: the omission of the subject may be intentionally naive (Gemoll), but it is perhaps rather meant as an open discourtesy; Hermes refuses to utter Apollo's name throughout his speech.

e)s *(hmete/rou: the genitive in this expression occurs, with varying manuscript support, in Od. 2.55 , h 301, r 534. The scholia note the reading, which was that of Aristarchus (see La Roche on Od. 2.55). The genitive is also given by the MSS. in Herod.i. 35Herod., vii. 8.It is no doubt due to the false analogy of ei)s patro/s etc. Many editors read h(me/teron in the Odyssey; it is quite possible that the accusative is origiual in Homer, and that the genitive may have become idiomatic by the time of the hymn-writer and Herodotus.
mh*nu/ein: on the quantity of u_ see Schulze Q. E. p. 340.

filokude/os: only here and in 481, “loving glory,” “splendid.” The line may be a reminiscence of Theog. 988 te/ren a)/nqos e)/xont' e)rikude/os h(/bhs, but this is no justification for Schneidewin's violent e)rikude/os here.
*pat/hr ktl.: a parody of the epic ui(o\s . . . eu)/xomai ei(=nai (Gemoll).
The abruptness of the construction quite suits Hermes' parenthetic style.

w(s . . . e)/lassa . . . e)/bh*n: dependent on pei/qeo, w(\s o)/lbios ei)/hn being interjectional, “so may I prosper.” Hermann unaccountably ejects 379-381, although the whole passage is full of humour. Before Apollo, Hermes did not scruple to perjure himself freely (cf. 263 f., 309 f.); but in the presence of Zeus, his words are literally true, as the editors note: he did not drive the cows home, but to a cave; nor did he step across the threshold on his return journey, but passed through the keyhole.

There is irony in the mention of Helios. Hermes pretends to respect the Sun who sees all things; but the Sun had set when he started, and did not rise until he had returned. There is a further covert allusion to the night-time, in which Hermes loves to thieve (15, 67, 578). Gemoll quotes Hes. Op.607h(mero/koitos a)nh/r.

†e)*pidai/omai: this and e)pideu/omai are certainly corrupt, and point to an older corruption e)pi\ de/omai; Barnes' conjecture, e)pidw/somai, is too familiar to be mutilated, apart from the fact that the sense of the verb in Il. 22.234 qeou\s e)pidw/meqa is doubtful; Herwerden's e)pimai/omai is not used in the connexion. The suggestion in J. H. S. xv. p. 291 that the original here was me/gan d' e)pi\ o(/rkon o(mou=mai may still hold: if o(/rkon was once displaced, and added at the end of the line, depiomoumai orkon might give a corruption out of which d' e)pide/omai o(/rkon might arise; such transpositions are frequent; see J. H. S. l.c.

The “great oath” which Hermes swears “by the door” must have some special propriety; according to Bau meister, Hermes swears as a)guieu/s or propu/laios. Whatever the ostensible significance, there is no doubt a cryptic allusion to Hermes pulhdo/kos (see on 15).
kai/, which has been suspected, is in character: 385 is an addition, after Hermes has taken his oath.

*pot' . . . *pote/: the repetition is not more offensive than that of a)/ra in 365, and can be justified by the emphasis of the threat “some day—I say—some day.” It is possible, but unlikely, that pot) is for poti/, and the elision another Aeolism, like per' i)gnu/si 152; kai\ poti/ would be for kai\ pro/s in prose, poti\ de/ and poti\ d' au)= in Homer, poti\ kai/ in Hippocrates e.g. peri\ a)/rqrwn e)mbolh=s 97, 247, 286. Or, again, M's poti\ nhle/a may be right,=pro/s adverbial, if the preceding pot) is for pote. In any case Hermann's pou, though appropriate to a threat, and an easy change, is not required.

fwr/hn: for the accent see Schneider on Nicand. Alex. 273. Cf. Hesych. fwra=n to\ ta\ kleyimai=a zhtei=n kai\ fwria=n: fw/ran de\ th\n e)/reunan. “Some day I will pay him out for his pitiless search.” There may be here also a hidden meaning as Gemoll suggests: “I will pay him with a pitiless theft” (cf. the use of fwrh/ in 136).

e)*pilli/zwn: in Od. 18.11 ou)k a)i+/eis o(/ti dh/ moi e)pilli/zousin a(/pantes the verb= “make sidelong glances at a person” (cf. i)llo/s “squinting”), with a further idea of “hinting.” So here also Hermes probably “winks” or “leers” at Zeus to enlist his support. In Apoll. Arg. 1.486 , *g 791, the action is an insult (Matthiae). Cf. Anth. Pal. v. 199. 3 qh=lu katillw/ptonti *prih/pw|, “leering at,” and other compounds of i)llw/ptw.
o(mo/frona qumo\n e)/xontas: cf. Il. 22.263, h. Dem. 434, Theogn. 81, 765; a formulaic ending.

dia/ktoron: Solmsen I. F. iii. 90 ff. connects this epithet with kte/rea, kteri/zw, etc., in the sense of “giver,” “dispenser.” For other views see Oestergaard Hermes, 1902, p. 333, Cook Class. Rev. 1903, p. 177.

e)*p' a)blabi/|hsi *no/oio, “in all innocence of heart,” without guile. The commentators quote Cic. Tusc.iii. 8. 16, where a)bla/beia is given as the nearest equivalent of innocentia; *)ablabi/ai are personified, inscr. Dittenberger Syll. 600. 68. The adjective a)blabh/s=“innocent” is more common in this sense. e)pi/ may imply the purpose (ut animum insontem habeat, Franke, Ebeling), as in 524; but it seems rather to indicate present circumstances, “in,” so that the expression=a)blabw=s, bona fide.
d\h au)=t) (d' au)=t)); see Leaf on Il. 1.340, and for the crasis or elision H. G. § 350. au)=te here emphasises the question: pou= dh\ au)=t' a)pe/kruyas “where have you hidden now?”
a)*pe/kruye: for the quantity of the second syllable cf. e)ne/kruye e 488; H. G. § 370, and n. on 348.

*(hxou=: this form (=Attic o(/pou) is restored by Fick (B. B. xxii. p. 271), who compares h(xoi= in an inscription of Oropus (*)ef. a)rx. 1885 p. 93, C. I. Gr. Sept. i. 235, Dittenberger Syll. 589); see Smyth Ionic § 716, Hoffmann p. 16, Herwerden Lex. Supp. s.v. h(xoi=, Solmsen inscr. graec. dial. 1903, p. 95. The inscr., according to Fick, is in the Eretrian dialect, but the form may be local, and its presence in the hymn may be added to the argument for Boeotian authorship (see also on 255).
The previous emendations either depart from the tradition or, as Matthiae, suppose a double relative (h(=|x' ou(=). Ludwich's h(=xi a(/dhn and Gemoll's w)=x) are better, but w)=ka is distinctly weak.

xr/hmat), “chattels,” is remarkable for “beasts” in this context, but need not be suspected. If any emendation were required, kth/ne) might be suggested (cf. xxx. 10); the word is sufficiently rare to admit a gloss xrh/mata. So Hesychius kth/nea: xrh/mata, boskh/mata.

kiw<*>*n *para/: Hermes “went to” the cave, and drove out the cattle. The expression is loose, whether we read para/ or e)s, as Hermes obviously entered the cave. Franke's explanation that he stood at the mouth of the cave (solent enim boves apertis stabuli valvis, nisi vinculis retinentur, ultro exire) seems over-subtle.
a)*pa/terqen, “apart,” i.e. the hides were outside the cave. For the confusion of this word with a)pa/neuqen (M) cf. Il. 5.545.
e)du/nw: not elsewhere in epic.
au)to/s is as sound here as in 234, where see note.
qaumai/nw: this seems original, for even with Stephanus' alteration deimai/nw, kato/pisqe must mean “for the future.” The verb occurs in Od. 8.108, h. Aphr. 84.

Here, as Baumeister saw, a lacuna is imperatively required, for tai/ cannot possibly have an antecedent desma\ a)/gnou. A line must have fallen out containing a plural feminine substantive, and referring to some plant (cf. 410, 411), with which Apollo prepares to bind Hermes, either as a punishment for the theft, or in order to prevent further mischief. (The view that Apollo intended to bind the cows is most improbable.) The missing substantive may have been lu/goi, which denote the pliant twigs of the a)/gnos, agnus castus (Dioscor. i. 136); cf. Il. 11.105 , i 417, k 166, h. Dion. vii. 13. The apparent sense may be expressed by a line such as e)ndh=sai memaw\s *(ermh=n kraterai=si lu/goisi. It seems necessary, however, to suppose a further loss; for the lacuna should contain a fuller description of Apollo's attempt to bind Hermes, and of the way in which Hermes extricated himself from the withies. A miracle then took place, *(erme/w boulh=|si: the withies, as soon as they touched ground (ai)=ya), rooted on the spot, and multiplied into a thick interlacing grove (e)mbola/dhn), which covered the cows (or, perhaps, as D'Orville thought J. P. xxv. 255, entangled their feet).

e)mbola/dh*n: with a)llh/lh|si, “turned to fit into one another,” as if grafted on one another. For the idea of grafting cf. L. and S. , e)mba/llw, e)mbola/s, e)/mbolos. The adverb does not elsewhere occur, but is doubtless original, as a)mbola/dhn (426) gives no good sense here, and would leave a)llh/lh|si without construction.
r(ei=a/ te kai\ *pa/s|hsin: for te kai/ coupling an adverb with an adjective Gemoll quotes Theog. 86 o( d' a)sfale/ws a)goreu/wn
div2.l: ai)=ya/ te kai\ me/ga nei=kos e)pistame/nws kate/pause.

div2.p: Gemoll places a lacuna after this line; but this is unnecessary, as the sense seems complete from 410 to 415.
qau/masen: in Homer the imperfect takes the place of this aorist.

Here again Baumeister's lacuna is justified, for (1) Hermes' action in 415 has no assignable motive; (2) e)gkru/yai requires an object; (3) some mention of Hermes' lyre is wanted, to explain e)prh/u+nen in 417, and to provide an object to labw/n in 418. What Hermes wished to hide can hardly be discovered; it cannot have been the cows or the skins, which Apollo had seen, nor the cooked meat, which was unimportant when the slaughter of two cows had been admitted. He may have tried to conceal himself, or (as Gemoll thinks) his lyre. It might be suggested that Hermes enchanted the desma/ with his lyre, like Orpheus, and then looked for a place to hide it in; a lacuna to contain a mention of the lyre will still be required after 415.
u(*pobl/hdh*n: apparently “askance”; in Il. 1.292 it seems to mean “interrupting.”
*pu=r a)maru/sswn: cf. Theog. 827 u(p' o)fru/si pu=r a)ma/russe, Quintus viii. 28. pu/kn) (on the analogy of 278) is therefore needless.

The schol. on Dion. Thrax (Bekker Anecd. i. p. 752), quoted by Gemoll, fancifully connects lu/ra with lu/tra, adding h(ni/ka de\ tou= h(li/ou bou=s kle/yai h)boulh/qh, kai\ dia\ to\ mantiko
 tou= qeou= ou) dedu/nhto, a)nelh/fqh: ei)dw\s de\ kai\ tou= qeou= to\ mousiko
 de/dwken u(pe e(autou= th
 lu/ran lu/tran. So Boisson. Anecd. iv. p. 459 (there derived from lu/tron), from Antiope (Dind. fr. 190) lu/ra bow=n r(u/sa e)cerru/sato (lu/ra| and r(u/si) Boisson.).
labw/n is no doubt sound; and as the lyre must have been mentioned after 415, no further expression of the object is here necessary (Baumeister and Ludwich, after Hermann, supply a line).
e)*p' a)ristera\ xeiro/s=499; for the sense cf. e)pwle/nion 433. The shell rests “on the arm,” “to the left of the hand” which holds it.
419, 420=53, 54, and, with variations, 501, 502. Line 420 resembles Od. 17.542 smerdale/on kona/bhse: ge/lasse de\ *phnelo/peia.

Gemoll should not have objected to this line; its omission by the MSS. (except M) is accidental. The collocation i)wh\ e)noph=s is not elsewhere found, but presents no difficulty, “sound of divine music.” For i(/meros, passion roused by music, cf. Od. 23.144, and i(mero/eis 452; so e)/ros 434.

e)*p' a)ristera/: the repetition of this phrase in a different connexion from that of 418 is an example of the writer's carelessness; Baumeister points to the repetition of kiqari/zwn 423, 425, 433, e)ge/raire 429, 430. Add the recurrence of e)rato/s 421, 423, 426. Cf. on 352 f.

a)mbola/dh*n: Baumeister translates intenta voce, “lifting up his voice”; cf. Il. 22.476 a)mblh/dhn goo/wsa, and a)mbola/dhn *f 364, of a seething cauldron. Others render “in a prelude,” comparing a)naba/llesqai in Od. 1.155, etc. (a sense derived from the primary meaning “strike-up”). The Homeric use of the adverb favours Baumeister's translation, butitis possible that the hymn-writer used the word in the other sense; Pindar Nem.x. 33 has a)mbola/dan apparently “in prelude” (see Bury ad loc.).

krai/nwn: the nominative is sound, as e)rath\ de/ oi( ktl. is parenthetic, but krai/nein in this connexion is remarkable. Hesychius explains krai/nein by tima=n, following which Maurophrydes in K. Z. vii. 346 gives the sense of “honour in song” definitely to the word here, as in 531 (e)pikrai/nousa) and 559. This may be doubted, but the writer appears to use the word in an unusual sense both here and in 559, probably for a)ei/dwn. The use of the word in Empedocles 462, 3 (Mullach) might suit this sense: fa/rmaka d' o(/ssa gega=si kakw=n kai\ gh/raos a)/lkar
div2.l: peu/sh|, e)pei\ mou/nw| soi e)gw\ krane/w ta/de pa/nta; and there is a possible ambiguity in Eur. Ion464(compared with 559 of this hymn). See the discussion in Ebeling s.v. The explanation in L. and S. “finish the tale of” is not suited to the context.
div2.p: *gai=an e)remn/hn: Hermes may have begun his song with a cosmogony (cf. Theog. 1-21, Apoll. Arg. 1.496 f., Verg. Ecl.vi. 31 f.), but the simple mention of gai=a, without ou)rano/s and qa/lassa, hardly implies this. Gemoll prefers to see a reference to the honour paid to the gods on earth. For the language cf. e)remnh\n gai=an w 106, where the epithet is more in place, of the underworld.
*mn*hmosu/n*hn: cf. Theog. 52 f.

la/xe, “was assigned to Hermes” as patron-deity. For the form of expression cf. Il. 23.79 (of the fate assigned to a man at birth), Pind. Ol.viii. 15, Ar. Eccl.999, Theocr. iv. 40, Apoll. Arg. 2.258, Callim. h. Apoll. 45. So in prose, Plato Phaed.107D, Rep.617E, Lysias ii. 78.
kata\ *pre/sbin: so Plato Leg. 855 D kata\ pre/sbin i(ze/sqw (Matthiae). On the word see Johansson K. Z. xxx. 404 n. 2.

boufo/ne: first in this place, although the verb boufo/neon occurs Il. 7.466. The compound no doubt originally expressed the sanctity of oxen in early times (fo/nos=murder); cf. the boufo/nia at Athens, in which the priest was called o( boufo/nos (see Frazer on Paus.i. 24. 4). But in the Homeric passage the idea of “murder” seems to have disappeared from the verb (see Leaf ad loc.), and here also the substantive (“ox-killer”) has probably lost its early significance, which at Athens might be preserved until the latest times by the familiar local ritual. Even at Athens, however, the adjective boufo/nos could be used with no invidious meaning; P. V. 531 qoi/nais boufo/nois, quoted by Leaf. See supra 132.
mhxaniw=ta: (only here) formed like a)ggeliw/thn 296, sparganiw=ta 301, ei)rafiw=ta h. Dion. 1.2, 17, 20, xaridw=ta xviii. 12, and others.

*poneu/mene: generally thought corrupt, but perhaps with insufficient reason. The part. may be taken in a quasisubstantival sense, “busy one,” a use which seems justified in hymnal style, among attributes. Cf. Orph. h. 14. 8 o)brimo/qume,
div2.l: yeudome/nh, sw/teira ktl., ib. 51. 7 faino/menai, a)fanei=s=55. 10. If these analogies are insufficient, it would be possible to join the part. closely with mhxaniw=ta, adjectivally: “busy trickster.” The sense is quite suitable. Schneidewin s poleu/mene is graphically possible (n and l are interchanged Il. 16.726, h. Aphr. 20 etc.), and might be accepted, if combined with mhxaniw=ta, “ranging trickster”; but the same commentator's nukto/s should not expel daito/s; Hermes is “comrade of the banquet,” as the inventor of the lyre, which is daito\s e(tai/rh 31.
div2.p: The objection to Waardenberg's conjecture mhxane/wn a)ponh/mene (made independently by Tyrrell) is that it does not account for the existence of the rare but correctly-formed mhxaniw=ta.
*pent/hkonta bow=n ktl.: Apollo indirectly proposes an exchange of prerogatives; see on 464.

me/mhlas: the construction of me/lw with an accusative (even cognate) is unique, but none of the corrections suggested can be entertained. The passive participle is found (melhqe/n Anth. Pal. v. 200, 3, where however melisqe/n or meli/qroun are suggested), and the active with an object accusative may be an extension of the passive.
e)k *genet=hs: so M rightly; Hermann compares Il. 24.535 , s 6. Add (for prose) Aristot. Eth. Nic. vi. 13. 1.
*ne/hfatos: only here; cf. palai/fatos.

mou=sa a)mhxane/wn meledw/nwn: the hiatus may stand in the trochaic caesura of the third foot; Eberhard Metr. Beob. ii. p. 10, H. G. § 382. For mou=sa=song, cf. h. Pan 15, and in tragedy. The genitive is objective, as Franke explains, “a song for (against) cares.” Cf. Eur. Tro.609mou=sa/ q' h(\ lu/pas e)/xei. a)mhxane/wn may come from a)mhxanh/s, which is elsewhere unknown, but is more probably feminine from a)mh/xanos, a poetical exception to the general rule of two terminations in adjectives of this class. The exceptions are numerous in Homer, who uses a feminine termination for the following adjectives compounded with a privative: a)/brotos, a)eike/lios, a)qa/natos, a)/niptos (so Zenodotus on Il. 6.266), a)peire/sios, a)/sbestos. Hesiod has a)kama/th; for the hymns cf. h. Aphr. 133. For meledw/nwn cf. h. Apoll. 532, and for the sentiment Theog. 55, Cypria fr. 10. The conjectures are violent.

tri/bos: not in Homer, nor elsewhere found in connexion with music; “path of song,” like oi)=mos a)oidh=s 451. tribh/, however, “knack” is common, and perhaps that is the sense here. Cf. of the body Hippocr. Mochl.41to\ e)/qos tri/bon poiei=.
e)/rwta: the first indication of a nominative e)/rws=the Homeric e)/ros.

According to the present hymn, Apollo and the Muses had known only the flute (452) until Hermes invented the lyre; in h. Apoll. 131 Apollo claims the lyre as his own in his childhood. According to a third version, Apollo and Hermes fought for the lyre; e.g. in a group at Helicon, Paus.ix. 30. 1(see B. C. H. xv. p. 399). For other representations of this version cf. Monumenti 1830, pl. ix. 2.

oi)=mos a)oid=hs: it is doubtful whether u(/mnos a)oidh=s (=Od. 8.429), should not be preferred; Ludwich (Homerica i. p. 6 n.) thinks that oi)=mos is a phonetic corruption of u(/mnos. For the metaphor of oi)=mos cf. 447 tri/bos, Pind. Ol.i. 110o(do\n lo/gwn, Pind. Ol.ix. 51e)pe/wn oi)=mon ligu/n, Callim. h. Zeus 78 lu/rhs eu)= ei)do/tas oi)/mous. The word is not found in Homer, who uses oi)/mh “lay.”
oi)=a: for e)kei/nwn a(/. e)*nde/cia e)/rga: in apposition to oi(=a.
*ne/wn: wrongly altered by Gemoll and Herwerden to qew=n; for the text cf. 55 h)u_/tekou=roi
div2.l:
h(bhtai\ qali/h|si paraibo/la kertome/ousin, Apoll. Arg. 1.458
oi(=a/ te polla\ ne/oi para\ daiti\ kai\ oi)/nw|
terpnw=s e)yio/wntai (see on 56), Chaerem. fr. 327 qali/ai te ne/wn. e)*nde/cia, “clever,” only here in this sense. Homer uses only a neuter plural e)nde/cia, always adverbially (in Il. 9.236 the word qualifies a)stra/ptei). The hymn-writer probably did not coin the adjective e)nde/cios (which occurs Eur. Hipp.1360, Eur. Cycl.6 for “on the right”), but he may have assigned to it the meaning “clever” on the analogy of e)pide/cios. See on these words Darbishire Relliq. Phil. p. 67 f.

div2.p: oi)=das: here M has substituted the usual form; in 467 there is no variant. The Ionic oi)=das only once occurs in Homer, Od. 1.337 (Smyth Ionic § 702).
457-458. The two lines are preserved by M alone, but this is no sign of interpolation; the omission by other MSS. is probably due to the homoearchon in 456, 458.

The verse is corrupt, and the uncertainty of the sense required makes emendation more difficult. i(=ze seems genuine, but qumo
 e)pai/nei cannot stand, and one or other of the two words must be emended. (1) In J. H. S. xvii. p. 265 qumo
 e)pi/aine was suggested: “sit (as a minstrel) and cheer the heart of your elders” (on Olympus). The synizesis -iai- might stand (cf. *(isti/aian *b 537, *ai)gupti/as *i 382, d 83, *(istiaieu/s in a Delian inscr. B. C. H. vi. 33 § 41, u(giai/nein Athen. 694 F=Lucian pro laps. in salt. 6). But the last vowel would not be lengthened by position in the fourth foot; and e)piai/nein (cf. 480) might therefore be suggested; the transition from imper. to infin. is abrupt, but may be justified by Il. 1.20 and Il. 3.459 e)/kdote kai\ timh
 a)potine/men. Otherwise the sense is good: for i(/zein “sit at the board” cf. Theogn. ap. Plat. Meno95D kai\ para\ toi=sin pi=ne kai\ e)/sqie kai\ meta\ toi=sin
div2.l: i(/ze kai\ a(/ndane toi=s w(=n mega/lh du/namis. The compound e)piai/nein is not elsewhere found, but the simple verb is common in this connexion; e.g. Od. 4.548, h. Dem. 435, Theocr. vii. 29 qumo\n i)/aine (of music), Bacchyl.xiii. 187 Bacchyl., xvii. 131.
div2.p: (2) Ruhnken retained e)pai/nei, with mu=qon for qumo/n (a neat metathesis; cf. 256), i.e. “sit (? as a pupil, or in submission; cf. in a game o)/nos ka/qou: e)pi\ tw=n e)n pra/gmati h(ttwme/nwn schol. Plat. Theaet. 146A) and respect the words of your elders.” Apollo, speaking with the gravity of an oracle, bids Hermes listen humbly. For the general presbute/roisi of a particular person cf. 386. But the conjecture is doubtful, as e)painei=n ti/ tini is unknown, although it may be defended by Il. 2.335 , *s 312 taken together.

So Achilles swears by a sceptre, Il. 1.234 . krane/i+*non: this form appears to be correct; so Schulze Q. E. p. 253. Fick requires a form kraneai=on or krane/eion. Cornel - wood was commonly used for bows and spears; see L. and S. s.v. kra/neia, krane/i+nos. Apollo bears the spear (besides the bow) as a warrior, rather than as a herdsman, although Gemoll compares Od. 14.531 for the latter view; add Anth. Pal. vi. 177. 3 (Theocr. Ep. x.).

*(hgemoneu/sw: almost certainly corrupt; it is just possible that the writer used the verb as equivalent to h(gei=sqai, in the post-Homeric sense of “deem,” ducere. There is indeed no parallel, but there are analogies (e.g. the probable misuse of e)nde/cia 454), and the sense is fairly satisfactory. The conjectures are impossible, except Tyrrell's h(ge/mon' ei(/sw, but no future ei(/sw is known, although ei(/somai (intrans.) exists.

*perifrade/s, “cunningly”; Apollo had only hinted his wish to obtain the lyre. Hermes, with equal cunning (mu/qoisin kerdale/oisin) insinuates a veiled request for the cattle while praising the lyre (Baumeister).

qaa/sseis; no doubt correct, although qoa/sseis (M) is not a mere clerical error; the grammarians considered qoa/zein to be equivalent to qaa/ssein (Hesych. qoa/zei: ka/qhtai, and schol. Suppl. 595, O. T. 2, Apoll. Arg. 2.1026). In 172 qaasse/men, and in Homer, there is no variant. Cf. Schulze Q. E. p. 434 f., who gives qo/vakos as the original form of qw=kos (Hesych. qa/bakos).

The older critics complicated this sentence by punctuating after tima/s and *(eka/erge. This involved the change ge to de/, and the omission of q). But the whole sentence runs on after fasi; tima/s=the ritual due to the gods, to explain which was one of the functions of the Delphic oracle. *dio\s pa/ra repeats e)k *dio\s o)mfh=s emphatically, and qe/sfata pa/nta recapitulates the whole, in apposition as qau/mata e)/rga 80, 440, vii. 34, e)nde/cia e)/rga 454. This is simpler than to make *dio\s . . . pa/nta a gnome, whether pa/ra or ga/r be read.

The line as it stands is unmetrical. pai=d) must be corrupt. Neglecting this, we may translate “of which I myself have knowledge”; Hermes claims a share in some of Apollo's accomplishments, i.e. in music. Such a claim suits his bargaining character. For the gen. tw=n cf. Il. 21.487 ei) d' e)qe/leis pole/moio dahme/nai; the other l. kai/ is also possible. For pai=d' a)fneio/n we may read peda/fneion, Aeolic for meta/(i)fneion, “quickly”; Hermes is proud of his rapid progress since his birth. The word is preserved by Hesych. metai/fn(e)ios: e)capi/nhs. Cf. Hesiod Op.455a)nh\r fre/nas a)fneio/s “hasty,” see C. R. xi. p. 397. It is true that Aeolic ped-=met- nowhere occurs in Hesiod, but the working of dialectal influence on literature is essentially sporadic (cf. p. lxxiii); words beginning with ped- are frequent in Aeschylus, who also elides peri/ (see on 152). For inscriptions cf. Meister pp. 117, 284. Otherwise e)gw/ se for e)/gwge is easy, and is usually accepted. With this alteration, Tyrrell's ped' a)fneiw=s is ingenious (so paido/qen for pedo/qen in many MSS. Od. 13.295 , paidi/on for pedi/on in MSS. of Hesych. s.v. *)ra/rion), though the construction is complicated. Hermann's panomfai=on, which has since been received, stands in no relation to pai=d' a)fneio/n. In J. H. S. xvii. p. 266, pai= for pai=d) was suggested, d) being presumably added to avoid the hiatus. But although Hermes calls Apollo *dio\s kou=re in 490, a curt vocative pai= seems quite inappropriate to Apollo in the mouth of a child. With regard to the rest of the line, tw=n . . . a)fneio/n, “wealthy in which,” seems (with the reading e)gw/ se) quite sound, but it is possible that the writer used the postHomeric form a)fneo/n (first in Theognis, Pindar and Bacchyl. ; the a is common in quantity). This would suggest that pai=d) is a gloss on the rare accusative pa/i+n (Apoll. Arg. 4.697), the last syllable being lengthened by ictus: “wherein I myself know that thou wert rich, even as a boy.” Hermes naturally compares his own childhood with that of Apollo. For another probable gloss in this hymn cf. on 90.
au)ta/greton: the editors compare Od. 16.148, where au)ta/greta means “taken of themselves,” “to be had for the taking” (Merry); so here “thou canst lay thy hand on any knowledge.”
e)*pieu/ei: with infinitive, as in Il. 18.175, where see Leaf; Schulze Q. E. p. 340.
de/gmenos: see on h. Dem. 29. ku=dos o)/paze: as promised by Apollo 461.

478, 479. As these lines stand in the MSS. (with e)pistame/nws) there is no copula. Of Barnes' two suggestions, e)pistame/nhn is bad, and should not have been so generally accepted; e)pista/menos, on the other hand, can be explained as due to a scribe who thought of correcting the metre. For the lengthening of the short syllable in Homer see H. G. § 375. In late epic there are examples in the fifth foot (as here) in Apoll. Arg. 1.725 h)e/lion a)ni/onta, 1361 eu)rei=an e)side/sqai.
Ludwich's transposition of eu)mo/lpei and eu)/khlos (480, where he reads fe/rwn) is ingenious, but unmotived.
fe/rein: infinitive for imperative; Baumeister compares Hes. Op.671eu)/khlos to/te nh=a qoh\n a)ne/moisi piqh/sas
div2.l: e(lke/men.

div2.p: filokude/a: as in 375; in both places the sense of “glorious” suits the context and can be extracted from the word without violence. kw=mon: not in Homer or Hesiod, but the latter has kwma/zw (Scut. 281).
For the asyndeton see note on 151. This and the following lines continue the personification of the lyre (e(tai/rhn 478).

sun*hqei/|hsin: the word is probably original, although the sense is disputed; Baumeister understands “sweet societies,” but it is far preferable to render “gentle practice”=te/xnh| kai\ sofi/h|. The plural refers to continual and repeated practice, the adjective malakh=|sin to the soft touch on the strings.
a)qurome/n*h: almost certainly passive of the cognate construction, not middle; see on 151.

e)rgasi/h*n feu/gousa du/hpaqon: if feu/gousa is sound, the meaning (as given in J. H. S. xvii. p. 266) must be “avoiding painful (sc. to the lyre= violent) labour”; i.e. the lyre does not respond to unscientific handling. The metaphor would be similar to Plat. Rep. 531B e)carnh/sews kai\ a)lazonei/as xordw=n (see Adam). We should, however, expect such an antithesis to be marked by a)qurome/nh me\n . . . feu/gousa de/; the two participles, as they stand, can hardly express a contrast. Moreover e)rgasi/h for “handling” a lyre is perhaps unusual; the subst. generally means “work,” although it is true that e)rgasi/a, e)rga/zesqai, are frequent in the sense of exercising or “practising” the arts generally; and the application to an instrument appears precisely parallel to our “practice.” If the text be thought unlikely, we must assume that feu/gousa, fqe/ggousa, are corruptions of another participle, such as qe/lgousa, “giving relief from the pains of labour.” du/hpaqon (elsewhere duhpaqh/s) is perhaps rather strong as an epithet of manual labour, but may be explained by passages like Theocr. xxi. 2 f.
ou)de\ ga\r eu(/dein
a)ndra/sin e)rgati/naisi kakai\ pare/xonti me/rimnai; and, for the consolation of music in or after work, id. x. 22
kai/ ti ko/ras filiko\n me/los a)mba/leu: a(/dion ou(tw=s
e)rgach=|.
met/hora: apparently adverbial, like ma/y, “uncertainly”; cf. the use of mete/wros in prose.

qruli/zoi: the manuscript qruali/zoi points to uncial corruption from qrulli/zoi (a constant variant), but the single l is correct for the word and its cognates; Cobet Misc. Crit. 221, Schanz Plato vii. p. 7, Dindorf on Eq.348.

489=474. The repetition is no doubt a kind of parody of Homeric style; the line itself, as Gemoll notes, is here quite in place, to return to Apollo after the digression. Apollo alone can command the instrument without need of practice.

That Hermes can have the care of cattle only by favour of Apollo is clear not merely from the general context, but by the express word boukoli/as t' e)pe/tellen 498. The genitives o)/reos, pedi/oio depend on nomou/s, for which cf. Od. 10.159 e)k nomou= u(/lhs “pasture in the wood.” There is no need to suppose a lacuna, with Baumeister. bousi\ *nomou\s . . . *nomeu/somen: not a poetical equivalent of bou=s nomeu/somen (schema etymologicum), but=“will eat down the grass with cattle”; cf. nomoi=o 198.
e)/nqen a(/lis: unaccountably thought corrupt by Gemoll; e)/nqen is of course temporal, a(/lis=in abundance, with qhlei/as te kai\ a)/rsenas, the common Homeric construction; so 180.
494, 495. The words imply a fear that Apollo's anger may be too strong for his cupidity.
mi/gdh*n: in late epic, for the Homeric mi/gda.

e)/xwn: probably corrupt, though it is not perhaps more otiose than e)/xousa 345. D'Orville's e)/xein (repeated by Matthiae) hardly accounts for e)/xwn. Martin's e(kw/n is possible, and e(lw/n (suggested in J. H. S. xvii. p. 266) is also a simple correction; for the confusion, cf. Il. 5.136.

501, 502. The lines are a repetition, with further variations, of 53, 54, and 419, 420. M's reading u(*pe/nerqe (u(po\ ne/rqe the MS.) is here restored; in sense it is equivalent to u(po\ xeiro/s 419. The other MSS. have u(po\ kalo/n, probably due to the next line. smerdale/on: so in 54, 420; here the MSS. except M substitute i(mero/en, for which cf. Il. 18.570 i(mero/en kiqa/rize: li/non d' u(po\ kalo\n a)/eiden. It is, however, possible that the actual passage diverged throughout from 53 f. and 419 f., and ran h( d' u(po\ kalo\n i(mero/en ktl., and that M preserved one variant, xp the other; cf. h. Apoll. 255 with 295.
a)/eisen: the tense of the completed action is here as clearly appropriate to the context as the imperfect a)/eiden is required in 54 and Il. 18.570.

kai\ ta\ me/n: it is remarkable that the conjectures kai/ q' o( me/n, etc., should have been accepted down to Ludwich's text. Either ta\ me/n or to\ me/n gives excellent sense, “firstly,” as often in Greek from Homer onwards (cf. Od. 2.46). o( me/n would introduce an opposition between persons, whereas Hermes is subject to both actions, e)fi/lhse and e)kma/ssato.

w(s e)/ti kai\ *nu=n: the reading is amply justified by 125 w(s e)/ti nu=n, where, as here, the writer is thinking of contemporary belief or practice; diampere/s does not necessitate a change to e)ce/ti kei/nou: Hermes loved Apollo “right through,” as he still loves him. The line refers to the close connexion between the cults of the two gods in various parts of Greece; Baumeister mentions their common altars in Messenia, Olympia and Thebes ( Paus.iv. 33. 4Paus., v. 14. 8Paus., ix. 17. 2). Add to this the cult of the two gods at Cyllene (E. M. *kullh/nios: *kullh/nh de\ *)arkadi/as, i(ero\n *(ermou= kai\ *)apo/llwnos), which is more significant in connexion with this hymn; there was a temple of the Muses, Apollo, and Hermes, at Megalopolis, Paus.viii. 32. 2.They had a common altar in Mysia C. I. G. 3588 b. On the Arcadian connexion of Apollo and Hermes see Immerwahr die Kulte u. Mythen Ark. i. p. 95, 135. For the two gods (with the Charites) at Elatea see B. C. H. xi. p. 341; they are joined in Delian votive inscriptions, B. C. H. viii. p. 126, xv. p. 251. See Pauly - Wissowa “Apollon” 37 f., Forchhammer Lex. der Mythensprache p. 43-53, Preller-Robert i. p. 393; Introd. p. 129.

s/hmat): possibly corrupt, although no alteration is more than plausible. The plural sh/mata can hardly be right, for Hermes gave only a single “token,” i.e. the lyre; nothing is said about Apollo's gift of the cows. But sh/mat) may be for sh/mati, a dative of “reason” or “occasion,” common in Homer (H. G. § 144). The elision need present no difficulty; cf. Il. 3.349 a)spi/d' e)ni\ kraterh=| *d 259 e)n dai/q), *e 5 a)ste/r' o)pwrinw=|, and many other examples collected in H. G. § 376 (3). For the position of e)pei/ Baumeister compares Il. 6.474 , c 175.

i(mert\hn dedaw/s: the position of i(merth/n is very remarkable if we take it closely with dedaw/s, and the difficulty of the line is increased by uncertainty as to the subject and meaning of dedaw/s. The verb might be causal, “teach,” as de/dae bears this sense in Homer; but it seems necessary to refer dedaw/s to Apollo, who “knew” the lyre by intuition (cf. 474 soi\ d' au)ta/greto/n e)sti dah/menai, and Od. 17.518). This makes Ludwich's correction almost certain.

e)*pwle/nion: this form is found in all manuscripts at 433, and gives the requisite sense; the lyre rested on, not under, the left arm. u(pwle/nion is due to such expressions as u(po\ xeiro/s 419, where the right hand, used in striking the strings, is meant.

The asyndeton is like that in the similar lines 25, 111. On the invention of the flute cf. Apollod.iii. 10. 2. 6*(ermh=s de\ tau/tas ne/mwn su/rigga pa/lin phca/menos e)su/rizen. *)apo/llwn de\ kai\ tau/thn boulo/menos labei=n, th\n xrush=n r(a/bdon e)di/dou h(\n e)ke/kthto boukolw=n. Apollodorus must have derived the exchange of the pipe for the staff from some other source, as nothing is said of this exchange in the hymn.

There is nothing suspicious about thlo/q' a)kousth/n (as Gemoll thinks): the epithet is true of the su=rigc. For the connexion of the flute with Hermes see Euphor. fr. 33 (Athen. iv. 184 A), Preller-Robert i. p. 418, Roscher Lex. i. 2372 f. Roscher, as usual, sees in the flute a characteristic of the whistling wind; it is rather an attribute of Hermes *no/mios—the common instrument of the shepherd.

M's reading a(/ma kle/yh|s is usually accepted. But a)nakle/yh|s, a more significant word, seems guaranteed by a Dodonean inscription in Collitz ii. 2, no. 1586 p. 12. 4 a)nek[leyen], where Hoffmann cites this passage; cf. also Hesych. a)nakle/ptesqai: a)naxwrei=n. An actual theft of the to/ca is recorded by Horace ( Od.i. 10. 10), who may have followed Alcaeus in this particular, and by Lucian (Dial. Deor. vii. 1).

e)*pamoi/bima: the form is well restored by Wolf and Ludwich from M's e)p' a)moi/bhma. The variant is due to the comparative rarity of the termination; cf. Il. 4.381 parai/sima parai/sia, *z 62 ai)/sima ai)/sia. The humorous identification of “exchange” with “robbery” is characteristic of the style. Matthiae notes that the evil reputation of merchants was due to the Carians and Phoenicians, who combined trading with piracy; but in this respect also Hermes reflects the Greek character.

Cf. Od. 5.178 , k 343, h. Apoll. 79 (qea/ for qew=n). qew=n me/gan o(/rkon= Il. 2.377, where the context shows the meaning to be “an oath by the gods.” Here the o(/rkos qew=n is the oath by which the gods swear; cf. Od. 10.299. This oath was regularly by the Styx; cf. Il. 15.36 , e 185, Theog. 784, h. Dem. 260 etc.

kefal*=|h *neu/sas: a reminiscence of Il. 1.524 f., where the “nod” is the substitute for an oath, in the case of Zeus. That it is here an alternative to the oath by the Styx is no sign of interpolation, as Matthiae and others suppose. e)*pi/: in Homer the simple accusative only is found with o)/mnumi “swear by”; but various prepositions are used in prose with the verb in this sense; see L. and S. s.v.

Hermann's e)/rdein for e)/rdois rests on the use of ei)/ moi tlai/hs ktl., without apodosis, in h. Apoll. 79, but the change is quite needless here; the subject of the o(/rkos is sufficiently clear from the context.

e)*p' a(rqmw=| kai\ filo/thti=apparently a stereotyped expression; cf. P. V. 192 ei)s a)rqmo\n e)moi\ kai\ filo/thta . . . h(/cei. So Callim. fr. 199 (fili/an). There is no probability that Aeschylus borrowed from the hymn, or that Callimachus copied from either source.

*dio\s *go/non: i.e. a hero such as Heracles; for a)/ndra Baumeister compares the Homeric h(miqe/wn ge/nos a)ndrw=n. The correction *dio\s go/nou misses the point: qeo\n and a)/ndra *dio\s go/non are subdivisions of a)qa/natoi.

A lacuna is here clearly indicated: the transition from indirect to direct narration is not warranted by Il. 4.303 , *y 855; Longinus de sublim. defends such transitions in an interesting chapter (xxvii), but his Homeric example Il. 15.348 can be otherwise explained. Moreover, e)k has no reference, te/leion seems unnatural with su/mbolon, and se is indispensable. Since the sanction of Zeus appears necessary both here and in 568f., and is stated in 575 xa/rin d' e)pe/qhke *kroni/wn, perhaps a line has fallen out such as ai)eto\n h(=ke path/r: o( d' e)pw/mosen, h)= se ma/l' oi)=on (J. H. S. xvii. p. 266). Possibly the missing passage was longer, containing a reference to the exchange of the pipe, and a direct request by Hermes for mantei/a. This view, however, is unnecessary; see further on 533.

su/mbolon: this appears to be from su/mbolos, and can only refer to Hermes, who is pisto\s e)mw=| qumw=|. The meaning is very doubtful; Ilgen's translation, “mediator,” gives an unparalleled sense to the word. We should naturally understand it as “omen,” and this is not impossible; Hermes is the god of luck and of e(/rmaia, and might be called a personified “omen” for gods and all alike. But this is undoubtedly harsh; the meaning must remain uncertain owing to the lacuna, which leaves the context unknown.
a(/ma *pa/ntwn: i.e. a)nqrw/pwn. The expression may be weak, but it is genuine; h)d' a)nqrw/pwn would not have been corrupted.

r(a/bdon: not to be confused with the ma/stiga faeinh/n (497), which had already been given to Hermes, as god of cattle. This is, of course, the magic staff, which entrances or wakes men; Il. 24.343 f., Od. 24.2 f. Hence Hermes is xruso/rrapis e 87, k 277, 331. It is the staff afterwards called the khru/keion (see 530), although a distinction is sometimes made in art, Hermes being represented with both r(a/bdos and khru/keion (PrellerRobert i. p. 404). According to Preller, the staff was originally a divining-rod, for finding treasure or gold. It was, indeed, thought to have had this function (see Preller-Robert i. p. 412 n. 3), but the idea is not Homeric, nor probably original. Hermes has a “golden” staff just as he has a golden sword and shoes (xrusa/oros, xrusope/dilos); the epithet is common to attributes of the gods. The form of the khru/keion may have been borrowed from the Phoenicians (Hoffmann Hermes und Kerykeion) but Hoffmann's deduction that Hermes was a Phoenician moon-god does not follow. See on 15.

tripe/thlon: best explained by Preller (Philologus i. p. 518) as=“with three branches,” one forming the handle, while the other two spring from it, and are united at the top. See also Roscher Lex. 2401, Harrison Proleg. p. 46.

a)k/hrion: passive, “unharmed,” with se. For the order Schneidewin compares Od. 20.47 diampere\s h(/ se fula/ssw. Add Od. 23.56 kakw=s d' oi(/ pe/r min e)/rezon. Ludwich, following the old editions, takes a)kh/rion as co - ordinate with the preceding adjectives, “harmless.” The rhythm would favour this view, but there is no certain example of the active use; in Hes. Op.823a)kh/rioi h(me/rai are days which bring no fate or destiny.

*pa/ntas e)*pikrai/nousa qeou/s: the construction e)pikrai/nein ti/ tinos seems impossible, even if the presumed meaning “confirming all the gods in respect of good words and deeds” made any sense in the context, or could be justified by any known virtue of the r(a/bdos. pa/ntas appears to be sound; cf. Il. 15.599 pa=san e)pikrh/neie (a)rh/n), “fulfil all the prayer.” Nothing, however, can be said in favour of the numerous conjectures, except that qeou/s (from qeo/n 526, qew=n 537) may have displaced another word; for its introduction cf. h. Apoll. 59. As a correction, e)pikrai/nous' a)/qlous may be suggested: “fulfilling (winning) all the tasks (whether of word or deed) which I claim to know.” This is supported by Od. 8.159 f. ou) ga/r d' ou)de/, cei=ne, dah/moni fwti\ e)i+/skw
div2.l: a)/qlwn, oi(=a/ te polla\ met' a)nqrw/poisi pe/lontai, where the neut. oi(=a/ te, as o(/sa here, refers adverbially to the masc. a)=qloi (see M. and R. on Od. 8.108). Cf. also Od. 8.133 a)/eqlon oi)=de/ te kai\ deda/hke. e)pikrai/nousa would=e)ktele/ousa, cf. e.g. Od. 8.22 e)ktele/seien a)e/qlous. The khru/keion would be a certain talisman for victory in any contest, whether of word (e.g. music), or deed (e.g. athletics), unless the reference is more general, to any difficulties in life.

div2.p: mantei/h*n . . . *(\hn e)reei/neis: unless Hermes asked for the gift of prophecy after 526 (where see note), the request had only been made by a hint at 471 f.; see on 464.
to/: sc. to\ manteu/esqai, from mantei/hn.

541-549. Matthiae and others have curiously assigned this passage to Hermes; Ludwich prints it after 474. At first sight, indeed, the lines appear more suited to the character of Hermes, as described in 576 f. But the view is certainly wrong; the sentiment is quite appropriate in the mouth of Apollo. No objection should have been raised to the futures dhlh/somai etc.: Apollo means to do as he has always done; the tenses refer to the frequent deception of the oracles, down to the hymn-writer's own day. The tone of his speech sounds like a frank confession of deceitfulness; and, as such, would not be inconsistent with the general spirit of the hymn. The poet need not have been more careful of Apollo's morality than he was in the case of Hermes. But the explanation of the occasional deception in oracles is probably meant to be serious; it might stand as an official vindication of the god in his dealings with men. Stress is laid on the observance of the proper ritual, without which inquirers approach the god at their risk. If they are duly accredited with the right omens, a true answer is obtained; cf. (of Dodona) Hes. fr. 134. Rzach=schol. ap. Soph. Trach.1174e)/nqen e)pixqo/nioi manth/i+a pa/nta fe/rontai,

l.quote: o(\s dh\ kei=qi molw\n qeo\n a)/mbroton
e)cereei/nh|

div2.l: dw=ra fe/rwn e)/lqh|si su\n oi)wnoi=s a)gaqoi=sin. See further Schoemann Griech. Alt. ii. p. 321. The uncertainty of the oracle is like that of the lyre, 482 f.; both answer under proper conditions. The language of the Muses in Hesiod is in a similar vein; cf. Theog. 27 f. i)/dmen yeu/dea polla\ le/gein e)tu/moisin o(moi=a,
i)/dmen d), eu)=t' e)qe/lwmen, a)lhqe/a ghru/sasqai.

div2.p: *polla\ *peritrope/wn: probably a reminiscence of Od. 9.465 polla\ peritrope/ontes e)lau/nomen (mh=la), where the verb seems to mean “driving about.” So Apoll. Arg. 2.143 a)/speta mh=la peritropa/dhn e)ta/monto. So here Apollo “drives” men like silly sheep, i.e. perplexes them. The common translation “deceiving,” “misguiding,” does not suit the present context, as a)/llon o)nh/sw precedes; nor could this sense, which is elsewhere unknown, be easily derived from the Homeric use of the verb.

fwn*=|h t' *)hde\ *pot*=|hsi: there is no difference in meaning or value between this reading and the variant fwnh=| kai\ pteru/gessi. The modal datives present no difficulty; su/n is added in the Hesiodean line quoted on 541 f.
telhe/ntwn, “fateful,” “significant.” The editors compare Od. 2.181 o)/rniqes de/ te polloi\ u(p' au)ga\s h)eli/oio
div2.l:
foitw=s), ou)de/ te pa/ntes e)nai/simoi, and Callim. v. 123
gnwsei=tai d' o)/rniqas o(\s ai)/sios, oi(/ te pe/tontai
h)/luqa, kai\ poi/wn ou)k a)gaqai\ pte/ruges.

div2.p: mayilo/goisi, “telling a vain tale,” ou)k e)naisi/mois.

e)*gw\ de/ ke dw=ra dexoi/mh*n: if the hymn-writer has as low an opinion of Apollo as he undoubtedly has of Hermes (according to modern ideas), this line might be explained as a cynical admission of filoke/rdeia (see on 335). But here, as in 541 f., there is probably a serious defence of Apollo's oracle. Baumeister understands the words to be spoken petulanti cum irrisione; but, as he himself allows, the Delphian priests might have used the same language. The dw=ra are obligatory, whether a true response is vouchsafed or no; they are, in fact, like money staked in a lottery— necessary for all competitors, without commandingsuccess as a matter of course.

semnai/, “there are certain reverend ones, sisters, three in number.” The reference is undoubtedly to the Thriae, but there is no reason to substitute *qriai/ here; the mythology would be sufficiently clear from the context, aided by the emphatic trei=s, from which the ancients derived *qriai/. To an Athenian, semnai\ (qeai/) would probably have suggested the Furies, but the hymn-writer was no Athenian. The variant moi=rai, which is obviously wrong, may have been a gloss due, partly at least, to trei=s. Apollodorus alluded to the Thriae in his account (dida/sketai th\n dia\ tw=n yh/fwn mantikh/n), but this is no argument that he read *qriai/ here, nor does he use the actual word. On the *qriai/ see III. They App. are certainly here closely connected with bees (see on 559) if not actually personifications of the bee.
*pepalagme/nai a)/lfita leuka/: first explained by Matthiae; “with white meal sprinkled over their heads,” i.e. white-haired. See III. HermannApp. 's lacuna after this line may be neglected.
mantei/hs: obviously with dida/skaloi. The Thriae were teachers of private divination, although not of the highest oracular mantei/a, to which Apollo attained after his boyhood.

a)*pa/neuqe: not “apart from men,” but, as the context shews, “apart from me”; the Thriae had given Apollo his first lesson in divination, and still continued their art, though the god had outgrown it.
a)le/gizen: an evident correction; cf. 361 where the MSS. give all three verbs a)legu/nwn, a)legi/zwn, a)leei/nwn.

a)/llote a)/ll|h: for the hiatus Schneidewin compares Od. 4.236 a)/llote a)/llw|; so Hes. Op.713 where for a)/llote a)/llon some MSS. from a desire, as here, to avoid the hiatus give a)/llote/ t' a)/llon, a)/llot' e)s a)/llon. Add Phocyl. fr. 12 a)/llote a)/lloi, Solon fr. 13. 4 a)/llote a)/llos.

khri/a bo/skontai: honey is the food of gods 562; Callim. i. 49 gluku\ khri/on e)/brws (of the infant Zeus). Hence honey gave inspiration, prophetic or poetic: cf. the title me/lissa of the Pythia, Pind. Pyth.iv. 60; see also Pind. Ol.vi. 47.Compare the common folk-tale that poets and sages were fed by bees, generally in their infancy. (References in Cook's exhaustive essay, p. 7 f.) For the mantic bee in Semitic belief cf. Joseph. Archaeol. v. 6 *debw/ra profh=tis, me/lissan de\ shmai/nei tou)/noma, and see generally Robert-Tornow de apium mellisque signif. 1893, Frazer on Paus.x. 5. 7, Usener in Rhein. Mus. (1902) 57. 2 p. 179, Harrison Proleg. p. 91.

The omission of iota in the diphthong ui is a common fault in MSS. So Il. 11.180 only the A Ven. and two other MSS. have qui=en, in Hesiod papyri in some places preserve the iota, in others no trace is left of it; cf. Theog. 109, 131, 848, 874, Op.621; there are similar variants in the case of gui=on, o)pui/ein, mhtruih/. The papyrus of Timotheus (ed. Wilamowitz 1903) has u(pere/quien v. 75. For ui, u in inscriptions see Meisterhans p. 46 f.

On the variant see J. H. S. xv. p. 302, Hollander l.c. p. 28. The lines are evidently alternatives, but the version of y is far preferable. done/ousai (cleverly corrected by Baumeister from dene/ousai) is peculiarly appropriate to bee-women. Cf. Choerilus ap. Herod. p. m. l. 13 muri/a fu=l' e)donei=to polusmh/noisi meli/ssais.
daei/hs: the indefinite optative may well be correct, although followed by e)pakou/setai, which suggests the subjunctive daei/h|s (dah/h|s). For this form cf. Il. 16.423 o)/fra daei/w.
ai)/ ke tu/x|hsi, “if he has good luck”: divination, as well as oracular prophecy, is uncertain.

Here again the syntax shews a lacuna. a)na/ssein ku/dimon *(ermh=n cannot be an imperative, as some commentators suppose; it requires a main verb, and the subject, as Gemoll notices, can hardly be other than Zeus, who authorises this empire over all animals. In J. H. S. xvii. p. 267 two lines were suggested: w(s e)/fat): ou)rano/qen de\ path\r *zeu\s au)to\s e)/pessi
div2.l: qh=ke te/los: pa=sin d' a)/r' o(/ g' oi)wnoi=si ke/leuse.

div2.p: tetelesme/non: the editors compare Hes. Op.799tetelesme/non h)=mar, a “perfect” or lucky day. The present context shews that “perfect” here connotes the idea “duly appointed,” with proper credentials; cf. Dem. 171. 19strathgo\s telesqh=nai “to be formally appointed general.”

a)/dotos, “without receiving presents” from Hermes, Latin ultro. *ge/ras: this present from Hades to Hermes can only be explained by the preceding line; i.e. the right to be the a)/ggelos ei)s *)ai+/dhn. Entrance to the underworld by the gods is spoken of as a favour granted by Hades. Hermes is superis deorum gratus et imis ( Od.i. 10. 19). It is just possible that the “present” is mystic, i.e. death (cf. the story of Cleobis and Bito ); dw/sei would then be general, like dhlh/somai 541, and the recipients would be men; but the context is against this view.
o(milei=: genuine, for M's nomi/zei cannot be justified by such passages as Her.ii. 50(nomi/zein h(/rwsin).

It is astonishing to find objections raised to this passage by some of the older critics. The lines 577-578 conclude with the theme which runs through the whole poem—the deceitfulness and waywardness of Hermes.
*pau=ra o)*ni/n*hsi no doubt ironically corrects the title e)riou/nios, as Baumeister explains.
to\ d' a)/kriton, “endlessly”; cf. 126 (without the article).

div1.head: HYMN TO APHRODITE

listBibl.head: BIBLIOGRAPHY
listBibl.bibl: A. LUDWICH, Rheinisches Museum p. 566, 1888.
R. PEPPMÜLLER, Philologus xlvii. p. 13 f., 1889.
A. FICK, in Bezzenberger Beiträge xvi. 1890, p. 23 f.
T. W. ALLEN, J. H. S. xviii. p. 23 f., 1898.
TÜMPEL and DÜMMLER, art. “Aphrodite” in Pauly-Wissowa Real-Encycl.
L. DYER, Gods in Greece p. 270 f., 1891.
L. R. FARNELL, Cults of the Greek States ii. p. 618 f., 1896.
A. LANG, The Homeric Hymns (Translation) p. 40 f., 1899.

div1.p: Subject.—Aphrodite has power over gods and men alike, and over all the birds of the air and the creatures that move on the earth or in the waters. Athene, Artemis, and Hestia alone are free from her influence. But she constrains even Zeus to love mortal maids. He therefore, in his turn, set passion in her heart, so that she might love a man, and might not boast of her conquest over the gods. So she loved Anchises, who tended the flocks on Ida. First she went to Paphos, and adorned herself in her temple; thence she came to Ida, followed by a train of wild animals in whom she inspired passion. The hymn then describes her meeting and union with Anchises, the subsequent revelation to him of her divinity, and her announcement that a son would be born whose name should be Aeneas. She prophesies that this child and his descendants shall sit upon the throne of Ilium. After warning Anchises not to boast of her love, lest Zeus should strike him with a thunderbolt in anger, she departs to heaven.
The myth of Aphrodite and Anchises.—The germ of the story handled by the hymn-writer is found in Homer Il. 2.820 *ai)nei/as, to\n u(p' *)agxi/sh| te/ke di=) *)afrodi/th,
div1.l: *)/idhs e)n knhmoi=si qea\ brotw=| eu)nhqei=sa. Hesiod (Theog. 1008-1010) follows Homer. Compare also Il. 5.313, where the statement is added that Anchises was tending the herds; this is copied by later accounts (Theocr. xx. 34, Prop. ii. 32, 35, Dion. xv. 210 f.). The myth was related by Acusilaus ap. schol. Il. 20.307 (who makes Anchises elderly, parhkmakw/s, at the time) and Apollodorus (iii. 142), who seems to have ignored the hymn; in his version Aphrodite visits Anchises di) e)rwtikh\n e)piqumi/an, while the hymn-writer lays stress on the agency of Zeus (45 f.). The mythographer names two children of the union—Aeneas and Lyros. In the same passage (iii. 141) Apollodorus follows the later account that Ganymede was carried off di) a)etou=; in the hymn (202 f.) a whirlwind takes the place of the eagle. See further Rossbach in Pauly-Wissowa s.v. Anchises (2107 f.).
