It is remarkable that so graceful a hymn should have made little or no impression on later literature;For its possible influence on the hymn to Demeter see below, p. 198. it is not cited by any ancient writer, nor is there any certain mark of imitation by the Alexandrines.
div1.p: Character of the poem.—The hymn has often been compared with the “Lay” of Demodocus on the love of Ares and Aphrodite (Od. 8.266 f.). There can be no doubt that the author was acquainted with the lay (see notes on 58 f., 234). But the resemblance is confined to language; for the moral tone of the hymn is far higher than that of the Olympian society depicted by Demodocus. Baumeister (p. 250) misunderstands the character of the hymn in remarking that Aphrodite is represented as Vulgivaga, a lascivious goddess who rejoices in the base love with which she inspires the gods. Against this view Gemoll (p. 258) rightly points out that Aphrodite shews shame and modesty. Her passion for Anchises is no wantonness, but has been forced upon her by Zeus. The poet treats the adventure with considerable frankness, indeed, but not without dignity; and the note of humour and raillery, which is sounded in the Odyssean lay and the hymn to Hermes, is entirely absent. The merits of the poem have been perhaps extravagantly lauded by some critics, but have been unfairly depreciated by others. There may be some inelegance (according to modern taste) in repetitions such as that of e)/rgon, used five times in 1-16; but these blemishes, which are collected by Suhle,De hymn. Homerico iv, 1878, p. 23. A. and M. Croiset (i. p. 590) think the poem too long for the subject. do not justify that scholar's verdict that the writer is a permediocris poeta. It is true that there is little originality in work which follows the Homeric language so closely (see below, p. 198); but credit at least is due to an imitator who has successfully caught the spirit as well as the letter of the old epic. The scene of Aphrodite's progress to Ida (67 f.) is finely picturesque; and the whole poem, in Mr. Murray's words,Anc. Greek Lit. p. 50. “expresses perhaps more exquisitely than anything else in Greek literature that frank joy in physical life and beauty which is often supposed to be characteristic of Greece.”

The poet's conception of Aphrodite is simple. She is mistress over the whole world of animal life (2-6); but the hymn gives no hint of a deity who inspires the whole Cosmos—an Aphrodite Urania, by whose agency
e)ra=| me\n a(gno\s ou)rano\s trw=sai xqo/na, e)/rws de\ gai=an lamba/nei gamou= tuxei=n.

Such an idea of the universal love-goddess doubtless grew up, as Mr. Farnell remarks (p. 699), on eastern soil; but in Greek literature it found no full expression until the time of Attic tragedy (e.g. Eur. fr. 89), and later, of the Orphic hymns (cf. Orph. h. lv. 4).

Date.—The date of the hymn, as of the others, is very doubtful. Hermann calls it Homeri nomine dignissimum, and some have even thought it contemporary with the Iliad and Odyssey. WindischDe hymnis Homericis maioribus, 1867 (p. 68). thinks it as old as the later parts of the Odyssey; ThieleProlegomena in h. in Ven., 1872 (p. 49). assigns it to the time of the Cypria. Others (e.g. EberhardSprache der hom. Hymnen ii. p. 34.), without urging so early a date, consider the hymn to be the oldest in the collection. On the other hand, Suhle Op.cit. p. 27. believes that the author may have been a contemporary of the Pisistratids, or even of Sophocles. This view is extreme; but it will hardly be disputed at the present day that the hymn is later than the earliest parts of the Odyssey. The theory of great antiquity rests mainly on the fact that the hymn is o(mhrikw/tatos in diction. As many as twenty verses are taken from Homer with little or no variation; and the poem abounds in epic hemistiches and formulas. But this only proves that the author was a diligent student of the Homeric poems, while there are a number of words and usages which are not Homeric (a full list is given by Suhle p. 16 f.).

Reminiscences of Hesiod are scattered through the poem (5, 14, 29, 108, 258, etc.). Still more remarkable is the close connexion between this hymn and that to Demeter. The two hymns have, in common, several words, or uses of words, which do not occur elsewhere in extant Greek literature: 31 tima/oxos (h. Dem. 268), 157 eu)/strwtos (h. Dem. 285), 257 baqu/kolpos, applied to nymphs (h. Dem. 5), 284 kalukw=pis (h. Dem. 8), which only reappears in the Orphic hymns. Some striking expressions are also confined to the two hymns: 156 kat' o)/mmata kala\ balou=sa (h. Dem. 194), 173 mela/qrou ku=re ka/rh (h. Dem. 188). Unfortunately, scholars are not agreed as to the question of borrowing. Some (e.g. Abel) hold that the writer of the hymn was the imitator; Gemoll and others think it scarcely doubtful that the hymn to Aphrodite is the older. The latter view seems the more probable. In that case, it may well be at least as old as the seventh century B.C.

Place of composition.—If the date of the poem is uncertain, the place of composition is not less obscure. According to Groddeck, who is followed by various scholars, including Abel and Fick (B. B. ix. p. 200), the hymn is Cyprian. It is pointed out that Aphrodite is called the goddess of Cyprus in 2, 292, and the rare word sati/nas in 13 is supposed to be Cyprian. No argument, however, can be based on the occurrence of the title *ku/pris, which is Homeric, and, like *kuqe/reia, belongs to the common stock of divine epithets (cf. vi. 2 and 18; x. 1 *kuprogenh= *kuqe/reian). The Cyprian origin of sati/nh is also very dubious (see on 13); and in any case a word used by Anacreon and Euripides need not be considered distinctly “local,” even in early poetry.

Others (Matthiae, O. Müller, etc.) place the home of the author in Asia Minor, and believe the poem to have been recited in honour of a chieftain who claimed descent from Aeneas. But the hymn bears no trace of having been composed for a definite occasion, or in honour of a particular person. The allusion of the revived Trojan kingdom in 196 f. is quite vague, and is merely a reminiscence of the Homeric tradition. Many, without committing themselves to the “Trojan” theory, believe that the author was an Ionian, or at least lived in Asia Minor. This is as likely as the Cyprian view, and as equally incapable of proof. The myth handled by the poet is not local, but Homeric; the love of Aphrodite and Anchises was famous wherever Homer was known. The language may be “very pure Ionic—almost Homeric-Greek,” but it does not follow that the composer was an Asiatic, as Prof. Mahaffy argues (Hist. Greek Lit. i. p. 148). At a time when the epics had become the property of the whole Greek-speaking world, the author of such a hymn might have belonged to any branch of the Hellenic stock. The further argument of those who see a contamination of Aphrodite with the Asiatic Cybele is unsound. It is true that Aphrodite was probably, in the Troad, another form of Cybele (Farnell p. 641), and as a nature-goddess had power over all the brute creation; but the hymn-writer is influenced by the Homeric conception of the goddess, and for Homer Aphrodite is far removed from Cybele. As Gemoll observes, the goddess is called a daughter of Zeus, and her train of beasts is a mere imitation of the animals which follow Circe (see on 69).

State of the text.—The general unity of the hymn is so obvious that it has suffered little from the “higher criticism.” The Germans, for the most part, have been content to expunge isolated lines. One passage—the description of the nymphs—was suspected by Groddeck and Ilgen (260-274). The lines are perhaps the most interesting in the poem, and there is absolutely no valid ground for denying them a place in the original document. Hermann's theory of a double recension cannot be neglected; but such a recension, if it existed, has left but slight traces; cf. notes on 97 f., 274 f.

div2.p: *mou=sa/ moi e)/n*nepe: a reminiscence of Od. 1.1 a)/ndra moi e)/nnepe, *mou=sa.
3-5. The goddess of love inspires all living things, not only men; cf. Eur. Hipp.447 f.Eur. Hipp., 1269 f., Lucr.i. 1 f.

diipete/as, “that fly in the air,” not elsewhere of birds; cf. Il. 17.675 u(pourani/wn petehnw=n. In Homer the word is only applied to rivers “which fall from Zeus”; Baumeister suggests the same meaning here, “sent from Zeus,” comparing Od. 2.182 e)nai/simoi, a passage, however, which is rather against his view; for only some birds are e)nai/simoi, whereas the power of Aphrodite extends over all alike.
Cf. Theog. 582 knw/dal), o(/s' h)/peiros polla\ tre/fei h)de\ qa/lassa. Fick compares Cypria 5, 11-12.
Matthiae compares Proclus h. iv.13 pa=sin d' e)/rga me/mhlen e)rwtoto/kou *kuqerei/hs.

*glaukw=pin *)aq/hn*hn: so in Od. 1.156, Theog. 13, 888, h. Apoll. 314, without variant; glaukw=pin polu/mhtin in xxviii. 2. On the other hand, glaukw/pid' *)aqh/nhn h. Apoll. 323, glaukw/pida ei)/ph| *q 373. See Kühner-Blass i. p. 421 n. 7.
eu)/aden: Il. 14.340 , *r 647 (where see Leaf).
u(smi=nai/ te ma/xai te=Od. 11.612. For the infin. a)legu/nein correlative with the preceding substantives cf. 18 and often.
a)*glaa\ e)/rga: here of arts generally, including masculine accomplishments; below 15, of women's work. See also xx. 2.
The asyndeton is common with prw=tos and similar words; cf. Il. 1.105 , *n 46, 91, *w 710, g 36 etc. For Athena as patron of crafts see xx Introd.

te/ktonas: for dedications to Athena by te/ktones cf. Anth. Pal. vi. 204 and 205. Athena gave men th\n tektonikh\n te/xnhn Diod.v. 73; so, as early as Hesiod ( Hes. Op.430), the plough-builder is *)aqhnai/hs dmw=os.

sati/nas: this rare word occurs elsewhere only in Anacr.xxi. 12satine/wn, Eur. Hel.1311; see Hesych., and Herod. p. dixr. 291. 25. It is derived by G. Meyer Alban. Stud. iii.=Sitzungsber. d. Wiener Akad. 125 p. 51 Anm. 1: “Das Wort stammt aus Vorderasien, und gehört zu ai. śátr<*>s ‘Feind’ air. cath ‘Kampf,’ gall. Caturiges, ahd. hadu, ags. heado.” This is accepted by Solmsen K. Z. xxiv. p. 38 and 69 who adds the Phrygian *ko/tus and the Thracian tribe *sa/trai, *satroke/ntai. This etymology and the quotations in literature (in Anacreon the word is part of a description of eastern luxury, in Euripides it represents Cybele's car) seem to make sati/nh a Grecised Asian, perhaps Phrygian, word. Fick's view (B. B. ix. p. 200) that the word is Cyprian rests on no better evidence than Hesychius' gloss sa/sai: kaqi/sai. *pa/fioi (Smyth Melic Poets p. 291).

kai\ a(/rmata *poiki/la xalkw=|=Il. 4.226 , *k 322, 393. Ruhnken (h. Dem. 274) would neglect position throughout, i.e. write te kai/. The question is discussed in J. H. S. xviii. p. 23f. True exx. of kai/ making position (i.e. with no digamma or other consonant lost before the following vowel) are rare, and Ilgen's view cannot be considered as proved, owing to the ease with which te is dropped in the MSS. Flach (B. B. ii. p. 18) omits te in 85, 169, 232; Fick reads i)de/.
14= Hes. Op.519parqenikh=s a(palo/xroos, and ibid. 521 e)/rga i)dui=a poluxru/sou *)afrodi/ths, with which cf. 9. Gemoll remarks that the debt to Hesiod is plain.

xrushla/katon keladein/hn=Il. 7.183 , *u 70, xxvii. 1. Hesych. is probably right in explaining xrushla/katos (for Homer) as=kalli/tocos: h)laka/th ga\r o( tociko\s ka/lamos. For h)laka/th=“arrow,” cf. a)/traktos=oi)sto/s. This is the view of D'Orville J. P. xxv. p. 257, who also compares Soph. Trach.636.The sense “of golden distaff” is quite unsuited to the character of Artemis. The addition of keladeinh/ in several passages is a further argument. The epithet refers to the goddess as a hunter who “calls on the hounds”; cf. schol. *a on Il. 16.183 kunhgetikh=s: para\ to\n gigno/menon e)n toi=s kunhgi/ois ke/ladon. So, probably, in Bacchyl.xi. 37*)/artemis a)grote/ra xrusala/katos . . . toco/klutos. Later poets (Pindar and Bacchyl.ix. 1) must also have understood the epithet to refer to the distaff.

filommeid/hs: Curtius is no doubt right in connecting this with √smi (mm for sm), i.e.=filo/gelws, in spite of the Hesiodean filommhde/a, o(/ti mhde/wn e)cefaa/nqh, Theog. 200. So Brugmann Grundriss i. p. 165 and 421, iii. p. 1051.

ou)/resi ktl.=Il. 21.485 (of Artemis). With the whole passage cf. Callim. h. Art. 2 f.
th=| to/ca lagwboli/ai te me/lontai
kai\ xoro\s a)mfilafh\s kai\ e)n ou)/resin e(yia/asqai. M's reading can hardly be due to mere mistake; perhaps a line has fallen out between 18 and 19 kai\ ga\r th=| a(/de [ . . . poulu/xrusa de\] to/ca ktl.
The omission was due to homoeomeson, sc. a(/de and -a de/. polu/xrusos in Homer is applied to persons and places, but Artemis' bow is pagxru/sea in xxvii. 5. poulu/xrusos in not Homeric.

diapru/sioi: the adject. is not found in Homer, though diapru/sion (adv.) occurs several times; cf. h. Herm. 336. o)lolugai/, the cries of women at the dances in honour of Artemis. For the musical character of Artemis see Farnell p. 471, xxvii. 18.

dikai/wn te *pto/lis a)*ndrw=n: for Artemis as a lover of justice compare Callim. h. Art. 122 f. a)lla/ min ei)s a)di/kwn e)/bales po/lin (she slays the unjust with her arrows). pto/lis in contradistinction to a)/lsea refers to her political and social character. This side was not very prominent. See Pauly-Wissowa s.v. 1350 f., Farnell Cults ii. p. 467 f. The epithet polih/oxos given her in Apoll. Arg. 1.312 does not seem to occur in actual cult. Although Zeus promises her “thirty cities to cherish no other god but thee, and be called by the name of Artemis” (Callim. h. Art. 34, cf. ib. 225 polu/ptoli), these cities, as Farnell points out, are not Greek cities proper, or are unknown to us. At Athens and Miletus, her titles *boulai/a and *boulhfo/ros shew some connexion with civic life; at Olympia she was worshipped as *)agorai/a. Cf. also Anacr. i.h(/ kou nu=n e)pi\ *lhqai/ou di/nh|si qrasukardi/wn a)ndrw=n e)skatora=|s po/lin. Artemis dwells in Metapontum ( Bacchyl.v. 115 f.) as de/spoina law=n. But the ordinary Greek conception of Artemis is well expressed by Callim. h. Art. 19 f. sparno\n ga/r, o(/t' *)/artemis a)/stu ka/teisin. ou)/resin oi)kh/sw ktl.

The sing. pto/lis is somewhat abrupt, and no doubt produced M's po/leis. However “a city” is after all collective: its inhabitants may possess the a)/lsea and produce the solemnities of 19. pto/lis is Cyprian - Arcadian, according to Fick B. B. ix. p. 204, but it is certainly used here purely for metrical convenience, as pto/lis pto/lemos in Homer. Bothe's view, that a single city (Delphi) is meant, cannot be accepted.

The Ionic form i(sti/h (Smyth Ionic § 144) has survived in the greater part of the MSS.; in the two minor hymns xxiv. 1 and xxix. 1 e(sti/h is invariable, though at xxix. 6 i(sti/h is read by all copies but two. In the four places where the word occurs in the Odyssey, i(st- is the vulgate, but in all except Od. 20.231 the common form has crept into some copies. In Il. 2.537 i(sti/aian does not vary. In Hesiod e(sti/h| is the vulgate ( Op.734), and e(sti/hn is found sporadically in Theog. 454.

Ejected by many editors after Heyne. But there is no good reason for suspicion; the poet alludes to the legend of Cronus, who disgorged his children in an order inverse to that in which he had swallowed them ( Theog. 495 f.) Hestia, who was the eldest child, was swallowed first and disgorged last. She could be said to have a second birth, as much as Dionysus, who was born again from the thigh of Zeus. This curious mention of Hestia as the “eldest and youngest” is perhaps connected with the custom of pouring libation to her at the beginning and end of a feast; see xxix. 5.

The wooing of Hestia by Poseidon and Apollo is not elsewhere mentioned. The myth, as Gemoll suggests, may be an invention of the poet himself. There is no ground for supposing any physical meaning with Preller and Baumeister. Welcker's explanation is more satisfactory, that Poseidon and Apollo stand for the highest suitors; Hestia would not accept any proposal. There was a group of Poseidon, Amphitrite, and Hestia at Olympia ( Paus.v. 26. 2), a conjunction of deities which may have a physical origin, but has certainly nothing to do with the present myth.
e)/qelen: the lengthening is justified by the pause; H. G. § 375. Hermann needlessly conjectures e)qe/lesk).
sterew=s a)*pe/eipen=Il. 9.510.

kalo/n: the shortening of the first syllable is not Homeric, but occurs in Hes. Op.63, Theog. 585. The last passage (dw=ke kalo\n kako\n a)nt' a)gaqoi=o) is probably the original of this verse (Gemoll). Some older editors omitted *zeu/s, reading dw=ken kalo/n. Baumeister objected to this on the ground that path/r is not used with the omission of *zeu/s. This, however, is a mistake; cf. Il. 8.69 , 245, *l 80, *c 352 etc. See Ebeling s.v. path/r 147. But no alteration of the text is required.
*pi=ar e(lou=sa: cf. Il. 11.550 bow=n e)k pi=ar e(le/sqai. See note on h. Apoll. 60.
31-32. Cf. xxix. 1-3, where Hestia is said to have a place in the temples of all the gods, as well as in the houses of men.
tima/oxos: only here and in h. Dem. 268.
*pre/sbeira does not occur elsewhere before Euripides (I. T. 963).

tw=n a)/llwn: sc. ou)de/ni. *pefugme/non: for the use of the middle perfect participle cf. Il. 22.219 (neuter, as here). In Il. 6.488 , i 455 it is used in the masc. In Od. 1.18 the object is in the genitive; see Nitzsch ad loc.
Cf. Il. 10.391 pare\k no/on h)/gagen. For the sense Matthiae compares Troad. 948 f. *dio\s krei/sswn genou=
div2.l: o(\s tw=n me\n a)/llwn daimo/nwn e)/xei kra/tos,
kei/nhs de\ dou=lo/s e)sti. Add Mosch.i. 76*ku/pridos, h(\ mou/nh du/natai kai\ *zh=na dama/ssai.

div2.p: eu)=te qe/loi: Baumeister and Gemoll seem right in retaining the form qe/loi, as the hymn does not belong to the oldest epic. See note on h. Apoll. 46. Some edd. after M read eu)=t' e)qe/lh|, but the opt. qe/loi is to be retained; h)/gage and sune/mice are not indefinite in time, but refer to Aphrodite's treatment of Zeus in the past, for which he now punishes her.
42-44 were suspected by Ilgen, but rightly defended by Matthiae. The poet is imitating epic prolixity, and airing his mythological knowledge.
a)/fqita m/hdea ei)dw/s: the phrase is comparatively rare, occurring only in Il. 24.88, Theog. 545, 550, 561, fr. xxxv. 2 (135). Compare also h. Dem. 321 *zeu\s a)/fqita ei)dw/s.
See Introd. p. 196 and cf. 189 f., where Aphrodite's passion is a sorrow to her. Lang (Transl. p. 42) compares Homer's lenient view of Helen, who is the unwilling tool of destiny.

For the change of mood in ei)/p|h following ei)/h compare Il. 15.598 (e)mba/lh| . . . e)pikrh/neie: Hermann e)mba/loi), Od. 12.156 (qa/nwmen . . . fu/goimen: some MSS. and edd. fu/gwmen), Il. 5.567 pa/qh| . . . a)posfh/leie (where pa/qoi is read by Leaf after two MSS.). The usage, however, appears to be established; cf. Il. 16.648 -651, *s 306, d 692. So Il. 24.654 au)ti/k' a)\n e)cei/poi . . . kai/ ken a)na/blhsis lu/sios nekroi=o ge/nhtai, where the subj. appears to express the certainty of the further consequence as though the hypothetical case (au)ti/k' a)\n e)cei/poi) had actually occurred (H. G. § 275). In all these cases the subj. indicates that greater stress is laid upon an alternative or consequence.

a)*ne/mice: Schäfer's correction sune/mice is palaeographically easy, but it is hard to see why, if the MSS. preserve sune/mice in 39, 50, and sune/mica 250, they should not have done so here. Ixion read a)nami/sgomai (for e)pimi/sgomai) Il. 10.548.

54=e)n a)kropo/loisin o)/ressin *e 523, t 205. *polupida/kou: the form (for polupi/dakos) was condemned by Aristarchus; cf. schol. *a on Il. 14.157 to\ de\ dia\ tou= u gra/fein tele/ws a)/groikon. It is given, however, in the Cypria fr. 3. 5 (Athen. xv. p. 682 F); cf. Strabo 602 polupi/dakon de\ th\n *)/idhn i)di/ws oi)/ontai le/gesqai. See La Roche Hom. Textkr. p. 343. For the double form cf. fu/lac, fulako/s.
e)kpa/glws is supported by Il. 3.415 e)/kpagla fi/lhsa and Il. 5.423. The form e)kpa/glws occurs in Il. 1.268. Hence there is no need for Köchly's obvious correction e)/kpaglos.

58-62=Od. 8.362-365, with the addition Il. 14.169 (=60) and Il. 14.172 (=63). 58 is not literally identical with Od. 8.362 (h( d' a)/ra *ku/pron i(/kane filommeidh\s *)afrodi/th), and in 59 the hymn has quw/dhs against quh/eis of Od. 8.363. A more important difference is e(anw=| in the hymn 63, against e(danw=| *c 172. As e(a^nw=| cannot be an adj., and as (in Il. 14.172) Athen. 688 E, schol. Il. 14.346, and the papyr. Brit. Mus. 572 have e(anw=|, it is probable that e(danw=| was original here, and suffered an easy graphical corruption to the common word (see on 63).

It might be doubted whether the writer consciously combined the two contexts from *c and q, or whether the passage in q, which is the closer parallel, was at one time fuller. But he must also have been familiar with *c; see on 66, 68.

For the Phoenician temple of Aphrodite at Paphos see Gardner E. in J. H. S. ix. 193-215, Dyer p. 305 f. For the repetition of e)s cf. note on h. Apoll. 439. It does not appear in Od. 8.362. The inelegancy quw/dea—quw/dhs is also due to the imitator. bwmo/s te quw/dhs following quw/dea nho/n draws special attention to the incense, which was a prominent feature of the Paphian templecult; cf. Verg. Aen.i. 415 f. ipsa Paphum sublimis alit, sedesque revisit

l.title: laeta suas: ubi templum illi centumque Sabaeo
ture calent arae sertisque recentibus halant.

div2.p: qu/ras e(*pe/qhke faeina/s = Il. 14.169 , f 45; cf. Od. 6.19 , *e 751. The doors are “brought to” their staqmoi/. The epithet faeina/s probably refers to metal ornament. In the house of Alcinous the door is golden (Od. 7.88).
e)/nqa de/: de/ is given in Od. 8.363. Hermann would read e)/nqa te here and in h. Pan. 31. But de/ and te appear to be equally correct; e)/nqa de/ = et ibi, e)/nqa te=ubi.

In Il. 5.338 the robe of Aphrodite is called the work of the Charites; in the Cypria fr. 2 it is woven by the Charites and Horae. Aphrodite is associated with Charites in the dance; cf. Od. 18.194, h. Apoll. 194 f. The Nymphs and Charites with Aphrodite sing together on Ida— Cypria fr. 3. The connexion is certainly old, although we cannot assert that it is primitive; see Farnell p. 625. At Elis Pausanias (vi. 24. 5) saw statues of the Charites, who bore emblems of Aphrodite, and remarks *xa/ritas de\ *)afrodi/th| ma/lista ei)=nai qew=n (oi)kei/as). Cf. also Od. 8.362, Hes. Op.73, Mosch.i. 71, Colluth. 16, and other reff. in Roscher Lex. s.v. 875.

oi)=a: the plur. following e)lai/w| is curious; according to M. and R. (on Od. 8.365) “it is not used merely adverbially, but takes up generally the idea suggested by the emphatic epithet a)mbro/tw|.” This view seems better than to take oi(=a as= “in such manner as,” in which case e)/laion will be the subject of e)penh/noqen.

e)*pen/hnoqen: second perf. e)p-en-a)nqe/w, “flowers out upon” (stem a)noq for a)nq in a)/nqos etc.). Others translate “is laid upon,” from e)ne/qw; see Et. 304, Buttmann Lexil. 130 f. Meyer (Griech. Et. i.) marks the etymology as doubtful.

The verse has been generally ejected, but is rightly retained by Gemoll; see further on 97. There is no reason why the writer of the hymn, who apparently borrowed 60 from *c, should not have added another line from the same context. For the meaning of a)mbrosi/w| see Leaf on Il. 2.19. There can be little doubt that it is here used as a synonym of a)mbro/tw|, though Gemoll thinks that the writer may have distinguished between the two words. For the close conjunction of the words see Od. 18.191-93.
e(danw=|: the meaning may be “sweet,” as Apollon. and Herod. understood, but the derivation is unknown; see Meyer Griech. Et. i. s.v., and cf. Solmsen Untersuchungen p. 283, 4.
66, 67. In both lines the reading of M has been accepted. For e)*pi/ with gen.= “towards” cf. Il. 3.5 , *e 700. r(i/mfa, as the rarer word, is prima facie more probable than qow=s.

eu)w/dea: all Cyprus is filled with the fragrance of the goddess. The epithet, as Gemoll notes, is suggested by Il. 14.173 f., where the smell of the oil, with which Hera anoints herself, reaches heaven and earth.
68=Il. 8.47 (i(/kanen) and Il. 14.283 (i(ke/sqhn); the latter verse was probably in the poet's mind, as 67=Il. 14.282.
mhte/ra qhrw=n: cf. mhte/ra mh/lwn *b 696, *i 479, *a 222, h. Pan 30.

Lenz remarks that this passage is suggested by the episode of Circe, Od. 10.212 f., where, however, wolves and lions fawn on the companions of Odysseus, not on Circe. But the main idea— the power of a goddess over brutes —is the same. In Apoll. Arg. 1.1144 f. wild beasts fawn on Rhea, and in Arg. Il. 4.672 f. they follow Circe like sheep following a shepherd. So Lucr.i. 16ita capta lepore
div2.l: te sequitur cupide quo quamque inducere pergis (pecudes).

div2.p: *parda/lies Mx, porda/lies p. The Paris family preserves the Aeolic form (Smyth Ionic § 147. 2), which, however, remained in common use; e.g. Strabo 619. In Homer (Il. 13.103 , *r 20, *f 573, d 457) the MSS. are divided; Aristarchus read pa/rd-. D'Orville wished to alter the line so as to assimilate proka/dwn to the declension pro/c, proko/s which we find in Od. 17.295. But do/rc, dorka/s is a sufficient parallel for the double form.
su/nduo: not in Homer, but cf. su/ntreis i 429.

staqmoi=ci: the locatival dat. here and in 79 is defended by such passages as Od. 8.66 me/ssw| daitumo/nwn (qh=ke), Il. 20.22 ptuxi\ *ou)lu/mpoio h(/menos; see H. G. § 145. The use is most common with names of places, as Od. 6.8, 162 etc. (*sxeri/h|, *dh/lw|). For exx. in the hymns cf. infra 173, h. Dem. 99, xx. 4.
qew=n a)/po ka/llos e)/xonta=Od. 8.457 (e)/xousa). Cf. Od. 6.18 *xari/twn a)/po ka/llos e)/xousai (= Hes. fr. 81. 1), and 12 qew=n a)/po mh/dea ei)dw/s.
qa/mbainen (the form in p) is found also in one MS. of Pind. Ol.iii. 33, where the majority have qau/maine or qau/maze, some qa/maine.
faeino/teron *puro\s au)*g=hs=Il. 18.609 (qw/rhka).

e)*pig*nampta/s: the verb e)pigna/mptw is not uncommon, and the adjective, though a(/p. leg., need not be suspected. Baumeister reads eu)gna/mptas, which, however, is of two terminations: Od. 18.294, Apoll. Arg. 3.833, Orph. Arg. 499. e)/pi gnampta/s (Barnes and Döderlein), sc. e)pi\ tou/tw|, is quite impossible.

e(/likas ktl.: the description of the jewels is evidently borrowed from Il. 18.401, which=163 infra. According to Helbig the e(/likes were brooches, such as have been found in graves of the “Mycenean” period, formed of two spirals (H. E. p. 279-82). The ka/lukes were probably earrings in the shape of flower-buds, but nothing is really known about them. The schol. AB on Il. 18.401 gives a choice of several meanings—rings, earrings, and spirals for the hair (cf. Il. 17.52).

e)la/mpeto is probably impersonal (Franke, Gemoll). The old view that the subject is o(/rmoi (by schema Pindaricum) is most improbable. Baumeister suggests that Aphrodite is the subject, but, as Gemoll observes, the goddess is clothed, and it is the pe/plos, not the skin of the goddess herself, which shines (cf. 86). The construction would be simplified if, with Wakefield (followed by Suhle and others), we transpose 89, 90 between 86 and 87, reading kalo\n xru/seion pampoi/kilon in 89; the subject of e)la/mpeto is then clear.

*)agxi/sh*n d' e)/ros ei)=len: Anchises loved Aphrodite at first sight; lines 143, 144 merely imply that the goddess added to his passion. Peppmüller's ta/fos for d' e)/ros is no improvement to the sense, and is objectionable on account of the asyndeton.
The passage was probably suggested by Od. 6.149 f. (Odysseus' address to Nausicaa). With 97-99 cf. Od. 6.124-25.

a)/nassa is only applied to goddesses in Homer: to Demeter Il. 14.326, and Athena Od. 3.380 (in Od. 6.149 Odysseus doubts whether Nausicaa is not a goddess, and uses the word reverently). So in the hymns: h. Dem. 75, 440, 492; xxxii. 17.

In Homer the Charites are mainly associated with Aphrodite (see on 61), although Charis is the wife of Hephaestus in Il. 18.382, and Hera promises one of the Charites in marriage, Il. 18.267, 275. But in later times they were connected with various other deities, e.g. with Apollo, Artemis, the Muses, Hermes, Dionysus, and Hera. For references see Preller-Robert ii. p. 482 f.

97, 98. Here (as in 62, 63 a)mbrosi/w| a)mbro/tw|) the repetition of *numfa/wn *numfw=n has been a ground for assuming two recensions; but (1) in each case the second line introduces a fresh item of description, (2) the redundancy does not involve more than a poverty of art. Therefore it is probable that 63 and 98 are original. numfa/wn—numfw=n, if remarkable, has the exact parallel of w)dh=s—a)oidh=s h. Dem. 494, 495. Lines 97, 99=Il. 20.8, 9 (ou)/t' a)/ra for h)/ tis). With 98 cf. Od. 6.123 numfa/wn ai(\ e)/xous' o)re/wn ai)peina\ ka/rhna (Od. 6.124=Il. 20.9). Gemoll is wrong in suggesting that the Oreads may be a later conception, owing to their absence in *u. They are mentioned in Il. 6.420 nu/mfai o)restia/des, as well as in the Odyssey. See on 258.
*ph*ga\s *potamw=n: sc. nhi+a/des n 104 (nhi+/s *h 22).
w(/r|hsin *pa/c|hsi, “at all seasons” rather than “for all time,” which is h)/mata pa/nta. Gemoll compares h. Dem. 399 and xxvi. 12.
The editors compare Il. 6.476 do/te dh\ kai\ to/nde gene/sqai
div2.l: pai=d' e)mo/n, w(s kai\ e)gw/ per, a)riprepe/a *trw/essin.
div2.p: a)/ndra: Schneidewin's a)ndrw=n is quite unnecessary; nor is ai)ei/ an improvement, although a)nh/r and ai)ei/ are confused in h. Apoll. 151.
ei)sopi/sw=e)copi/sw ( Od.), which Hermann and Abel would read here. For ei)sopi/sw cf. Soph. Phil.1105.
au)ta\r e)/m) au)to/n ktl.: sc. do/s, supplied from 103. Gemoll's e)/a for e)u+/ in 105 is not fortunate.
*zw/ein ktl.=Od. 10.498.
xamaigene/wn a)*nqrw/pwn is Hesiodean (Theog. 879). Cf. h. Dem. 352.
109=Od. 16.187 (a)qana/toisin).
In Il. 3.186 Otreus is a chief of the Phrygians, who was assisted by Priam in an invasion of the Amazons.
eu)teix/htoio: a(/p. leg. For the Homeric forms eu)tei/xeon, eu)tei/xea see Leaf on Il. 16.57.

The recognition of difficulties in understanding another's language is quite Homeric, and is not “a note of late authorship, or at least of a self-conscious art not found in very early poetry” (Tyrrell Hermath. ix. p. 48). Cf. Il. 2.804 , *d 437; and later Agam. 1034, Eur. Phoen.301 with schol. A foreign nurse must have been common wherever slave-trading was known.
kai\ *(hmete/rh*n: i.e. “I know your tongue as well as my own.”

118=Il. 16.183 (e)n xorw=|), where Hermes earries off Polymele, whom he himself loves. Lines 119-21 are an amplification of the Homeric passage, characteristic of an imitator. In Eur. Hel.44 f. Hermes earries off Helen.
*nu/mfai, “brides” or “young wives”; the word is applied to Helen, Il. 3.130, and to Penelope, Od. 4.743.
a)*pei/ritos e)stefa/nwto=Od. 10.195 (po/ntos), of an island, and Scut. 204 (o)/lbos), of the chorus on Olympus. For the crowd surrounding the dancers cf. Il. 18.603.
xruso/rrapis: see on h. Herm. 529.

a)/klhron, land which has not been divided into klh=roi, “allotments” (see Il. 15.498). a)/ktiton, “not built over”; it might possibly=“uncultivated,” as its opposite eu)kti/menos appears sometimes to mean “well-tilled”; cf. Od. 9.130 , w 336, For the omission of gh=n cf. Il. 14.308 , u 98, h. Dem. 43 e)pi\ traferh/n te kai\ u(grh/n, h. Apoll. 529. So Il. 10.27 , d 709 poulu\n e)f' u(grh/n, Theog. 440 etc.

*yau/sein: the present yau/ein would mean “we went (i.e. ran) so fast that I was flying.” This is certainly wrong, for the motion of Gods or persons conveyed by Gods is through the air: e.g. of Hera Il. 14.228, Aeneas Il. 20.335, Hermes Od. 5.40, Persephone h. Dem. 383, Iphigenia I. T. 29, Memnon Smyrn. Quint.ii. 569.The meaning required is: “I thought I should go on for ever, without touching ground.” Ruhnken and Matthiae alone accept the future.

kale/esqai: for the form cf. Od. 7.313 (ai)\ ga\r) e)mo\s gambro\s kale/esqai, a passage which renders Guttmann's kline/esqai quite superfluous. The fut. act. kale/w occurs four times in Homer. The fut. pass. keklh/somai is commoner in epic, cf. 148; for kale/esqai cf. Soph. El.971; Kühner-Blass ii. 108 n. 6, Smyth Ionic § 592. 4.
tekei=sqai for te/cesqai is remarkable. Baumeister classes the form as an Attic (second) future.
krater/h ktl.=Od. 10.273.
Cf. Od. 4.64 e)pei\ ou)/ ke kakoi\ toiou/sde te/koien, h. Dem. 213. ke is no doubt right, though te would be possible. For the confusion of the two particles cf. Il. 15.224.
For negative adjectives with three terminations see n. on h. Herm. 447, and for other adjectives n. on h. Apoll. 32. Cf. a)eikeli/h 136, 136^{a}.
o(mo/qen, “of the same stock”; cf. Hes. Op.108, Soph. El.156, I. A. 501, Or.486.

136, 136^{a}. These lines are obviously incompatible, unlike 97, 98 above. On the other hand, they do not seem corruptions, either one from the other, or from a common original. Ruhnken's attempt to construct a single verse out of the two is unsuccessful. Flach (das nachhes. Digamma p. 36 n.) prefers 136^{a} on the ground that a)ll' e)i+kui=a neglects the digamma. D'Orville compares Ovid Heroid. v. 83 non tamen ut Priamus nymphae socer esse recuset,
xruso/n ktl.=Od. 13.136 , p 231.

a)/poina, “price,” is here used apparently for the presents given to the bride as a dowry by her parents. Cf. Il. 9.147, where the presents are called mei/lia (see Leaf ad loc.), Il. 22.51. Matthiae understands a)/poina to bear its common meaning of “reward” (as in 210), translating retributio pro reperta et servata filia; but this seems forced and improbable.
ti/mion apparently refers to a regular marriage, as opposed to illicit intercourse (Baumeister).

A striking instance of the retention by M of an earlier stage of language; cf. h. Apoll. 341. Where e(/khti occurs in Homer the digamma is observed (Od. 15.319 , t 86, u 42) except in <*> 42, where there is a variant t' a)e/khti. In xxvi. 5 the digamma is neglected.

cx/hsei *pri/n: cf. Il. 16.502 ou) ga\r <*>w/ ge *(/ektora . . . sxh/sesqai o)i+/w tri\n . . . bh/menai i(/ppw. Baumeister and Gemoll find a difficulty in the con<*>truction here which, however, seems perfectly logical and intelligible. We might indeed expect the simple inf., as in Il. 17.182 sxh/sw a)mune/menai, but this construction does not occur again in Homer. The Attic mh\ ou) is, of course, later.
e(khbo/los au)to\s *)apo/llwn: cf. n. on h. Herm. 234.
*proi+*=|h is rightly adopted by recent editors; proi+/oi would necessitate the correction of ken to me/n or kai/, neither of which is satisfactory.
Baumeister compares Hero and Leand. 79 au)ti/ka teqnai/hn lexe/wn e)pibh/menos *(hrou=s. We may add Il. 5.685 e)/peita/ me kai\ li/poi ai)w/n and Od. 7.224 i)do/nta me kai\ li/poi ai)w\n

l.quote: kth=sin e)mh/n ktl.

div2.p: kat' o)/mmata kala\ balou=sa= h. Dem. 194.
e)*pi\ qro/nou a)rguro/hlou=Od. 7.162 etc.
*n/hdumon: see on h. Herm. 241.

klisi/|h: sc. in the hut; cf. 76. Stephanus printed pa/r for a)/ra, and this was long believed to be a manuscript reading. For the locative see on h. Dem. 99. The passage in the MSS. is very abrupt; if correct, there is a rhetorical asyndeton, with a sort of climax. The harshness is removed by Ruhnken's eu)poih/tou de/, but there is no motive for such a corruption. A crasis keu)poih/toio is a much simpler solution of the difficulty; k might easily drop out after h, owing to similarity of minuscules. For exx. of crasis in the hymns see n. on h. Dem. 13. mela/qrou ku=re ka/rh recurs in h. Dem. 188. The substitutes for ku=re in all the MSS. except M are a typical case of the transformation of the minuscule k.

e<*>u+stefa/nou is probably correct. The epithet occurs in this hymn at 6 and 288 without variant. It is Homeric; cf. Od. 8.267 e)u+stefa/nou t' *)afrodi/ths. i)oste/fanos appears first in vi. 18 (with the variant in p), Solon fr. 19. 4, Theognis 250 etc. In Solon fr. 52 the two words are again variants.

Hermann omits to/, La Roche me, to avoid the correption of pr. Franke however compares se pro/s 131, 187. For Homeric exx. see H. G. § 370, La Roche Hom. Unters. i. p. 9. On the other hand cf. ta\ prw=ta in 185.
e(mmape/ws u(*pa/kousen=Od. 14.485.
The passage was apparently suggested by Il. 3.396 kai/ r() w(s ou)=n e)no/hse qea=s perikalle/a deirh\n
div2.l: sth/qea/ q' i(mero/enta kai\ o)/mmata marmai/ronta, where Helen recognises Aphrodite through her disguise as an old woman.

div2.p: Cf. Od. 16.179 tarbh/sas d' e(te/rwse ba/l' o)/mmata, mh\ qeo\s ei)/h.

a)men*hno/n: the idea that union with a goddess would deprive a man of his vigour is perhaps, as Gemoll suggests, borrowed from the story of Circe, Od. 10.301 mh/ s' a)pogumnwqe/nta kako\n kai\ a)nh/nora qei/h| and ib. 340 f. There, however, Circe is a sorceress, not an ordinary goddess. In Homer, the lovers of goddesses have to fear the jealousy of the gods, not danger from the goddesses themselves. Calypso, who is not married to a god, does no harm to Odysseus. But Artemis and Zeus slay Orion and Iasion the lovers of Eos and Demeter (Od. 5.121 f.). Tithonus, too, is the victim of divine jealousy. In folklore the same notion appears in the jealousy with which the fairies regard one of their own number who has loved a mortal.

In these cases the underlying idea is that union with a mortal is disgraceful for a goddess, as the superior being. But the explanation of a fqo/nos qew=n does not apply to many instances of the wide-spread belief that these mixed unions are disastrous. Probably the superstition often springs from a vague fear of the supernatural, like the belief “that no man may see God and live.” In northern Europe the love of a nymph or giantess was thought to bring death or misfortune to a mortal (EltonPowell Saxo p. lxiv); the natives of New Caledonia think that intercourse with a supernatural being is deadly (see Lang in Kirk's Secret Commonwealth p. xxxi and other exx. in his trans. of the hymns p. 42). Istar's lovers come to an unhappy end; Gilgamesh therefore rejects her overtures (Jastrow Religion of Babylonia p. 482, Sayce Religion of Anc. Egypt and Bab. p. 434). According to Frazer G. B. iii. p. 162 f. the story of Gilgamesh points to the union of a divine pair, of which the male died every year. But this explanation is inapplicable to many examples of the superstition.

In the present passage the writer adopts the Homeric view of the fqo/nos qew=n, as is plain from 288. But he may also have a confused idea of the essential danger in such a union, as he makes Aphrodite promise that neither she nor any of the gods will hurt Anchises (194 f.).

bioqa/lmios: only here. The editors compare Pind. Ol.vii. 20zwqa/lmios, where there is a reading zwofqa/lmios similar to the curious variant biofqa/lmios here. The mistake is a case of the effect of a more familiar word, as in a)riqmw= for a)rqmw=| h. Herm. 524.
193=Od. 4.825 (pa/gxu for s*=|hsi).
de/os always makes position in Homer (dve/os), Ebeling s.v. H. G. § 394.
196-7 from Il. 20.307 - 8 nu=n de\ dh\ *ai)nei/ao bi/h *trw/essin a)na/cei,
div2.l: kai\ pai/dwn pai=des, toi/ ken meto/pisqe ge/nwntai. For the tradition that the kingdom of the Troad passed, after the destruction of Troy, to Aeneas and his descendants cf. Leaf on Il. 13.460, Pauly-Wissowa 2752, Farnell p. 638, who points out that the character of Aeneas, and the prophecy about him, imply that Homer knew of the tradition. Strabo (607, 608) states, on the authority of Demetrius of Scepsis, that the descendants of Aeneas survived in that town for many generations, and were called kings (e)/xonte/s tinas tima/s, probably priestly functions). See also Hellanicus fr. 127, Menecrates F. H. G. ii. p. 343, Acusilaus fr. 26, Conon in Phot. Bibl.139a 16.

div2.p: e)kgega/ontai: if this word is sound, it must be a fut. perf., as Buttmann (G. G. ii. p. 137) supposed. For this Anth. Pal. xv. 40. 20 e)kgega/anto only is quoted. Kühner-Blass ii. p. 391 reject the form. Baumeister's ingenious alteration e)kgega/ontes (Aeolic perf. part.) is accepted by Suhle (p. 8) and Abel. For the dat. pai/dessi with e)kgi/gnomai see exx. in L. and S. s.v. 2.

ai)*no/n: the significance of a name is Homeric; cf. the well-known instance of *)odusseu/s explained by o)du/ssomai, a 62, t 407-9. The connexion of *)axilleu/s with a)/xos (*)ili/ou or laou=) is not in Homer, but is given by the schol. on Il. 1.1. For heroic etymologies in tragedy see the comm. on I. T. 32, and cf. Aristophanes' excellent parody (fr. 357) *qo/as bradu/tatos w)\n e)n a)nqrw/pois dramei=n.

Cf. Il. 18.85 h)/mati tw=| o(/te se brotou= a)ne/ros e)/mbalon eu)nh=|. The conjunctival use of e(/neka, “because,” has been suspected, but it occurs, in this sense, in Apoll. Arg. 4.1521 and in Bionxii.(ii.) 7, where Ahrens violently alters e(/nex' oi( to o(/ka oi(. Callimachus seems to have used e(/neka in this way; cf. fr. 187 (quoted by Baumeister, who remarks that he was no doubt following more ancient authority, such as this passage). It=o(/ti in Pind. Isthm.viii. 33. Dys. Apollon. and Thrax Dionys. (quoted in Ebeling) call it a su/ndesmos ai)tiologiko/s. It may therefore stand, and the repetition (ou<*>/neka in 198), if offensive, is not worse than numfa/wn—numfw=n 97, 98. The conjectures are unacceptable; Gemoll's o(/te te (cf. Il. 18.85 quoted above) is the best.
ai)ei/: Hermann followed by most editors would correct this to ai)e/n before a short vowel. See Ebeling s.v.
The legend is borrowed from Il. 20.234 f. to\n kai\ a)nhrei/yanto qeoi\ *dii\ oi)noxoeu/ein
div2.l: ka/lleos ei(/neka oi(=o, i(/n' a)qana/toisi metei/h. Cf. also Il. 5.265 f. Here Zeus, instead of the gods, carries off Gauymede, apparently in a whirlwind (cf. 208), like the daughters of Pandareus, Od. 20.66. The eagle is a later invention; see PrellerRobert ii. p. 499 f. The variants e)pioinoxoeu/ein—tetime/non—a)fu/ssein in M (the second confirmed by the conflation os tetime/nonos =tetime/non in x) are remarkable for consistency. The construction is not impossible, and Ruhnken accepted it, but the change from opt. with i(/na to infin. is very violent, and a copula requires insertion in 206. The infin. may, as Baumeister says, be due to Il. 23.234 oi)noxoeu/ein.

div2.p: e)*pioinoxoeu/oi: the prep. e<*>pi/ is explained by Baumeister as e)pi\ th=| *(/hbh|, which is very forced. Gemoll compares e)pibouko/los, where, however, e)pi/ implies “mastery over.” It is more reasonable to connect the prep. with qeoi=s, in the sense of “going from one to another.” Cf. Od. 1.143 kh=ruc d' au)toi=sin qa/m' e)pw/|xeto oi)noxoeu/wn.
a)rsi/podas=the Homeric a)ersi/podas. For the gifts of the horses to Tros see Il. 5.265 f.
w(s e)/oi: this use of w(s with opt. in oratio obliqua is not Homeric, except in Od. 24.237 ei)pei=n w(s e)/lqoi.

a)*g/hrws: so a)gh/rwn h. Dem. 243, but in h. Dem. 260 the MSS. give a)gh/raon. Aristarchus and Aristophanes only admitted the uncontracted form. The word is only found with a)qa/natos in Homer. Cf. Il. 8.539 . i<*>sa qeoi=sin: the authority of My, which is stronger than that of xp, supports this (=Od. 11.303), and the sense is livelier than with the epic commonplace h)/mata pa/nta, which is probably due to 209. Fick, however, prefers h)/mata pa/nta in order to preserve a)gh/raos.
Compare the rape of Cleitus, Od. 15.250 a)ll' h)= toi *klei=ton xruso/qronos h(/rpasen *)hw\s
div2.l: ka/lleos ei(/neka oi(=o, i(/n' a)qana/toisi metei/h. Tithonus was son of Laomedon, and brother of Priam, Il. 20.237. This legend of the eternal old age of Tithonus does not occur in Homer. In Il. 11.1 , e 1 Tithonus is still the consort of Eos. The story is usually supposed to allegorise the change from the fresh morning to the wearisome heat of noonday (see Preller-Robert ii. p. 442). But see note on 188.

div2.p: *nh*pi/h, ou)d) e)*no/hse: for the formula cf. Il. 20.264 , *x 445. So Il. 2.38 nh/pios, ou)de\ ta\ h)/|dh, Hes. Op.40nh/pioi, ou)d' i)/sasin.

*cu=sai/ t' a)*po\ *g=hras: cf. Il. 9.446 gh=ras a)pocu/sas. “The metaphor is no doubt that of smoothing away the wrinkles,” Leaf ad loc. Compare also *no/stoi fr. 6. 2 gh=ras a)pocu/sas). For the form o)loio/n see Solmsen Untersuchungen p. 114.

The beauty of Tithonus was proverbial: Tyrt. fr. 9. 5 ou)d' ei) *tiqwnoi=o fuh\n xarie/steros ei)/h. ei(/ws: in Homer h(=os is restored, no doubt rightly, but the later form may stand in the hymn, although the earliest instance of ei(/ws appears to be in a Thasian inscr. (end of fifth century B.C.); see Herwerden Lex. Graec. Supplet. s.v.

eu)*hgene/os: the presence of the h is difficult to explain; it may be due to false analogy with such words as eu)h/nwr, where h is quite regular. Cf. Il. 11.427 and Il. 23.81 (where it has been corrupted in several MSS. into the common form eu)genh/s, as in this passage also). Aristoph. and Rhianus on Il. 23.81 read eu)hfene/wn which is now confirmed by inscriptions (Schulze Q. E. p. 34, Herwerden Lex. s.v. a)/fenos). But eu)hfenh/s, “wealthy,” is impossible here. For eu)genh/s in this connexion Ilgen compares Eur. Ion242eu)genh= parhi_/da, Eur. Hel.135eu)genh= de/rhn. The assonance with genei/ou is no doubt accidental.
kata\ *gh=ras e)/peigen=Il. 23.623 (e)pei/gei). Cf. Mimnerm. fr. 4 *tiqwnw| me\n e)/dwken e)/xein kako\n a)/fqiton o( *zeu\s
div2.l: gh=ras, o(\ kai\ qana/tou r(i/gion a)rgale/ou.
div2.p: 234=Od. 8.298 (h)=n for du/nat)) from the Lay of Demodocus.

The common line h(/de de/ oi( (moi) ktl. is followed by an inf. in Il. 2.5 , *k 17, *c 161, Hes. fr. 110 (21). 1. In Od. 9.424 , l 230 a main verb follows, as here, with asyndeton (in Od. 9.318 for ga/r Platt reads g' a)/r).
237-8. Cf. Od. 11.393-4; Il. 11.669 , f 283. ki=kus: only here and in Od. 11.393, Aesch. fr. 230.

r(ei=: the hiatus is very awkward (cf. Eberhard Metr. Beob. ii. p. 9); r(e/ei (Wolf and others) would avoid the difficulty. The editors have raised objections to the verb, and Hermann (followed by Abel) would read trei= a)/speton, comparing Il. 17.332. But r(ei= a)/spetos is no doubt correct, being borrowed from Il. 18.403 r(e/en a)/spetos (of Ocean). Gemoll points out the debt of the writer to *s; cf. on 86, 87. The meaning of r(ei=, however, is disputed. In Il. 1.249 r(e/en au)dh/ is used of a “flow of speech”; cf. Theog. 39 a)ka/matos r(e/ei au)dh\
div2.l: e)k stoma/twn h(dei=a, and ibid. 84 tou= d' e)/pe) e)k sto/matos r(ei= mei/lixa. The sense seems therefore to be “his voice flows on ceaselessly” (like that of a garrulous old man). Ernesti's vox fluit immensa and Ilgen's vox fluit tam demissa ut aegre eam sequi et quid dicatur percipere possis are not satisfactory explanations.

div2.p: *g=hras o(moi/ion=Il. 4.315, where see Leaf's note. o(moi/ios is an epithet of gh=ras, nei=kos, po/lemos and qa/natos, but the meaning is very doubtful, as the usual translation “common to all” has no parallel in any use of o(moi=os. It is probable that the two words were distinct in origin. Christ connects o(moi/ios with w)mo/s: Skt. amIva, Lat. aerumna, for o)mi/vios, i.e. “cruel.”
*nhleie/s: the form first in Theog. 770. Schulze Q. E. p. 290. e)/peita is explained by ta/xa (244), i.e. soon in the future.
kamathro/n does not occur in early epic; Apoll. Arg. 2.87.

248=Il. 16.499 e)/ssomai h)/mata pa/nta diampere/s (kathfei/h kai\ o)/neidos). Kämmerer's transposition ei(/neka sei=o diampere\s h)/mata pa/nta is therefore quite needless, although he rightly notes that h)/mata pa/nta is regularly found at the end of the verse.

sto/ma xei/setai (Martin) for stonaxh/setai is still the best correction, and has lately been supported by Tyrrell (l.c. p. 33). It is true that xanda/nein is chiefly used materially: Od. 18.17 ou)do\s d' a)mfote/rous o(/de xei/setai, Anth. Pal. vii. 4. 3 to/son xa/den a)ne/ra nh=sos. But the present passage is very similar to Il. 11.462 o(/son kefalh\ xa/de fwto/s. Of the other conjectures the only one which deserves a bare mention is Buttmann's a)xh/setai (approved by Suhle p. 14), which would be a future of a)xe/ein h. Dem. 478, h. Pan 18. But the construction with infin. following seems impossible.

o)*notasto/n: o)nomasto/n has been hitherto received by the editors, and is a natural conjecture, but the sense in Homer and Hesiod is always “what cannot be named,” i.e. countless. The meaning “unmentionable,” i.e. horrible, does not occur till Apoll. Arg. 3.801. Clarke's suggestion o)notasto/n is undoubtedly what the scribe intended by o)no/taton. o)nota/zw occurs h. Herm. 30 and Hes. Op.258; o)notasto/n corresponds to o)nosta/ *i 164 and many phrases with o)/nomai in Homer; sc. “dreadful,” “not to be made light of”; she has fallen from her proud estate (247-251). J. H. S. xviii. p. 27.

For the resumptive min after to\n me/n Baumeister compares Od. 16.78 f. o)reskw=|oi: applied to the centaurs, Il. 1.268; to goats Od. 9.155; and twice in the hymns to animals, h. Herm. 42, h. Pan 43. The last part of the compound appears to be related to koi=tos (kei=mai), i.e. “sleeping on the mountains”; see Prellwitz Et. Wört. But Döderlein, comparing kw=n: to\ koi=lon, to\ baqu/ (E. M.), and kw=s: ei(rkth/, desmwth/rion (Hesych.), connects the word with koi=los “dwelling in mountain-caves.”

baqu/kolpoi, “full-breasted”; the ko/lpos in Homer is always the breast, not the fold of the robe. The word is applied only to Trojan women in the Iliad (Il. 18.122 , 339, *w 215), but this is no doubt accidental; we are not to suppose that it refers to a form of dress confined to barbarians (see Leaf on Il. 18.122). Mannhardt (A. W. F. p. 7) sees an allusion to luxuriant vegetation, comparing the full breasts of German and Scandinavian tree-nymphs. But the epithet has no such special significance; in h. Dem. 5 the Ocean nymphs are baqu/kolpoi.

*naieta/ousin o)/ros: it is difficult to distinguish between the mountainnymphs (o)reia/des) and the tree-nymphs (drua/des). In their origin, no doubt, the Oreads were tree-spirits, like the Dryads; in a mountainous and wooded country like Greece the largest class of tree-spirits would naturally be that of mountain-nymphs. These, however, often lost their original connexion with the tree, and had their homes in mountain-caves (a)ntria/des); cf. 263. In Il. 6.420 the Oreads (nu/mfai o)restia/des) plant trees on a grave.
o)/ros . . . te= Theog. 2.
e(/pontai: numerantur in (Hermann).
dhro\n me\n *zw/ousi: for the long life of the nymphs (who are not, however, immortal) cf. Hes. fr. 171 Rzach ap. de def. orac. 11 (of a Naiad) e)nne/a toi zw/ei genea\s lake/ruza korw/nh

l.quote: a)ndrw=n h(bw/ntwn: e)/lafos de/ te tetrako/rwnos:
trei=s d' e)la/fous o( ko/rac ghra/sketai: au)ta\r o( foi=nic
e)nne/a tou\s ko/rakas: de/ka d' h(mei=s tou\s foi/nikas

div2.l:
nu/mfai eu)plo/kamoi, kou=rai *di/os ai)gio/xoio (the foi=nic is, of course, the bird, not the plam, as Preller understands; cf. foi/nikos e)/th biou=n HH Herm.53), Paus.x. 31. 3ta\s nu/mfas de\ ei)=nai polu
 me/n tina a)riqmo
 biou/sas e)tw=n, ou) me/ntoi para/pan ge a)phllagme/nas qana/tou poihtw=n e)sti
 e)s au)ta\s lo/gos, Apoll. Arg. 2.481
druo\s h(/likos, h(=| e)/pi poulu

ai)w=na tri/beske dihneke/s, Dionys. xiv. 209 mhkedano
 zw/eskon e)pi\ xro/non (*)oreia/des).

div2.p: kalo/n: see on 29. e)rrw/santo: only here with an accus. (cogn.). Cf. Il. 24.616 numfa/wn ai(/ t' a)mf' *)axelw/i+on e)row/- santo, Theog. 8 e)perrw/santo de\ possi/n (in the dance).

*seilh*noi/: not Homeric, either in sing. or plur. The cognate *sa/turoi occur first in Hes. fr. 198 (44), where they are related to the mountainnymphs. The sileni frequently appear as lovers of nymphs on vases; also on coins of Thasos (Head Hist. Num. p. 227). For Hermes and the nymphs cf. xix. 34 (lover of Dryope), and often. Preller-Robert i. p. 399 f., ii. p. 720.
eu)/skopos: for the trisyllabic form cf. h. Apoll. 36 *)/imbros t' eu)ktime/nh. Hermann omitted te, to conform to Homeric usage.

This passage is the first in which there is a definite mention of the idea that the life of the tree-nymphs (dru/ades, a(dru/ades, a(madru/ades) is bound up with the trees. The belief appears not uncommonly in poetry after Pindar. Cf. Pind. fr. 146 i)sode/ndrou te/kmar, ai)w=nos laxoi=sai (ap.    amat.14; de defect. orac. 11), schol. Apoll. Arg. 2.478, Callim. h. Del. 83 f. 
h)= r(' e)teo\n e/ge/nonto to/te dru/es h(ni/ka nu/mfai;

nu/mfai me\n xai/rousin, o(/te dru/as o)/mbros a)e/cei

nu/mfai d' au)= klai/ousin, o(/te drusi\n ou)ke/ti fu/lla, Apoll. Arg. 2.481 mh\ tame/ein pre/mnon dru/os h(/likos,  Dionys. ii. 92 f. *(adrua/des de\
div2.l: h(/likes w)du/rontolipo/skia de/ndrea nu/mfai, ib. xiv. 212 sumfue/es *meli/ai druo\s h(/likos, ib. xvi. 245 kai\ druo\s e)/ntos i(/kanen o(mh/likos (*meli/h), ib. xlviii. 641, Ov. Met.viii. 738-878. Similarly the life of the tree-spirits who, under various names (Moosleute, Elfen, etc.) occur in Czech and German folklore, depends on the life of the tree: Mannhardt A. W. F. p. 4 f., B. K. p. 75; Botticher Baumkultus and Frazer G. B. i. p. 166 give instances.
div2.p: The fir and oak are, of course, only representatives of trees in general. The Dryad stands for any tree-nymph, although the name must go back to the very early time when especial reverence was paid to the oak. Cf. Paus.x. 32. 6e)fu/onto (nu/mfai) a)po/ te a)/llwn de/ndrwn kai\ ma/lista a)po\ tw=n druw=n.

267, 268. These verses have been suspected, partly on the ground of the asyndeton. Gemoll avoids it by reading unmetrically kalai\ thleqa/ousai e)n d). It would, of course, be easy to correct this to e)n ou)/resi d' u(yhloi=sin e(sta=s). But the asyndeton of e(sta=s) is excused by the opening of the parenthesis. e( has also been a cause of offence; it is unique as a plural; but cf. e(a=s of a plural subject Pind. Pyth.iv. 187, which seems to justify the use. It is, of course, possible that the writer has blindly copied such passages as Od. 4.355 *fa/ron de/ e( kiklh/skousi; so Dyrott Geschichte des Pron. reflex. 1892, p. 69 f. See also Brugmann ein Problem der hom. Textkritik p. 22, 23.

*)hli/batoi: in Homer this obscure word is found only in connexion with pe/trh, and is taken to mean “abrupt,” “precipitous.” So in h. Herm. 404, h. Pan 10. In Od. 9.243 and Theog. 675 it is an epithet of pe/trh in the sense of a moveable “stone,” not a “cliff.” There is a further extension of the meaning in Theog. 483 a)/ntrw| e)n h)liba/tw| a “deep” cave; and in Scut. 421 Rzach reads with one MS. w(s o(/te tis dru=s h)/ripen h)\ o(/te peu/kh
div2.l: h)li/batos (the vulg. has pe/trh for peu/kh). Cf. also the epigram in Plutarch v. T. Q. Flamin. c. 9 *)alkai/w| stauro\s ph/gnutai h)li/batos, Euseb. P. E. ix. 14 (Abydenus) tu/rsin h)li/baton, and see L. and S. s.v. We need not therefore suspect the use of the word, here applied to trees. Schäfer conjectures h)liba/tois, with ou)/resi. teme/n*h: although, according to a wellknown superstition, every tree has some kind of mysterious life or “soul,” a peculiar sanctity attaches to certain trees, as being intimately connected with a god (at Dodona, Aricia, etc.), or as here, with a nymph. It was only such trees that might not be felled. Mannhardt (A. W. F. p. 33) compares the te/menos with the Homeric a)/lsos cf. Od. 10.350 gi/gnontai d' a)/ra tai/ g' e)/k te krhne/wn a)po/ t' a)lse/wn, where, however, the a)/lsea seem to be woods in general; so Il. 20.8 -9 numfa/wn ai(/ t' a)/lsea kala\ ne/montai
kai\ phga\s potamw=n kai\ pi/sea poih/enta.
div2.p: a)eana/twn: not, of course, the nymphs themselves, who are not immortal, but the gods to whom the sacred groves belong. Compare the tree-nymphs in the grove of Demeter (Callim. h. Dem.), and of Ceres ( Ov. Met.viii. 738 f.).
The MSS. reading de/x) is a curious corruption for de/ q); cf. h. Dem. 490.

There appears to be a double recension, as 274-75 are scarcely consonant with 276-77. We can hardly accept Ilgen's explanation, that the nymphs first shewed the boy to his father, and afterwards Aphrodite brought the child herself. This view is contradicted by the following lines, in which Anchises is to take Aeneas to Ilium as soon as he sees him for the first time (278, 280). Moreover, as Franke notes, poluh/ratos h(/bh cannot be applied to a young child; nor can the nymphs be called qeai/. Gemoll emends h(/bh to w(/rh, understanding the line to refer to the birth of the child.

e)s *pe/mpton e)/tos: Roscher (die Enneadischen Fristen p. 75) compares Herod.i. 136paideu/ousi de\ tou\s pai=das (sc. oi( *pe/rsai) a)po\ pentae/teos a)rca/menoi . . . pri\n de\ h)\ pentae/ths ge/nhtai, ou)k a)pikne/etai e)s o)/yin tw=| patri/, a)lla\ para\ th=|si gunaici\ di/aitan e)/xei.

*nin (M's nu=n is an itacism) is the only example of the Doric acc. in Homer or the hymns; the earliest case of its use is Theognis 364. Hermann's alteration to min is easy (Il. 18.64 the papyr. Brit. Mus. 107 has nin), but the peculiarity, like that of e( 267, is possible; Smyth Ionic p. 445 Kühner-Blass i. p. 592.
fasi/n: the editors have accepted Matthiae's fa/sqai, from the similar passage Od. 9.502 *ku/klwy, ai)/ ke/n ti/s se kataqnhtw=n a)nqrw/pwn
div2.l: o)fqalmou= ei)/rhtai a)eikeli/hn a)lawtu/n,

fa/sqai ktl. But fa/sqai is neither an easy nor a necessary correction here. The construction requires no imperative, as we have muqei=sqai 283. The child is to be brought up by the nymphs and handed over to Anchises, who is instructed to explain “they say he is the son of a nymph.” He does not deny paternity, but allows it to be inferred without express statement. For nymphs as mothers of a race see Agroetas a/ *libukw=n F. H. G. iv. 294.
div2.p: kalukw/pidos: see h. Dem. 8.
o)/ros ktl.=Od. 13.351.

According to Matthiae, the line refers to a tradition that Anchises was actually struck by a thunderbolt for boasting of Aphrodite's love. But the tradition (which first occurs in Hyginus) may very well be later than this hymn, and probably arose from this line. In Hyg. fab.94Anchises is slain by thunderbolts; according to Servius he was paralysed or blinded ( Serv. on Aen.i. 617 Aen., ii. 649).
Cf. Od. 11.251 i)/sxeo mhd' o)nomh/nh|s and Od. 5.146 *dio\s d' e)popi/zeo mh=nin.
*)hnemo/enta: only here an epithet of the sky. In Homer it is applied to lofty places or to trees growing on heights. Abel's a)stero/enta is, however, quite gratuitous.

div1.head: HYMN TO APHRODITE
div1.p: THIS slight hymn was composed for a contest (19, 20), but there are no distinctive marks either of date or locality. Baumeister's theory of a Cyprian origin is as likely as any other, but cannot be proved from line 2, h(\ pa/shs *ku/prou krh/demna le/logxen (see h. Aphr. Introd. p. 198). The mention of the Cyprian Aphrodite is purely literary, and the title would be familiar to any Greek audience. The rhapsodist was certainly acquainted with Hesiod (see on 1, 3, 5, 12, 19), and no doubt also with the Cypria, where there occurs a similar description of the adornment of the goddess (see on 5). Indeed it would have been remarkable if the author of a hymn to Aphrodite had not been influenced by an epic in which she played so large a part. On the other hand, as Gemoll notes, there is no clear trace of any debt to the longer hymn to Aphrodite. The writer also obviously borrows from *c (see on 8, 14) and other parts of Homer, so that Baumeister is hardly too severe in speaking of him as rhapsodus inops ingenii. No great originality was looked for in a short and formal prelude.

div2.p: ai)doi/h*n ktl.: Gemoll compares Theog. 193 f. e)/nqen e)/peita peri/rruton i(/keto *ku/pron,
div2.l: e)k d' e)/bh ai)doi/h kalh\ qeo/s, and Theog. 17 for the collocation xrusoste/fanon kalh/n. The epithet ai)doi/h “reverend” is the keynote of the hymn, and is suitable to a goddess whose cult, as Farnell observes (Cults ii. p. 668) is on the whole pure and austere; see also h. Aphr. Introd. p. 196.

div2.p: kr/hdemna: the early epic usage of this word, in the sense of “battlements,” requires a genitive of the city (*troi/hs, *qh/bhs, po/lhos; see on h. Dem. 151). The genitive of the country *ku/prou is a later extension; it is uncertain whether the meaning is here “walled cities” or simply “high places,” “mountains.”

le/logxen: a variation for e)/xei, nai/ei etc.; cf. Orphica p. 289 (Abel) kai/ t' e)/laxes deina\s me\n o(dou/s etc., Orph. Arg. 2; Adami (p. 242) quotes many examples from hymnal literature of such relative clauses giving the place connected with the god; so xxii. 3 etc.

The goddess was carried in the foam from Cythera to Cyprus, i.e. by the west wind; cf. Theog. 190 f. For other references to Aphrodite *)afrogenh/s see Farnell p. 748. The Hesiodean etymology was accepted by Plato Crat. 406C, Anacr.54. 13, Apul. Met.iv. 28, Nicand. Alex. 406, Bionx. (xvi.) 1, Mosch.i. 71, Choerob. ap. Cramer An.ii. 170, Orph. h. i. 11. For other ancient and modern derivations of the name see Pauly-Wissowa 2773 f.

The connexion of Aphrodite with the Horae is similar to that of the Charites, with whom she is more often mentioned (see on h. Aphr. 61); cf. h. Apoll. 194, Pax456*(ermh=|, *xa/risin, *(/wraisin, *)afrodi/th|, *po/qw|. For other references see Roscher Lex. i. 2719, Preller-Robert i. p. 477 f. In functions the Charites and Horae are almost identical (Harrison M. M. A. A. p. 383). Compare the adornment of Pandora, by the Charites with golden chains, by the Horae with flowers, Hes. Op.73 f., and Cypria fr. 2 ei(/mata me\n xroi+\ e(/sto, ta/ oi( *xa/rite/s te kai\ *(=wrai
div2.l: poi/hsan kai\ e)/bayan e)n a)/nqesin ei)arinoi=sin,
oi(=a fe/rous' *(=wrai ktl., and fr. 3. For the number of the Horae see on 12.

div2.p: e)*n de\ trhtoi=si loboi=sin: cf. Il. 14.182.

a)/nqem): not in Homer, who, however, has the adjective a)nqemo/eis of decoration Il. 23.885 , g 440, w 275. The schol. T on Il. 23.885 derives this from a)/nqema, quoting Pind. Ol.ii. 72(xrusou=): the word first occurs in Pindar.

o)reixa/lkou: first in Scut. 122, where see Sittl's note. The metal (whether pure copper, or a compound) cannot be identified: it was a mere name to Plato (Critias 114 E) and Aristotle (schol. on Apoll. Arg. 4.973). Strabo (610) calls it yeuda/rguron, i.e. an alloy of silver and copper. Suidas explains by o( diaugh\s xalko/s, o( do/kimos. Pliny (H. N. xxxiv. 2) calls it a natural metal no longer to be found, iam tempore effeta tellure. The metal intended by Cic. Off.iii. 23 and other Latin writers is unknown; see Conington on Verg. Aen.xii. 87.The Latin aurichalcum is no doubt due to false etymology.
a)rgufe/oisin: not applied to the body by Homer; the editors compare Apoll. Arg. 4.1406 xei=ras a)rgufe/as.

kosmei/sqh*n: the dual is given in all MSS., and alteration is uncalled for. According to one tradition there were only two Horae (so on the throne of the Amyclean Apollo, Paus.iii. 18. 10, and at Athens, Paus.ix. 35. 2, although Pausanias may be mistaken in the latter case; see Robert de Gratiis Atticis, Preller-Robert i. p. 478 n. 4). For two Horae in art see Roscher Lex. i. 2723 f., 2726 f. (Rapp). Two seasons were in all probability the original number, corresponding to the old division of the year into Summer and Winter; cf. the Egyptian statues of those seasons mentioned by Herod.ii. 121.The dual may therefore keep its proper force; the following plural i)/oien is a natural irregularity. Baumeister, however, defends the dual on the ground that in late epic it was sometimes used as an equivalent of the plural verb (see on h. Apoll. 456). He thinks that the hymn-writer would follow the Hesiodean version of three Horae (Theog. 902). Although this latter supposition is uncertain, Baumeister's explanation of the dual is very probable.

e)s xoro
 <*>mero/enta: cf. Od. 18.194 eu)=t' a)
 i)/h| *xari/twn xoro
 i(mero/enta (of Aphrodite). Cf. the dance of the Muses and Charites xxvii. 15.
e)decio/wnto: so Apoll. Arg. 2.756, Cf. H. G. § 55 c.
*)hr/hsanto: a reminiscence of Od. 1.366 pa/ntes d' h)rh/santo parai\ lexe/essi kliqh=nai, and Od. 8.336-342.
i)ostefa/nou: for this and the variant e)u+stefa/nou see on h. Aphr. 175.

e(likoble/fare: first in Theog. 16 (of Aphrodite). The meaning has been disputed; it is natural to compare e(likw/pida kou/rhn (Il. 1.98), e(li/kwpes *)axaioi/ (ib. 389), but the sense of e(li/kwy is equally uncertain. The translation “with arched eyebrows” would suit e(likoble/faros, but Leaf on Il. 1.98 points out that e(/lic means “twisted,” and is not used of a circular curve. e(li/kwy is probably “rolling the eyes” or “with flashing eyes,” and in e(likoble/faros Leaf is perhaps right in seeing a loose use of ble/faron for o)/mma, as in tragedy. See Meyer Griech. Et. i. s.v.
*glukumei/lixe: only here; cf. x. 2 mei/lixa dw=ra, of Aphrodite.
e)/ntunon a)oid/hn, “lend grace to my song”; in Od. 12.183 the same phrase occurs with different meaning “they prepared (raised) their song).”

div1.head: HYMN TO DIONYSUS

listBibl.head: BIBLIOGRAPHY
listBibl.bibl: A. CHUDZINSKI, ubi et quo tempore ortus sit h. Hom. VII. in Dion., 1886.
A. LUDWICH, Königsberger Studien i. p. 63 f., 1887.
MAASSE. , Hermes xxiii. p. 70 f., 1888.
R. PEPPMÜLLER, Philologus xlvii. p. 20 f., 1888.
O. CRUSIUS, Philologus xlviii. p. 193 f., 1889.
HARRISONE. , Mythology and Monuments of Ancient Athens p. 247 f., 1890.
F. A. VOIGT and THRE. ÄMER, art. “Dionysus” in Roscher's Lex.
PRELLER-ROBERT, i.^{2} p. 684 f.

div1.p: The myth in literature and art.—The story of Dionysus and the pirates, which is the subject of this hymn, was a favourite theme in classical literature. There is an allusion to the myth in Eur. Cycl.11, where the Tyrrhenians are said to be inspired by Hera. Ovid (Met. iii. 582-691) and Nonnus (Dion. xlv. 105-168) describe the adventure of Dionysus at considerable length; and shorter accounts are given by Apollodorus iii. 5. 3, Hyginus fab.134, poet. astron. ii. 17 (after the Naxica of Aglaosthenes), Seneca Oed.449-466, and Nonnus Dion. xliv. 240-249. Servius on Verg. Aen.i. 67 closely follows Hyginus. Oppian (Hal. i. 650) mentions the transformation of men into dolphins by Dionysus. It cannot be proved that any of these versions depend on the Homeric hymn; Ovid and Nonnus handle the legend after their characteristic methods, and certain similarities of expression (noted in the commentary) are probably due to the choice of subject, the broad outlines of which did not admit much variation of treatment.For a full discussion of the various versions see Crusius p. 218 f. Pindar knew the myth, if we accept Bergk's reading of Philodem. peri\ eu)seb. p. 48 *p<i/nda>ros de\ die/rxetai peri\ th=s lh|<stei/>as (P. L. Gr. i. p. 465).

On the other hand, the myth has rarely found a place in art. With regard to extant monuments, the metamorphosis of the pirates (the culminating point of the myth) does not appear in any vase-paintings; for, as Miss Harrison shews (after Gerhard), the celebrated cylix of Execias has no connexion with the Tyrrhenians. On this vase Dionysus is depicted as sitting in a ship, from the mast of which springs a vine loaded with grapes. The vacant space round the ship is filled by seven dolphins. But the vine simply indicates the sacred ship which played a part in the cult of Dionysus, while the dolphins are a conventional indication of the sea, as often on coins.See Harrison op. cit. p. 252; the vase is reproduced on p. 251, and by Lang p. 213; first in Gerhard A. V. pl. xlix. The god of wine, whose cult spread over all the Aegean and its coasts, was early associated with the sea,On Dionysus pela/gios see PrellerRobert i.^{2} p. 678; Maass Hermes xxiii. p. 70 f.; Roscher 1084; Crusius p. 215; Frazer on Paus.ix. 20. 4. and it was his journey from isle to isle that doubtless suggested the possibility of his capture, and the consequent manifestation of his might by sea as well as on land. The dolphins, which Greek sailors often saw sporting round their vessels (see h. Apoll. 496), would readily suggest a metamorphosis of actual sailors who had offended the god.For other explanations of the myth see Voigt in Roscher's Lex., and Crusius (p. 217), who thinks that it refers to the victory of Dionysus over fish-like seagods, with an accretion of historical elements united at Brauron.

In painting, there is a record by Philostratus (Imag. i. 19) of a picture in which a Tyrrhenian ship is attacking the sacred vessel of Dionysus and his Maenads. The metamorphosis has begun, and the god's ship is covered with ivy and vines. The introduction of a naval battle is evidently a later invention, when the myth was accommodated to other stories of Dionysus' prowess in war; cf. Lucian dial. mar. 8 (Crusius p. 223).

It appears, therefore, that the well-known choregic monument of Lysicrates (B.C. 334) is the sole extant work of art illustrating the myth. A detailed description of the frieze is unnecessary; it may be sufficient to point out that artistic requirements have considerably modified the myth. The scene is laid, not in a ship, but on the sea-shore; there is thus no place for the pilot or for the vines and ivy. Dionysus sits at ease on a rock playing with a panther, while the Tyrrhenians are punished by a band of Satyrs. Some of the pirates are being beaten with the thyrsus, others are leaping into the sea, half transformed into dolphins.The frieze has been frequently reproduced, e.g. Müller- Wieseler Denkmäler i. pl. 37; Harrison p. 248; Mitchell Anc. Sculpt. p. 487; cast in British Museum.

Style of the hymn.—Groddeck and Baumeister, followed by Abel, trace the influence of dithyrambic poetry in the theme and treatment of the hymn; but the debt, if any, is not easily estimated. The formula a)mfi/ tina a)ei/dein is not confined to the dithyramb (see on 1), and the harsh transitions, in which Baumeister sees a mark of dithyrambic haste (44, 54), are due rather to unpolished workmanship. For, although the hymn is a valuable and interesting document, it is hard to dissent from Gemoll's judgment that its artistic merits have been generally overrated. Gemoll remarks on the carelessness of the writer in using the particle de/ seven times in 4-10.Crusius, however, notes that this repetition of de/ has many parallels; e.g. it occurs seven times in as many lines, h. Dem. 38-44; add xxxiii. 8-17 (seven times). Nothing is said about the scene of the event; the description of the bear created by Dionysus (46) is at least clumsy, even if it is partly justified as one of the signs by which the god shews his power. It may be added that there is an obvious improbability in the indifference shewn by all the crew, except the steersman, after the god has miraculously freed himself from his bonds (see on h. Dem. 188). Ovid, more careful of artistic propriety, makes the steersman conjecture the divinity of the captive from his general appearance only; Bacchus performs no miracle until it is too late for repentance.

Date of the hymn.—The general uncertainty in dating most of the hymns is strikingly exemplified in the case of the present poem, for the composition of which the critics have suggested various periods down to the third or fourth century A.D. This late date has been advocated by Ludwich, who believes the hymn to be a work of the Orphic school and closely related to the Argonautica, which passed under the name of Orpheus. Ludwich draws attention to the following points of similarity between the two poems: (1) both are characterised by extreme rapidity of diction, and by numerous words expressing haste (e.g. ta/xa—qow=s—ta/xa—ai)=ya, Hom. h. 6-9; ma/l' w)=ka—qoh/— e)peigome/nh, Arg. 268-270. For a full comparison see Ludwich p. 61-67). It may be replied that adverbs, etc., denoting haste or swift transition, are common in epic poetry (e.g. Il. 18.525-532, compared by Crusius), and ta/xa, au)ti/ka, ai)=ya, and the like are especially frequent in hymnic literature; the hymn to Hermes affords many examples (see on h. Herm. 70). (2) Ludwich remarks on a general resemblance in diction between the hymn and the Argonautica (p. 68, 69). None of these parallels, however, are very striking, and all are “Homeric,” and may therefore have been modelled independently on epic originals (see further on 2).

(3) The position of the hymn in the collection—next to the hymn to Ares—is thought to be a sign of Orphic origin. The eighth hymn is undoubtedly late, but not necessarily Orphic (see Introd.); in any case the argument is of little value, as it would apply equally to the ninth hymn, which is certainly not Orphic. The style of the hymn to Dionysus, which is a pure narrative poem, is quite foreign to the religious tone of the hymn to Ares. The latter cannot be adduced as evidence for the date or origin of any other hymn.

If there is no strong argument in support of Ludwich's theory, there is equally little reason to follow Gemoll, who places the hymn (doubtfully) in the Alexandrine period. As evidence of lateness he instances au)to/n (22), the use of o(/de (19, 27), e)rei= (30), e)ka/qhto (14), the dat. plur. in ois (5, 12, 16, 21), the art. in tw=| e)mw=| (55). Some of these usages are perfectly regular, at least in the later parts of the genuine epic (see on 22, 55); and there is nothing in the language which need not belong to a date far higher than that of the Alexandrines. The double title *dio/nusos h)\ lhstai/ (in DELIIT) reminds us of similar alternatives in Theocritus and Herondas; but this title is not given by M, and is probably a later addition. Nor is there any proof that such titles were first adopted by the Alexandrines. In style, the hymn has little in common with the works of Callimachus or the hymnic idylls of Theocritus; its simplicity and directness of expression, which often pass into abruptness, differentiate it from any characteristic product of the Alexandrine age. This will appear from a comparison between the hymn and the idyll of Theocritus, which deals with the fate of Pentheus (xxi); the subject—the might of Dionysus and the punishment of Pentheus—is similar to the theme of the hymn; but the latter is quite free from the affectation of rare or “precious” words (malopa/rhos, e)quma/rei, etc.) that mark the Alexandrine work. The hymn-writer's disregard of all superfluous details is in strong contrast to the fuller and more “literary” compositions from which Ovid drew his inspiration.

The hymn has also been referred to the fifth or fourth century, with no great probability.So Murray (Anc. Gr. Lit. p. 50), who curiously miscalls the hymn a “fragment.” The chief argument for this date, based on the youthful form of Dionysus, is of no value (see on 3). There is, in a word, no reason to separate the hymn from the rest of the collection (the hymn to Ares and possibly one or two others being excepted), or to deny it a place in the literature of the sixth or even the seventh century B.C.

Place of composition.—There is no internal evidence pointing to any special country, and the efforts to localise the hymn have not been fruitful. Several scholars, however (Welcker Ep. Cycl. i. p. 367; Baumeister p. 339; Chudiński p. 9; Christ Handbuch der klass. Alt. vii.^{2} p. 63), have argued for an Attic origin, and this view has been upheld with some confidence by Crusius (p. 204 f.). It is suggested that the hymn served as a prelude at the Brauronian festival of Dionysus, in which rhapsodists recited the Iliad (Hesych. s.v. and Clearch. ap. Athen. vii. 275 B=F. H. G. ii. p. 321). Crusius lays stress on the legend that Tyrsenian pirates carried off Attic women from Brauron ( Herod.vi. 138), and he sees in the sole extant representation—the monument of Lysicrates—a proof that the myth was peculiarly He Attic. suggests that the bear created by Dionysus is Brauronian, as Attic maidens at the festival were called a)/rktoi (but see on 46). The arguments may be plausible, but there is really no more reason to attribute the hymn to the Athenians than to almost any other branch of the Hellenic race. The myth itself may have arisen in Naxos; later accounts, at least (Aglaosthenes, Apollodorus, Ovid), connect it with the island; and it is not impossible that the hymn is also Naxian.Chudiński (p. 9) holds that the hymn, though Athenian, was due to Naxian influence.

div2.p: a)mfi/: the use with a)ei/dein or similar verbs occurs at the beginning of xix, xxii, xxxiii, and in h. Herm. 57. The formula is found in Od. 8.267 (with genitive), and was stereotyped in dithyrambic verse (cf. Terpand. fr. 2) according to the schol. on Nub. 595, Suid. s.v. a)mfianakti/zein; so in tragedy Troad. 511.

e)fa/n*h: such e)pifa/neiai are a marked feature of Dionysiac mythology; cf. Rohde Psyche p. 305. Ludwich traces the hand of an Orphic writer in this “epiphany,” comparing Orph. Arg. 16 prw=tos ga\r e)fa/nqh (of Phanes). But there is nothing mystic in the line; on the contrary the absence of any specific indication of locality is against Ludwich's theory; Crusius notes that such picturesque details are common in the Orphic Argonautica. According to Apollodorus, Dionysus wishes to cross from Icaria to Naxos, and therefore, embarks on a Tyrsenian ship; but the sailors refuse to land him. In Ovid (l.c. 597) Dionysus is found in Ceos (Ciae telluris Lachmann for MSS. Chiae); Nonnus localises the legend in the Sicilian sea. The hymn gives no reason for the god's appearance or for his easy capture; he is mero somnoque gravis (3.603) in Ovid's account.

a)kt*=|h e)*pi\ *probl=hti: cf. Od. 5.405 , k 89, n 97, Apoll. Arg. 2.365. *nehni/|h a)ndri\ e)oikw/s=Od. 10.277, followed by prw=ton u(phnh/th| (of Hermes). It was supposed that the youthful type of Dionysus in art was created in the age of Praxiteles; but it is now known that the type goes back to Calamis ( Curtius A. Z. 1883, p. 255; cf. Roscher 1089 f., 1126 f.), i.e. to the first half of the fifth century. In any case the present passage is no indication of lateness, for, as Bergk notes, the god only assumes the form of a youth for the occasion; the transformation is on Homeric analogy. Moreover it is probable that the young Dionysus was familiar to poetry for many years before the art-type was created (see Sandys, Eur. Bacch.p. xcix f.). The hymnwriter does not conceive of the god as effeminate and voluptuous, but as the ideal of a young Greek athlete with broad shoulders (5) like Telemachus, Od. 15.61; cf. the metamorphosis of Apollo, h. Apoll. 450 a)ne/ri ei)do/menos ai)zhw=| te kraterw=| te
div2.l: prwqh/bh|, xai/th|s ei)lume/nos eu)re/as w)/mous; so Verg. Aen.x. 485pectus ingens of the young Pallas.

div2.p: stibaroi=s w)/mois=Od. 14.528 , o 61, Orph. Arg. 200.
a)*po/ is supported by xxxiii. 8 where oi( d' a)po\ nhw=n=oi( nau=tai, with no idea of motion in the context. Köchly's e)pi/ is not only needless, but involves a repetition of the preposition in 7.

*proge/nonto . . . e)*pi/: Gemoll suggests e)ni/, understanding the verb to mean “hove in sight.” But progi/gnesqai often implies movement, “come forward,” and is followed by e)s or e)pi/; cf. Il. 18.525 oi( de\ ta/xa proge/nonto, “came on,” Scut. 345 toi\ d' a)/mudis proge/nont), of warriors rushing to meet one another, Callim. h. Art. 178 ko/pron e)/pi proge/nointo, Theocr. xxv. 134 progenoi/ato qh=res e)s pedi/on.

*tursh*noi/: first in a suspected passage of Hesiod (Theog. 1016). According to Herod.i. 57 and 94, the Tyrsenians were ancient Pelasgic inhabitants of Thrace; Thucydides (iv. 109) places them in Lemnos and Athens. They had a reputation as corsairs, if we may judge from their rape of women at Brauron; Crusius notes that a similar story was told at Samos (Athen. xv. 672). Most scholars assume that the hymn refers to these obscure Tyrsenians, who are rarely mentioned in ancient literature. It is barely possible that the Etruscans are meant (as Chudiński holds, p. 9); pirates from Etruria were a terror to the early colonists in Italy and Sicily, from the seventh century (probably) down to their defeat by Hieroin 474 B.C. (Mommsen i. ch. x.).
