But, although their name became proverbial for piracy, it is difficult to account for their presence in an early Greek hymn, which appears to have no connexion with the colonies of Sicily or Magna Graecia. It seems therefore better to follow the common explanation. Nonnus (Dion. xv. 104) naturally understands the Tyrsenians to be Etruscans, and Philostratus (Imag. i. 19) speaks of *turrhnoi/, obviously Etruscans; but this proves nothing for the original myth.

ui<*>o\n . . . basil/hwn: he appeared to be a prince from his beauty (cf. h. Dem. 215), and from his purple cloak, which was a mark of high rank. A purple xlai=na was worn by Telemachus, Od. 4.115, and Odysseus, Od. 19.225. In Nonnus the god wears jewellery as well as a cloak of Tyrian purple.
For the miraculous loosing of the bonds cf. Eur. Bacch.447 with Sandys' note, ib. 498Eur. Bacch., 616 f. In Ovid l.c. 700 the miracle happens to the steersman Acoetes, when imprisoned by Pentheus.
e)ka/qhto=the epic form kaqh=sto.

kartero/n: emphatic, explained by the following words ou)de\ fe/rein ktl. Gemoll punctuates with the mark of interrogation at the end of the line; but the sense is clear with the usual punctuation, adopted in the text.
au)to/n: the position is unusual, as there is no emphasis on the pronoun; but it is justified by such passages as Od. 16.370 i(/na fqi/saimen e(lo/ntes
div2.l: au)to/n, where no stress is laid on the pronoun, in spite of its emphatic place, Od. 6.277, 308, 329; so au)to/s is unemphatic at the end of a line, Il. 9.562 , *p 519. Baumeister's au)=tis would eliminate the necessary object of a)fw=men.

div2.p: o)/rs|h a)rgale/ous: an hiatus vix ferendus, according to Baumeister; Abel adopts Barnes' o)/rsh| e)p). But the text is a reminiscence of Od. 24.110 o)/rsas a)rgale/ous a)ne/mous, or Od. 11.400 o)/rsas a)rgale/wn a)ne/mwn a)me/garton a)u+tmh/n. For the hiatus in thesis see H. G. § 380.
a(/ma: not “besides,” but “with me,” as Franke saw: the steersman is to “lend a hand” with the captain, who is the subject of e(/lketo in 32.

a)/ndressi mel/hsei: a formula usually put into the mouth of a man speaking to a woman and contrasting the two sexes: Il. 6.492 , a 358, f 352; in Il. 20.137 the antithesis is between gods and men. Gemoll quotes Od. 11.353 as the nearest parallel to this passage, a)/ndres being in both places, as he thinks, equivalent to pa/ntes. But in l a)/ndressi is followed and explained by pa=si, ma/lista d' e)moi/. Here the implied contrast must be, as usual, a)/ndressi, ou) gunaici/. The taunt of womanish fear explains stugerw=| mu/qw| 25. The translation of a)/ndressi, “crew,” does not suit the context or the regular meaning of the formula.
M's o)e\ kaste/rw is perhaps a survival of o(/ g' e(kaste/rw, o(/ g) having strayed in from the previous line; J. H. S. xv. p. 298.

30, 31. The collocation fi/lous, kth/mata, kasignhtou/s is no less curious than the omission of any reference to the captive's country or parents. Köchly supposes the original passage to have been longer; but the lame expression need not surprise us in a hymn which shews other marks of careless workmanship.
kt/hmata *pa/nta of course implies a large ransom; in Apollodorus the pirates are prepared to sell the god (a)pempolh/sontes).

e)/mp*neusen has been altered on the ground that e)mpnei=n elsewhere takes a dative. But there is a clear case of e)mprh/qein with acc., Il. 1.481 e)n d' a)/nemos prh=sen me/gan i(sti/on, and on this analogy e)mpnei=n can stand with acc. In Pind. Isthm.ii. 40ou)=ros e)mpneu/sais u(pe/steil' i(sti/on the construction is ambiguous; i(sti/on may however be governed by e)mpneu/sais, though most editors supply i(sti/w|, taking the acc. with u(pe/steile alone.
In Ovid (l.c. 660) and Seneca (l.c. 450) a sudden calm falls before the god manifests his power.

katta/nusan: the Homeric equivalent appears in Od. 2.430 dhsa/menoi d' a)/ra o(/pla “having made all fast.” Cf. Apoll. Arg. 2.933
ka\d' d' a)/ra lai=fos e)russa/menoi tanu/onto
e)s po/das a)mfote/rous, and vela deducunt in Ovid's version (663).

*pa/ntas i)do/ntas: elsewhere in the hymn hiatus occurs before i)dei=n (8, 42, 48, 52). For the variation, within a few lines, cf. Od. 21.122 ta/fos d' e(/le pa/ntas i)do/ntas with 112 o)/fra i)/dwmen. On the observance and neglect of v in i)dei=n see H. G. § 390. The less familiar ta/fos is supported by f, and is to be preferred to fo/bos read by Gemoll.

Cf. Ovid (664 f.)
impediunt hederae remos nexuque recurvo
serpunt, et gravidis distinguunt vela corymbis. The details of the transformation vary in the several accounts: in Apollodorus the mast and oars became snakes, and the ship is filled with ivy; in Nonnus the mast is changed into a cypress wreathed with ivy. So in Opp. Ven. iv. 261 f. a boat, which carried the infant Bacchus across the Euripus, was covered with ivy, vines, and smilax.
thleqa/wn: not Homeric as a part. with dative.

*n*=)h *)/hdh: Hermann's correction, if not quite certain, is strongly supported by h. Apoll. 392 h)maqo/hn, corrected by *g, the second hand of M, and Demetrius to nh=a qoh/n. nh=) h)/dh would have been written in full *nh*ah*dh, i.e. nhdhdh, from which mhdhdh is a slight step. It is to be observed that the MSS. except M have been further corrupted. The fact that there is no instance of the collocation h)/dh to/t' e)/peita is not serious; the nearest approach is the formula dh\ to/t' e)/peita, l 44, Apoll. Arg. 4.716, 1629, which always begins a sentence or clause; cf. however Solon fr. 16. 3 ei)/hn dh\ to/t' e)gw/. The other emendations may be disregarded: the older editors, taking pela/an as intrans. (a rarer Homeric use), looked for the steersman's name, i.e. *mhdei/dhn or *mh/dhn dh/. A name *mhdei/dhs would be suitable for an “experienced” steersman; cf. Od. 3.282 *fro/ntin, in the ship of Menelaus. The form could be supported by *megamhdei/dao, h. Herm. 100. But the name should have been mentioned before (i.e. at 15), if at all; in Ovid and Hyginus the helmsman is called Acoetes, but no other name is given in the accounts. An adj. agreeing with kubernh/thn (cf. 49) might be thought in place, i.e. from mh=dos; but none exists.

le/wn *ge/net): a common transformation of Dionysus; Eur. Bacch.1018, Hor. Od. ii. 19. 23, Dion. xl. 44. In the accounts of Ovid and Seneca, the god retains his human form, but various wild beasts appear at his side (Ov. Met. 3.668), or occupy the prow and stern (Sen.457). According to Nonnus, Dionysus suddenly becomes a giant, while animals swarm on all the ship's benches. The scene in the hymn is closely parallel to a myth in Ant. Lib.10, where Dionysus, to frighten the Minyades (who stayed at their looms instead of joining the Bacchanals) e)ge/neto tau=ros kai\ le/wn kai\ pa/rdalis, kai\ e)k tw=n keleo/ntwn e)rru/h ne/ktar au)tw=| kai\ ga/la. For the transformations see also Sandys on Eur. Bacch.1017.
*nho\s e)*)p a)krota/ths=the Homeric nho\s e)p' i)krio/fin.

a)/rkton e)*poi/hsen: Ovid's simulacra inania (668) is a more “modern” touch. In his contest with Deriades, Dionysus takes the form of a bear, among other changes, Dion. xl. 46. Crusius is therefore wrong in stating that the mention of the bear is mythologically unique in connexion with Dionysus.
s/hmata fai/nwn=Od. 21.413 (of Zeus thundering); cf. Il. 2.353.

47, 48. a)\n d' e)/sth: to be taken with le/wn as well as a)/rktos, unless some verb is to be mentally supplied from a)ne/sth for le/wn. In either case there is some harshness, though not more, perhaps, than elsewhere in the hymn. But it is possible that a line has dropped out after 47, containing a verb for le/wn. deino\n u(*po/dra i)dw/n is not to be disturbed; cf. Il. 15.13, Scut. 445.

a)rxo\n e(/l): Köchly objects to e(/le on the ground that nothing is said about the captain's fate when “seized.” But his death may be inferred, or we may actually translate “killed”; Gemoll remarks that this use of e(lei=n is quite Homeric.
qu/raze, “out”; for this general sense cf. Il. 5.694 , *p 408, e 410, f 422 etc.
The omission of the subject is again abrupt.
e)/qhke *pano/lbion: obscurely expressed; the meaning intended is apparently “made him happy” by allaying his fears; cf. Ov. 3.668 pavidum . . . firmat deus.

†di=e ka/twr: eka/twr, ka/twr appear to be impossible and meaningless forms, although the latter is defended by Chudziński (p. 9), and Ridgeway (J. P. 1888, p. 113) who translates “oarsman,” comparing kath/rhs; this, word, however, properly means “furnished with,” and only bears the special sense “fitted with oars” when joined to ploi=on ( Herod.viii. 21) or in a similar context. Again, on this theory, the first part of the word is kata/, and it is hardly possible that this prep. with the termination -wr could imply “mariner.” Of the conjectures, only a)ka/twr, a)/ktwr, kra/twr are formally possible, and there is little probability in any of these. M's e(ka/twr (M has often the closest form of a corruption; cf. 43) might be thought to suggest a shortened form of a proper name, e.g. *(ekath/nwr (Fick Personennamen p. 117); but the introduction of the name seems even more out of place here than it would be at 43.

There is no objection to di=e, which might be applied to the helmsman as appropriately as to the swineherd in the Odyssey. Gemoll suggests that there is a corruption of Dia, the old name of Naxos (cf. Ov. 3.689
“excute” dicens
“corde metum Diamque tene”); but the place-name is unmanageable in the verse.
tw=| e)mw=| kexarisme/ne qumw=|: Gemoll points to the use of tw=| as a mark of late epic usage; as a matter of fact the whole formula occurs in Il. 11.608 , d 71.
ei)mi\ d): for de/ introducing an explanation (instead of ga/r or an asyndeton) cf. h. Dem. 77 (ou)de/).
58, 59. With the concluding formula cf. h. i.18 f.

div1.head: HYMN TO ARES
div1.p: IT is evident that this hymn is quite removed from the style and tone of the other hymns in the collection. Ruhnken, Hermann, and a large majority of the older scholars assigned it a place among the Orphic poems. Matthiae, indeed, thought it to be nearer akin to the philosophic works of Cleanthes and Proclus; and parts of the hymn seem to shew the influence of the latter poet (see on 6, 10). Recent students of the Orphica refuse to class it in the Orphic category (Maass Orpheus p. 198, Abel Hom. Hymns p. 91, who dates it as “in or after the age of Nonnus,” Adami p. 223 f.). The accumulation of epithets is of course a marked characteristic of the Orphic school; but it is pointed out that this feature is not confined to the Orphica (Maass and Adami, l.c.; see on h. Dem. 18). There is, however, little or nothing in the hymn to distinguish it from the acknowledged works of the Orphics; as Gemoll remarks, the first half is exactly in their style, and the prayer that Ares may remove kako/ths is really a prayer for peace, similar to that in Orph. h. lxv (see on 12, 16). The inference is that the writer, if not a genuine “Orphic,” was at least steeped in the literature of that sect.

The cause which led to the inclusion of this hymn among “Homeric” poems is by no means evident. According to one view, the compiler of the collection was ignorant of the very plain distinction between an Orphic and an Homeric hymn. In this case Gemoll argues that the present form of the collection must belong to a very late age; for the Alexandrines, who knew some of the short hymns, would have had more critical acumen than to confuse the two kinds of hymns, even if the hymn to Ares were not later than the Alexandrine period. According to another theory, the presence of the hymn is caused by the juxtaposition of Homeric and Orphic poems in a manuscript, which led to the misplacement of one hymn.

If the presence of the hymn is not due to this purely accidental cause, the compiler of the collection must have had some reason for the choice of this particular hymn. It may be suggested that he was influenced by mythological considerations. The cult of Ares was of so little importance, that it would not be surprising if no genuine Homeric prelude in honour of the god were ready to hand. The compiler, however, may have been anxious that his collection should not lack mythological completeness; he was therefore compelled to search further afield for recognition of Ares' claims. On this supposition, it is not necessary to argue that he was destitute of critical ability; he may have allowed a sense of religious obligation to outweigh literary fitness.

div2.p: brisa/rmate: of Ares, Scut. 441.

*ni/khs: in Theog. 384, Apollod.i. 2. 4(cf. Bacchyl. fr. 71. 1), she is daughter of Styx and Pallas. Gemoll well remarks that Ares' connexion with Nike and Themis is here not mythological, but purely symbolical.

dikaiota/twn a)*ge\ fwtw=n: there may be a verbal reminiscence of Il. 13.6 dikaiota/twn a)nqrw/pwn, but there cannot be any mythological allusion to the Scythians, as Baumeister thinks; Ares is simply the “Lord of the Just. ”
*)hnore/hs skh*ptou=xe: there is perhaps no parallel for this use in early Greek; cf. Orph. h. 55. 11 qew=n skhptou=xe.

*purauge/a ku/klon ktl., “wheeling thy red orb among the bodies that move in the sevenfold paths of heaven.” The passage closely resembles Proclus h. iv.17 ei)/te kai\ e(pta\ ku/klwn u(pe\r a)/ntugas ai)qe/ra nai/eis (quoted by Matthiae). In purauge/a there is an allusion to the distinctive redness of the planet Mars, which was called o( puro/eis; Mund. vi. 18, often in Manetho, Maximus peri\ katarxw=n 298, 398, Io. Lydus Mens.ii. 8, N. D. ii. 20.
trita/ths: this passage is to be explained by the periodic times of the planets (Saturn, Jupiter, Mars, etc.), see the reviewer of Maass' die Tagesgötter in Rom etc., Class. Rev. 1903, p. 87.

eu)qhle/os, “thriving,” more appropriate to h(/bhs than eu)qarse/os, although the latter is not impossible. Gemoll's correction of eu)qale/os is necessary, as the Doric form of eu)qhlh/s cannot stand; the error doubtless arose from confusion with eu)qa^lh/s. Cf. xxx. 13 eu)frosu/nh| neoqhle/i+.
klu=qi katasti/lbwn: i.e. klu=qi kai\ kata/stilbe; Matthiae compares Orph. h. iv. 9, xxviii. 11, xxxiv. 27.

bio/thta: the form is rare and late, but may be retained in this hymn; cf. C.I.G. 6206, 6290, both inscriptions from imperial times. For the general sense of 10 f. Matthiae compares Proclus h. iv.21 polu/moxqon e)mh\n bio/toio porei/hn
div2.l: i)qu/nois se/o, po/tna, dikaiota/toisi bele/mnois.
ou)x o(si/wn pau/ousa po/qwn kruo/essan e)rwh/n.

div2.p: kako/thta: the “baseness” is further explained by yuxh=s a)pathlo\n o(rmh/n; the poet prays for freedom from the passions which deceive the mind and incite to bloodshed.

Ares is similarly prayed to stay the strife and give peace in Orph. h. lxv. 6 sth=son e)/rin lussw=san; cf. ib. 9 ei)rh/nhn poqe/wn. So Hephaestus, as the god of fire, is asked to stay the rage of fire, Orph. h. lxvi. 12. The principle is that expressed by the proverbial o( trw/sas kai\ i)a/setai.
biai/ous: for the termination Baumeister compares Plat. Rep.iii. 399A, Leg.x. 885A.

div1.head: HYMN TO ARTEMIS
div1.p: THE hymn is no doubt Ionic, and it is obvious to suggest that the composer was a rhapsodist at Claros. The marks of locality (the Meles, Smyrna, and Claros) are not of sufficiently PanHellenic importance to be merely “literary,” as would be, for example, the mention of Cyprus and Cythera in connexion with Aphrodite (see h. Aphr. Introd.). Nor is it impossible that the prelude was recited at a common festival of Apollo and Artemis (Baumeister); but we have no proof that such a festival existed, although there are Colophonian coins of Apollo *kla/rios and Artemis *klari/a, dating from imperial times (Head Hist. Num. p. 494). The two deities, however, are not represented together on this coinage (see also Farnell Cults ii. p. 532); and the reference to the Clarian Apollo may have a mythological rather than a ritualistic significance (see on 5 and xxvii. 13 f.).
2=h. Apoll. 199.

div2.p: i(/p*pous: Artemis was called eu(ri/ppa at Pheneos in Arcadia, Paus.viii. 14. 5.Cf. Pind. Ol.iii. 26*latou=s i(pposo/a quga/thr, id. fr. 89 i(/ppwn e)la/teiran. More often, in art, she drives stags or deer (e.g. on the frieze of the temple of Apollo at Bassae).
a)/rsasa: for the verb (a)/rdw) and construction the editors quote Euphor. fr. 75 (Mein.) oi(\ d' ou)/pw *simo/entos *)axaii/das h)/rsamen i(/ppous.

*me/lhtos: preserved by M alone. The river Meles flowed by Smyrna, and is to be identified with a stream at Bournoubat, near Old Smyrna (Frazer on Paus.vii. 5. 12). Homer was said to have composed his poems in a grotto on its banks ( Paus. ib.).
*kla/ron: see on h. Apoll. 40. Artemis visits her brother in his famous sanctuary at Claros, just as she visits Delphi, xxvii. 13 f. (where see note).
e(kathbo/lon: apparently only here of Artemis, who however is e(khbo/los, Soph. fr. 357, and on a Naxian inscription at Delos, B. C. H. iii. (1879) p. 3 f.; and e(kae/rgh (Farnell Cults ii. p. 465).
7 = xiv. 6, where, as here, only M preserves the correct reading q) for d).

div1.head: HYMN TO APHRODITE
div1.p: THE hymn, like its parallel, vi, was a prelude recited at a contest (cf. 5). There is no reason to suppose that it was Cyprian in origin. The MSS. offer several singular variants in the few lines of the hymn.

div2.p: *kuprogen=h: first in Theog. 199, in the older form *kuprogene/a, which need not be read in the hymn; Fick (B. B. ix. 203) reads *kuproge/nhn. The variations eu)progenh= etc. are due to the initial being left to the scribe to paint in red; mistaken attempts were made to fill up the gap.
*kuqe/reian: Theog. 196, 198 etc., but also in the Odyssey (Od. 8.288 , s 193) as a proper name. See Roscher Lex. ii. 1769 f.

mei/lixa dw=ra, “her gracious gifts,” i.e. beauty; cf. meilixo/dwros (see L. and S. ), of Wine and Health; so ta\ mei/lixa, “joys,” of Charis, Pind. Ol.i. 30.Gemoll also suggests a less probable explanation from Mimnerm. i. 3 kruptadi/h filo/ths kai\ mei/lixa dw=ra kai\ eu)nh/.

e)f): here and in 3 in a local sense: “she has ever a smile on her lovely face, and lovely bloom runs thereon.” It seems unnecessary to add a new word e)fimerto/s, although e)fimei/rw is found in late epic.

The editors read fe/rei; if this is original the dative to be supplied is brotoi=si, although Matthiae and Gemoll understand fe/rei as=“bears” (on herself). Gemoll thinks that a)/nqos is literally a flower, and, objecting to the collective singular, proposes e)/sqos. But a)/nqos is here “bloom,” “beauty,” as in h. Dem. 107, h. Herm. 375 and often. The reading of M qe/ei is more appropriate than fe/rei to a)/nqos; for the metaphorical use cf. Il. 6.45 leukh\ d' e)pide/dromen ai)/glh.

The alternatives are equal in point of sense, but M's xai=re ma/kaira *kuqh/rhs can hardly be paralleled in metre; Batrach. 287 is similar, where, however, Abel reads a)ei\ malero/n (Schmidt) for deimale/on.

ei)*nali/hs te *ku/prou: here M's reading is in all respects equal to kai\ pa/shs *ku/prou. For the short u cf. Empedocles 282, 419, Ibycus fr. v. 2, Pind. Nem.iv. 46 etc. For the worship of Aphrodite in Cyprus and Cythera see Farnell Cults ii. p. 740 f.

div1.head: HYMN TO ATHENA
div1.p: THIS and the following hymn have no formula of transition to a rhapsody. Hence it is very doubtful whether the hymn was a prelude at a recitation at Athens or elsewhere. The cult of Athena polia/s or poliou=xos was common to many Greek states (Farnell Cults i. p. 299).

div2.p: e)rusi/ptolin: the epithet occurs in Il. 6.305 and xxviii. 3 of Athena. The suggestion (Ebeling, Gemoll) that the word is non boni ominis, “making cities to fall,” cannot be entertained. The first part of the word must be connected with e)ru/omai, “protect,” although Leaf suggests that the original form was r(usi/ptolis (so schol. A l.c.), e)rusi/ptolis being coined on the mistaken analogy of e)rusa/rmatos (from e)ru/w “draw”).

The epithet recalls Athena poliou=xos (Pauly-Wissowa “Athena” 1946). The reference to perqo/menai po/lhes (3) does not negative this view; Athena goes forth with her own people (4) to sack the enemy's city.

Athena and Ares are very rarely united in myth or ritual; they had a common altar at Olympia as patrons of horse-racing ( Paus.v. 15. 6). Pindar brackets them as warlike deities ( Pind. Nem.x. 84). There was a statue of Athena in the temple of Ares at Athens ( Paus.i. 8. 4), and occasionally Athena *)arei/a or *strati/a is mentioned with Ares (Farnell Cults i. p. 309 and 407); but generally there was little in common between the rough Thracian god and the <*>ivilised goddess. See Voigt Beitr. zur Myth. des Ares und der Athena, 1881.

i)o/nta te *nisso/meno/n te, “in their goings (out) and returnings.” The verb ni/ssomai appears primarily to have the sense of “return” (so Ebeling, although L. and S. ignore the usage), being, no doubt, connected with ne/omai, no/stos; so, perhaps, Il. 12.119 , *y 76. On the spelling see La Roche Hom. Textkr. p. 316.
With the concluding form of prayer cf. the last lines of hymns xv, xx, Callim. h. Zeus di/dou d' a)reth\n a)/feno/n te.

div1.head: HYMN TO HERA
div1.p: THIS hymn alone in the collection (except viii, which is unique in other respects) has no verse of farewell, or concluding address to the deity. There seems to be no probable explanation of the peculiarity. Possibly the hymn is the opening of a longer poem.

div2.p: a)ei/dw: the lengthening of the a is not Homeric (except Od. 17.519), but occurs in *)il. *mikr. fr. 1, Theognis 4, xviii. 1, Callim. h. Del. 304, Aratus 1000, Theocr. vii. 41, Mosch.iii. 82, Anth. Pal. ix. 485 and 545, and often in Oppian. In xxxii. 1 a)ei/dein is uncertain.
a)qana/th*n: Matthiae's a)qana/twn would be more normal, but the harder reading is to be retained; in sense, “immortal queen” does not differ materially from “queen of the immortals.”

div1.head: HYMN TO DEMETER
div1.p: THIS cento, as Gemoll calls the short hymn, is formed from the longer hymn to Demeter (1 = h. Dem. 1, 2 = h. Dem. 493) except for the third line, which occurs in Callim., h. Dem. 134, as far as po/lin. But, although obviously a patchwork, the hymn is not necessarily later than Callimachus. The Alexandrine poet might perhaps have disdained to borrow from such a source; but both he and the hymn-writer may have taken the sufficiently commonplace xai=re, qea/, kai\ th/nde sa/ou po/lin from an older hymn. Guttmann's view, that a)/rxe d' a)oidh=s is a mark of late work, is rightly criticised by Gemoll; it is addressed to Demeter herself, who inspires, and so may be said to begin, the recitation; cf. Od. 8.499 o( d' o(rmhqei\s qeou= h)/rxeto.

div2.p: *persefo/neian: the Homeric form; the aspirated *fersefo/neia (xp) may be due to the forms *fersefo/na (h), *ferse/fassa, *fer(r)e/fatta; so in Orph. h. xli. 5. On the various forms see Förster der Raub der Persephone p. 276 f.

sa/ou: the MS. form here is a variant for sa/w in Od. 17.595, the sole form Callim. Epigr. 35; on the other hand sa/w alone is given in Od. 13.230, Callim. h. Dem. 135, Anth. Pal. xxii. 2, Inscr. Graec. metr. ed. Preger 63. 4. sa/ou is supported by Nauck Mélanges iv. 134, Kühner-Blass ii. 545.

div1.head: HYMN TO THE MOTHER OF THE GODS
div1.p: THE goddess commonly identified by the Greeks with Rhea and the Asiatic Cybele was almost certainly in her origin Hellenic, and was widely worshipped, from early times, as simply mh/thr qew=n. At Athens, for example, her cult was important, in the *mhtrw=|on (see Frazer on Paus.i. 3. 5, Harrison M. M. A. A. p. 43 f.). The absence of a personal name (Rhea or Cybele) is therefore no indication of a late date. Nor is there any question of Orphic influence in the hymn. Two Orphic hymns are dedicated to the goddess; one (xiv) mentions *(re/a by name, the other (xxvii) calls her the Mother of the Gods. Whatever the date of the present hymn, it is far removed from the spirit of the Orphic compositions, and, as Baumeister remarks, is quite “Homeric.”

div2.p: For Rhea cf. h. Dem. 60, 442, 459, h. Aphr. 43. She appears as mother of the gods in Il. 15.187, Theog. 453 f., 625, 634; as mother of gods and men Orph. h. xiv. 9, xxvii. 7.

bro/mos au)lw=n = h. Herm. 452; cf. Anth. Pal. vi. 165. 5 tupa/nou bro/mon, ib. 217. 5 *kube/lhs i(ero\n bro/mon, Apoll. Arg. 1.1139 r(o/mbw| kai\ tupa/nw| *(rei/hn *fru/ges i(la/skontai. The unmetrical tump- is also found in Apollonius and the Anthology. Examples of the connexion of tu/mpana with the goddess, in literature and art, are too numerous to quote.

4, 5. Cf. h. Aphr. 70 lu/koi xaropoi/ te le/ontes, and ib. 74 kata\ skio/entas e)nau/lous. The resemblance, as Gemoll notes, is hardly accidental. The lion is the constant symbol of the Mother in art, from the time of Pheidias (see Harrison l.c., Rapp in Roscher Lex. ii. 1644 f.).
u(lh/entes e)/nauloi=xxvi. 8.

div1.head: HYMN TO HERACLES THE LION-HEARTED
div1.p: As the epithet leonto/qumon is not elsewhere known in classical literature, Baumeister thinks that the present title is due to the Byzantines. But a similar compound leonto/xlainos occurs in Anth. Plan. iv. 94, and for the title Baumeister himself compares Il. 5.639 qumole/onta, of Heracles. There is no proof that the Byzantines contributed anything to the hymns. The variations in the titles of other hymns (xiii, xiv, xxiii, xxv, xxx, xxxiii) may have originated at a much earlier period. In any case the possible lateness of the title would prove nothing for the hymn itself, the date of which is quite uncertain.
Baumeister's view that the hymn is Attic (as Heracles was first worshipped in Attica, Diod.iv. 39) is a mere hypothesis.

div2.p: There are the same apparent alternatives as in h. x. The versions are equally good, except that line 5 as it stands is imperfect; Ilgen's de/ will correct it. The other version contains no main verb and polla\ d' a)ne/tlh is necessary; cf. note on h. Herm. 471.
7, 8. Cf. Od. 11.602 f. au)to\s de\ met' a)qana/toisi qeoi=si
div2.l: te/rpetai e)n qali/h|s kai\ e)/xei kalli/sfuron *(/hbhn. Lucian (dial. deor. xvi. 1 au)to\s me\n ga\r o( *(hraklh=s e)n tw=| ou)ranw=| toi=s qeoi=s su/nesti kai\ e)/xei kalli/sfuron *(/hbhn) certainly borrows from l, not (as Matthiae thought) from the hymn.

div2.p: di/dou d) ktl.=xx. 8, Callim. h. Zeus 96.

div1.head: HYMN TO ASCLEPIUS
div1.p: THERE are no data for determining the place of composition, but the antiquity of the hymn is proved by the citation of 1-3 in the scholia on Pind. Pyth.iii. 14.
The most recent discussion of Asclepius is to be found in Miss Harrison's Prolegomena p. 341 f. For earlier literature see Roscher Lex. and Pauly-Wissowa Real-Encycl. s.v.

div2.p: *korwni/s: on the myth of Coronis see Preller-Robert i.^{2} p. 515, A. Walton in Cornell Studies iii. (1894), and for her connexion with the crow (korw/nh), Frazer on Paus.ii. 11. 7.
*dwti/w| e)*n *pedi/w|: from the *)/hoiai; cf. Hes. fr. 76 (ap. Strab. 442, 647) h)\ oi(/h *didu/mous i(erou\s nai/ousa kolw/nous

l.quote: *dwti/w| e)n pedi/w| polubo/truos a)/nt' *)amu/roio

div2.l: ni/yato *boibi/ados li/mnhs po/da parqe/nos a)dmh/s. So fr. ap. quaest. conv. 748 B a)na\ *dw/tion a)nqemo/en pedi/on. The locality is described by Strabo 442 plhsi/on th=s a)/rti lexqei/shs *perraibi/as kai\ th=s *)/osshs kai\ e)/ti th=s *boibhi+/dos li/mnhs, e)n me/sh| me/n pws th=| *qettali/a|, lo/fois de\ i)di/ois perikleio/menon. For the myth of the crow which informed on Coronis cf. fr. 125 (schol. on Pind. Pyth.iii. 14 and 48).
div2.p: *flegu/ou: in Hes. fr. 123 the form is *flegu/ao; the schol. on Pindar cites the Homeric line with the Doric *flegu/a, following Pindar, as Baumeister saw.
Cf. Orac.ed. Hendess 34. 1 w)= me/ga xa/rma brotoi=s blastw\n *)asklhpie\ pa=sin

l.quote: o(\n *fleguhi_\s e)/tikten e)moi\ filo/thti migei=sa

div2.l: i(mero/essa *korwni\s e)ni\ kranah=| *)epidau/rw| (ap. Paus.ii. 26. 7), ib. 13. 2 *(ele/nh| me/ga xa/rma.

div1.head: HYMN TO THE DIOSCURI
div1.p: THE lines are no doubt an abbreviation of the longer hymn to the Dioscuri (xxxiii), just as the following hymn is borrowed rom iv. For the parentage of the “Tyndarids” (from Zeus) see on xxxiii. 2. Lines 3, 4 are copied with variations from xxxiii. 4, 5. The hymn was apparently not intended for a prelude, as the verse of transition (xxxiii. 19) is here omitted.

div2.p: a)ei/seo: the solitary instance of this aor. imper. middle has the authority of the MSS.; in xx. 1 a)ei/deo, which Stephanus read here; a)ei/seo was maintained by Buttmann (Kühner-Blass ii. p. 103).
M's reading e)p' a)mh/twn had its origin probably in a graphical corruption of e)*pibh/tores; cf. e)k mh\ tou= de/, for e)kbh=t' ou)de/ h. Apoll. 457.

div1.head: HYMN TO HERMES
div1.p: THE shorter hymn to Hermes is merely an abstract from the longer, as is the case with the preceding hymn to the Dioscuri. Gemoll notices that the subject of both these abbreviated versions is confined to the birth of the gods. Further, as the hymn to Asclepius (xvi), which also stops at his birth, must be old (see Introd.), Gemoll concludes that xvii and xviii belong to the same age as xvi. This reasoning seems to be sound, and we may therefore reject Baumeister's theory that the present hymn was compiled a grammatico nescio quo ingenioli ostentandi causa.

The three hymns are to be considered as equally genuine products of antiquity, although their precise date cannot be decided. But the reason for the existence of the two abbreviations (xvii and xviii) is not obvious. The original hymn to Hermes (iv) is of course far too long to have served as a prelude to an ordinary recitation of epic poetry; it would therefore be natural to suppose that xviii was an abstraction for the use of rhapsodists. But the original hymn to the Dioscuri (xxxiii) hardly exceeds the limits of the usual preludes, and it is hard to see why it should have been further shortened. Perhaps even a hymn of moderate compass came to be thought excessive by rhapsodists who were anxious to begin the actual recitation. The prelude had become a mere convention, just as a few bars of God save the King are now taken to represent the entire national anthem at the conclusion of a play.

2-9=h. Herm. 2-9, with a few variations: 4 *)/atlantos quga/thr=nu/mfh e)u+plo/kamos, 5 a)le/einen=h)leu/aq), 6 a)/ntrw| naieta/ousa paliski/w| = a)/ntron e)/sw nai/ousa pali/skion, 8 eu)=te=o)/fra, 9 la/nqane d) = lh/qwn.

div2.p: xaridw=ta: for these words see on h. i.2, and add olbiota zeu J. H. S. xxiii. p. 243. The line is a curious addition to 11, which in h. Aphr. and h. ix is the formula of transition at the end of a prelude. It has been thought an alternative to 11, or an interpolation; but there is no reason for demanding complete uniformity in these endings.
dw=tor e)a/wn=xxix. 8, Callim. h. Zeus 91, Od. 8.335.

div1.head: HYMN TO PAN

listBibl.head: BIBLIOGRAPHY
listBibl.bibl: A. LUDWICH, “der Homerische Hymnus auf Pan,” Rheinischer Museum p. 547-558, 1887.
R. PEPPMÜLLER, Philologus xlviii. p. 1-19, 1889.
PRELLER-ROBERT i.^{2} p. 738 f.
W. ROSCHER, “die Sagen von der Geburt des Pan,” Philologus, 1894.
W. ROSCHER and K. WERNICKE, art. “Pan” in Roscher's Lex. (with literature to 1902).

div1.p: Subject and style.—The hymn to Pan, with its keen appreciation of Nature and its sympathy with the free open-air life of the field and mountain, has a freshness and charm peculiarly attractive to a modern reader. The poem, though a hymn in form, is an idyll in spirit—a picture, or rather a series of pictures, with landscapes of snowy peaks and rocky ways, and meadows where the crocus and fragrant hyacinth are intermingled with the grass. In all the scenes Pan is the central figure, alone, or with his attendant nymphs: Pan the hunter, roaming over the snowy hills, or among the thick bushes, or along the gentle streams; Pan the musician, making sweet melody beside the dark fountain in the dusk, or joining in the dance of Oread nymphs. Nowhere, perhaps, in Greek literature has the love of the country found clearer expression than in this hymn, which challenges comparison with the chorus to Pan in the Helena, Eur. Hel.167-190. or with the seventh idyll of Theocritus. “ Eur. Itis assuredly”—to quote a fine critic—“the voice of no small poet which breathes through this lovely hymn.”Palgrave Landscape in Poetry p. 16.

Date of the hymn.—It is to be regretted that so interesting a poem cannot be dated with any certainty. On one point, however, scholars are substantially agreed—that the hymn is one of the latest in the collection, and that it could hardly have been composed before the age of Pindar at the earliest. The evidence of mythology, if not conclusive, strongly supports this consensus of opinion. It is true that Pan is one of the oldest creations of Greek folklore, being (as Mannhardt has shewn) the representative in Greece of the numerous wood-spirits who appear in a semi-caprine form.Mannhardt A. W. F. K. ch. iii.; Frazer G. B. ii. p. 261 f. The old theory, recently revived by Immerwahr (Kulte u. Myth. Ark. i.) and Bérard (de l'Origine des cultes Arc.), that Pan was a sun-god, cannot be accepted; see a review of the latter work in Class. Rev. ix. p. 71, Roscher Lex. 1405. Pan is simply a shepherd-god made by the Arcadians with their own characteristics. But the old Arcadian woodspirit and shepherd-god had no place in the “higher mythology” of Homer and Hesiod, and scarcely won any recognition in literature before the Persian wars. Until that period he was probably ignored by cultivated Greeks (outside Arcadia), and hence Herodotus was led to infer that Pan was one of the most recent of Hellenic deities (ii. 145). In Pindar he is a mere attendant of the *mega/lh *mh/thr ( Pyth.iii. 77, fr. 6. 1 *matro\s mega/las o)pade/). The first reference to the god is quoted from Epimenides, who called Pan and Arcas the twin-sons of Zeus and Callisto (schol. on Theocr. i. 3, schol. on Rhes. 36). It is difficult to believe that a hymn which shews so developed a conception of Pan's nature and of his place in the Greek mythological system could have been the product of the seventh or early sixth century, in which all other literature passes over the god in silence. Pan is equally neglected in Greek art until the beginning of the fifth century (Roscher Lex. 1407).

On the other hand, the hymn does not appear to be Alexandrine, as various critics have suggested.Guttmann (de Hymn. Hom. hist. crit.), Sittl L. G. i. p. 199, Gemoll (p. 334), Murray Anc. Greek Lit. p. 50. Forms such as ti/sh (2), to/qi (25), *(ermei/hn (28), w)/n (32), xe/ra (40) are instanced by Gemoll as “late”; they are of course foreign to the oldest epic, but there is little or nothing in the language which cannot be paralleled in the genuinely ancient hymns. Usages such as nu/mfh for “daughter” (34), tiqh/nh “mother” (38), are also unknown in Homer; but there is no reason to see in them a mark of Alexandrine affectation. There are a large number of a(/pac lego/mena (filo/krotos 2, xoroh/qhs 3, a)glae/qeiros, a)nake/klomai 5, au)xmh/eis 6, mhlosko/pos 11, ligu/molpos 19, teratwpo/s 36); all these, however, are simple and straightforward, and may well belong to an early stage of the language. The hymn reads like the product of a good period (perhaps the fifth century), and Ludwich is probably correct in refusing to see any traces of Alexandrine workmanship.

Place of composition.—The hymn treats of an Arcadian god, and mentions his birth on Cyllene; but the cult of Pan became the common property of the Greeks from the beginning of the fifth century, or a little earlier, so that there is no internal evidence of locality. Baumeister and Wilamowitz (aus Kydathen p. 224) suggest an Athenian origin; all that can be said in favour of this theory is the fact that Pan became a favourite at Athens after the battle of Marathon, when his cult, if known before to the Athenians, was first officially organised. Herod.vi. 105, Simonid. fr. 133; Harrison M. M. A. A. p. 538 f. ; Milchöfer A. Z. 1880, p. 214.

The further suggestion of Baumeister, that the hymn served as a proem to Homeric recitations at the Panathenaea, is mere guess-work. It may be sufficient to remark that, if the hymn is Athenian, it could not have been composed at a time when the memory of the Persian defeat was fresh. There is no mention of the familiar part which the god played in the war, or of the “panic” which he caused at Marathon. His character in the hymn is entirely pacific; he is a hunter, but no warrior.Barnes' ai)xmhth/n for au)xmh/enq) (6) scarcely deserves record as an emendation.

Integrity of the hymn.—The unity of the poem is sufficiently obvious, although the motif does not lie in a single episode, as in the hymns to Demeter, to the Delian and Pythian Apollo, and to Aphrodite (see II. App. p. 311); and there is no question of interpolated lines. An attempt to disintegrate the hymn was made by Groddeck, who divided it into two parts, the first (1-27) relating to Pan and the Nymphs, the second (28-47) describing the birth of the god. Groddeck thought that the narrative languished in the latter half; to this Ilgen rightly replied that the comparative failure of interest is due to the subject, not to a different composer. Further, Groddeck argued that the birth of Pan should have been described at the beginning; he did not realise that the birth was the subject of the nymph's song, and that the Homeric hymns afford two exact parallels to the order of the narrative. In h. Herm. 59 Hermes sings of his own birth, and in h. Art. (xxvii) an account of Artemis at the chase is followed by a mention of the song describing the birth of Apollo and Artemis, while the goddess herself, like Pan, directs the chorus.
Peppmüller divides the hymn into “nomic” parts: a)rxa/ (1-7), katatropa/ (8-26), o)mfalo/s (27-47), e)pi/logos (48-49).

div2.p: a)mfi/: cf. on vii. 1. *(ermei/ao fi/lon *go/non: the genealogies vary; Roscher (die Sagen etc.) gives a complete list. For Hermes as the father cf. Herod.ii. 145, Lucian dial. deor. 22, Anth. Plan. iv. 229 and elsewhere. Hermes and Pan were both shepherdgods (no/mioi) in Arcadia, and were both worshipped on Cyllene, so that their connexion, no doubt, originated in Arcadia.

ai)*gipo/dh*n: this form is preserved in 37, and should be restored here, although Ilgen and Baumeister retain ai)gopo/dhn in this place, charging the inconsistency on the hymn-writer rather than on the scribe.

Numerous epithets allude to the goatfooted Pan (*ai)gi/pan): e.g. Simon. fr. 33 trago/poun, Herod.ii. 46tragoskele/a, Arist. Ran. 230 keroba/tan, Theocr. Ep. xiii. 6 ai)giba/tan, Orph. h. xi. 5 ai)gomele/s, Dion. xxiii. 151 ai)gei/ois po/dessi, Anth. Pal. vi. 35. 1 ai)gw/nuxi; for ai)gipo/dhs cf. Anth. Pal. vi. 57. 3, ix. 330. 2.
dike/rwta: l.c. ai)gopro/swpon, Lucian l.c. kerasfo/ros, Anth. Pal. ix. 142 dike/rwn, ib. vi. 32 dikrai/rw|, Dion. xiv. 72 *pane\s keraalke/es, xvi. 187 u(yi/kerws, etc.

a)/mudis: not in Homer. xoroh/qesi: the form may stand; Schmidt's xorogh/qesi would itself be a(/pac leg., although supported by dafnogh/qhs, lurogh/qhs (Ludwich). For the sense Gemoll compares Orph. h. xxiv. 2 xoropai/gmones, of the Nereids.

ai)*gi/lipos: the derivation is still obscure. In A. J. P. xvi. p. 261 the latter part of the word is connected with le-lim-me/nos, i.e. “loved by goats.” Prellwitz s.v. maintains the ancient etymology (lei/pw). The construction has been doubted; stei/bousi might be intrans., the order being stei/bousi kata\ ka/rhna ai)g. pe/trhs. Some join kata/ to the verb, which would thus be trans., cf. O. C. 467 katastei/yas pe/don. But as kat' ai)gi/lipos pe/trhs is a Homeric formula (Il. 9.15 , *p 4), the prep. is here also to be taken with the genitive, so that stei/bousi is trans., “tread on the peaks.” For the direct obj. acc. cf. Apoll. Arg. 3.835 stei=be pe/don (wrongly explained by L. and S. as a cogn. acc.).
*no/mion: of Pan, Anth. Pal. vi. 96. 6. There was a temple of Pan under this title on the *no/mia o)/rh, near Lycosura, Paus.viii. 38. 11.

a)*glae/qeiron, “bright-haired,” does not seem a very appropriate epithet; but the first part of the compound probably means “thick” or “long,” for which Preller compares a)glao/karpos “with rich fruit.”
au)xmh/enq), “shaggy,” “unkempt”; au)xmhro/s, au)xmwdh/s, au)xmhroko/mhs are similarly used.

o(\s *pa/nta lo/fon ktl.: the goat-god was naturally at home on the rocky mountains of Arcadia, the chief of which (Lycaeus, Cyllene, Maenalus, Parthenion) were sacred to him. So O. T. 1100 o)ressiba/ta| *pani/, Aj.595w)= *pa\n a(li/plagkte *kullani/as xionoktu/pou
div2.l: petrai/as a)po\ deira/dos fa/nhq), Anth. Pal. vi. 32. 3 *pani\ filoskope/lw|, ib. 106. 5 *pa\n bouni=ta. See Roscher (Lex. 1383), who thinks that the connexion with the mountains arose from Pan's character as a hunter and also as a shepherd; Arcadians drove their flocks up the mountains as spring approached. In any case, the god of a country like Arcadia must have haunted the mountains.
div2.p: *nifo/enta: so Aj. l.c., Castorion in Athen. x. 455 A se\ to\n bolai=s nifoktu/pois dusxei/meron

l.quote: nai/onq' e(/dran, qhrono/me *pa/n, xqo/n' *)arka/dwn

div2.l: klh/sw.

div2.p:
e)felko/menos: this is certainly sound, and is rightly explained by Gemoll “attracted by,” comparing Thuc.i. 42. 4.mhd' . . . tou/tw| e)fe/lkesqe. Add the Homeric au)to\s ga e)fe/lketai a)/ndra si/dhros (Od. 16.294 , t 13), which is hardly less metaphorical; so often in the Anthology (Anth. Pal. vii. 707. 8 pro/s t' au)dh
 e(lko/menos mega/lhn, xii. 87. 6 e)felko/meqa, xv. 37. 38 e(/lkomai, Anth. Plan. iv. 136 and 139 a)ntimeqelko/menon, 140, 286, all exx. of the mind); cf. also Lith. 332 e)fe/lketai (middle) and Plat. Soph.265 Hence E. we need not give a physical sense to the verb, with Matthiae, i.e. “drawn by,” “floating on,” for which cf. Dicaearch.i. 29kai\ ga o( *eu)/ripos disso
 e)/xwn to
 ei)/sploun e)fe/lketai to
 e)/mporon ei)s th
 po/lin. Baumeister's e)fezo/menos would not have been corrupted to e)felko/menos, and r(ei/qroisin cannot be used for o)/xqh|sin, even in late Greek (see Peppmüller p. 6).
For Pan's association with rivers see Roscher (Lex. 1384 f.), who derives the idea from the watering of the flocks in Arcadian streams, comparing Theocr. iv. 24, Verg. Ecl. iii. 96.

mhlosko/pon: Gemoll's correction of the accent is rightly adopted by Roscher; mhlo/skopon could only mean “watched by sheep.” The reference is, of course, to a skopia/ or peak, from which shepherds watch their flocks on the mountain-slopes.
a)rgino/enta: not for nifo/enta (6), but “bright” in the clear air of Greece; the word is applied to towns in Il. 2.647, 656.
dih/lase: intrans., like dioixnei= (10).

o)*ce/a derko/menos: cf. Anth. Pal. vi. 16. 1, ib. 109. 9 *pa\n w)= skopih=ta, ib. 107. 1 u(lhskopw|, Orph. h. xi. 9 eu)/skope, qhrhth/r; for Pan a)poskopw=n cf. Ital.xiii. 340, and see Roscher die Sagen p. 161, Lex. 1401. So Artemis is qhrosko/pos xxvii. 11.
to/te: here and in 19 preferable to tote/, but in 22 an oxytone accent seems required, with the meaning “anon.”

oi)=on: the simplest correction of oi(=on; qualifies e(/speros, “only at evening,” when the sport is over, tum demum. For oi)=on = mo/non cf. Theog. 29 gaste/res oi)=on, Aesch. Ag.136(glossed mo/non), and it has been so taken in Il. 9.355; often later, e.g. Theocr. xxv. 199, Apoll. Arg. ii. 634 etc.
Of the conjectures, none are graphically possible except Hermann's oi)=os, “alone”; but Pan is attended by the nymphs; cf. 19.

a)/grhs: a certain correction of a)/krhs; cf. Theocr. i. 16
a)p' a)/gras
tani/ka kekmakw\s a)mpau/etai of Pan; id. xxv. 87 e)k bota/nhs a)nio/nta of sheep; Apoll. Arg. ii. 938 a)/grhqen o(/t' ou)rano\n ei)sanabai/nh| (Artemis); id. iii. 69 qh/rhs e)caniw/n (Jason). For Pan as a hunter cf. Hesych. *)agreu/s: o( *pa\n para\ *)aqhnai/ois, E. M. 34, 38, so a)gro/tas Anth. Pal. vi. 13. 1 and 188. 3, a)grono/mos ib. 154. 1, eu)/qhros ib. 185. 4, qhrono/mos Castorion ap. Athen. x. 454 F, qhrhth/r Orph. h. xi. 9. Cf. also imag. ii. 11, Arrian cyneg. 35. 3, Paus.viii. 42. 3, Calpurn. 10. 3 f. Hunting was the natural occupation of the semi-bestial Pan or the Centaurs; moreover Pan's chief worshippers, the Arcadians, were themselves great hunters. The images of Pan were beaten with squills by Arcadian boys when the chase was unsuccessful, Theocr. vii. 107. See further Roscher die Sagen p. 154 f., Lex. 1387.
dona/kwn u(/po=do/naci; see on xxi. 1. For Pan's connexion with the su=rigc see Roscher Lex. 1402. The pipes were used by herdsmen in Homeric times; cf. Il. 18.525.
mou=san a)qu/rwn: the editors quote Apoll. Arg. 4.948 molph\n a)qu/rein.
*nh/dumon: for the form see on h. Herm. 241.

e)/aros *poluanqe/os: apparently a gen. of time, “in flowery spring,” but parallels for an epithet used in this construction are hard to find. Baumeister compares Scut. 153 *seiri/ou a)zale/oio, explained as temporal by Göttling; but Flach denies this. Examples such as Il. 11.691 tw=n prote/rwn e)te/wn are different, as tw=n prote/rwn defines the time more closely (like tou= e)pigignome/nou xeimw=nos etc.), and is not a mere epithet. Edgar and Lang construe with e)n peta/loisi “the leaves of spring,” but this is very doubtful Greek; the adj. ei)arinoi=s would be required as in Il. 2.89, Theog. 279, Op.75, Cypria fr. ii. 2 etc. Köchly marks a lacuna after e)/aros, supplying poliou= ne/on i(stame/noio
div2.l: u(/lhs e(zome/nh. We should perhaps expect w(/rh|, as in Mimnerm. fr. 1 poluanqe/os w(/rh| ei)/aros, Hes. Op.584qe/reos kamatwde/os w(/rh|, but Peppmüller's supplement after 17 w(/rh| o)/pa proiei=sa gives an impossible order of words, with e)n peta/loisi intervening.

div2.p: a)xe/ei: the nearest conjecture to the text, in which the repetition e)piproxe/ousa xe/ei can hardly be tolerated. There is, however, some doubt as to the existence of a)xe/ein; see on h. Dem. 478. Ruhnken's i)axei= (better i)a/xei) is also possible; cf. Anth. Pal. vii. 201. 2 a(dei=an me/lpwn e)kproxe/eis i)axa/n (of a cicala). Gemoll's h)xe/ei is equally good; the rest of the conjectures are violent.

sfin: the use as dat. sing. is not Homeric, and has been denied for any Greek; but the present passage cannot be otherwise explained. The dat. sing. is probable, if not certain, in Aesch. Pers.759, O. C. 1490, where Jebb thinks it “unsafe to deny that poetry sometimes admitted the use.” See Brugmann Grundriss ii. p. 822. Pind. Pyth.ix. 116, h. xxx.9 are uncertain.
For Pan and the nymphs see Roscher Lex. 1390 f. (literature), 1420 f. (art).

*pukna/: usually altered to pu/ka, but the correption is supported by Hes. Op.567a)kro^kne/faios, fr. 138 w)= te/knon— *zeu\s e)te/knwse path/r, Theocr. xx. 126 a)/llh| de\ sto/ma tu/ye puknoi\ d' a)ra/bhsan o)do/ntes, Quintus vii. 15 pukna\ mh/dea h)/dh|; so te^/xnas Empedocl. 185, and other exx. in J. H. S. xviii. 30. Cf. Eberhard Metr. Beob. i. p. 31.
melanu/drw|: only with krh/nh (Il. 9.14 , *p 3, 160, *f 257, u 158), of the dark colour of deep water.

xorw=n requires no alteration; the plural is justified by xxvii. 18 (of Artemis), the genitive by h. Herm. 226 ai)na\ me\n e)/nqen o(doi=o, ta\ d' ai)no/ter' e)/nqen o(doi=o, and 357 o(dou= to\ me\n e)/nqa to\ d' e)/nqa. Both sets of adverbs follow e(/rpwn. qorw/n, like most of Köchly's emendations, is needless: the aor. part. is inappropriate, and the verb is too violent even for Pan's ungainly motion.

For Pan as a dancer cf. Pind. fr. 99 xoreuth\n telew/taton qew=n, Aesch. Pers.448o( filo/xoros *pa/n, Soph. Aj.696w)= qew=n xoropoi/) a)/nac, scolium ap. Athen. xv. 694 D w)= *pa\n *)arkadi/as mede/wn klee/nnas
div2.l: o)rxhsta/, Orph. h. xi. 9 su/gxore numfw=n, Anth. Pal. vi. 32. 2 eu)ska/rqmw|, imag. ii. 11 and 12.

div2.p: oi(=o/n q), “and for example”; Baumeister compares the formula h)\ oi(/h, which gave a title to the Hesiodean Catalogue of Women.
*(ermei/h*n: so *(ermei/h| 36, but *(ermei/as 40. The hymn-writer may well have used the forms indifferently; cf. *(ermei/ao 1.
e)/n*nepon, following u(mneu=sin, must have the force of an aorist; cf. die/dramen, dih/lase 12, 13, following dioixnei= 10. For the imperf. instead of the indefinite aor. see h. Apoll. 5.
*polupi/daka, mhte/ra mh/lwn: cf. h. Aphr. 68. For the flocks of Arcadia cf. Bacchyl.xi. 95*)arkadi/an mhlotro/fon, Theocr. xxii. 157 eu)/mhlos, h. Herm. 2 polumh/lou.
*kullh*ni/ou, “as god of Cyllene.” For the genitive, after oi(, see on h. Dem. 37. The accusative *kullh/nion is possible, but much weaker, and is a natural alteration of the unfamiliar genitive.
For Hermes *kullh/nios see on h. Herm. 8, and for the same title of Pan cf. Soph. Aj.695; his cult at Cyllene is attested by Anth. Pal. vi. 96. 3.
w)/n: see on h. Apoll. 330. yafaro/trixa: the x family, as Gemoll observes, has preserved the strict Ionic form yafero-, which is used by Hippocrates according to L. and

qa/le, “waxed,” i.e. became inflamed. The word is frequently applied to the strength of disease in tragedy (see L. and S. ); it is used, as here, of love in verses quoted by Plutarch quaest. conv. 761 B su\n ga\r a)ndrei/a| kai\ o( lusimelhs *)/erws e)ni\ *xalkide/wn qa/llei po/lesin, Plat. Symp. 203E qa/llei kai\ zh=| (of Eros personified). Ruhnken's la/qe has been generally accepted from its false look of palaeographical probability (Ilgen's labw/n for balw/n is the only clear case of anagrammatismus in the hymns); but neither la/qe nor e)/le is an improvement on the text; the other conjectures are impossible.
e)*pelqw/n, “attacking,” more forcible than u(pelqw/n; Gemoll compares Soph. fr. 607 e)/rws a)/ndras e)pe/rxetai.

*nu/mfh|: not elsewhere, apparently, for “daughter”; Roscher's explanation, “bride” (die Sagen p. 368), is hardly possible; the reference is to Dryope, who was the daughter of Dryops, son of Arcas ( Ant. Lib.xxii, cf. Verg. Aen.x. 551). The conjectures *druo/phs, *druo/ph| are unlikely. An oak-spirit is appropriate as the mother of Pan, whom the Arcadians called to\n th=s u(/lhs ku/rion, Macrob. Sat.i. 22; so Cheiron is the son of Philyra, the lime-nymph ( Theog. 1001), and Pholos, another centaur, is the son of Melia, the ash (see Mannhardt A. W. F. p. 48). Roscher, however, thinks that the genealogy is due to the settlement of the Dryopes in the neighbourhood of Cyllene (see Immerwahr p. 136 f.), so that the legend may be local and Cyllenian.

e)k d' e)te/lesse: the subject is almost certainly Hermes (not Dryope, as Ludwich understands), “he brought the marriage to pass.” Cf. Od. 4.7 toi=sin de\ qeoi\ ga/mon e)cete/leion, and Od. 20.74 te/los qaleroi=o gamoi=o; cf. h. Dem. 79. The change of subject in te/ke presents no difficulty.
e)*n mega/roisin: Roscher thinks the expression unsuitable to a nymph. But me/garon is applied to the cave in which the nymph Maia dwells, h. Herm. 146.

a)/far, “from his birth.” Baumeister compares Od. 4.85 *libu/hn, o(/qi t' a)/rnes a)/far keraoi\ tele/qousin. Add, for later Greek, Callim. h. Apoll. 103
eu)qu/ se mh/thr
gei/nat' a)osshth=ra.

tiqh/n*h, “mother”; for this rare meaning only Colluth. 372 is adduced by Baumeister and Gemoll (add id. 84, 87, 99, 174). But the use may also be defended by trofo/s=mh/thr in Soph. Aj.849, th\n qre/yasan for mother-land, in Leocr. § 47. Köchly's pai=d' a)ti/qhnon (after Maneth. iv. 368) is out of the question. Peppmüller thinks that tiqh/nh is used advisedly to suggest that Dryope in her terror neglected a mother's duty of “nursing” her child.
ei)s xe/ra qh=ke: a rather curious expression for “took in his arms.”

The hare is a symbol of Pan, e.g. on coins of Rhegium and Messana (Head Hist. Num. p. 93 and 134). On a coin of the latter city Pan is seated upon a rock caressing a hare (dated by Head 420-396 B.C.). Pan has also the lagwbo/lon, Roscher Lex. 1386.

On the close connexion of Pan and Dionysus cf. Anth. Pal. vi. 154 (a dedication to Pan, Bacchus, and the Nymphs), ib. 315 *pa=na fi/lon *bromi/oio, scolium ap. Athen. (quoted on 22) *bromi/ais o)pade\ nu/mfais, Lucian dial. deor. 22. 3 o( *dio/nusos ou)de\n e)mou= a)/neu poiei=n du/natai, a)lla\ e(tai=ron kai\ qiasw/thn pepoi/htai/ me kai\ h(gou=mai au)tw=| tou= xorou=, Dion. xliii. 10 *pa\n e)mo/s (of Dionysus), v. ap. Euseb. P. E. v. 6 xruso/kerws blosuroi=o *diwnu/sou qera/pwn *pa/n and often. Pan and Dionysus were both “vegetation-spirits,” according to Frazer (G. B. ii. p. 291, etc.); but as Dionysus was not a primitive Arcadian god like Pan, the connexion must have been a later development, due to the wild and orgiastic nature of the Dionysiac cult, which attracted such woodland deities as Pan and the Satyrs.
*peri/alla: only here in the Homeric poems; once in Pind. Pyth.xi. 8.

The derivation from pa=s is given by Plato Crat.408 The Orphic B. identification of Pan with the ko/smos (to\ pa=n) must have been caused by this etymology (Orph. h. xi. 1 ko/smoio to\ su/mpan), although the Egyptian god Mendes no doubt aided the conception (Roscher Pan als Allgott p. 56). In a similar spirit Hesiod explains Pandora o(/ti pa/ntes . . . dw=ron e)dw/rhsan ( Op.80). Another tradition made Pan the son of Hermes and Penelope, which may be due to the same etymology (Doric *panelo/pa, Mannhardt W. F. K. p. 128); the ancients disagreed whether this Penelope was a nymph or the wife of Odysseus (see Roscher die Sagen p. 368, Lex. 1405). The schol. on Theocr. i. 3 combines the connexion with Penelope and the derivation from pa=s: ui(o\n *phnelo/phs kai\ pa/ntwn tw=n mnhsth/rwn, kai\ dia\ tou=to le/gesqai kai\ *pa=na. The true etymology is generally assumed to be for *pa/wn, from &root;pa, cf. pa/omai, poimh/n, pasco, Pales etc.; the termination is Arcadian, cf. *)alkma/n, *(erma/n, *posoida/n in that dialect (Roscher Lex. 1405).

i(/lamai: so xxi. 5, i(/lhqi xx. 8, xxiii. 4. For the verb used in taking leave of a deity cf. Theocr. xv. 143, Apoll. Arg. 4.1773, Archer-Hind on Phaed.95A. The alternative li/somai is taken by Veitch Greek Verbs s. v. as a future; however, we have the variant li/tomai li/somai in Anth. Pal. v. 164. li/tomai occurs in xvi. 5.

div1.head: HYMN TO HEPHAESTUS
div1.p: THE fact that Hephaestus and Athena were joined in a common cult at Athens, and (as far as is known) in no other Greek city, gives colour to Baumeister's suggestion that this hymn is Athenian. The two deities were worshipped together as patrons of all arts and crafts; the shops of braziers and ironmongers were near the temple of Hephaestus, in which stood a statue of Athena ( Paus.i. 14. 6), and the festival called Chalceia was sacred to both (see Frazer l.c., Harrison M. M. A. A. 119 f.; Preller-Robert i.^{1} p. 180 and 209). According to Plato (Critias 109 C), Athena and Hephaestus, filosofi/a| filotexni/a| te e)pi\ ta\ au)ta\ e)lqo/ntes, became joint patrons of Attica; cf. Solon fr. 13 (quoted on 5) and other references in Farnell Cults i. p. 409 f. Athena was *)erga/nh, the Worker; but in a wider sense she was the giver of all civilization; Hephaestus, the Fire-god and the divine smith, gave men the skill (kluto/mhtin 1, klutote/xnhn 5) which differentiated them from wild beasts. Aeschylus, indeed, attributes these gifts of civilization to Prometheus; but the importance of the Titan was mainly mythological; in practical cult Hephaestus appropriated most of the credit (see Sikes and Willson on P. V. p. xix f.).

But this aspect of Athena and Hephaestus was by no means exclusively Athena Attic. was the patron of arts in Homer (Il. 5.61 , u 78), and under titles such as *)erga/nh, *kalli/ergos, and *maxani=tis, she was worshipped in many parts of Greece (Farnell Cults i. p. 314 f.). In Hesiod she instructs Pandora, the creation of Hephaestus, in weaving ( Op.60 f.); see further h. Aphr. 12 f. We may therefore fairly look for Epic rather than Athenian influence in the mythology of this hymn.

div2.p: a)*glaa\ e)/rga here = te/xnas generally; cf. h. Aphr. 11 and 15.
For ancient poetic accounts of the savage life of primitive man cf. P. V. 446 f., Suppl. 201 f., fr. 582, fr. ap. Nauck 393, Moschion fr. 7, Lucr. v. 933 f., Juv. xv. 151 f., etc.
e)*pi\ xqono/s: the genitive is unusual in this phrase, where either xqoni/ or xqo/na would be regular, for “on (the whole) earth”; see Ebeling, s.v. e)pi/ p. 450, and note on xxv. 3.
e)/rga dae/ntes: cf. Solon fr. 13. 49 a)/llos *)aqhnai/hs te kai\ *(hfai/stou polute/xnew
div2.l: e)/rga daei/s, Theocr. xvii. 81 brotw=n e)/rga dae/ntwn, of civilized men.

div2.p: telesfo/ron ei)s e)*niauto/n, “for the full year”; the adjective no doubt means properly “bringing (the seasons) to completion.” The phrase occurs in Il. 19.32, h. Apoll. 343, and several times in the Odyssey, M. and R. on Od. 4.86.
For the ending cf. xv. 9.

u(*po\ *pteru/gwn: cf. Av.771(ku/knoi) summigh= boh\n o(mou= pteroi=s kre/kontes i)/akxon *)apo/llw . . . o)/xqw| e)fezo/menoi par' *(/ebron potamo/n. Clearly Aristophanes means that the voice (boh/n) of the swan blended (summigh=) with the accompaniment of the flapping wing. This sense would suit u(po/, which is used from Hesiod onwards for “accompanying” music; see exx. in L. and S. s. v. Il. 1.5. But it was commonly believed that the swan's “song” was made by the noise of the actual wings: cf. Pratin. ap. Athen. 617 C oi(=a/ te ku/knon a)/gonta poikilo/pteron me/los, Anacr.vii. 8a(/te tis ku/knos *kau_/strw|

l.quote: poiki/lon pteroi=si me/lpwn

div2.l: a)ne/mw| su/naulos h)xh=|. u(po\ pteru/gwn therefore=pteru/gessi, rather than inter volatum, as Ebeling explains (s.v. pte/ruc); cf. h. Pan 15 dona/kwn u(/po, which=do/naci, as Pan could not sing while piping. The music of the swan's wings may have been a conception due to a similar (and correct) belief that the cicala's or grasshopper's “song” was caused by the wings: Hes. Op.583kataxeu/et' a)oidh\n pukno\n u(po\ pteru/gwn, imitated by Alcaeus fr. 59; cf. Anth. Pal. vii. 192. 1 and 4, 194. 1, 195. 4, 197. 2, 200. 1.
div2.p: Gemoll's view, that the passage in Aristophanes, quoted above, is the origin of the present line, is most unlikely.
References to the swan's song are collected by Voss Myth. Br. ii. p. 112, and Thompson Greek Birds p. 104 f. Aelian (V. H. i. 14) is incredulous.

*ph*neio/n: a literary reference to one of the places famed for the cult of Apollo. In the same connexion Aristophanes (l.c.) mentions the Hebrus, Callimachus (h. Del. 249) Pactolus and Delos, Moschus (id. iii. 14) the Strymon, etc.

*prw=to/n te kai\ u(/staton: i.e. “all his song is of thee.” In xxix. 5 prw/th| puma/th| te the meaning is different. With the present passage cf. Il. 9.97 e)n soi\ me\n lh/cw, se/o d' a)/rcomai (imitated by Verg. Ecl.viii. 11), Theog. 34, 48, fr. 132, Theocr. xvii. 3, h. i.18, Aratus 14.

div1.head: HYMN TO POSEIDON
div1.p: THE hymn appears to be rather a prayer for safety at sea (cf. 7) than an ordinary prelude, although the phrase a)/rxom' a)ei/dein suggests a rhapsodist. It should be compared with Hom. Ep. vi, which, however, is more personal in tone, and refers to a special occasion, whereas plw/ousin a)/rhge may be quite general.

div2.p: a)mfi/: see on vii. 1.

*(elikw=na: cf. Il. 20.404 *(elikw/nion a)mfi\ a)/nakta. Commentators, both ancient and modern, have doubted whether the adjective refers to Helice in Achaea, or to Helicon, the Boeotian mountain. Aristarchus (ap. E. M. 547. 16) takes the latter view, a)po\ *(elikw=nos . . . e)pei\ h( *boiwti/a o(/lh i(era\ *poseidw=nos; the schol. A on *u l.c. prefers Helice, and this is strongly supported by Il. 8.203, where Helice and Aegae are mentioned together as sacred to Poseidon (for Helice cf. Il. 2.574, for Aegae Il. 13.21). The two towns were close neighbours on the Corinthian gulf. Leaf on *u l.c., comparing this passage, suggests that Helicon was another form of Helice, and distinct from the Boeotian mountain. There is, however, no authority for Helicon=Helice. The proper epic adjective from Helice would presumably be *(elikh/i+os (see E. M. l.c.); it is, however, possible that the author of *u intended Helice, but used the wrongly formed *(elikw/nios which had a familiar sound; the hymn-writer translated the adjective into *(elikw=na, regardless of Il. 8.203; so Hom. Ep. vi. 2 eu)ruxo/rou mede/wn h)de\ zaqe/ou *(elikw=nos (of Poseidon), a passage which disposes of Martin's *(eli/khn te here. In later times the worship of Heliconian Poseidon was connected with Helice (see Paus.vii. 24. 5 f., Strabo 384); the cult was also famous among the Ionians at Panionium ( Herod.i. 148), and at Athens (Frazer on l.c., Harrison M. M. A. A. p. 231). Helice was destroyed by an earthquake in 373 B.C. For Poseidon *(elikw/nios cf. Dittenberger Sylloge 603, 637.
Poseidon, as horse-tamer and saviour of ships, is akin to the Dioscuri (see xxxiii).

Hermann's Orpheum audire videaris is rightly refuted by Baumeister; the hymn is “Homeric” in spirit, although the language of this line suggests Orph. h. lxiv. 12 f. a)lla/, ma/kar . . . eu)mene\s h)=tor e)/xwn (quoted by Gemoll).

div1.head: HYMN TO ZEUS
div1.p: IN this hymn Baumeister sees Orphic influence, comparing Orph. h. lxii. 2 (of *di/kh), h(\ kai\ *zhno\s a)/naktos e)pi\ qro/non i(ero\n i(/zei,
div1.l: ou)rano/qen kaqorw=sa bi/on qnhtw=n polufu/lwn. But the close connexion of Zeus with Dike or Themis is frequent in Greek poetry, and this hymn appears to be not less “Homeric” than its predecessors (xx-xxii).
div1.p: The introduction of Themis gives the keynote of the hymn; the poet entreats for the favour of Zeus, the god of Law and Righteousness. For the Homeric conception of Themis see Il. 15.87 , *u 4, b 68. Her relation with Zeus is prominent in later myth and cult. In Hesiod (Theog. 901) she is the wife of Zeus; cf. Pind. fr. 30 (this was the Theban belief; cf. Paus.ix. 25. 4). At Aegina she was worshipped as *dio\s ceni/ou pa/redros, Pind. Ol.viii. 21(the title pa/redros is applied by Bacchyl.xi. 51 to Hera as the wife of Zeus). Cf. also Aesch. Supp.360, Soph. El.1064; Preller-Robert i.^{2} p. 475 f.

It is a question whether Themis is here the wife or merely the adviser of Zeus. In the latter case her position would be similar to that of Dike in Hesiod, who sits by the side of Zeus and complains when men work injustice ( Hes. Op.258, cf. Orph. h. lxii quoted above). But the passage in the Theogony and the language in line 3 suggest the former interpretation.

div2.p: telesfo/ron, the “fulfiller”; the exact sense of this word varies according to the te/los required in each context; it is applied to *moi=ra, P. V. 511, to Dike, Soph. Aj.1390, to Gaea, Dittenberg C. I. G. (Septentr.) i. 2452. Here, as Zeus is closely connected with Themis, the te/los must be the fulfilment of Law or Justice; cf. te/leios L. and S. s.v. ii.

*qe/misti: the unmetrical *qe/miti is probably due to the ligature st, often in good minuscule mistaken for t. The schol. on Pind. Ol.x. 28 expressly read the form in Il. 15.87, where there is no trace in the Homeric MSS.
e)*gklido/n: bending towards, or leaning on, Zeus. The editors compare Apoll. Arg. 1.790 , *g 1008, of looking “askance” or aside.

o)a/rous: in early epic the word and its cognates do not necessarily imply the talk of lovers; cf. Il. 13.291 , *r 227, t 179, h. Herm. 170; but they are often used in that connexion; Il. 14.216 , *x 126, h. Aphr. 249, h. Herm. 68.

div1.head: HYMN TO HESTIA
div1.p: HESTIA is here invoked to make her home, with Zeus, in a building, the nature of which cannot be determined. According to Baumeister, it was probably a private house or a palace, in which rhapsodists recited epic at a feast. But there is weight in Gemoll's criticism, that Hestia and Zeus would not be invoked into a private house with so much solemnity. The occasion is rather to be sought in the dedication of a temple.

No stress can be laid on the words *puqoi= e)n h)gaqe/h|, which certainly need not imply that the hymn was Delphian; the reference is, as often, literary, being due to the fame of Hestia's connexion with Delphi and the Pythian Apollo. There was a Hearth at Delphi in the Prytaneum, at which a perpetual fire was kept up by widows (see references in Frazer on Paus.viii. 53. 9). The allusion in the present passage is, however, to a hearth actually in the temple at Delphi, which is frequently mentioned; cf. Choeph. 1038; Eum.282; O. T. 965; Eur. Ion462; Paus.x. 24. 4 etc.

In view of the abrupt style, many commentators believe it to be a fragment from a longer hymn; Matthiae marks a lacuna after 3. A lacuna is also probable after 4; but we need not suppose that the original form of the hymn was widely different from the present tradition.

div2.p: *(esti/h: for the form see on h. Aphr. 22 (Solmsen p. 213 f.). *(isti/h is of course correct for true Ionic; but the pseudo-Ionic *(esti/h (influenced by the common *(esti/a) may be allowed to stand in the present hymn, and in xxix. Compare i(sti/h in the Odyssey with e)fe/stios, g 234, h 248, y 55.

Cf. orac.ed. Hendess 32. 2 *puqw/ t' h)gaqe/hn (quoted by Ephorus) and 45. 1 o(\s e)mo\n do/mon a)mfipoleu/ei. h)ga/qeos is common with *puqw/; cf. Od. 8.80, Theog. 499, *puqoi= e)n h)gaqe/h|, Pind. Pyth.ix. 77, Bacchyl.iii. 62Bacchyl., v. 41.

a)*polei/betai u(*gro\n e)/laion=Od. 7.107 (also with genitive). For the transference of the Greek use of unguents to the gods the editors compare Callim. h. Apoll. 38 f.
ai( de\ ko/mai quo/enta pe/dw| lei/bousin e)/laia:
ou) li/pos *)apo/llwnos a)posta/zousin e)/qeirai,
a)ll' au)th\n pana/keian. It is improbable that the present passage suggested itself to Callimachus, who at all events gives a less material significance to the oil (as pana/keian).

The line is abrupt and frigid, unless there was some peculiar propriety in the mention of the oil. Baumeister thinks that the reference may be to an actual statue of Hestia, which was sprinkled with oil by the worshippers. Oil was often poured on sacred stones; cf. Paus.x. 24. 6, Lucian Alexand. 30, Flor. 1. 1 etc. In the case of a statue, a dressing of oil was part of the ko/smos, like the decoration with jewels etc.; cf. oneir. ii. 33 qew=n a)ga/lmata . . . a)lei/fein. There were statues of Hestia (e.g. in the Prytaneum at Athens Paus.i. 18. 3), but as a rule her cult was aniconic, at least in early times. Possibly the line is merely an anthropomorphic description of a sacred hearth or lamp, which maintained a perpetual oil-fed flame (ai)ei/). Probably every Greek city had a perpetual fire in its Prytaneum; this was sometimes in a lamp (Theocr. xxx. 36, Athen. xv. 700 D; see Frazer on Paus.viii. 53. 9 and his article in J. P. xiv. p. 145 f.).

e)*pe/rxeo qumo
 e)/xousa: since qumo
 e)/xousa is meaningless, at least in regard to Hestia, an epithet to qumo/n must be supplied; cf. h. Aphr. 102 (eu)/frona), vii. 49 (sao/frona), xxii. 7 (eu)mene\s h)=tor e)/xwn) etc. It is usual to assume that e)pe/rxeo is corrupt, and conceals e)u+/frona or the like. As the adjective in this formulaic expression seems regularly to precede qumo/n, very probably this view is correct. On the other hand e)pe/rxeo would be sound, if a lacuna were made after the line. The repetition of the verb has force, and the compound following the simple verb has many parallels ( Soph. El.850, Iph. T. 984, Ran. 369, Anth. Pal. v. 161. 3 oi)/xom' e)/rwtos o)/lwla dioi/xomai. Byz. Steph. s.v. *su/baris quotes eu)dai/mwn, *subari=ta, paneudai/mwn su\ me
 ai)ei/).
xa/rin d' a(/m' o)/passon a)oidh=|: the words do not necessarily imply that a rhapsody is to follow; Gemoll remarks that a)oidh=| may refer to the present hymn.

div1.head: HYMN TO THE MUSES AND APOLLO
div1.p: THE prelude is a mere cento from Hesiod: 1 is suggested by Theog. 1, 2-5 = Theog. 94-97, while 6 is modelled on Theog. 104. The old view, that the lines Theog. 94 f. are borrowed from the hymn, is no longer entertained. It is rightly pointed out that e)k de\ *dio\s basilh=es is motiveless in the hymn, while it is quite suitable to the context of the Theogony. But although later than Hesiod, the abstract was doubtless made in ancient times, for purposes of epic recitation (cf. 6, 7). Guttmann's arguments for his theory of Byzantine compilation are worthless (see Gemoll p. 346).
For references to the joint worship of Apollo and the Muses see on h. Herm. 450.

div2.p: e)*pi\ xqoni/: in Hesiod e)pi\ xqo/na; for the accusative in Hesiod cf. Theog. 187, Op.11; it is also Homeric, as in Od. 23.371 (especially in the Odyssey); h. Apoll. 69, h. Dem. 305. The dative e)pi\ xqoni/ is commoner, Il. 1.88 etc. Even e)pi\ xqono/s is found in xx. 3.

div1.head: HYMN TO DIONYSUS
div1.p: THE occasion for this hymn was no doubt some festival of Dionysus; the singer hopes to be present for many successive years. It can hardly have been recited at the Brauronia, as Baumeister supposes, for this festival was held every four years, whereas e)s w(/ras naturally implies an annual rite (see on 12).

div2.p: kissoko/mh*n: of Dionysus inscr. gr. ined. (Ross) 135, of a Satyr Anth. Pal. vi. 56. 1. Cf. kissoxai/ths Ecphant. fr. 3, Pratin. fr. 1. 42, Delphic paean (B. C. H. xix. 147). On the ivy in connexion with Dionysus see Roscher Lex. i. 1060.

*dio/nuson: the “Attic” form for the epic *diw/nusos (except Od. 11.325). For the various forms see Preller-Robert i.^{2} p. 664. In the hymns *diw/nus) occurs in h. i.20, while the author of h. vii is indifferent (*diw/nuson 1, *dio/nusos e)ri/bromos, as here, 56).
e)ri/bromon; as *bro/mios (a title confined to poetry).
For the nurses of Dionysus (*diwnu/soio tiqh=nai *z 132) cf. Preller-Robert i.^{2} p. 663, and Roscher Lex. (s.v. “Mainaden”) ii. 2244.
*nu/shs: see on h. i.8.
a)/ntrw| e)*n eu)w/dei: see on h. Herm. 231.
to/nde: for to/n ge in Homer (Hermann).
foiti/zeske: only in late epic (Apoll. Arg. 3.54, Callim. fr. 148).
a)/speton u(/lh*n = Il. 2.455; the emendation a)/spetos is therefore to be rejected.
*polusta/ful): not elsewhere of Dionysus. For the order of the words see on h. Apoll. 14.
do\s d' *h(ma=s xai/rontas: so in the paean to Asclepius (Ziebarth Comm. Philol. Monach. 1891, p. 1, v. 15) do\s d' h(ma=s xai/rontas o(ra=n fa/os h)eli/oio.

e)s w(/ras: Baumeister tries to prove that this phrase does not necessarily imply “for a year.” In Od. 9.135 ei)s w(/ras may be indefinite “as the seasons come,” but generally a definite year seems intended. Gemoll compares Plato Ep. vii. p. 346 me/ne . . . to\n e)niauto\n tou=ton, ei)s de\ w(/ras a)/piqi. Add (for Attic) Thesm. 950 e)k tw=n w(rw=n ei)s ta\s w(/ras “year in, year out,” Nub. 562, Ran. 381, and (for other dialects) Theocr. xv. 74 ei)s w)/ras kh)/peita, “for next year and ever,” a passage similar to the present. For the idiom generally cf. Plutarch Lycurg. 6 w(/ras e)c w(/ras, Isyllus in C. I. Pel. et Ins. i. 950 B 25 w(/rais e)c w(rw=n no/mon a)ei\ to/nde se/bontas, Theocr. xviii. 15 kei)s e)/tos e)c e)/teos, Aeschines i. 63 xro/nous e)k xro/nwn, Anth. Pal. xii. 107 ei)s w(/ras au)=qis a)/goite.
ei)s tou\s *pollou\s e)*niautou/s: so inscr. Dittenberger Sylloge 607 ebohsen o dhmos: pollois etesi tous newkorous; ib. 737. This is the modern R. C. Latin “ad multos annos.”

div1.head: HYMN TO ARTEMIS
div1.p: THE hymn to Artemis, which gives a pleasing picture of the youthful goddess returning from the chase to take part in the dance at Delphi, seems to belong to a good period. The writer was almost certainly influenced by the hymn to Apollo; Gemoll compares lines 5 f. with the opening scene of that hymn, and 15 f. with h. Apoll. 189 f. It does not, however, follow as a matter of course that the writer knew the hymn to Apollo as an undivided document, for he might have borrowed from two separate hymns. The prelude may have been used at Delphi, where portions of ancient poetry, bearing on Delphi and the god, were recited (Dittenberger Sylloge 663); but it is very possible that the scene at that place (13 f.) is simply introduced for literary effect.

div2.p: xrushla/katon keladein/hn: see on h. Aphr. 16.

*parqe/non: the common Greek conception of Artemis (as “Queen and Huntress, chaste and fair”) is here brought out, bnt parqe/non probably also suggests the youth of Artemis; it need not refer to her cult-name *parqe/nos, as in xxviii. 2 of Athena.
e)lafhbo/lon: not Homeric as a title of Artemis; on the epithet see Farnell Cults ii. p. 433; cf. Anacr.i. 1, Soph. Trach.214.
o)/rh: for the late form cf. *mousw=n 15.
a)/grh| terpome/n*h: as a)grote/ra; cf. Il. 21.470 po/tnia qhrw=n,
div2.l: *)/artemis a)grote/rh, z 105 terpome/nh ka/proisi kai\ w)kei/h|s e)la/foisin. On the title a)grote/ra see references in Farnell Cults p. 562 f., and add to his list Bacchyl.v. 123.
div2.p: *pagxru/sea: of the chariot of Artemis, ix. 4.
to/ca titai/nei: cf. h. Apoll. 4.
i)axei=: for the form see on h. Dem. 20.
klag*gh=s qhrw=n: cf. xiv. 4.
qhrosko/pos: of Artemis, Bacchyl.xi. 107.

The lines do not prove that the writer had any idea of a common cult of Apollo and Artemis at Delphi. The goddess simply visits her brother to take part in the chorus of Muses and Graces (see ix Introd. and ib. note 5). Artemis, however, has some connexion with Delphi, although she is not mentioned in the earliest myths of the oracle and temple. This connexion gave her the cult-names *delfini/a (Attica, Thessaly) and, in imperial times, *puqi/h (Miletus). At Delphi itself, as Farnell (Cults ii. p. 467) remarks, we have few traces of her cult; an inscr. (379 B.C.) records an Amphictyonic oath to Apollo, Leto, and Artemis (C. I. G. 1688), and slaves (? female) were sometimes emancipated in the name of Apollo and Artemis (Collitz Dial. Inschr. 1810). The eastern pediment of the Delphian temple represented Apollo, Artemis, Leto, and the Muses, but no trace of this sculpture has been discovered.

In extant art, the most familiar representation of Artemis at Delphi is the archaistic relief in the Villa Albani. In this Artemis stands by Leto, while Nike pours a libation to Apollo as Citharoedus. The Delphian temple in the background gives a setting to the scene. In the majority of representations of the two deities the connexion is simply mythological, with no bearing on the Delphian cult.
The Muses and Graces take the place, at Delphi, of the nymphs who usually accompany Artemis (Od. 6.105). The passage may have been suggested by h. Apoll. 189-206, where the scene is on Olympus.
Cf. h. Apoll. 8.
e)/rgmasin: first in Hes. Op.801Hes. Op., xxix. 12Hes. Op., xxxii. 19.

div1.head: HYMN TO ATHENA
div1.p: THE style of this hymn is so similar to that of the preceding, that Gemoll confidently attributes both to the same composer. For coincidences of language he points to 3, 10 in this hymn (see notes). More striking is the fact that the influence of the hymn to Apollo is probably to be seen here, as in the hymn to Artemis. Gemoll compares 15 with h. Apoll. 7, and 16 with h. Apoll. 12.

According to the earliest detailed version of the myth ( Theog. 886-900), Zeus swallowed Metis, who was already pregnant with Athena. The goddess then sprang from the head of Zeus (ib. 924-926). Hesiod says nothing of the agency of Hephaestus (or other god who assisted ZeusAs Prometheus, Eur. Ion452.) nor of an armed Athena. The schol. on Apoll. Arg. 4.1310 remarks that Stesichorus (whose poem is lost) first mentioned the panoply of the goddess at her birth. The scholiast passes over the hymn, of whose existence he was probably unaware, as he could hardly have had enough critical acumen to place a “Homeric” hymn later than the time of Stesichorus. The myth next appears in Pindar ( Ol.vii. 38), who describes the agency of Hephaestus, and the terror of Heaven and Earth at the loud cry of Athena.

For later accounts of the birth see Pauly-Wissowa s.v. “Athena” 1895 f.; Farnell Cults i. p. 280 f., and (from the “anthropo-logical” standpoint) Lang Myth Ritual and Religion ii. p. 242 f. It seems clear that the mention of the panoply, which is elaborated in the hymn (5, 6, and 15), is not part of the primitive myth; but this early became prominent in literature and art (cf. dial. deor. 8: imag. ii. 27). On archaic vases, down to the time of Pheidias, the usual type represents Zeus as sitting in the midst of gods, while Athena, a small armed figure, issues from his head (see vases in Brit. Mus. *b 147, 218, 244, 421, *e 15, 410). Pheidias probably represented Athena as already born, either standing by the side of Zeus, or moving away from him, as in the well-known relief at Madrid (reproduced by Baumeister Denkm. fig. 172, and Frazer on Paus.i. 24. 5, where references to the recent literature on the subject are given). See Gardner Handbook Gk. Sculpture ii. p. 279 f.

div2.p: a)mei/lixon *)=htor e)/xousan = Il. 9.572 (of Erinnys).
*parqe/non ai)doi/h*n: of Artemis, xxvii. 2.
e)rusi/ptolin: see on xi. 1.
*tritogen*h=: Barnes' *tritogene/a is unnecessary in this hymn; so teu/xh 15 (but teu/xe) 5); cf. xxvii. 4. The form *tritogenh/s is not Homeric.

au)to/s: cf. Il. 5.880 e)pei\ au)to\s e)gei/nao pai=d' a)i+/dhlon (the only reference in Homer to the birth of Athena); Theog. 924 au)to\s d' e)k kefalh=s glaukw/pida gei/nat' *)aqh/nhn. Cf. h. Apoll. 314, 323.

*pro/sqen: proleptic; “she sprang before Zeus, from his immortal head”; *dio/s is to be taken both with pro/sqen and karh/nou. The poet may have had in mind representations of the scene after the type of the Madrid relief (see Introd.). The actual process of the birth is not described; and this, as Gemoll notes, may account for the omission of Hephaestus with his axe.

For the terror of all Nature at the birth cf. Pind. Ol.vii. 38*ou)rano\s d' e)/frice/ nin kai\ *gai=a ma/thr. The upheaval of Nature is simply due to this stupendous scene. Later Greek rationalists gave a physical explanation of Athena's birth, and some modern mythologists (of the school of Preller, Max Müller, and Roscher) interpret Athena as a personification of thunder or lightning, or some other natural phenomenon; but it is certain that Hesiod, Pindar, and the hymn-writer have no idea of reading a physical interpretation into the myth (see Farnell l.c.). Compare the fear inspired by Artemis in the chase, xxvii. 6 f. Adami (p. 231) collects other examples.

u(*po\ bri/mhs: the manuscript reading u(p' o)bri/mhs is scarcely defensible, as o)/brimos has always i short. It is true that certain adjectives have a medial lengthening on the analogy of o)pwrino/s i)/fqimos (Schulze Q. E. p. 473), but there is no authority for extending the list, with Ilgen's obvious correction to hand. Agar believes that o)bri/mhs is the strict grammarian's correction of o)bri/moo; but it is improbable that the genitive in -oo was known to the author of this hymn. bri/mh does not occur in early epic, but cf. Apoll. Arg. 4.1676
u(po/eice damh=nai
*mhdei/hs bri/mh| polufarma/kou (schol. th=| i)sxu/i+); so *brimw/, brimw/dhs, which seem to shew that bri/mh is not mere ‘strength,’ but connoted the idea of terror inspired by Athena; Hesych. also explains by a)peilh/. For deino\n u(po\ bri/mhs Gemoll compares xxvii. 8 deino\n u(po\ klaggh=s. On the derivation of o)/brimos etc. see Johansson I. F. iii. 239 n.

e)/sxeto: Baumeister's objection to this word, which he thinks a contradiction of e)kinh/qh, is unfounded; e)/sxeto is defended by sth=sen . . . i(/ppous. Nature was first upheaved by terror at the coming of Athena, and then her regular course was stopped; the sea was “stayed,” and no longer heat on the shore.

At the birth of Athena represented on the eastern pediment of the Parthenon, Helios and his horses were sculptured at one end, and Selene in her chariot at the other. This scheme became common, e.g. on the base of the statue of Olympian Zeus depicting the birth of Aphrodite ( Paus.v. 11. 8). But the presence of the Sun and Moon gives only a local or temporal frame to these scenes; in the hymn the Sun stops miraculously, from terror. In Il. 18.241 f.
