Hera sends the Sun to Ocean before his time; so Athena prolongs the night, Od. 23.243 f. Cf. also the Sun's threat to disturb the course of nature, Od. 12.383.

In E. M. p. 474 s.v. *(ippi/a the following explanation of the title is given: e)klh/qh ou(/tws h( *)aqhna=, e)pei\ e)k th=s kefalh=s tou= *dio\s meq' i(/ppwn a)nh/lato, w(s o( e)p' au)th=s u(/mnos dhloi=. It is, however, plain that the lexicographer does not allude to the present hymn, as the horses belong to the Sun. Baum. notes that hymns to Athena were not uncommon; cf. Nub. 967 schol.
The MS. reading ei)so/te is defended by Fuch die Temporalsätze mit den Konjunctionen “bis” und “so lang als” Würzburg, 1902, p. 41. For the variant cf. Od. 24.134.

div1.head: HYMN TO HESTIA
div1.p: ALTHOUGH primarily addressed to Hestia, the hymn is equally in honour of Hermes. If the order of lines 9 f. is correct, Groddeck's inference is probably right, that nai/ete dw/mata kala/ alludes to the cult of the two deities in a common temple. Gemoll further supposes that here, as in xxiv, the hymn was sung at the dedication of a new temple. Baumeister's view, that the occasion was a feast in a private house, depends on the adoption of Martin's order of the lines, by which dw/mata kala/ is joined to e)pixqoni/wn a)nqrw/pwn; but see on 9 f.

For the close connexion of Hestia and Hermes see PrellerRobert i. p. 423, Roscher Lex. i. 2649 f. Pheidias represented them as a pair on the basis of Olympian Zeus ( Paus.v. 11. 8). There was a hearth (e(sti/a) in front of a statue of Hermes at Pharae, on which incense was offered before Hermes was consulted for omens ( Paus.viii. 22. 2 f.).

The origin of this connexion is not very clear; Preller sees a link in their relation to human life, Hestia representing quiet family life at home, while Hermes is the patron of the streets and ways, a god of active pursuits. According to others (e.g. Campbell Religion in Greek Lit. p. 119), the connexion is mainly local: Hermes, as the god of boundaries, is akin to the goddess of the house.

It is difficult to see why Gemoll should call the style of the hymn more lyric than epic; his theory of strophic arrangement (in stanzas of four lines) is also very dubious, and indeed breaks down, if we assume a lacuna after 9.
1-3. Cf. h. Aphr. 31, 32. For the form *(esti/h see on h. Aphr. 22, xxiv. 1.
2 = Il. 5.442. xamai\ e)rxome/nwn = e)pixqoni/wn, hence te stands as third. The MSS. in Homer do not support Barnes' e(rpome/nwn.

div2.p: a)i+/dion: for the word see on xxxii. 1. There is of course no objection to the lengthening of the final syllable by the ictus.

e)/laxes is clearly right, between the vocative in 1 and sou= in 4. fe/rbei in xxx. 2 is no parallel, being preceded by the accusative *gai=an. e)/laxe is due to the relative and its effect; cf. Il. 3.277, where for h)e/lios o(\s pa/nt' e)fora=|s kai\ pa/nt' e)pakou/eis pap. Brit. Mus. 126 has efora —epakouei.

*presbhi+/da tim/hn: Hestia was the eldest daughter of Cronos, but Gemoll is no doubt right in understanding this as simply “high honour”; cf. h. Aphr. 32 para\ pa=si brotoi=si qew=n pre/sbeira te/tuktai.

tim/hn: the repetition of the word in 3, 4 is in itself insufficient to warrant change at either place; but there is a further objection to the spondee at the pause in 4, where a bucolic diaeresis would be regular. The second timh/n may therefore have ousted an adjective, as Baumeister and Gemoll suppose.
There is no difficulty in sou=, though followed in the same sentence by *(esti/h|; the proper name gives dignity, and also suggests the actual word used in the libation (6).

*prw/th| *puma/th| te: the first libation was regularly offered to Hestia; hence the proverb a)f' *(esti/as a)/rxesqai, schol. on Vesp. 846, who quotes Chrys. (fr. 653) w)= prw=|ra loibh=s *(esti/a (so schol. on Pind. Nem.x. 6), and Euthyphro 3 A; cf. also Plat. Crat. 401B and D. Cf. Zenob. i. 40. The word puma/th| is more difficult, as Hestia was not honoured in the last libation, at least in secular feasts. But ei)lapi/nai no doubt includes sacrificial feasts, at which the last, as well as the first, libation was poured to Hestai; cf. Cornut. de nat. deor. 28 e)n tai=s qusi/ais oi( *(/ellhnes a)po\ prw/ths te au)th=s h)/rxonto kai\ ei)s e)sxa/thn au)th\n kate/pausan. See Preuner Hestia-Vesta p. 3 f and his art. in Roscher Lex. i. 2605 f. In Rome, of course, Vesta had the last libation; Preuner thinks that the variation points to an indefiniteness in early “Aryan” custom: the Italian branch of the race chose the last place for their goddess, while the Greeks continued the Aryan practice, sometimes assigning both places to Hestia, but more often the first exclusively.
a)rxo/menos spe/ndei: Gemoll's objection to this is unfounded; for the omission of tis, which is eased by the presence of the participle, cf. n. on h. Herm. 202.

Martin's arrangement, by which 9 is transferred to follow 11, is accepted by several editors, but it involves several difficulties: (1) the translation is unmotived palaeographically; (2) the apodosis, which should include both Hestia and Hermes, is thus in the singular (e)pa/rhge); (3) the sense becomes “you both dwell in the fair houses of men”; this hardly suits Hermes, who, though propu/laios etc. is not essentially a god of (in) the house. (4) The clause e)/rgmata kala/ ktl. is left with an asyndeton, for q), after the third word, can hardly be a copula to the clause. In the Oxford text a lacuna was assumed after 9, beginning with ei)do/tes.
There is no great difficulty in nai/ete following su/; the construction is ad sensum, Hestia being logically, though not grammatically, included in the subject of the verb.

ei)do/tes e)/rgmata kala/: the deities give grace to all noble deeds; ei)do/tes, like suneido/tes, implies “share in” or “give a te/los to” the work. Baumeister compares (for Hermes) Orph. h. xxviii. 9 e)rgasi/ais e)parwge/.

The following words are obscure, and possibly corrupt. e(/spesqe is presumably a gnomic aorist, although in form it might be imperative (e(spe/sqai for se-spe/sqai, a redupl. aor., cf. Leaf on Il. 5.423). The translation might be “you follow (men) with wisdom and strength (dat. of accompaniment); or perhaps “you follow their wisdom” etc., i.e. “watch and give increase to,” an amplification of ei)do/tes. No reasonable correction has been proposed; Gemoll's no/on q), e(/spesqe kai\ h(mi=n is supported in sense by xxvii. 20, but is too violent.

div1.head: HYMN TO EARTH THE MOTHER OF ALL
div1.p: GRODDECK'S theory that this hymn is Orphic has rightly met with no support, except from Crusius (Philolog. xlvii. p. 208, 1889), who compares Orph. h. xxvi. It is a genuine prelude in the Homeric style. There are absolutely no indications of date or place; we may, however, infer that it is of no great antiquity, as the writer seems to have borrowed from the hymn to Demeter; Gemoll compares 7, 12, and 18, 19 (see on h. Dem. 486). The hymn resembles the two following in length, and seems to belong to the same age and perhaps to the same workmanship (Crusius l.c.).

div2.p: *pamm/hteiran: a late form for pammh/twr (of Earth P. V. 90). On the epithet see Roscher Lex. i. 1570 f.
*)hu+qe/meqlon: only here.
The omission of the subject to tele/qousi is not harder than the omission of tis in xxix. 6, where see note. Here a)/nqrwpoi is to be supplied from 7.
eu)/paides: in allusion to *gh= kourotro/fos; Preller-Rober i.^{2} p. 635 f.
eu)/karpoi: cf. the Dodonaean hymn ( Paus.x. 12. 10) *ga= ka/rpous a)ni/ei, di) o(\ klh/|zete mate/ra *gai=an.
a)fele/sqai: i.e. as a Chthonian deity.
o( d) o)/lbios ktl.: cf. h. Dem. 480, and 486 me/g' o)/lbios o(/n tin' e)kei=nai
div2.l: profrone/ws fi/lwntai.

div2.p: tw=| t) a)/fqona ktl.: cf. h. Apoll. 536 ta\ d' a)/fqona pa/nta pa/restai. But the substitution of d) for t) is here not required.
sfin: probably the singular, as in h. Pan 19, where see note.
eu)qh*nei=: the subject is o( o)/lbios, not a)/roura, which would not suit kat' a)grou/s (Gemoll).
kalligu/naika has emphasis; men (au)toi/), women, and children (13 f.) are alike blessed.
o)/lbos ktl.: from h. Dem. 489 *plou=ton o(\s a)nqrw/pois a)/fenos qnhtoi=si di/dwsin.

feresanqe/sin: this correction, though Solmsen (p. 20 n. 1) disapproves, is clearly indicated by x's peresanqe/sin; for the form cf. fere/sbios, feressi/ponos, Scut. 13 feressake/as, Stesich. fr. 26 lipesa/noras; feranqh/s is also found (Meleager, Anth. Pal. ix. 363. 2), whence Lobeck preferred fereanqe/sin; for this form cf. also fereauge/a Anth. Pal. ix. 634.
skai/rousi: Ruhnken's emendation is brilliant and certain.

qew=n m/hthr: the confusion, or identification, of Gaea and Rhea as mother of the gods is early; cf. Soph. Phil.391pambw=ti *ga= ma=ter au)tou= *dio/s, Solon fr. 36 mh/thr megi/sth daimo/nwn *)olumpi/wn. As wife of Uranus she was in strict Hesiodean mythology the mother of the Titans and Cronos; but the simple qew=n is no doubt meant to include all the gods.
bi/oton qum/hre) o)/paze: cf. Orph. h. xxviii. 11, and lxvii. 8 bio/tou te/los e)sqlo\n o)/paze.

div1.head: HYMN TO HELIOS
div1.p: THE resemblance of this and the following hymn is striking. If the two are not the work of a single author, as Gemoll and (less confidently) Baumeister suppose, the writer of one hymn must have taken the other as his model. The description of the bright Sun is closely parallel to that of the Moon, and the language is in several places identical; cf. 10, 13, and see further on 15 f. In both hymns there appears to be a search after recondite mythology (Euryphaessa 2, Pandia xxxii. 15). The concluding formulae of the hymn shew that they were preludes to recitation. There are no distinctive marks of date, except the mention of Selene as winged, in xxxii. 1. This literary conception seems to belong to the decadence of mythology, perhaps not before the Alexandrine period; cf. the winged Dioscuri in xxxiii. 13. The two hymns, though rather turgid in style, are written in the “Homeric” manner; Baumeister has no reason in attributing them to the Orphic school of Onomacritus, and they have nothing in common with the extant Orphic hymns (viii and ix) to the same deities.
The place of composition cannot be recovered; the cult of Helios was widespread, especially in the Peloponnese, and was of course famous at Rhodes; see Preller-Robert i.^{2} p. 429 f.

div2.p: *(/hlion: the later form, in Homer, only Od. 8.271. In the hymns also *)he/lios is regular. For the invocation to Calliope cf. Alcman fr. 45 (Smyth 18) *mw=s' a)/ge, *kallio/pa, qu/gater *dio/s,
div2.l: a)/rx' e)ratw=n e)pe/wn, Bacchyl.v. 176 etc.
div2.p: au)=te, “now”; the word does not imply other hymns. Baumeister compares Terpander fr. 2 a)mfi/ moi au)=te a)/naxq' e(katabo/lon ktl.
*eu)rufa/essa: only here. In Hesiod Theog. 371, Theia is the mother of the Sun, Moon, and Dawn; cf. Pind. Isthm.iv. 1.See Roscher Lex. ii. 3160.

The line is apparently borrowed from Il. 11.60 h)i+/qeo/n t' a)ka/mant), e)piei/kelon a)qana/toisin, which disposes of conjectures in place of e)piei/kelon (Gemoll). Franke's explanation that the two last words refer to the sun's inferiority compared with the Olympians, requires some modification. The Sun, with Selene and Eos, is mentioned with the Olympian gods in Theog. 8; in any case he was certainly a)qa/natos. The poet may have drawn a distinction between the visible gods of nature and the invisible a)qa/natoi, such as Hermes or Athena. More probably he borrowed e)piei/kelon a)qana/toisin without troubling to consider its propriety; he knew a)ka/manta as an epithet of the Sun (Il. 18.239, 484).
Cf. Od. 3.2.

i(/p*pois in its Homeric use of a “chariot and horses”; but the conception of the Sun as a driver is not Homeric (h. Dem. 63, 88, h. Herm. 69); see Rapp in Roscher Lex. i. 1998 and 2005. In Homer the Dawn has horses, Od. 23.224 f.
xruse/hs: the MSS. have xrush=s; in the parallel passage xxxii. 6 xruse/ou a)po\ stefa/nou, all except p have the open form, which may be restored here.
a)*p' au)tou=: cf. xxxii. 3 h(=s a)/po.

*pareiai/: this must be corrupt unless it means “cheeks of a helmet” (Hermann), for which there is no authority; the sense would thus be “from his temples the bright cheekpieces enclose his beautiful, far-shining face, from the head (downwards).” There is no objection to para\ krota/fwn = a)po\ krato/s. Matthiae's para\ krota/fwn de/ t' e)/qeirai would give an easier sense, and is at least better than peri\ krota/foisi/ t' e)/qeirai.
thlauge/s: cf. xxxii. 8, where ei(/mata e(ssame/nh = e)/sqos here.

The line, though undoubtedly difficult, is not of necessity corrupt. leptourge/s is certainly sound, and pnoih=| a)ne/mwn may be taken (with Matthiae) as depending in sense on la/mpetai, “the fair fine-spun garment on his body shines in the wind.” To u(po\ d' a)/rsenes i(/ppoi we may supply la/mpontai or merely ei)si/n, cf. Orac.ed. Hendess 54. 4 *tundari/das d' e)popizo/menoi *mene/lan te kai\ a)/llous
div2.l: a)qa/natous h(/rwas oi(\ e)n *lakedai/moni di/h|, rather than assume a lacuna after this line, with Hermann. Valckenär's emendation (see crit. n.) is too far removed from the MSS.
div2.p: 15, 16, Here a lacuna seems necessary owing to the sense and to the mood of pe/mph|si, which must be subjunctive; Gemoll objects that the body of the hymn should have 16 lines only, to match xxxii. But the correspondence between the two hymns is in any case imperfect, as the concluding verses are unequal in number. Although 16 is a favourite number (suggesting four quatrains; cf. hymns xxviii, xxx, xxxii), the hymn to the Dioscuri (xxxiii) has 17 verses. The lacuna can only be avoided by the assumption that e)/nq' a)/r) is corrupt, as well as sth/sas, which is inconsistent with pe/mph|si in the present context. If a line has fallen out the sense may be, “then, having stopped his golden car and horses (he rests at the topmost point of heaven, until he again) sends them wondrously through heaven to ocean.” sth/sas would refer to the sun's apparent halt at mid-day, before he begins his descent; cf. Shelley (Hymn of Apollo) “I stand at noon upon the peak of Heaven.” The description of the sun's brightness is most appropriate, if noon is meant; cf. the parallel hymn, where Selene is brightest as she comes to the full (xxxii. 11 f.).

qespe/sios: for the adverb cf. h. Herm. 103 a)dmh=tes d' i(/kanon. The more difficult nominative is not to be corrected into qespesi/ous; nor is it likely that e(spe/rios would have been corrupted (cf. xxxii. 11).
klh/|sw: on the form cf. Schulze Q. E. p. 281 n. 3.
*h(miqe/wn: sc. h(rw/wn, as in Il. 12.23, Hes. Op.158.

qeoi/: Gemoll adopts Matthiae's qeai/ (Muses), to correspond with xxxii. 20. This is not impossible, although with qeoi/ the sense is satisfactory, “whose deeds the gods shewed to mortals,” i.e. the gods taught the heroes divine deeds.

div1.head: HYMN TO SELENE
div1.p: ON this hymn see Introduction to xxxi, and on the mythology of Selene see Roscher Selene und Verwandtes 1890, with Nachträge 1895, and his art. in Lex. ii. 3119 f.

div2.p: a)ei/dein and e)/spete seem incompatible; but the parallel with xxxi. 1 (u(mnei=n a)/rxeo) suggests that e)/spete may be used irregularly for “follow,” i.e. “go on to” sing. The sense would be very appropriate, if the two hymns were not only the work of one poet, but were recited on the same occasion, as might well be the case; cf. Aristot. Eth. Nic. iii. 1. 2 e(/petai dielqei=n. Ebeling's translation dicite ut canam does violence to the Greek. Most editors accept Bothe's eu)eidh=, but this would not be corrupted to a)ei/dein. If there is any corruption, a)i+di/hn may be suggested: if the alternative form a)eidi/hn were written, a)ei/dein would easily result as a metrical correction. a)i+/dios is of two terminations in Scut. 310, xxix. 3, but of three Orph. h. x. 21, lxxxiv. 6. e)/spete, at all events, is sound; for its regular use cf. xxxiii. 1, Il. 2.484 etc.

tanusi/pteron: the epithet seems to imply lateness of composition. There appears to be no other example of a winged Selene in literature, and the type is very uncertain in art; Roscher (Lex. ii. 3140) doubtfully identifies a winged goddess on a gem (MüllerWieseler ii. 16, 176a) as Selene-Nike. The attribution of wings to Selene is rather due to a confusion with Eos than with Nike. Even when she drives a car, Eos is regularly represented as winged.
w)|dh=s: for the form cf. h. Dem. 494.
e)li/ssetai with direct accusative is remarkable. Franke translates in terram volvitur (funditur); Gemoll's suggestion “surrounds” (for e(li/ssei) is better.
krato\s a)*p' a)qana/toio = Il. 1.530.
Barnes' correction of the metre by inserting t) is simpler than any of the emendations of a)la/mpetos.

xruse/ou: the epithet “golden” is at least as common as “silver” in classical allusions to the moon; cf. Pind. Ol.3. 20, Eur. Phoen.176, Anth. Pal. v. 15. 1, orac.ap. Jo. Lyd. p. 94, Dion. 44. 192, and other references in Roscher Lex. ii. 3130, 3136. On the ste/fanos see ib. 3133.
a)kti=nes: the last syllable is lengthened by position; see on h. Dem. 269, and cf. h. Dion. 1.18.

e)*ndia/ontai: the verb has been accepted, although the middle is not found elsewhere, and it is difficult to see how e)ndia/w (= sub divo sum or simply versor in) is appropriate to the rays of the moon. The usual translation “are diffused” cannot fairly be extracted from the word. The writer may intend it to mean “are as bright as day.” The rarity of the verb is an argument for its genuineness; otherwise Roscher's e)ndai/ontai might be received.
*pw/lous: of the horses of Eos Od. 23.246, and Selene Theocr. ii. 103. On the car of Selene see Roscher Lex. ii. 3134 f., 3174 f.
*prote/rws): Homer has only prote/rw (with hiatus Il. 9.199 , d 36); for the later prote/rwse cf. Apoll. Arg. 1.306, 1241.
dixo/mh*nos: i.e. at the full. Another form is dixo/mhnis, for which cf. Pind. Ol.iii. 19dixo/mhnis . . . *mh/na, Apoll. Arg. 1.1231.
o(/ te *plh/qei: this may be accepted, with tele/qousin (for tele/qwsin which is due to e)la/sh| 10). But o( de/ (Baumeister) would be the epic usage.

o)/gmos, “orbit”; cf. Aratus 749 me/gan o)/gmon e)lau/nwn, Nicand. Ther. 571(of the sun). Gemoll's o)/gkos is therefore unnecessary, although supported by Parmen. 102sfai/rhs e)nali/gkion o)/gkw|, “mass,” “bulk.”
te/kmwr ktl.: i.e. men compute periods of time by the full moon (Baumeister); for te/kmwr or te/kmar of the heavenly bodies cf. Eur. Hec. 1273, Apoll. Arg. 1.499, 3.1002 etc.

*pandei/h*n: elsewhere unknown as a daughter of Selene; the point of her introduction here is not apparent. Hermann's pandi/hn would make the mythology even more obscure. The daughter of Selene seems to be merely an abstraction of the moon herself; cf. Ulpian on Mid. 517 oi( de\ *pandi/an th\n *selh/nhn nomi/zousin, Orph. h. fr. 11 pandi=a *selhnai/h, Maximus (peri\ katarxw=n) 22, 281, and 463. The Attic festival *pa/ndia was not connected with the goddess (Preller-Robert i.^{2} p. 445 n. 1).
*pro/fron: here a true adjective, “benevolent”; in xxx. 18, xxxi. 17 the word is used predicatively with a verb, as in Homer (Il. 1.543 etc.).

Cf. Od. 1.338 and for the phrase *mousa/wn qera/pwn Hes. Theog. 100-102, Theognis 769, Margites i. 2, Epig. gr. Kaibel 101. 3, Orac.ed. Hendess 77. 3 and (b) 1, Inscr. gr. metr. ed. Preger 248 (of Linus ), Ar. Av. 909, 913.
klei/ous): on the form see Schulze Q. E. p. 281.

div1.head: HYMN TO THE DIOSCURI
div1.p: Although placed last in the collection, this hymn is no doubt older than xvii, which seems merely an abstract of it. The poem is a vigorous piece of writing, and may well belong to a period at least as early as the fourth or third century B.C. The reference to the Dioscuri as winged (13) seems a mark of lateness; on the other hand the hymn appears to be pre-Alexandrine, for there is little doubt that it was imitated by Theocritus,Of recent editors, Baumeister, Gemoll, and Abel agree on this point; see also Crusius in Philolog. xlviii. (1889) p. 202. whose description of the storm lulled by the Dioscuri is more elaborate than the simple language of the hymn (idyl. xxii, see on 6, 15).

In this hymn, as often, the Twin Brethren are identified with the lights (of an electric nature) which appear on the masts or sails of a ship during a storm; cf. Eur. Or. 1636 f.; Plin. N. H. ii. 101, Diod. iv. 43, Plut. de def. or. 30; Lucian dial. deor. xxvi. 2: Seneca Q. N. 1. 1. 13; Ov. Fast. v. 720. Two lights were a sign of safety; a single light (identified with Helen = e(le/naus) betokened the worst. From the middle ages the lights have been called the fire of Elmo St.(Telmo). Frazer on Paus. ii. 1. 9 gives references for the mediaeval and modern belief.

The editors do not notice the similarities of language between this hymn and vii (to Dionysus); cf. 1 (a)mfi/) = vii. 1; 8 a)po\ nhw=n = vii. 6 a)po\ nho/s (a rare use); 12 e)fa/nhsan = vii. 2 e)fa/nh; 14 a)rgale/wn a)ne/mwn = vii. 24 a)rgale/ous a)ne/mous; 16 sh/mata = vii. 46; 16 oi( de\ i)do/ntes = vii. 42; see also on 10. These resemblances, taken singly, are slight; but their number suggests the possibility that this hymn was influenced by that to Dionysus, which is probably much older.

div2.p: a)mfi/: see on vii. 1.

*tundari/das: according to Od. 11.299 they were sons of Leda and Tyndareus; here and in xvii they are called sons of Zeus, but also Tyndarids from their putative father; so Castor is *tundari/dhs (Theocr. xxii. 136), but in the next line both are called *dio\s ui(w/. Some poets reconciled the apparent discrepancy by making Castor the son of Tyndareus, and Polydeuces the son of Zeus, Cypria fr. 4, Pind. Nem. x. 80 (who, however, calls them Tyndarids, 38).
Cf. Il. 3.237, Od. 11.300, Cypria fr. 6. 6.
*tau+*ge/tou: the MSS. have the form in a here and in xvii. 3, for the Ionic in h (Od. 6.103, Cypria fr. 6. 2).

swth=ras: in Theocr. xxii. 6 f. the Dioscuri are saviours of horses, as well as of men and ships. They bear the title *sw*th*re*s on coins of the city Tyndaris (Head Hist. Num. p. 166 f.); cf. Eur. Electra 992
brotw=n e)n a(lo\s r(oqi/ois
tima\s swth=ras e)/xontes.
a)*po\ *nhw=n: cf. vii. 6.

a)krwt/hria: in Herod. viii. 121 a)krwth/ria nho/s is a ship's beak, and Kämmerer would read prw/|rhs for pru/mnhs, on the ground that the images of the ship's patron-deities were placed in the bows. But a)krwth/ria means any “upper part” or “end,” and is here clearly equivalent to “deck,” i)/kria. As there were decks fore and aft (see M. and R. I.App. , Torr Ancient Ships p. 57) pru/mnhs is added to limit the word. Gemoll wrongly takes pru/mnh = nhu/s. The sailors crowd to the stern for safety from the waves, as in vii. 48 (for a different reason).
qh=kan u(*pobruxi/h*n: cf. Od. 5.319
leukh=s, “calm,” as in leukh\ galh/nh Od. 10.94. Cf. Theocr. xxii. 19 ai(=ya d' a)polh/gous' a)/nemoi, lipara\ de\ gala/na a)\m pe/lagos.

*po/nou sfisin: one of these words is necessarily corrupt; Matthiae's plo/ou sfisin fails to account for sfisin satisfactorily, so that the latter word seems to require emendation. The substitution of kri/sin, lu/sin, sxe/sin, or sbe/sin (Oxford Text) has been suggested; of these only the last two are graphically probable. Bury's po/nou a)pono/sfisin (C. R. 1899, p. 183) is also formally good (omitting nau/tais, which might have been inserted metrically when a)pono- had been dropped after po/nou).
